Mt. Camisong also offers multiple dining options outside of Alapaap, such as Marahuyo Café and the Muni-Muni Snack Bar, also conceptualized by Suva. These casual spots serve creative Filipino rice bowls with twists such as Tapa Pigar-pigar with stir fried cabbage and kangkong sambal and Pinangat na Tilapia. Visitors and diners will find that a meal at Mt. Camisong lets you experience the best of what Cordillera has to offer: food that celebrates its community, respects its environment, and reflects the artistry that continuously elevates it. – Rappler.com
label: True
title: How Mt. Camisong’s Alapaap elevates Cordillera food, culture in Benguet

text: MANILA, Philippines — It’s that time of year again — the holiday rush, the gift hunting, and the annual quest for the planner you’ll be facing 2026 with. Let’s be honest: planners only ever meet three fates: actually being used, being used halfway, then tucked safely in a drawer, or rewrapped as a “brand new” gift for someone else. Sounds bad? Maybe not. Most planners don’t make it to the first category simply because they weren’t built for the person using them. The right one isn’t always the most hyped in the market, but something that matches your pace, habits, and kind of productivity. So before you pick up another planner, here’s a quick look at which 2026 edition might actually work for you, based on your preferences. Now in its 23rd year, Starbucks continues its holiday tradition with the 2026 Traditions Collection. This season’s theme, “Invite Joy,” leans into the cozy, familiar warmth of the coffeehouse experience with art pages designed by local artists within the new planner. At the center of the lineup is the Siren Planner, with a more refined and functional upgrade. It comes in a small, handy leatherback format with siren-themed, embossed details on the front. Inside, the minimalist planner keeps things simple but organized: a monthly view, a monthly checklist, a weekly layout, plus freehand dotted pages you can use for journaling, habit-tracking, or brain dumps. Another new touch this year is the standalone leather holder — no longer attached to the planner itself — which makes it easier to slip your planner in and out and keeps it protected inside your bag. The pockets and sleeves inside are convenient to store your cards, files, documents, and photos in. Likely to use? If you’re not a Starbucks regular, the 18-sticker hunt might feel like more work. But if you already have a caffeinated routine going, this could be an extra treat. For those looking for local, vibrant stationery, Limelight’s 2026 collection has new colorful options. The 365 Days, 365 Stories: The Unwritten Travels edition spices up planning with a little adventure. Available in eight colors inspired by cities like Tokyo, Sydney, and Dubai, every pretty cover is designed to make you feel as if you were traveling not just across countries, but within yourself. Inside, you’ll find 216 dotted pages filled with travel features like monthly travel goals, places-to-visit lists, mood and savings trackers, postcard pages, fun facts about different countries, a mini scrapbook section, and even gift-and-souvenir idea pages. Likely to use? At P249 for the mini and P365 for the A5, Limelight checks the boxes for a planner who prioritizes personality and affordability. The cover is sturdy, and the papers are of quality material. BDJ’s 2026 Big Dreams Journey Planner sticks to what it does best: “turning dreams into action.” Inside the women-centric planner, you’ll find not only monthly and weekly views but “dream tools” that guide you in setting goals, building habits, and checking in with yourself. And if you find a menstrual tracker useful, this planner dedicates a page to help you stay in sync with your cycle. You can also choose between dated and undated versions. Both include a calendar and dedicated pages for notes and reflection, and the undated one gives you blank headers for the month and days so you can begin whenever you want. This empowering planner also comes with a sturdy gray carrier with two spacious pockets on either side (for receipts, stickers, or other important notes) and a built-in ribbon marker so you can easily keep track of your current page. Likely to use? At P896, this one’s for goal-oriented planners or those simply thinking of a holiday gift for a loved one, as you can have the cover customized with their name. Feel like planners aren’t your thing, but still want one? Papemelroti’s pocket-sized 2026 planner reminds you that less is more. Made from 100% recycled paper, they highlight Pinoy-inspired designs like a bahay kubo (nipa hut) and a pedicab, as well as empowering quotes and Bible verses. While the covers are multi-colored, the inside keeps it simple with black-and-white calendars and a reminder list. As for those looking for undated versions, Papemelroti has a quirky pocket planner series with a more spacious calendar layout (without the reminder list) and a short inspiring quote at the bottom. Likely to use? For only P35, this compact planner is perfect for those who don’t need the weight of many pages or the pressure of lengthy goal-oriented tabs. So if you’re not the type to dive deep into heavy scheduling or detailed lists, this is a convenient choice. For the minimalist planners, MUJI’s 2026 Monthly/Weekly Planner is a crowd-favorite — and its variety of options and colors are available at its newest branch in Estancia Mall, Pasig City. The covers come in either faux suede or the newest vinyl material. Colors include light brown, vivid red, black, white, and the latest mustard. They come in landscape or portrait orientations, in sizes A6, AB, and HB6. The planner contains a two-page layout: a monthly calendar on one side and a weekly spread with grid pages on the other. The yearly overview lets you see the months clearly, and the dated pages begin in December 2025, so you can immediately start without waiting for January. Likely to use? At P325, this planner is designed for those who like simple, straightforward layouts, where checking daily tasks and scheduled events feels easier on the eye than wading through cluttered pages. For those who want both form and function, Flying Tiger’s 2026 planner lineup has muted nude tones for low-key planners and gradient or floral covers for those who like a splash of color on their desk. Inside, you’ll see a yearly overview of 2026 and 2027, habit trackers with grid tabs (so you can simply mark a check or highlight a box once you’ve done a task), bulleted wish lists, goal planning sections (a page for noting your goals and another for “steps to get there”), and diary spaces. They also follow a journal-style format: each daily page has lined space for thoughts, a small to-do list, a “today’s goals” box, and even a mood tracker at the bottom, making it more like a reflection page than a strict planning spread. There’s also variety in size: pocket-sized versions for easy noting, A5 planners for a more structured scheduling, and larger desk planners for a full week’s view. Likely to use? Ranging from P200 to P450, Flying Tiger offers a wide variety of layouts, cover designs, and sizes for every kind of planner; whether you’re jotting down schedules or just want to write. More than a calendar, The Paper Bunny’s 2026 Planner gives reflection space on the page. The lifestyle and stationery brand from Singapore opened its first overseas branch in Uptown Mall, Bonifacio Global City last November. Aside from its contemporary collection of puffer bags, totes, phone accessories, caps, clothes, keychains, and more, The Paper Bunny’s planner selection is also a favorite among patrons. Available in regular and compact sizes, the planners are bound in vegan leather and come in six designs. Their new weekly layout highlights weekly focus and “gratitude of the day” sections, while the monthly spreads include extra room for notes. There are also guided pages: vision board, yearly goals, self-ca​​re check-ins, and milestone reflections, encouraging you to balance introspection and work. Likely to use? With the compact at P1,900 and the regular at P,2050, this planner leans on the pricier side for those searching for budget-friendly options. But if you want to invest more in your writing, this one’s ideal for both planning and journaling. At the end of the day, the best planner isn’t the one with the most pages or the prettiest cover, but the one you’ll actually want to open and keep opening throughout the next year. — Steph Arnaldo and Jaella Magno/Rappler.com Jaella Magno is a Rappler intern studying AB Literature major in Creative Writing at De La Salle University.
label: True
title: Different planners for 2026, and how likely you are to actually use them

text: MANILA, Philippines – The Bangko Sentral ng Pilipinas (BSP) slashed the country’s key interest rate to 4.5% on Thursday, December 11, amid a faster inflation forecast and weaker outlook on economic growth. BSP Governor Eli Remolona Jr. noted that the monetary authority has shed 2% off the policy rate since August 2024. “The cut will revive economic activity a bit at a time when painful governance issues around infrastructure investments have weakened government spending, business confidence, and domestic demand,” he said. Interest rates are one of many tools a central bank can use to control inflation. A lower interest rate means cheaper borrowing costs, encouraging people to spend more and stimulate the economy. Although the central bank downgraded its 2025 inflation forecast to 1.6%, it hiked its inflation outlook for 2026 and 2027 to 3.2% and 3%, respectively. Remolona noted that business and consumer confidence remains tepid amid ongoing investigations into alleged corruption in public works and within the Bureau of Internal Revenue. Because of this, the BSP expects the economy to recover only by the second half of 2026. “I think the main factor would still be the governance issue. [When] investors and consumers feel that those issues are being addressed, then we should see some recovery,” he explained. The Philippine economy grew only 4% in the third quarter — the lowest since the COVID-19 pandemic — as government infrastructure spending plunged to a 14-year low due to the flood control scandal. While reforms in fiscal policy or the use of taxation and spending to manage an economy would still play a bigger role in resolving governance issues, Remolona said monetary policy can compensate for the negative effects brought by weak consumer and business sentiment. With the latest rate cut, the BSP said it may be nearing the end of its easing cycle. Moving forward, additional rate cuts may be limited and will assess the impact of previous reductions on the economy. Remolona said it may take one to two years before the economy feels the full effect of the rate cuts. “We also hope that government infrastructure spending will return to normal levels and be more effective with reduced leakages, and that investor sentiment and consumer sentiment will improve,” he said. – Rappler.com
label: True
title: Bangko Sentral cuts policy rate as ‘painful’ corruption woes mute growth outlook

text: BAGUIO CITY, Philippines – The Mile Hi Group has asked Malacañang to review the procedures that led to the closure of its outlets inside Camp John Hay, saying the enforcement of Cease and Desist Orders (CDOs) on November 3, 2025 left “no prior notice or opportunity to cure any alleged deficiencies,” based on its official statement dated November 28. The group said its appeal is anchored on “documented timelines and official communications” it previously submitted to authorities. A September 5, 2025 letter from JHMC president and CEO Manjit T. Singh Reandi confirmed that Mile Hi’s leases at the Mile Hi Complex were extended “until January 5, 2026,” while expansion proposals remained under review. This followed an August 28 letter from proponent Luigi Nuñez requesting continued collaboration and lease extension. This written extension stands in contrast to later public statements that the tenants were operating without a subsisting lease. In its statement, the Mile Hi Group said it had invested in bringing activity back to long-unused portions of the Mile Hi Complex under the June–August 2025 lease, subsequently extended by JHMC. It added that it raised billing and utility questions in letters sent on September 6, September 24, and October 28 — among them a water charge exceeding ₱182,000 for three months, far higher than the reported averages of other outlets. Despite these unresolved issues, the group said it delivered checks on November 14 “to cover the full amount of the outstanding billing,” but JHMC staff did not accept the payment due to internal approval procedures. According to the Mile Hi Group, the CDOs were dated October 30 and served on November 3, about an hour after one of the owners visited the JHMC office to discuss billing concerns. The orders were implemented immediately, halting operations at all outlets. It also noted that Final Demand and Notice to Vacate letters, typically issued before closures, were dated November 17 and served on November 18, more than two weeks after the shutdown. The group said the sequence was included in its statement “solely to complete the factual timeline.” A separate November 6 letter from JHMC building official Engineer Bobby Akia revoked the Authority to Operate for In-Bento, Hay&Co, and Mile Hi Diner. The letter cited expired lease agreements, continued operations after their lapse, accumulated lease and Common Use Service Area (CUSA) obligations, utility arrears, and items listed in an October 23 Notice of Violation. It also said the Office of the Building Official (OBO) would recommend cancellation of the outlets’ business permits by the Baguio City Government. The group said more than 30 employees have been unable to work since the closures and estimated losses at around ₱3.8 million from non-operations, cancelled bookings, and spoilage. On November 25, Nuñez submitted an administrative complaint to the Office of the Deputy Executive Secretary for Legal Affairs, accusing Reandi of abuse of authority, oppression, retaliation, harassment, gross violation of due process, defiance of the BCDA Board, and conduct prejudicial to the best interest of the service. Nuñez wrote that the complaint stemmed from the “simultaneous Cease-and-Desist Orders issued without due process on November 3, 2025” and affirmed that its contents were based on his personal knowledge and official records. Reandi, in an interview with the media on December 5, Friday, said JHMC acted within normal procedures and stressed that the tenants’ contract had ended. He said the outlets were allowed to operate temporarily “under the tolerance of the management” to support economic activity but maintained that collection efforts must be fair to other tenants who pay regularly. He added that JHMC had documentation of attempts to reach the locators and said that when obligations are “due and demandable,” agencies cannot override Commission on Audit (COA) rules. He also said tenants issued CDOs for non-payment should approach the imposing agency for guidance. “Ayaw din naman namin na magsarado, kaso gusto namin fair,” Reandi said. (We also don’t want them to close, but we want fairness.) In its statement, the Mile Hi Group said it respects “all lawful processes” and is seeking clarification to ensure it is given a fair chance to comply. It emphasized that its release “is not intended to make allegations of wrongdoing,” but to inform stakeholders of its status and request for review. Malacañang has yet to announce the status of the review request or the administrative complaint. – Rappler.com
label: True
title: Mile Hi Group seeks Palace review of Camp John Hay closures

text: MANILA, Philippines – For the longest time, fan art has been an essential part of fandom culture. Whether it’s something as small as anime characters reimagined as Hogwarts students from the Harry Potter universe, or something as big as crucial Marvel superheroes brought back to life in Avengers: Endgame, fan art is a medium pursued by fans who pour their love and admiration into the media they consume. In the era of the internet and advanced technology, fan art has been shared digitally. These online spaces have become avenues for fans to express themselves with fellow fans and creators alike — from commissioning artworks and entering art contests to joining art challenges on social media and more. In 2022, artists Adriann Delmo and Jireh Villafuerte (aka Kyouzins) were two of five winners in Talenthouse’s Morbius global fan art competition, where their artworks were featured as promotional posters for the Philippine premiere. Much like traditional museums and art galleries that we visit, fan art now acts as its own modernized iteration — a space where fans can celebrate the original media while creating new media for others to enjoy and share. Given the wide scope of audiences and enthusiasts all over the world, fanart has become the internet’s version of a local museum. Rather than having art displayed in big-time galleries, these artists turn to social media to share their creativity and imagination with others. Websites like X, Instagram, and Tumblr serve as 24/7-access galleries where anyone can view and share works. These “galleries” are updated in real time, reflecting not just the artists’ imagination but also current trends and emotional responses in fiction. A simple drawing can start conversations among fans, giving them more opportunities to share ideas and excitement over their favorite characters and stories. It doesn’t necessarily have to relate to the plot of the media — it can also be reimagined in different “universes.” back on my hq!svt agenda! only this time it's the other way around 🤩 pic.twitter.com/oGyqDhZsED An example of fan art being used for reimagining is seen in Filipino artist mangobursts’ artwork posted on X in December 2020. In the post, members of the K-pop group Seventeen are drawn wearing jerseys and positions from the different teams of the popular volleyball anime Haikyuu!! “Back on my SEVENTEEN agenda! [O]nly this time it’s the other way around,” they wrote in the post, referencing an earlier fan art depicting Haikyuu!! characters as members of the K-pop group in a video. svt!hq drawover with msby+adlers+ejp+frogs 🥰💜✨ pic.twitter.com/Wy8Bn712J6 Today, where everything has a price, people have turned to fan art as a means of livelihood. Although social media allows artists to show their work for free, it also attracts potential customers who may want to commission personalized pieces. Artists open slots for commissions, drawing different characters or ship pairings for a price. The rate depends on the complexity of the artwork and the time it takes to complete. They usually sell their art through platforms like Etsy, RedBubble, or even their own websites to verify ownership and authenticity. Filipino artist Art of Neight has built a following of over 200,000 combined on X and Instagram as of writing. Known for his art inspired by the 2013 post-apocalyptic anime Attack on Titan, he sells his works through Inprnt and the tiered subscription service Patreon. In August, he was invited to a booth at the Komiket convention at Ayala Malls Manila Bay, featuring his art from Attack on Titan as well as pieces based on Netflix originals Arcane and K-Pop Demon Hunters. As the use artificial intelligence grows across creative and academic spaces, artists are now struggling with the problem art theft — their art stolen without their consent — for use in AI generation processes. AI websites rely on the input of information to generate text, images, and videos. This often includes countless artworks publicly posted online, leaving artists frustrated over the unauthorized use of their creations. The use of AI-generated imagery diminishes the time and effort human artists invest in their craft. From conceptualizing to polishing, human hands and minds are behind every authentic piece. To push back against generative AI, many artists now add watermarks to their works and post disclaimers on their profiles and captions. Just as art institutions grapple with plagiarism, theft, and uncredited acknowledgment, fan art communities face the same challenges today — intensified by the rise of AI and websites like ChatGPT. Each piece means something to its creator — whether it was drawn in minutes or over a month — and it can never replace the emotional factor that only human artists can convey. In this way, fan art in online communities mirrors local museums and galleries, not just in showcasing skill but in protecting creative ownership as well. – Rappler.com Juliana Chloe Gonzales is a Rappler intern studying AB Communication Arts at the De La Salle University.
label: True
title: ‘Fan art’ as fine arts: The modernized ‘galleries’ for fandom spaces

text: The Philippines’ widening flood-control corruption scandal — triggered by arrest warrants against former congressman Zaldy Co and senior Department of Public Works and Highways (DPWH) officials — has morphed into a systemic governance crisis that now implicates key figures across the legislative, political, and bureaucratic landscape. What began as a ₱289-million procurement anomaly has expanded into a broader indictment of the country’s fiscal-governance architecture, its opaque budget process, and the political economy that enable leakages in public-works spending. For global investors evaluating sovereign risk, the issue is no longer whether Zaldy Co would be arrested. It is now more of the structural configuration of governance failure — where policy architects, political brokers, contracting beneficiaries, and bureaucratic enablers appear entangled in one convergent breach of fiscal integrity. The addition of legislators to the constellation of bureaucrats linked to the scandal elevates the risk profile further. For markets, this signals not just individual misconduct but institutional permissiveness that corrodes public-expenditure predictability, procurement fairness, and long-horizon investment certainty. The scandal unfolds in the middle of the country’s infrastructure super-cycle — a critical phase under the Marcos Jr. administration’s “Build Better More” agenda, supported by multilateral lenders, bilateral financing, and increasing private-sector participation through hybrid Public-Private Partnership (PPP) models. Flood-control and DPWH spending have historically been hotspots for budget leakages, cost inflation, and execution failures. This scandal exposes structural weaknesses across three core governance risk pillars: 1. Fiscal Governance Alleged 2025 budget manipulation by senators Francis “Chiz” Escudero (specifically when he was Senate president), Joel Villanueva, and Jinggoy Estrada strikes at the credibility of fiscal planning — a key metric monitored by credit-rating agencies. 2. Procurement Integrity Zaldy Co’s dual posture as policymaker and contractor underscores the risks of embedded conflicts of interest and rigged procurement pathways. 3. Institutional Coordination DPWH regional involvement suggests systemic vulnerabilities inside a bureaucracy where flaunted political influence overrides prudent technical decision-making. For investors, these failures translate into higher cost of capital, longer project gestation, and elevated execution risk, particularly across infrastructure, the Philippines’ supposed growth engine. Global markets differentiate isolated corruption cases from structural governance breakdowns. The current scandal clearly falls into the latter category. Below is a governance-risk map showing how each implicated actor contributes to systemic vulnerability. Zaldy Co – Operational and contractual liability His case reflects the entrenched political-business networks that compromise the integrity of public procurement. Chiz Escudero – Policy-level liability Note: Markets assign significant weight to Escudero’s role because budget reliability is foundational to sovereign-risk evaluations. Joel Villanueva – Allocation and influence liability Note: This raises red flags on discretionary project allocation and political interference in appropriations. Jinggoy Estrada – Political-broker liability and pattern-risk amplifier While not yet the central political node, Estrada’s inclusion significantly escalates risk signals, for three reasons: Note: For foreign capital, Estrada’s emergence is not about personal guilt — it is about what it signals: that budget manipulation may be broader, more coordinated, and more institutionally embedded than initially assumed. The crisis now spans: This is the type of triangulated + political-broker failure pattern which I categorize as institutional weakness in sovereign-risk assessments. 1. Sovereign credit rating outlook A scandal implicating multiple senators and DPWH officials weakens the Philippines’ institutional-strength score and may introduce negative outlook bias if no systemic reforms are introduced. 2. Foreign direct investment hesitation Investors from Japan, Singapore, and the Middle East — major players in Philippine infrastructure — place heavy emphasis on transparent procurement. A scandal of this breadth may increase due-diligence cost and elevate required Interest Rate Risk (IRR). 3. PPP pipeline vulnerability Developers may demand risk premiums or defer participation altogether, weakening infrastructure rollout targets for PPPs. 4. Peso and bond market volatility Perceived political-governance risk can push up local bond spreads and increase currency volatility. 5. Infrastructure execution drag Investigations into DPWH offices and congressional participation can stall or halt regional flood-control and transport projects — directly affecting the country’s Gross Domestic Product (GDP). From a global-investor perspective, the case now implicates: This is no longer a mere procurement scandal. It is a multi-faceted, governance-risk event with direct implications for sovereign creditworthiness, foreign direct investment (FDI) inflows, PPP viability, and long-term infrastructure performance. The arrest warrants issued against Co are not closure. They are evidence of structural vulnerabilities that require institutional reform, not cosmetic enforcement. Until the investigative lens expands beyond DPWH intermediaries and contractor-linked lawmakers, foreign investors will continue pricing the Philippines as a high political-governance-risk market, particularly in infrastructure, sovereign bonds, and other long-horizon assets. Below is a Rating-Agency Style Risk Matrix which Vantage Point tailored in the mold of sovereign analysts, institutional investors, and credit-rating committees. Here, I followed the structure typically used by Moody’s, S&P, and Fitch — categorizing risks into Institutional, Fiscal, Political, and Execution buckets, assigning severity levels, likelihood assessments, and potential rating implications RATING-AGENCY STYLE RISK MATRIX Philippines: Flood-Control Corruption Scandal – Governance & Sovereign Risk Assessment 1. Institutional Governance Risk 2. Fiscal Governance Risk 3. Political Stability & Policy Continuity Risk 4. Execution, Infrastructure & Procurement Risk OVERALL RISK SCORE (Rating-Agency Model) The multi-node liability indicates deep structural weaknesses in budget integrity, procurement governance, and institutional accountability. For foreign investors, the lesson is clear: The flood control scandal should be interpreted as evidence of a governance system that requires structural reform. Until the investigative focus expands beyond Co to include policy-level actors, investors will continue to price in elevated political-governance risk, particularly in infrastructure-linked asset classes and long-horizon capital deployments. – Rappler.com
label: True
title: [Vantage Point] Why global investors see PH flood control scandal as systemic red flag

text: When COVID arrived early in 2020, pandemic restrictions made in-person mental health care difficult or impossible. Both therapists and patients had to adapt almost overnight. For many in the field, it felt like a gamble: could this screen-based format offer the same level of support for people struggling with depression, anxiety or trauma? Evidence has been growing, but until now few studies have compared treatment outcomes before and during the pandemic. Research my colleagues and I conducted offers new insights into this period. We followed 2,300 patients treated in Sweden’s public mental health system over six years — three years before and three years during the pandemic — and tracked outcomes for common conditions including depression, anxiety, post-traumatic stress disorder (PTSD) and obsessive-compulsive disorder (OCD). We found that nearly half of visits shifted online during the pandemic (up from just 4% pre-COVID), yet treatment outcomes did not decline — they remained stable, despite the rapid transition. We aren’t certain why remote care works, but one reason might be that the most important aspects of good therapy — things like building trust between patient and therapist, using evidence-based treatments and regular follow-up — can still occur online. In fact, for some people, meeting by video can make it easier to show up and feel comfortable. Our study suggests that, when care is done well, whether it’s in person or online doesn’t make much difference. Online care also helps with everyday difficulties. It’s often easier for people who live far away, have trouble getting around or have busy schedules to get help from home. And during a health crisis like the pandemic, being able to keep up with treatment probably helped many people stay on track instead of falling behind. Still, the findings come with limits. The study did not include children, people in acute psychiatric crisis or those with severe psychotic disorders — groups for whom in-person care may still be essential. And while online therapy offers flexibility, it also requires access to a private space, stable internet and the ability to engage through a screen — conditions that aren’t guaranteed for all patients. Just turning on a webcam isn’t enough. The clinics in this study followed proven treatment methods and kept a close eye on how patients were doing. These steps probably made a big difference and are important for making remote care work. Rather than being a temporary fix, online mental health care has become a core part of the system. Our study offers strong evidence that remote care, when well implemented, can match in-person treatment in effectiveness, even during something as challenging as a pandemic. There is no one-size-fits-all model — and not all patients will benefit equally from internet-based treatments. But giving people the choice — and maintaining high standards of care regardless of delivery method — appears to be a key to success. Because in the end, what matters most isn’t where care happens. It’s that it happens and that it works. – Rappler.com Fabian Lenhard is a researcher at the Department of Clinical Neuroscience, Karolinska Institutet. This article is republished from The Conversation under a Creative Commons license. Read the original article.
label: True
title: Online therapy as effective as in-person therapy, study says

text: MANILA, Philippines – The Department of Tourism (DOT) and TikTok Philippines on Tuesday, October 21, signed a memorandum of agreement to help micro, small and medium enterprises (MSMEs) promote their goods and services on the social media platform. The DOT and TikTok Philippines’ collaboration entails training DOT-accredited vendors on short-form video content creation and online marketing through a series of workshops nationwide. The collaboration will target MSMEs such as small hotels, travel agencies, souvenir shops, and tourism groups. DOT Secretary Christina Frasco said the first training camp will be held through a one-day hybrid setup in November for 50 MSMEs in Metro Manila and Cebu. Frasco, who hails from Cebu, said the province’s tourism sector had been devastated by the recent earthquakes that devastated Bogo City and the province’s other northern areas. The tourism chief added that the end goal of the DOT’s partnership with TikTok is to increase the revenues and market penetration of MSMEs in the sector, which she hopes will translate into more tourist arrivals. The Philippines logged 2.9 million arrivals in the first half of 2025, and the tourism sector is expected to contribute P2.7 trillion to the Philippine economy this year. The country missed its 7.7 million arrival target in 2024 amid the postponed e-visa program for the Chinese market, as well as geopolitical tensions. – Rappler.com
label: True
title: DOT, TikTok ink partnership to boost reach of MSMEs in tourism sector

text: MANILA, Philippines – Apart from running, hiking has become quite a trend nowadays to stay active. Many are being encouraged to explore the beautiful mountains in the country, whether you’re treating yourself on a solo date by trying out a new hobby, moving on from a situationship, joining the active lifestyle trend, or simply wanting to see the scenic views of mother nature. It won’t matter if you’re only a solo goer joining a group, or you’re a couple or a barkada (group of friends) wanting to create lasting memories and test your bond. There are also many groups in the hiking community that you can be part of by browsing online, especially on Facebook groups like Philippine Group of Mountaineers and Akyat Bundok. Just a friendly reminder: make sure to verify the accounts you’re communicating with. But before you perch the summit that is perfect for beginners like you, let’s first get familiar with a few terms and concepts that will guide you on your climb. First is the term “mother mountain,” which refers to the first mountain a person has hiked. Your mother mountain might influence your desire to try other mountains or continue your mountaineering journey, which is why choosing the mountain that matches your energy as a first-timer is a must. Next is the “summit” — a common term for hikers that refers to the peak of the mountain. Every hiker’s ultimate goal is to reach the summit, where the effort pays off with the majestic view from above. Prior to your arrival at the summit, you first have to walk on the path leading up the mountain, which is also called a “trail.” Trails vary: some are open with fewer trees, others are muddy and slippery, and some have steep sections, or the “assault” portions that require extra effort. To guide the joiners, trails are categorized into five trail classes. Class 1 is the easiest that usually requires no technical skills since the terrain is easy to navigate. As the class number goes up, more technical skills are needed. Aside from the trail class, it’s also important to be aware of the difficulty scale, with 1 being the easiest to 9 being the most difficult. If you’re wondering why it’s not 5 or 10, the scale was recommended by Pinoy Mountaineer around 2007. Difficulty scale measures how steep the trail is based on its trail class, duration of the hike, and whether you may need more technical skills like using ropes. Now that you’re familiar with the basics, it’s time to choose where to go with this list of beginner-friendly mountains that could be your very own mother mountain! Just one bus ride away from Manila, you can instantly start your hiking journey at Mt. Batulao in Nasugbu, Batangas, and appreciate its scenic beauty. Its trail class of 3 lets you experience different types of trails, both easy and challenging, with a 4/9 difficulty level where you can start learning how to maneuver your steps and position yourself. With proper body conditioning like walking or running prior to the hike, you can summit this mountain in about two to four hours. Mt. Batulao has a new trail that is mostly flat yet slanted, making it suitable for beginners. This is also ideal for those who are still new to high-altitude views or are quite scared of heights and anything too daring. Its old trail, on the other hand, has rappelling sections since there are steep cliffs and the views can be much more dizzying. Did you know that some parts of singer Aicelle Santos’ “Kapangyarihan ng Pag-ibig” music video were also shot on this mountain? Among the top list of the easiest mountains to climb in the Philippines, with a 2/9 difficulty level, is Mt. Kulis in Tanay, Rizal. This mountain has no age limit. You can bring anyone along, whether a kid, an elderly mountaineer, or even your four-legged friend. Everyone is welcome to climb with no restrictions! Since the hike does not heavily focus on endurance, all you need is a light and comfortable day-hike bag, and your readiness to traverse the three-kilometer trail. A post shared by Dylan Menor (@menordylan_) Because of how manageable it is, expect plenty of hikers visiting Mt. Kulis, especially on weekends. To avoid big crowds and enjoy the best photo spots, it’s best to head out early since it will only take about one to two hours to complete the hike. This is singer Zephanie’s mother mountain, and with its beginner-friendly trail, it might also become yours! A post shared by Zephanie (@zephanie) They say that If you conquer this mountain on your first hike, then nothing should scare you to climb more. While some would argue that this isn’t the easiest mountain choice for beginners, Mt. Daraitan is perfect for those beginning their hiking journeys but already have an active lifestyle. Located in Tanay, Rizal, Mt. Daraitan is part of the ever-strong Sierra Madre mountain range. Coming with a bit of challenge but still doable for beginners, it has a trail class that ranges from 1-3 (Class 1: walking, Class 2: hiking on rugged terrain, Class 3: scrambling with hands for balance, as noted by Pinoy Mountaineer). Travel light as you will encounter a mix of rocky and muddy trails, which makes the mountain extra challenging during the rainy season. Go heel first when going down to be safer in case you slip! Bring a first-aid kit just in case you get scratched by rocks during your hike. Since it usually rains in the area, you may also want to pack clothes that are easy to dry — such as those made with synthetic fibers like nylon or polyester. If you’re planning an early morning hike, bring a flashlight or headlamp to help you navigate the dark more easily. And of course, don’t forget to do some stretching and active resting prior to your hike. It usually takes about three to five hours to reach the summit of Mt. Daraitan. It may be a bit long and tiring for newbies, but once you get there, you’ll realize that it’s totally worth the climb with its breathtaking view. Seal your Mt. Daraitan experience by swimming at its cave in Tinipak River. It’s where you can enjoy the river’s cold water and appreciate the mountain’s rock formations. Ben&Ben band members and couple Pat Lasaten and Agnes Reoma hiked this mountain in 2024. Most know this mountain as the shooting location of Goyo: Ang Batang Heneral. But Mt. Balagbag offers much more than that. This mountain from Rodriguez, Rizal can be your family’s next getaway. It’s even senior-citizen approved, and you can bring your 4×4 vehicles for camping. With a difficulty level of 3/9 and a trail class of 1 to 2, this mountain does not pose steep challenges. Mt. Balagbag can be hiked for a total of five hours, and throughout your trail, you will be able tosee some waterfalls and rivers. Since it is an open trail with minimal tree cover, it is advisable to wear breathable clothes and schedule your trek early in the morning or late afternoon to avoid the scorching sun. Once you reach the peak, Mt. Balagbag’s elevation offers a view of Ortigas and some parts of Metro Manila. Even before the hiking trend grew, Kapamilya star Erich Gonzales hiked Mt. Balagbag in 2018, with her co-star Janella Salvador, describing it as her “happy place.” A post shared by Erich Gonzales (@erichgg) Another open trail on the list is Mt. Mariglem in Cabangan, Zambales. Opened in 2023, Mt. Mariglem instantly attracted hikers with its beautiful scenery featuring the view of the area’s coastline and mountain peaks and even a glimpse of the West Philippine Sea. This minor climb only takes two to three hours to reach the summit, with trail class of 1-3. While generally manageable, the trail includes several assaults, particularly on steep and rocky descents. Still, the trail itself is enjoyable and straightforward. Although the main challenge here is the heat. Hikers recommend that it’s best to reach Mt. Mariglem’s summit by sunrise. Bring lots of water, plus essentials like a fan, umbrella, or cap to protect yourself from the sun. Expect your footwear to get wet during river crossings, as most rivers are found near the jump-off point. Apart from the river swim, another adventure that hikers enjoy here is cliff jumping. Social media influencer Kimpoy Feliciano posted a vlog documenting his hike up Mt. Mariglem. Despite the evident heat in the video, the vlogger said the breeze felt refreshing and advised starting early to avoid the intense sun. Who would have thought that the highest mountain in Luzon could be part of this beginner-friendly list? It will only take about four to six hours to hike to perch the summit of Mt. Pulag with a trail class of 1-2 with a 3/9 difficulty level. Located in Benguet, Mt. Pulag is a favorite spot visited by hikers because of its breathtaking glory, most especially the sunrise above the thick sea of clouds during sunny weather. Apart from its view, it was also the previous home of Pugal, the online sensation cat that went viral earlier this year. Pugal conquered this mountain as it joined the mountaineers and guided them on the trails. Through the Ambangeg Trail, which is considered a minor hike, the climb does not require much technical skill or prior hiking experience. Assault sections are present but they are relatively mild. The distance from the jump-off point to Pulag’s summit is about eight kilometers, so you should be prepared for a long walk. As you ascend, expect colder temperatures, thinner air, and stronger winds. With the mountain’s landscape as your backdrop, you’ll definitely want to curate your picture-perfect outfit. Better choose one that keeps you warm yet comfortable enough for the long walk ahead. Roadtrip (2024) was shot in Mt. Pulag, telling the story of four friends on a hiking journey together. Actress and writer of the film Candy Pangilinan shared a vlog about their trek to the filming spots. Pangilinan repeatedly mentioned how cold it was throughout their adventure. While the actress found the hike challenging, she still expressed her appreciation for Mt. Pulag’s beauty. Although not a mountain, Aw Asen Falls still deserves a spot on the list! Because of its picturesque view, it has also become a popular destination among climbing enthusiasts. The hike to the falls takes only about two to three hours, with a 4/9 difficulty level and a trail class of 1-2. Aw-Asen’s trail is steep with very few flat sessions, so expect both uphill and downhill paths. While some sections of it are already paved, most of the way to the falls is made up of stairs, which makes it beginner-friendly. A light pack for hiking and swimming is recommended. The best part of this climb is that you will be greeted by the majestic view of the falls that surely inspire you to explore more mountains and waterfalls. After all, it is the highest falls in the Ilocos Region. This waterfall was featured in Biyahe ni Drew’s episode last July, where Drew Arellano talked about why it attracts hikers and how to get there. “Kahit na walang filter yung mata, ang ganda visually,” Arellano said, referring to how the falls look stunning up close compared to the photos posted on social media. (Even though the eyes have no filters, Aw-Asen Falls still looks beautiful visually.) – Rappler.com Alessandria Corral is a Rappler intern and a Bachelor of Arts in Speech Communication student at the University of the Philippines Diliman.
label: True
title: Tara, bundok! Mountains in the PH that every hiking beginner should know

text: MANILA, Philippines – With the mention of the Michelin Guide, many stop to wonder: Michelin, as in, the tires of my car? Are they the same thing? The short answer: yes. But how did a tire company end up creating what would become the holy grail of fine-dining recommendations and value-for-money food spots? Chefs around the world clamor for the renowned distinction, with diners relying on its selections and even planning their travel itineraries around them. The Michelin Guide today stands as part marketing genius, part cultural accident — an unlikely evolution that began over a century ago, founded on the need to simply sell more tires. In Clermont-Ferrand, France, brothers André and Édouard Michelin inherited a family business owned by their maternal grandfather in 1832 that made agricultural tools and rubber goods like hoses and belts. In 1889, they officially founded Michelin as a tire company. But how did the iconic Michelin mascot come to be? The brothers saw many tires stacked on top of each other and thought it resembled a man. Why not use that figure to advertise their products? The man named Bibendum — aka the adorable Michelin Man — was born, and is now one of the world’s oldest trademarks. As motoring began to infiltrate French life, the brothers faced a marketing problem: there were very few cars on the road, and drivers weren’t taking long trips that wore out tires. But they had a vision for the French automobile industry at a time when there were fewer than 3,000 cars in the country. They published a little handbook for motorists in 1900 that included maps, tire-repair tips, where to find petrol, and yes, places to eat and sleep. That first edition — with 35,000 copies — was distributed free. But one day, André Michelin walked into a tire shop and found copies of the guide being used as workbench props. The brothers realized: people value what they pay for. That line — “man only truly respects what he pays for” — is repeated in Michelin’s own history and is behind the decision in 1920 to stop giving the guide away and start charging for it. By the early 1900s, Michelin began expanding its reach beyond France, releasing guides for nearby territories, including Belgium, Algeria, Tunisia, as well as the Alps and Rhine regions. As mobility grew, so did the guide. In 1920, Michelin shifted from a free handbook to a paid publication, removing advertising and expanding its restaurant listings. The guide went toward a more professional, curated approach. By 1926, the guide introduced its first star to mark “fine dining” establishments. Five years later, in 1931, Michelin formalized the multi-star hierarchy still used today — one, two, and three stars — and standardized the red cover that would become the main pillar of the guide’s identity. After staying mostly European for decades, New York issued the first major US edition in 2005. In 2007, Tokyo became Michelin’s first foray into Asia, helping Tokyo become the city with the most three-star restaurants in the world. In 2016, Singapore became the first Southeast Asian country to get its own Michelin Guide. The pandemic shifted things for the guide, with printed global editions ending in 2021. The Michelin Guide can now be found on digital platforms, its website, and an app. After its 125-year history, Michelin entered the Philippines for the first time in late 2025, announcing that inspectors were already on the ground in Manila & Environs, and Cebu earlier in the year. How does the Michelin Guide decide which country to head to next? It’s not random. The guide takes a territory-by-territory approach, starting with research, local scouting, and anonymous inspectors on the ground. Part of the process is partnering with tourism bodies of country or local organizations. A country passes the research phase when editors decide that the country is worth a visit. They first determine the depth, density, and variety of the restaurant scene, tourism potential, and whether there’s enough “consistent culinary excellence.” Next, Michelin deploys its anonymous inspectors to dine anonymously, pay their bills, and visit restaurants repeatedly over time. Many times, Michelin’s teams spend months (sometimes even years) researching before an inaugural selection is announced. For some launches, Michelin works with local tourism boards or partners to facilitate research and logistics, with some countries or cities reportedly paying to invite the Michelin Guide over. According to Julianna Twiggs, Michelin’s chief international business development officer, tourism partnerships are the most vital in entering new territories. “We need these partners because what we do is costly,” she said in an NDTV report. However, Michelin is firm in saying that they still practice editorial independence in their selections. The Michelin Star is the most prominent award of the guide, rewarding the quality of the cooking. One star means “a very good restaurant in its category,” two stars means “excellent cooking, worth a detour,” and three stars means “exceptional cuisine, worth a special journey.” Introduced in 1957, the Bib Gourmand distinction was born from Bibendum, indicating establishments serving great food at great value. Value-for-money cuisine is the star of this award, anchored by a country’s local price ceilings. This is usually given to humble eateries, community stalls, and more affordable restaurants. The Michelin Green Star is awarded to restaurants championing sustainability and environmental awareness in its practices and sourcing. It was announced in 2020 and took effect in the 2021 editions. The Michelin Guide also has a Selected roster, a broader set of recommended places that don’t carry a star or award but are still worth the visit and appear on the Michelin Guide website. What began as a tire company’s travel handbook has grown into a distinction that can shape a chef’s career, influence a restaurant’s lifespan, and even guide how diners eat around the world, taking a nation’s culinary pride to greater heights through mere recommendations and those now-famous red-and-white plaques. However, despite the pressure the guide creates, the cuisines and establishments it sometimes overlooks, and the lingering questions around independence when countries pay to bring Michelin in, the impact of the guide cannot be denied. As the guide evolves — adding new badges, expanding its digital presence, and engaging with a more aware and discerning generation of chefs and diners — it remains committed to shining a spotlight on emerging culinary territories and the establishments that deserve to be showcased to the world. – Rappler.com
label: True
title: How did the Michelin Guide start from a tire company?

text: MANILA, Philippines – Inflation quickened to 1.8% in December 2025 as strong holiday demand pushed up prices of major food items, the Philippine Statistics Authority reported on Tuesday, January 6. This brings the average inflation rate for 2025 to 1.7%, below the government’s target range of 2% to 4%. According to National Statistician Dennis Mapa, food prices rose at a faster pace in December amid the holiday demand. Recent tropical cyclones also disrupted agricultural production, which led to higher food prices. “Kung naalala ‘nyo, ‘yung buwan ng Nobyembre, may malalakas tayo na bagyo. And this most probably impacted also ‘yung mga vegetable farms natin kaya tumaas ‘yung presyo, particularly sa labas ng National Capital Region,” he explained. (If you recall, we were hit by strong tropical cyclones in November. And this most probably also impacted our vegetable farms, hence the higher prices particularly outside the National Capital Region.) Rice deflation was at -12.3% in December from -15.4% in November, which means prices are now beginning to drop at a slower pace. Prices of vegetables such as eggplant (29.4%), okra (28%), and string beans (24%) notably saw double-digit inflation. Onions and shallots were also among the top contributors to December’s inflation figure, with a 79% inflation rate from 48.2% in November. In Metro Manila, inflation eased to 2.3% from November’s 2.8% due to a slower rise in power rates. Meanwhile, inflation for areas outside the capital region accelerated to 1.7% from the previous month’s 1.2% due to higher food prices. The Central Visayas region continued to record the fastest inflation rate at 3.8%, while the Bangsamoro Autonomous Region in Muslim Mindanao continued to log deflation at -1%. Deflation or a negative inflation rate means the general level of prices is going down. Department of Economy, Planning, and Development (DEPDev) Secretary Arsenio Balisacan said the latest inflation print reflected a “proactive and well-coordinated” approach to stabilizing prices and safeguarding Filipinos’ purchasing power. “Building on this momentum, the government will continue to pursue prudent fiscal and monetary coordination and advance structural reforms to sustain the downward inflation trend and support inclusive growth in 2026 and beyond,” he said. DEPDev added that the government is committed to keeping inflation within the 2% to 4% target for the remainder of President Ferdinand Marcos Jr.’s term. Balisacan noted that the 2026 national budget includes a P297.1-billion allocation for the agriculture sector, which aims to boost farmer productivity and strengthen food security. The Bangko Sentral ng Pilipinas earlier forecast inflation in December would settle between 1.2% and 2% due to higher food and gasoline prices. – with reports from Arriane dela Cruz/Rappler.com Arriane dela Cruz is a Rappler intern. Learn more about Rappler’s internship program here.
label: True
title: 2025 inflation stays below gov’t target despite rising to 1.8% in December

text: MANILA, Philippines – Baguio City moved one step closer to getting a world-class transport terminal that aims to alleviate congestion and traffic in the Philippines’ summer capital. Megawide Construction Corporation (Megawide) disclosed to the Philippine Stock Exchange that it received last Friday, October 17, the notice of award for the P1.2 billion Baguio City Integrated Terminal (BCIT) Project that it will put up along Marcos Highway. The BCIT will cater to provincial buses coming from outside Baguio and will serve as a passenger transfer terminal to other modes of transportation going to the city. It will have loading and unloading bays for the provincial and in-city transport, a passenger waiting area with commercial establishments, as well as public parking for park-and-ride. Its other features are: 24-hour safety and security systems, schedule information kiosks, ticket and customer service booths, baggage amenities, free wi-fi, toilets and lactation station, persons with disability-friendly facilities, according to a project description posted by the Baguio City Public Information Office (PIO) last year. In addition, the terminal will also have “high-quality facilities for transportation operators,” such as a “staging area for repair and cleaning, drivers’ lounge, and canteen and electronic vehicle charging,” the Baguio City PIO said. The BCIT seeks to make transfers to various points in and out of the city seamless, which will hopefully prompt people to shift to using public transport. It is designed to accommodate 25,000 passengers daily, both for daily commuters as well as for those from other provinces and cities. Megawide, the company behind the multi-awarded Mactan-Cebu International Airport and the Philippines’ first modern landport Parañaque Integrated Terminal Exchange or PITX, will build the project under a Public Private Partnership (PPP) with the Baguio City government. City Mayor Benjamin Magalong has long been pushing for the project. A post shared by Megawide (@officialmegawide) “Lahat ng mga buses, hindi na pupunta sa Baguio, ‘di na makakadagdag pa sa congestion. Doon na lahat ang mga pasahero, doon na sasakay, mas maayos, mas systematic, mas malinis. At ‘yung kanilang serbisyo doon, para kang pumasok sa isang airport terminal,” Magalong said in July 2024, after signing an initial agreement with Megawide. (All the buses won’t be going inside Baguio, they won’t be adding to the congestion. All the passengers will ride there. It’s more orderly, more systematic, cleaner. All the services will be there, it’s like you entered an airport terminal.) Magalong has opted for the PPP mode for infrastructure projects in a bid to eliminate corruption. As required under the government’s PPP rules, Megawide had to overcome a Swiss Challenge or comparative challenge from other potential builders. This was held last October 14, and Megawide hurdled it, leading to the award of the project. “Our vision of a First-World Philippines goes beyond building structures and critical facilities — we also need to connect the key districts across the country to promote commerce and accelerate economic activity. We are very thankful to our local government unit (LGU) partners for sharing our common goal and providing opportunities and platforms where socio-economic progress can thrive,” said engineer Edgar Saavedra, Megawide chairman and CEO. The BCIT will be under a 40-year lease agreement between the operator and the Baguio City government. The land for the project is under a usufruct agreement between the Department of Agriculture and Baguio City, Magalong previously said. The terminal intends to serve seven southbound routes from Baguio: to La Union, Pangasinan, Tarlac, Pampanga, Bulacan, Metro Manila, and Cavite via the South Luzon Integrated Terminal Exchange (SLITX). On September 23, a Megawide subsidiary signed a joint venture agreement with Carmona City, Cavite, for the development of the SLITX. This P800-million terminal will serve various destinations, from Baguio in the north and destinations in Visayas and Mindanao. It will have a capacity of 30,000 passengers. “The facility [SLITX] will connect to PITX and other in-city public terminals and will also have direct access to SLEX via new toll entry and exit to be built and completed before it commences operation. With abundant transport options and park-and-ride facilities, SLITX will allow passengers from the South to directly access the central business districts in Metro Manila as well as the Ninoy Aquino International Airport,” Megawide said. “Landports, such as our PITX, BCIT, and SLITX, as well as the ongoing Cavite BRT (Bus Rapid Transit) system, are part of the grand objective to provide the public with safe, secure, and efficient public transport while improving connectivity and enhancing mobility across key cities, initially in Luzon,” said Jaime Feliciano, head of Business Development at Megawide. – Rappler.com
label: True
title: Baguio City moves closer to having a world-class integrated transport terminal

text: MANILA, Philippines – College students looking to unwind during their free time aren’t limited to the same cafés and tambay (hangout) spots. For the art-inclined majors or even anyone looking for some leisure activities around these university areas, some have on-campus museums and galleries that are open to the public. And for those on a budget, the best part is that some offer free admission to university students and staff! The first museum of Philippine modern art, established in 1960, is just within one of the universities along Katipunan. When you enter the Ateneo de Manila University, you can find the Ateneo Art Gallery in the Areté building. Originally built on the donations of Spanish-Filipino painter Fernando Zobel, the museum’s collection features his works and paintings alongside other local artists like Fernando Amorsolo and Napoleon Abueva. These permanent collections are found on the first and second floors, with a wide range of art from impressionist paintings to works that highlight ordinary rural life. A post shared by Ateneo Art Gallery (@ateneoartgallery) Venture to the third floor and you will find a contemporary showcase with an often limited run-time, like this exhibition for the shortlisted awardees of the Ateneo Art Awards 2025. On the other side of Katipunan, the University of the Philippines Diliman has the Vargas Museum. Named after political figure and UP alumnus Jorge B. Vargas, it is home to his collections of art, books, archives, memorabilia, coins, and stamps. Almost nine years after Vargas donated his collection to the university, the building of the museum was formally inaugurated in 1987. After buying a ticket at the ground floor, you’re met upstairs with a temporary exhibition, book launch, or other special events. Go one floor higher, and you find the permanent art collection with works spanning from the late 19th century to the post-war era. In this gallery, the past meets contemporary, as the works of historical artists Juan Luna, Felix Resurreccion Hidalgo, and Fernando Amorsolo share a space with invited guest artists Poklong Anading, Roberto Feleo, and Alfredo Juan. Reach the third floor, and you see the archives, library, and the Vargas memorabilia. This also houses the North Wing Gallery, which features mostly photography and contemporary art. Did you know the oldest museum in the country is tucked away in España? Originally standing on Intramuros in 1869, the University of Santo Tomas (UST) Museum has since been transferred to the UST Main Building in Sampaloc. It started as compliance with a requirement for colleges to have a museum of natural history, which displayed specimens of shells, butterflies, and birds. After the old main building underwent renovation, old paintings were uncovered and eventually displayed in the new building, transforming the museum from purely scientific to mixing it with the arts. Now, apart from the original natural history collection featuring Philippine fauna, you will find historical coins, medals, and memorabilia displayed. Student life from 300 years ago is preserved through the display of bells, dry seal stamps, and maces used for special occasions like graduations. Of course, art-lovers cannot miss the visual arts collection, featuring a mix of paintings from the 16th to 20th century, with works from Juan Luna, Felix Resurreccion Hidalgo, Manuel Zaragosa, Simeon Flores, Fabian de la Rosa, and many others. After just a short walk from the De La Salle College of Saint Benilde, you’ll find the Museum of Contemporary Art and Design (MCAD). Unlike other galleries, MCAD has no permanent collections, as it offers a space for artists to exhibit their works. Its most recent exhibit was Elisa Tan: Container of Distance, showcasing the Filipino-Chinese artist’s minimalist, conceptual art, wherein she weaves together themes of language, migration, and belonging. A post shared by MCAD Manila (@mcadmanila) Apart from art exhibitions, MCAD also offers learning programs and other cultural and artistic opportunities that emphasize the possibilities of contemporary media and encourage engagement with art and culture. Since the museum temporarily closes to make way for preparations in between exhibitions, it’s best to stay updated on the MCAD Facebook page for their latest events and exhibits. While most museums display paintings, exhibits, or artifacts, one located along Padre Faura Street in Manila shows something a bit more abstract: ideas. The University of the Philippines Manila Museum of a History of Ideas (UPM-HI) showcases the intellectual history of the university and how it contributed to nation-building over the years. According to its website, “Ideas are like artifacts. They are created by societies in particular times and places for particular reasons.” It has seven interlinked galleries and five atria that display different images, sounds, and videos. But these just serve to supplement the ideas, which are the main thing the museum aims to present to viewers. While the museums accept walk-ins, guests are encouraged to book their visit through their Facebook page. – Rappler.com Alyana Fabella is a Rappler intern studying Bachelor of Arts in Communication at the Ateneo de Manila University.
label: True
title: View art after the bell rings at these 5 galleries, museums in universities

text: MANILA, Philippines – Following a disappointing third quarter gross domestic product (GDP) of 4%, what should the Marcos administration do in the coming months? If you ask the president of the Philippines’ largest mall developer and operator, the government’s plan to focus spending on social services for the rest of the year is a welcome development. “If you look at what happened in the last month or so, obviously because of the challenges and the scandals that have happened, government has actually, in a way, stopped infrastructure spending,” said Jeffrey Lim, president of SM Prime Holdings, in a press briefing on Monday, November 10, on the conglomerate’s third quarter earnings. “And I think, given that they’ll probably shift their spending priorities into social services than infrastructure, we hope that Q4 will be better for consumer spending as they would disburse more in the fourth quarter.” Led by its malls business, SM Prime reported an 8% year-on-year increase in its third-quarter net income to P12.8 billion from P11.8 billion. This lifted its nine-month profit to P37.2 billion, up 10% from P33.9 billion a year earlier. Together with steady inflation and lower interest rates, Lim said the government’s spending strategy “would create an environment where consumer spending will be better in November and in the [Christmas] holidays and into 2026.” The Department of Budget and Management (DBM) announced last week that it plans to spend around P1.3 trillion, mostly in social services, in the last quarter of 2025, amid the big drop in government construction spending. The 4% third-quarter GDP translates to a 5% GDP in the first nine months of 2025, which means the government will likely miss its GDP target of 5.5 to 6.5% in 2025. “Our programmed spending for the fourth quarter will boost year-end economic growth and thus impact overall economic growth for the year,” said Budget Secretary Amenah Pangandaman, in a press statement last Thursday, November 6. Among the priority social services in the last quarter, according to the DBM, are the following: Disaster aid Social welfare Agriculture Education Labor Health Year-end benefits The DBM said that as of October 27, it had already released Notices of Cash Allocations amounting to P1.13 trillion of the P1.3 trillion program for the fourth quarter of 2025. “I urge all departments and agencies — gamitin natin ang budget, gastusin nang tama at siguruhing makakarating sa ating mga kababayan (use the budget, spend it correctly, and make sure it reaches our people),” Pangandaman said. Meantime, Joey Salceda, a former Albay representative and a former economic adviser to several presidents, suggested in a research paper last Friday, November 7, that if the Marcos government puts the brakes on infrastructure spending, it “must compensate through aid,” especially in light of the series of natural disasters the country has had to deal with. “When people see billions for flood control while communities remain flooded, they demand accountability. But if pursuing accountability freezes infrastructure, we must keep money flowing another way,” he said. “The P100 billion sitting idle could be redirected to disaster response.” Salceda, however, said disaster assistance should just be a temporary measure, and that the government should still pursue infrastructure projects because if all public works are stopped out of caution, “the public pays twice: once for corruption, again for paralysis.” “The gap between Q3 2024’s 12.8% investment growth and Q3 2025’s negative 2.8% represents lost development momentum. The human cost is starker: the difference between consensus 5.4% growth and actual 4% means 200,000 to 250,000 Filipinos remain in poverty who otherwise would have escaped it,” he said. Salceda said the government should determine “which [infrastructure] projects may proceed, which are under review, which are suspended.” “A safe harbor policy will provide a sense of assurance for officials who just want to do their jobs. By making clear what conditions are required so that a project is not considered suspect, things can move. Cases with credible irregularities should be suspended specifically, not systemically,” he said. Salceda urged Public Works and Highways Secretary Vince Dizon to “make the rules clearer so that the clean [DPWH personnel] can proceed with the rules on their side.” “Instead, for example, of treating FLR projects as entirely suspect, rules can be made clear so that their release is conditional on readiness to implement and accountability of implementation,” he said. – Rappler.com
label: True
title: What Marcos administration can do to arrest slower economic growth in 2025

text: MANILA, Philippines — A society where no one gets left behind is the dream for many Filipinos. For three women with deeply personal advocacies, that vision looks like a Philippines where persons with disabilities, neurodivergent adults and children, and Filipino athletes not only receive care, but also experience dignity, opportunity, and belonging. During the Rappler Social Good Summit 2025 on Sunday, November 16, the panel “Resilience, Well-being, and Purpose” brought together Saab Magalona-Bacarro, Michelle Aventajado, and Aleah Finnegan, championing different causes with a common thread: inclusion and acceptance for all. Through their own stories and on-the-ground experiences, each woman painted a picture of what an inclusive and truly “resilient” Philippines could — and should — look like. Aventajado, the executive director of Best Buddies Philippines, a global nonprofit supporting individuals with intellectual and developmental disabilities, believes that inclusion starts from even the smallest of victories for children with special needs. “Whether it’s my daughter being included in a class they said she could not participate in because she had Down syndrome, or an individual who just got a job and now has a bank account… Did you know that individuals with autism or blindness are not allowed to open their own bank accounts?” Aventajado shared, pointing out that inclusion also starts from systemic change – from workplace practices and government protocols. “And now, the individuals we placed in employment have their own payroll account, full benefits, and health insurance. The success stories fuel me and our volunteers all around the country.” Magalona-Bacarro, podcaster for Wake Up With Jim and Saab, mental health advocate, and founder of the Chaos Control Club – an ADHD-focused coaching community – began her personal advocacy with her own family. “I’m an advocate for ADHD and also Cerebral Palsy. My son has Cerebral Palsy. And I got diagnosed with ADHD after I had two kids — perfect timing because my kids needed me. I was drowning in self-doubt. My children are the reason why I needed the support I could get and why I wanted to extend that accessibility to Filipinos,” Magalona-Bacarro shared. Aleah Finnegan — 2024 Olympian, SEA Games multi-medalist, and advocate for uplifting young Filipino gymnasts — gets real about her definition of inclusion for the athlete community. “As somebody who represents the Philippines, we’re kind of overlooked in sports. So when somebody tells us no, resilience is looking them in the eye and saying, ‘I can do this, and I will.’ Being resilient takes a huge mental toll — on you and the people you support.” For Aleah, competing can get mentally difficult — the pressure to always perform and appear “okay,” despite personal struggles and the inevitable failures, can make any athlete feel alone and afraid. Community support, her fans, and her family are what keep her grounded. “Honestly, what inspires me is the support from young athletes — really just Filipinos in general… On the hard days when I don’t want to train, that’s what I draw from. Maybe a little girl is watching me thinking, ‘If she can do that, then maybe I can too.’” But her strongest support system has always been her family. “Growing up, I was in the gym six hours a day, six days a week. When I got home, my parents would ask, ‘How was practice?’ Sometimes we’d talk, sometimes we’d talk about anything except the gym. That balance kept me going.” For Magalona-Bacarro, she explained what ADHD feels like. “It’s like watching multiple TV screens at the same time, and you can’t pick one. Every task is screaming at you at the same volume. When you finally understand what’s happening in your brain, you stop calling yourself lazy — you learn how to move forward and say, ‘This is my brain, and that’s okay.'” Accepting her diagnosis and understanding herself better happened through community coaching. “Group coaching worked best for me. Even if I was just lurking, hearing other people’s stories made me feel like I wasn’t going crazy. I wasn’t being dramatic. Studies show community support for ADHDers is very effective.” She was initially part of a group coaching program in the US, and it was “so effective” that she wanted to bring it to the Philippines. “We do weekly coaching calls, a private podcast feed, ADHD education, and the best part — a community where we talk about what we’re going through.” For Aventajado, inclusion is built on shared safe spaces and making areas accessible to all. “I’ve been involved in the disability community since I was 14 — even in New York. When my daughter was born, the light bulb went off. The Lord put me here to prepare me for her.” She recalled the moment she knew she had to lead her own community, advocating for those who couldn’t do so for themselves. Best Buddies creates friendships, leadership opportunities, and job placements. “My son got into a fight because someone used the R word. He said, ‘My sister has Down syndrome, it’s hurtful.’ The kid said he’d still use it. They came to blows. I realized — if in his school people are using these words, I needed to walk the walk.” “Individuals with disabilities suffer from social isolation. By 21, most will not have any friends outside of family or medical staff. We match buddies so they can have real friendships,” Aventajado added. One yearly event Best Buddies is most proud of is Dance Night at Xylo, Bonifacio Global City. “We close down the club so our young adults can dance. Nobody’s drinking — they’re just dancing. It’s part of socializing and belonging. We make Xylo accessible with ramps, and we train bartenders and bouncers on disability inclusion. It’s not just you can sit with us — it’s you can dance with us.” All women agreed that our call to action needs to first be rooted in education, awareness, acceptance, and saying “yes” more often. “I want to say that there’s no shame in having a disability. It starts with awareness. Education. And then we have the opportunity to educate people about disabilities. When you accept people where they are, you’re that much closer to including everyone where a society where no one is left behind,” Aventajado said. Magalona urged openness — let people ask questions, be curious, and jump off from their curiosity to spread awareness in a non-judgmental, compassionate way. “Back then, there were a lot more people hiding their children just at home. They were ashamed of protecting their kids. For me I love showing off what my kid can do. I love it when people ask — questions are encouraged,” she said. “It’s an opportunity to educate well-meaning kids and people who are curious to learn more. Keep doing the research, keep getting answers. Don’t make it taboo. I like that we’re having conversations about this. We’re a lot more forward.” For Finnegan, she said that access to resources is key for Filipino athletes. “The biggest resource we need is budget. Better equipment, facilities, and air conditioning. Support other sports too. We have the Junior World Championships here this week. These young athletes are so talented — you won’t want to miss it.” Government support is improving, she said, but more is needed. “There’s improvement, and that’s a good change. But we need more coaches, more support, so athletes continue to love the sport,” she added. And to build a more supportive culture, she wants athletes to remember that it’s okay to cry, and it’s okay to be upset. “It’s not always sparkles and rainbows,” she reminded. “We need understanding that athletes are human, too.” For these three strong women, an inclusive society is one where access is truly democratized — where children with special needs can earn their own money, where Filipino athletes do not fear showing emotion, and where adults can speak openly about mental health and know it is never too late to find community, healing, and answers. – Rappler.com Video recordings of all Social Good Summit 2025 main hall sessions will soon be available to all Rappler+ members. Rappler+ is our premium membership program that gets you access to exclusive content and briefings. Sign up to be a Rappler+ member here.
label: True
title: A truly inclusive society means equal access to care — these 3 women explain why
