text: MANILA, Philippines – After opening their 88th mall in the President’s hometown last May, the Sy family is set to unveil mall No. 89 to the public in La Union, the Philippines’ surfing capital in the north, on Friday, October 17. And the opening of SM City La Union perhaps best exemplifies why bricks-and-mortar retail are here to stay in the Philippines despite the popularity of online shopping. The three-story mall’s opening weekend in what’s also known as “ELYU” offers physical and community engagements that e-commerce can never match. Lined up are a beach volleyball tournament with 16 participating teams, frisbee play, three nights with DJs, sunset music sessions, and fireworks. All these seek to match the mall’s “vibe” with La Union’s reputation as a surfing capital. A post shared by SM City La Union (@smcitylaunion) These events are set to be held within the mall’s premises, mostly in a recreational space called “Sandbox.” This is a 1,348-square-meter outdoor venue, including a sand volleyball court, for sports tournaments, mini-concerts, yoga, Zumba, and other community activities. “Alongside it runs a bike lane parallel to a man-made sandbar, giving cyclists a unique way to enjoy the area’s open-air setting,” SM Prime said. SM City La Union also has water fountains, a long faćade with vertical fins that mimic waves, plus an art installation by artist-designer Leeroy New, whose works often portray the need for sustainable development. “Using bamboo, upcycled bottles, and construction scraps, he created a spaceship-inspired canopy that reflects light and sound throughout the day, symbolizing transformation and renewal,” said SM Megamalls. The mall’s interior also has “double-height atrium”that connects the Department Store, cinemas, and food hall,“with clerestories and wide glass spans bringing natural light across all three levels,” the country’s largest mall operator and developer said. In a statement on Wednesday, October 15, SM Prime president Jeffrey Lim said: “This is our ninth mall in Northern Luzon and we designed it to serve as a landmark for both residents and tourists. As the surfing capital of the region, La Union deserves a retail center that reflects its vibrant lifestyle and rich culture.” A post shared by SM City La Union (@smcitylaunion) Last year, La Union’s tourism sector recorded over P1 billion in revenues, driven by an increase in spending per visitor, as well as slightly higher average length stay, from 1.33 days to 1.39 days, the Sy conglomerate said. Over 500,000 tourists visited San Fernando City, and the surfing and beach towns of San Juan and Bauang. “With our diverse and unique offerings, we hope to strengthen La Union’s position as both a tourism and economic hub in Northern Luzon,” Lim said. Unlike SM’s early shopping centers with retail outlets that sell shoes, groceries, plus a few restaurants, the Sy family’s newer malls and the newly renovated ones put a premium on experiential retail rather than retail as simply shopping. In a recent interview with the ABS-CBN News Channel, SM Megamalls president Steven Tan said this shift is in response to what a younger demographic wants. “Filipinos, especially the GenZs and the Gen Alphas, they look for experiences nowadays. It’s no longer you put out your wares, they come and they buy. You really have to entice them, to make it really pleasurable and enjoyable for them,” Tan said. Sports activities have become big draws for the Sys’ malls. Their Mall of Asia Arena in SM MOA, Pasay City, for instance, has become a major source of revenues, with major sporting events being held there, including the FIBA World Cup in 2023. They recently renovated the MOA to include a 1,800-seat FIFA-grade football pitch at the rooftop. SM City La Union’s beach volleyball tournament from October 17, Friday, to October 19, Sunday, with 16 participating teams reflects the growing popularity of volleyball in the Philippines. Indoor volleyball is perhaps now the second most-watched sport next to basketball, with the country’s Premier Volleyball League (PVL) drawing large crowds, even dwarfing audiences in Philippine Basketball Association (PBA) games. Tan said around 40 SM malls also now have pickleball courts, a response to another rising sport in the country. “SM is now the biggest active lifestyle hub [in the Philippines],” he said. Last year, SM Megamalls opened the Japanese-inspired SM City J Mall in Mandaue City, Cebu in Central Visayas. It includes a JDistrict that allows visitors to experience some of Japan’s attractions. Tan said this shift means going to a mall is not just to buy essentials but “has become very experiential.” “Malls have become the modern-day plazas of this era,” he said. SM Supermalls saw a record high of 5.2 million average daily foot traffic in 2024, up 6% from the 4.9 million logged in 2023. It had also set aside P21 billion for mall expansions this year. Another mall in San Fernando is the Gokongweis’ four-level Robinsons Place La Union. – Rappler.com
label: True
title: SM set to open 89th mall — and why Filipinos keep flocking to these bricks-and-mortar

text: Rappler’s Life and Style section runs an advice column by couple Jeremy Baer and clinical psychologist Dr. Margarita Holmes. Jeremy has a master’s degree in law from Oxford University. A banker of 37 years who worked in three continents, he has been training with Dr. Holmes for the last 10 years as co-lecturer and, occasionally, as co-therapist, especially with clients whose financial concerns intrude into their daily lives. Together, they have written two books: Love Triangles: Understanding the Macho-Mistress Mentality and Imported Love: Filipino-Foreign Liaisons. Dear Dr. Holmes and Mr. Baer, I have a question that has been running through my mind for quite some time, and I hope you can shed some light on it: Does penis size really matter? For context, I used to have a “friends with benefits” setup with a guy who had a 7-inch penis, and I have to admit — the sex was incredible. Aside from the size, he was also attentive, skilled, and very in tune with my needs. We were so sexually compatible that we kept the arrangement going for quite a while, despite not having much else in common. He’s Filipino, by the way, I don’t know why I feel the need to mention it, but somehow it feels relevant. Haha. Eventually, we ended things because he wanted something more serious while I wasn’t ready to commit. To be honest, I also didn’t see myself in a long-term relationship with him, so it felt like the right decision to part ways. Fast forward to now, I’m currently dating someone new, and this time, I am open to committing. We connect on so many levels: we share hobbies, have the same sense of humor, and genuinely enjoy each other’s company. He’s thoughtful, patient, and very understanding. In short, he checks all the boxes of someone I can see myself building a future with. But here’s where my confusion lies: compared to my former partner, his penis is slightly smaller. He’s still a good lover, he tries hard to please me, and I appreciate the effort, but sometimes I feel like it doesn’t quite measure up to the physical intensity I used to experience. And I hate that this thought even crosses my mind, because it makes me feel shallow and guilty. I don’t want to jeopardize a relationship that feels so promising just because of this concern. Yet I can’t help but wonder — am I setting myself up for disappointment in the long run if I keep fixating on this? How much weight should penis size really have when it comes to sexual satisfaction and building a lasting relationship? I truly want this to work, but this issue keeps nagging at me. Please help me sort through this confusion. Sincerely, Veronica Dear Veronica, It seems that you are comparing very different relationships. The first is a friends with benefits, no commitment, focused on mutual pleasure and sexual compatibility, to the exclusion of all else. The second has all the components for a long-term commitment, combining shared interests and sense of humor, etc. The third is an imaginary future relationship which combines the best of the first two. In other words, the comparison is between physical attraction and emotional connection, two realities, and a fantasy. The frequency of sex in a relationship usually diminishes with time. The quality may not, but the quantity certainly does. As a result, a relationship built solely on physical attraction has almost no chance of long-term success. However, when the physical is complemented by trust, respect, love, and attention, then there is cause for hope. A connection of this sort can be nurtured and can grow into a special bond between two people. You have already rejected a sex only relationship because you didn’t have anything else in common. You have now found someone with whom you feel that a commitment stands a chance of success. He is already a good lover so it’s not as though you are physically incompatible, and with time, practice and experimentation, sex together might well get even better. All the best, JAFBaer Dear Veronica, Thank you so much for your letter, one with an honesty so rare it takes my breath away. This is because folklore and culture encourage women to think penis size doesn’t matter. An example of this encouragement is sayings like: “It’s not the size of the dog in the fight, but the size of the fight in the dog that counts” etc. Even science used to encourage the belief by implying that penis length doesn’t really matter since women feel the penis the most closest to the introitus (the vaginal opening). But that is old science. Some relatively more current science journal articles like this state that nerve endings were regularly identified in all locations with “no site of increased density.” This is in sharp contrast to “old science’s” insistence that approximately 90% of the women’s nerve endings are located in the lower third of a woman’s vagina (thus this is THE most sensitive part of a women’s vaginal canal, further implying that the upper two thirds do not “feel” as much stimulation. My answer, however, as a clinical psychologist rather than a biological scientist is that “there is feeling and there is FEELING.” While a woman’s feeling may have to do with density of nerve endings, a woman’s FEELINGS have to do with much more — including (but not limited to) how she likes her cervix stimulated. Thus, to answer the age-old question: “Does penis size really matter?” it seems to me that this depends on the woman answering the question. That is because each woman has her own expectations, fantasies, and yes, perhaps even concentration and /or distribution of her vaginal nerve endings. The answer can acknowledge both the physical sensations and the emotional ones, as in: “Yes, I felt more physical intensity with my former lover, but my current lover and I share a deeper emotional connection.” Furthermore, the answer can be even more nuanced than that, as in “what worries me is: To what extent will penis size matter in terms of the love I feel for my husband in the long run?” Alas, I cannot give you an equally nuanced answer to your more nuanced question because again, that depends, ultimately, on you. And no, wondering about this does not make you mababaw (superficial), it makes you an honest woman with an unflinching desire to know how the biological factors in with the entire picture. In my clinical experience, women who married men primarily for the physical intensity they felt with him during their sex encounters, all but one felt they had made the wrong choice. One client even said: “I married him because of his PhD and his 8-inch schlong, but men with PhDs are a dime a dozen (in the uni I teach at) but the mind-blowing sex stopped being when his 8 inches stopped mattering 8 months after the wedding.” Will your former lover’s 7 inches stop mattering 7 months after your commitment to your current lover? I have no doubt it will. I daresay it’s already stopped mattering now, given your choice of who you want to commit yourself to. Definitely, you look back on your sexual encounters, acknowledge and perhaps even accept that now the physical intensity of the past was more than the present. You do not have dementia, so of course you remember…but with how much wistfulness (as opposed to mere recollection) depends on so many factors, one of which is, do you share the same sense of humor? As to the one woman who did not regret her decision of marrying her lover with a large penis, that was clearly because the size of his penis matched the size of his mind and his heart. All the best, MG Holmes – Rappler.com
label: True
title: [Two Pronged] Does penis size really matter?

text: When Bank of the Philippine Islands (BPI) announced its intention to issue a blue bond, it did more than enter a rising frontier of sustainable finance. It opened a new debate: Can private capital genuinely protect the Philippine marine economy — or will “blue” merely rebrand old vulnerabilities in public infrastructure finance? This is no ordinary issue about geography. The Philippines is a nation of coasts — 36,000 kilometers of shorelines, marine biodiversity that rivals the Coral Triangle, and a population clustered along fragile waters. Yet those same waters have long been collateral damage in the country’s most expensive and politically charged public spending category: coastal development, flood control, port expansion, and wastewater systems. Through the years, billions of government funds have been allocated on these crucial concerns — billions that remain unaccounted for. Since public funding is generally used to benefit communities through health programs, environmental care, or infrastructure in high-need communities, one question naturally emerges when a private bank like BPI steps in with capital tied to oceans, wastewater, and coastal resilience: Are blue bonds a visionary tool or an admission that public funds tend to vanish before their job was done? 1. Definition creep / “blue-washing” risk Green, blue, and social bonds are all thematic bonds designed to finance projects that create a specific positive impact, but their focus areas differ. Green bonds are dedicated to environmental projects, and social bonds fund initiatives that promote social well-being. Blue bonds are a specialized category within green bonds, specifically targeting the financing of projects related to ocean and marine conservation. One of the largest risks in any green, blue, or social is the credibility of the Use-of-Proceeds and the risk of “green / blue-washing” (i.e., proceeds used for projects that claim sustainability credentials but in effect are only marginally so). For a blue bond especially, the boundaries can be fuzzy: what counts as “marine and ocean-based sustainability”? Does it include large commercial shipping that merely replaces one fuel with another? Does it include port expansion with increased traffic? Does it include coastal real-estate development labeled as “eco-tourism” but with heavy environmental impact? Without tight eligibility criteria and strong third-party verification, the risk is that the instrument becomes a mere marketing tool rather than a real effort with social impact. Given that BPI’s framework only includes Blue as one category (rather than clearly evidencing many projects ready for deployment) one must ask: will BPI refrain from issuing until there are enough pipeline projects with concrete measurable outcomes, or will market pressure push them to issue first and then find projects later? BPI says it already “has some projects that would be eligible once it have the framework,” but that still leaves the door open for opportunistic use. 2. Project risk / execution risk Marine and ocean-based projects often carry higher execution risk: permitting (coastal zoning, environmental impact assessments), community opposition, logistics (offshore installations cost more than onshore), climate risk (storms, sea-level rise, typhoons), and technology risk (marine renewables are less mature). If BPI finances these projects via the blue bond, then there is higher risk of cost overruns, delays, and non-performance which may either undermine investor confidence or lead to reputational risk for the bank. Also, if the projects generate revenue streams (fishing, tourism, port logistics) they may be subject to regulatory risk, biodiversity impact risk (if not done sensitively), or climate-shock risk, which raises questions for the bank about how it will mitigate such risk, and whether the bond documentation includes risk allocation, reserve funds, monitoring, etc. 3. Funding cost versus use-of-proceeds mismatch In BPI’s previous issuance (the SINAG bonds), the bond was a short tenor (1.5 years) and a relatively high coupon (5.85% per annum) for domestic investors. If a blue bond is issued, the maturity, coupon, currency and investor base will matter greatly. If BPI issues in peso with short maturity, then longer-lived marine projects (which might have pay-back periods of 10-20 years) risk a mismatch: short-term funding for long-term assets. That creates refinancing risk. If investors expect shorter durations, then BPI will have to roll over, potentially at higher cost. If cost of funds is too high, then the bank may either limit the types of projects financed or accept lower internal rates of return — which may challenge economic viability. 4. Accountability and reporting — not a one-off marketing exercise The value of thematic bonds lies not only in raising money but in linking capital to measurable outcomes. If BPI issues a blue bond and then fails to publish credible, audited impact reports (for instance: % of proceeds deployed, types of projects, socio-economic environmental outcomes, verification by independent third party) then the instrument risks being viewed cynically. For those interested in governance, the question they must ask is: will BPI publish disaggregated data on what portion of proceeds go to e.g., sustainable fisheries vs wastewater vs marine renewables? What are the Key Performance Indicators (KPIs) or jobs created in coastal communities, tons of plastics removed from Gulf of Manila, megawatts (MWs) of marine renewable energy installed? Will there be claw-back or penalty mechanisms if deliverables are not met? The Sustainable Funding Framework mentions reporting, but the devil will be in the details. 5. Potential crowding out / misallocation risk While blue bonds direct funding toward sustainability, there is a governance angle: will they inadvertently crowd out other equally needed investments (e.g., in weaker rural banking, in community credit, in infrastructure in less glamorous sectors)? Also, given the potential “buzz” around blue finance, will some sub-optimal projects be elevated simply to qualify, even though their social or ecological returns are low? In other words: the existence of a labeled bond does not automatically guarantee optimal allocation of capital — there must be a strong governance overlay. Given the Philippines’ history of large-scale infrastructure procurement concerns (which you routinely track), one must watch for transparency regarding project selection, procurement, bidding, supplier oversight, contractor performance. Otherwise, “sustainability theatre” is the risk that arises. 6. Macro / interest-rate / liquidity risk From an investor perspective, blue bonds are still niche, especially in the Philippines. If global interest rates rise, investor appetite may weaken, or yield premiums may widen. For BPI, issuing at the wrong time may mean paying a higher coupon or facing weaker investor demand. There’s also the potential of foreign-currency risk if the bond is issued offshore and repatriated back for domestic projects (unless hedged properly). These broader funding conditions may affect whether the blue bond becomes a cost-effective instrument — something BPI itself acknowledges as it watches market timing. BPI’s sustainable funding framework outlines eligible uses: 1. Waste and wastewater systems near rivers and coasts2. Marine renewable energy (offshore wind, tidal, floating solar) Crucially, traditional flood-control civil works do NOT fall under BPI’s eligibility list. That means no dredging contracts, no dikes, no embankments — the very contracts linked to some of the country’s most persistent procurement controversies. Still, the overlap is unmistakable. Where there are wastewater systems, permits follow. Where ports modernize, government concessions and the Philippine Ports Authority (PPA) loom. Where coastal assets rise, local government unit (LGU) approvals and environmental compliance certificates unlock land and water. Although the bond may not touch the flood-control budgets of the Department of Public Works and Highways (DPWH), it will stand at the shoreline of government influence. And historically, that shoreline is where public funds have washed out to sea. Fairness demands this: blue bonds can do good. They can move capital faster than the bureaucracy. They can unlock long-term financing for offshore wind and modern sewage systems — both of which government has talked about for decades and still struggles to scale. They can force measurable environmental KPIs, annual reporting, and independent verification — standards government projects only dream of. They can build wastewater treatment where fecal coliform still pollutes Manila Bay. They can support ports that don’t spew untreated bilge into coastal waters. They can finally bring credible financing to fisheries certification — protecting livelihoods instead of merely announcing “livelihood projects.” If executed with rigor, blue finance can leapfrog decades of bureaucratic neglect. And the Philippines — battered by climate change, reliant on ports, dependent on coasts — desperately needs that. For every promising headline, three hard questions follow: 1. IF THE GOVERNMENT ALREADY FUNDED COASTAL PROJECTS, WHY ARE BANKS NEEDED NOW? – Was public money wasted? Delayed? Diverted? Sustainable finance markets do not typically appear in countries where fiscal delivery works flawlessly. They emerge where public capacity is strained or compromised. 2. WHO DECIDES WHICH PROJECTS QUALIFY? – BPI screens internally and hires third-party verifiers. Government does not control the selection — and that is both a blessing and a risk. 3. COULD BLUE LABELS MASK OLD NETWORKS? – The framework bars generic flood-control projects, but wastewater and port environmental upgrades still intersect with traditional contractors and local fiefdoms. Without name-by-name disclosure, even verified funds could flow adjacent to power blocs with a history of shaping coastal budgets. BPI promises: Good — but not enough. The Filipino public deserves project-level visibility, not just aggregated summaries. If taxpayers spent years funding similar priorities, citizens have the right to know where gaps appeared — and who now fills them. A bond marketing like “blue economy” cannot operate behind a blue curtain. We should welcome innovation. We should welcome private capital that aligns profit with stewardship. And we should welcome banks that finance sewage treatment and offshore wind instead of casinos and condos. But we should never welcome with blind trust projects in sectors where billions in public money dissolved without trace. If BPI’s blue bond brings rigor, transparency, and project-by-project accountability, it can become a milestone — a Philippine case study in sustainable finance that protects the sea instead of subsidizing those who polluted it. If not? It risks becoming the next sophisticated vessel through which public failure is laundered into private opportunity — a sustainability label wrapped around old inefficiencies and new invisibility. What matters most now is whether BPI’s blue bonds will purify Philippine waters — or simply learn to swim in them. – Rappler.com
label: True
title: [Vantage Point] BPI’s blue bonds: Saving our seas or rebranding an old development gap?

text: CEBU, Philippines – Just weeks after a 6.9-magnitude earthquake and Typhoon Tino (Kalmaegi) devastated communities across Cebu province, over 400 business process outsourcing (BPO) workers were notified they would be placed on floating status, a temporary layoff with no pay and no option to seek similar work for up to six months. The notice from Wipro Cebu arrived as many were still repairing damaged homes and dealing with disrupted utilities, compounding the strain of the back-to-back disasters. BPO Industry Employees’ Network (BIEN)-Cebu chairperson Kyle Enero told Rappler that the layoffs have further heightened employees’ anxieties, particularly among long-serving workers. “Lisod sa ilaha jud,” said Enero. “Klaro ang tumong sa paglay-off sa ilaha: pagputol sa length of service nga mapugos og resign ang mga ahente aron mas gamay ilahang mahatag nga bayad ug benepisyo. Sa ingon ani nga pamaagi, gipakita sa kumpanya nga pagpasiguro sa dakong ginansya gihapon ang prayoridad.” (It is really difficult for them. The purpose of the layoff is clear: to cut the length-of-service of employees, forcing agents to resign so the company can provide lower pay and benefits. This way, the company shows that securing large profits remains its top priority.) This adds to ongoing labor and safety concerns in Cebu City’s BPO sector, where employees were reportedly forced to work during the September 30 earthquake despite building damage, with some threatened for opting to evacuate and others sent back to production floors without proper safety checks. Several of the affected Wipro Cebu employees have been with the company for six years or more, and many of them found the layoff notice completely unexpected. Enero told Rappler that for long-serving workers, the announcement “felt like a form of betrayal after years of service.” Workers also questioned Wipro’s claim that the layoffs were due to performance issues since some of the affected employees are among the company’s top performers, making the decision appear arbitrary. “They say it’s really unfair because the reason given for selecting them for the layoff was their performance, even though performance isn’t actually an issue, as some top performers were also included,” said Enero in Cebuano. He recounted the case of a worker who was initially placed on floating status arbitrarily and later subjected to a performance improvement plan for allegedly poor performance, despite already being on floating status at the time. He added that the same employee has now been included in Wipro’s latest round of floating layoffs. “This only exposes that the BPO industry practice of placing agents on floating status, combined with a high attrition rate, puts workers in a precarious situation where their livelihood is directly affected, often forcing them to leave the company — not by choice, but due to circumstances — which essentially amounts to constructive dismissal,” said Enero. He added that during his conversations with workers, their main concern was their benefits and fair compensation, particularly as many are still recovering from the recent typhoon and earthquake. Enero explained that the floating status system is a new form of cost-cutting in the BPO industry, designed to pressure employees to resign so companies can avoid paying benefits that increase with length of service. “While floating status is legal, it does not make it moral or ethical,” he said. Rappler has reached out to Wipro Cebu for comment. This story will be updated once we get a response. In a statement, BIEN-Cebu condemned Wipro’s recent actions, describing the placement of over 400 employees on floating status as an attack on workers’ rights. “While Wipro management has initiated a reprofiling process, they remain deaf to workers’ requests for separation pay and the option to exit the company,” the network said. BIEN-Cebu also urged the Wipro management to grant severance pay to employees placed on floating status, honor requests from workers who wish to be reprofiled to other roles, and show genuine compassion for those still recovering from recent calamities. Enero recently filed a request for dialogue with the Department of Labor and Employment-Regional Office VII (DOLE-VII) to discuss updates on inspections following the September 30 earthquake and address the numerous cases of temporary layoffs in the BPO sector. – Rappler.com Marjuice Destinado is a senior political science student at Cebu Normal University (CNU) and an alumna of the Aries Rufo Journalism Fellowship of Rappler for 2025.
label: True
title: After back-to-back disasters, 400 Cebu BPO workers face job uncertainty

text: MANILA, Philippines — For years, Manila’s nightlife has revolved around the south — Makati and the Manila Bay area, lighting up with the city’s most spirited nights and sights. But Solaire North in Quezon City shifts the scene northward, highlighting Quezon City’s own brand of sophistication and fun. Framing itself as “Manila’s best kept secret,” the newly-established Quezon Club gilds the first level of Solaire Resort North in its namesake Quezon City, distilling the shared ethos of the resort and its team: not to imitate the energy of the south, but to compose an experience much slower and theatrical, steeped in gold, sound, and history. From Tuesday to Saturday, Quezon Club comes alive with a changing lineup of performances. One night might feature a harpist playing French classics, another a violinist reimagining retro hits under warm amber lights. Each evening offers something different, keeping regulars and newcomers alike curious about what’s next. It takes a moment for guests to realize the melody’s origin. Still, it’s precisely what the club aims for: familiar and nostalgic pop refrains slipping through the language of strings. “It’s not just your standard musicians playing,” general manager Earl Butterhof told Rappler. “Let’s take the violinist, for example. She’s not playing classical music. She’s playing hip hop, commercial songs, and it takes you a while to actually realize, ‘Oh, wait, I know this song,’ but you’ve never heard it played that way before.” Other twilights give way to a lounge singer’s velvet rasp, a DJ’s midnight pulse, or the sculptural daring of a pole performance. Friday and Saturday heighten the spectacle, with their resident dance troupe bursting into choreography set to classic hits from Madonna and Britney Spears. “Is it a dining, immersive experience with entertainment involved?” Butterhof asked. “In most places, it’s generally that you have the dining element, and the entertainment’s a bit more separate. For us, we like to intertwine everything.” Reflecting the club’s flair for entertainment, Quezon Club’s menu brings the same attention to culinary artistry. Behind its kitchen doors, chef January Belardo and director of culinary Hylton Le Roux treat the plate as a stage — modern technique meeting timeless flavor, and a shared appetite for risk. “Many of the dining concepts are Chef Hylton’s babies,” said Butterhof. “I think he was thrilled for the Quezon Club opportunity because then he could kind of do things outside the box, nothing so normal —he could really take some risks and some chances and maybe put some things together that generally, you wouldn’t think of.” Still, the menu grounds itself in Western classics. Among the early crowd favorites are the Paella Valenciana, Beef Wellington, and lamb and duck dishes, all hearty signatures that turn fine dining into a communal affair. The daily specials also keep patrons guessing — dishes that change at the chef’s or the season’s whim. Among the evening’s selections is the Maryland Crab Cake: a starter that teases memories of seaside meals. The crab cake is golden and crisp on the edges, its interior rich with lump crab meat, celery, and onion. A dab of harissa aioli lends heat that blooms slowly, cut clean by the squeeze of a charred lemon. As for mains, the menu turns heartier, moving from shore to pasture. The Roast Halibut is atop a white bean ragout and spinach pesto, curdling into something almost munggo-like in spirit; earthy and clean. The Sous Vide Duck Breast, by contrast, deepens the register: tender slices resting against roasted sweet potato, orange jus, and cowboy beans. The Lamb Rack is seared to precision, its snap pea purée a cool counterpoint to the port wine jus. A true standout of the dessert section is the club’s Hazelnut Lava Cake. It parts open on the knife’s edge, spilling warmth into the cold vanilla scoop atop it and the praline flakes beneath. As dinner winds down, the focus shifts to the bar, which comes alive later in the evening. Here, the allusive signature cocktails section, led by head bartender Martin Protacio, bottles Quezon Club’s flair for reinvention and homage into liquid form. Each drink borrows from the language of Filipino modern art, its colors, textures, and impulses reimagined in glass. Sabel’s Appletini — standard spirits are reworked with calvados, homemade pear vermouth, and apple syrup, then poured from a flask that doubles as a portrait. It is sweet, restrained, and quietly precise. For something more playful, the Breakfast Arabesque lightens the tone: gin, banana syrup, and cereal milk brightened with lemon, a playful blend. Fernando A.’s Rice Highball, meanwhile, offers a familiar pandan syrup and horchata fizz that masks the dark rum. At first, the drink seems like all bark and no bite, with three marshmallows afloat the green drink, but the liquor’s warmth reveals itself after a short pause. The Bird Seller Boulevard completes the quartet, served in an egg-shaped glass cradled within a nested birdcage. Its mix of whisky, tomato vermouth, and salted-egg amaro is all about contrasts and presentation. Ultimately, Quezon Club stands as a reminder that the north’s nightlife need not live in the shadow of the south. “What we’ve been doing since the beginning is not really playing by a rulebook,” Butterhof said. “We want everyone to feel like they can do something here…there’s no bad event, there’s no bad ideas. We feel like this is the venue for everyone.” That spirit of openness, welcome, and play runs through everything within the club’s four opulent walls: the stage performers disciplined in various arts, the menu that changes with evolving appetites, and the bar that turns art into cosmopolitan drinks. Tucked within the city’s restless streets, the club doesn’t try to outshine the south’s nightlife so much as offer an alternative to it — a slower, more deliberate experience that values conversation as much as spectacle. Its prices alone place it among the area’s more extravagant haunts, as the kind of place you’d split the bill for on special nights that call for a little decadence. Quezon Club’s operating hours are Tuesday to Wednesday from 5 pm to 1 am, and Thursday to Saturday from 5 pm to 3 am. Expect to spend in the mid- to high-thousands for mains (entrées begin at P1,200+), with cocktails averaging a few hundred pesos each (~P600). Reservations can be made through their website. – Rappler.com
label: True
title: A new north star: Quezon Club lights up nightlife scene in Quezon City

text: MANILA, Philippines — The Philippines has signed a free trade agreement with the United Arab Emirates (UAE), its first with a Middle Eastern country, Malacañang announced Tuesday, January 13. The Comprehensive Economic Partnership Agreement (CEPA) between the two countries, Malacañang said in a release, was signed on the sidelines of the Abu Dhabi Sustainability Week (ADSW) 2026 Summit. Both Marcos and UAE President Sheikh Mohamed bin Zayed Al Nahyan witnessed the signing of the agreement. The two also held a brief meeting after the signing ceremony, said the Palace. According to the Palace, the deal “aims to reduce tariffs, enhance market access for goods and services, increase investment flows, and create new opportunities for Filipino professionals and service providers in the UAE.” The UAE hosts around 900,000 Filipinos. The agreement “covers strategic sectors such as digital trade, MSMEs, sustainable development, intellectual property, competition and consumer protection, government procurement, and technical cooperation.” While the Palace has yet to release a briefer on the agreement, it said Philippine “bananas, pineapples, canned tuna, electronics, machinery, and other high-demand products” are seen to benefit from the agreement. Malacañang said that based on initial studies, the CEPA may “boost Philippine exports to the UAE by 9.13%, generate consumer savings, and strengthen overall trade linkages with the Gulf region.” The UAE ranks 18th among Manila’s trade partners and is where around 39% of Philippine exports to the Middle East goes, according to government data. Bilateral trade between the Philippines and the UAE hit over $1.83 billion in 2024. Marcos is in Abu Dhabi for a two-day visit to attend the Abu Dhabi Sustainability Week upon the invitation of the UAE president. He is joined by a delegation that includes First Lady Louise Araneta-Marcos, Trade Secretary Cristina Roque, Foreign Affairs Secretary Ma. Theresa Lazaro, Acting Finance Secretary Frederick Go, and Special Envoy to the UAE for Trade and Investment Kathryna Yu-Pimentel. – Rappler.com
label: True
title: Philippines signs free trade deal with UAE

text: MANILA, Philippines — Tourism is no longer just about enticing travelers to visit the country, but to encourage them to keep coming back for different high-quality experiences. A recent study titled Capturing High-Quality Tourism in Southeast Asia by Oxford Economics (OE), in collaboration with the Asia Pacific International Spirits and Wines Alliance (APISWA) and the Alcoholic Beverages Alliance of the Philippines Inc. (ABAPI), shared key insights on how to maximize tourism opportunities in the region and in the Philippines. Across the board, they all agreed that 2026 is the perfect time to capitalize on travel opportunities, with the tourism sector steadily recovering from the pandemic. In January to August 2024, arrivals to the country reached 65% of pre-pandemic arrivals. But what part of travel should be prioritized? According to the study, it’s the food and beverage (F&B) experiences. The report surveyed 1,800 travelers from the region’s five major tourist source markets — China, South Korea, Australia, the United States, and the United Kingdom — to understand traveler destination choices. And from these insights, it was revealed that the availability of quality F&B is valued over historical and cultural sights, especially for higher-income travelers. Tourists are willing to pay more when premium food and beverage experiences are offered. To be precise, that’s around US$250 per person per day. “Premium” does not necessarily equal luxury or gourmet, at least in the context of the study. According to James Lambert, director of economic consulting at Oxford Economics, “premium” in their analysis means high-quality food and beverage products. On one hand, quality could mean serving dishes from award-winning chefs and offering a full range of international, branded alcoholic beverages. But it is also about having a wide variety of options that are easy to access. “That might mean opening early, closing late, [and being] easy to get to,” Lambert said. Apart from the quality of the food, quality of service is also a major factor. “[The premium traveler is] willing to grab a burger from a robot at a casual eatery, but he would not want his 25-year-old scotch to be served by a robot in a Michelin star restaurant,” said a respondent from the study, highlighting the importance of the staff and service of premium F&B. However, while they are willing to pay more for better quality, tourists across different income groups still demand value for their money. Safety and reliability also remain crucial aspects in F&B. The report also notes that premium F&B means different things to different travel groups. Notably, it revealed that tourists from China valued access to F&B, while tourists from Korea and the UK are willing to spend more on exceptional service. How exactly can the industry use this data to drive tourism? According to Lambert, apart from embracing high-quality premium experiences, offering variety is also a key factor in developing F&B experiences. During the panel discussion of the report’s launch, Ramon Alampay, associate professor of the University of the Philippines Institute of Tourism, also emphasized catering to domestic tourists who make up the bulk of tourism in the Philippines. He said that there is a need to provide tourists with more awareness of the local food scene, where to go, and the quality of experience they can expect. An emerging strategy from the industry is promoting this on social media and online sites that travelers seek information from. Meanwhile, Chef Jessie Sinciocio, president and CEO of Chef Jessie Restaurants, shared that the strengths of Filipino F&B are rooted in its novelty. “I believe our food can compete with the best in the world, as long as they are prepared properly,” she said. This comes at a prime time, when the Michelin Guide announced its first-ever selection of Philippine restaurants in its 125-year history. However, one concern is that local producers and suppliers fail to offer consistent quality. For Chef Jessie, the problem lies in the logistics of delivering quality ingredients, a key issue to be addressed in improving local F&B. Ultimately, Alampay believes the data from the report can lead to innovations within the industry that explore new ways of experiencing culture through food. “You also want to have that level of innovation at the regional level. Whether it’s Ilonggo, Kapampangan, Bicol,” he said. Apart from building competitive destinations that offer quality F&B, he emphasized the need for proper training when it comes to offering a Filipino brand of service excellence. — Alyana Fabella/Rappler.com Alyana Fabella is a Rappler intern studying Bachelor of Arts in Communication at the Ateneo de Manila University.
label: True
title: ‘Premium’ food experiences are key to tourism growth, study reveals

text: MANILA, Philippines – Corned beef sinigang. Don’t knock it until you’ve tried it — the admittedly unique take on the Filipino sour soup helped catapult chef Vicky Pacheco of Sentro 1771 into restaurant stardom, starting the trend of other restaurants following suit. Corned beef sinigang, featuring a homemade tamarind broth base, has all the trimmings of traditional sinigang — kangkong, sitaw, labanos, kamatis, and more — but instead of the usual pork, shrimp, or fish, the star is huge chunks of real corned beef simmered in the sourly comforting broth until soft and fall-off-the-fork tender. Did Pacheco expect her invention to take off and become an iconic staple? “Not at all. I just knew deep down that it was masarap (delicious), and it needed a stage so that many people could enjoy it. A specialty of the house that becomes iconic is a gift from God,” Pacheco told Rappler. It wasn’t the product of brainstorming sessions or extensive R&D. The idea was a spur-of-the-moment, lightbulb idea during Pacheco’s early days at the now-closed Chateau 1771 in El Pueblo, when she passed by a tall pot of broth where corned beef had just been boiled and tenderized. “I tasted the broth and thought to myself, ‘Hmm, ang alat! Lagyan ko kaya ng pangpa-asim? (Hmm, too salty! What if I put something to make it sour?) So I got a small pot and added tamarind. Lasang sinigang! (It tastes like sinigang!)” She then added the boiled corned beef — and just like that, Sinigang na Corned Beef was born. At the time, Corned Beef and Cabbage, a dish of Irish origin, was on the menu of Chateau 1771, which served “No Borders Cuisine.” “After that discovery, I kept on looking for the right opportunity to feature it, but our restaurant concepts at that time were not suited to it,” Pacheco said. So, why not at the modern Filipino restaurant Sentro 1771? It was a risk — we all know how Filipinos can be when a beloved dish is seen to be “butchered” in the name of innovation. But Pacheco knew she couldn’t play it safe. Initial reactions from diners ranged from: “How can corned beef be sinigang? Isn’t it the one in the can? How can that be?” “But it was mysterious. It was unimaginable. That’s why on the menu, I put, ‘You’ve got to try it to believe it!’” she said. Pacheco recalls mountaineer Romeo Garduce, one of the first Filipinos to climb Mount Everest in 2006, visiting Sentro 1771 in Greenbelt 3 to eat Sinigang na Corned Beef right after returning from his climb. “He knew about corned beef sinigang?! It was not even a press event. He went there on his own. I wasn’t even there, but I saw a photo of him in Sentro, and I cannot even remember where I saw it because there was no social media back then,” she shared. That’s when Pacheco realized the power of word of mouth and the impact of a simply delicious dish. Long before food reviews and TikTok vloggers, you knew you’d made it when people purposefully came to your restaurant, solely looking for your food. Shortly after, her Corned Beef Sinigang was well-received. It became viral in its own right, with many diners amazed at how something could taste both familiar yet intriguingly new. How did she strike that balance? “The Filipino taste buds (panglasang Pilipino) must always be honored, whether the dish is an innovation or not, and especially if it is a classic or traditional dish. If there is a fusion of cooking or preparation techniques, of cuisines or of ingredients, the taste of the dish must come home to the Filipino taste buds,” Pacheco said. “Dapat umakma sa panglasa natin (It should be just right for the Filipino taste buds). I don’t mix or use ingredients just because of trends.” At Sentro 1771, Pacheco sticks to her Filipino roots, but also takes pride in other “creations with a twist,” like kesong puti nuggets, crispy suman with mango, and catfish adobo flakes. They may be playful takes on local ingredients, but they remain comforting and familiar — new in form, but homey in flavor. She manages to surprise while staying grounded in her identity as a chef by keeping the specialties and signature dishes untouchable. But for everything else, she studies the “popularity index” while ensuring originality to maintain Sentro’s “Modern Filipino Cuisine” positioning. “What I have learned from good restaurants is to stick to the concept but always look new and polished,” she said. Sentro 1771 does know how to do the classics right — the chicken barbecue is grilled on skewers until moist and juicy, coated in a slightly sweet-savory glaze, while the signature gising-gising is comfortingly creamy with coconut cream and just the right amount of heat. It’s about integrity and finesse, Pacheco shared — from preparation to cooking to plating. “Integrity means being honest (with the ingredients, the weights, the procedures), being authentic (no substitutions that will lower the quality, no shortcuts), and always abiding by the food standards,” Pacheco said. Meanwhile, finesse is doing things with refinement, order, thoughtfulness, and care. She also values hospitality highly. “The customers are called guests, and they should feel at home and special, not ignored after the food has been served. I have been to good-tasting restaurants where I could have walked out after eating without paying the bill, and no one would have noticed.” Pacheco’s culinary lessons stem from years in the industry — but they started at home. She grew up hanging around the kitchen after school, checking what was being served for merienda or prepared for her father’s many gatherings. She ultimately learned how to cook because it became necessary in her job at Chateau 1771 — managing the dining room, but also needing to function as a chef. So she studied with the cooks and asked them to teach her, while buying and reading her favorite cookbooks every night. She mentioned her favorite “cookbook” mentors: Michel Roux, for his precise and refined recipes; Shirley Corriher’s Cookwise, a deep dive into kitchen science; Rose Levy Beranbaum’s The Cake Bible, a baking essential; Harold McGee’s On Food and Cooking, for its technical insights; and Nora Daza’s Cooking With Nora, a well-loved Filipino classic. “In our house, it’s torn, tattered, and stained, but I still use it to this day. The volume and variety of recipes are amazing — and they work!” And over the years, Pacheco realized that cooking was natural and easy for her — “I had the knack for it.” “I wanted to become a real chef after opening Chateau 1771 in 1995. Washing dishes and cooking in the heat appealed to me. I liked the freedom to be creative and the science of cooking. Most of all, the discovery of a new dish always brings joy to me,” she shared. “Not having any cooking experience in any hotel or restaurant and not having a mentor chef molded me to be unique and to rely on my instincts and childhood food memories,” Pacheco shared, noting she edited her own menus, was accountable for the direct costs, and did not do product testing or trial menus. “I became a keen observer. I was too shy to go out in the dining room and ask for feedback.” Instead, she would get her feedback from her harshest yet most trusted critics: her family. “The honest feedback of masarap o hindi masarap (delicious or not) was always the question and the issue. When the food is masarap (delicious), no one says so — you just see the food disappear from the table,” she shared. On her mother’s side of the family, when something is , they would ask for the recipe or discuss the cooking methods and provenance of ingredients. But in her dad’s family, it was not that technical — it was more about cooking from the heart. “It was my lola’s (grandmother) cooking that was masarap. I thought that the phrase ‘cooking from the heart’ was just a saying, but it turned out to be true. Because cooking is laborious, it is so easy to just throw everything together and not care as long as the family is not hungry. I realized why my dad kept saying, ‘Ang luto ng lola mo, ang luto ng lola mo…’ (Your grandmother’s cooking) — that was the standard.” Despite her dad telling her to resign due to Pacheco’s frequent absence during birthdays, holidays, and anniversaries, Pacheco kept on. And years later, after her stint in Chateau 1771, Pacheco decided to try something of her own. She wanted to see Filipino food served with finesse in a beautiful, upscale setting. The execution would be well thought out, and the food presentation would be pleasing to the eye and done with care using nice dinnerware, she said. Sentro 1771 was born — but not easily; she shared that the hardest part was balancing innovation and tradition. “It was not totally traditional nor totally Filipino. It was a fusion of sorts and hard to label because no one really tinkered with Filipino food that much unlike today. In the end, Modern Filipino Cuisine became a genre in the Filipino dining landscape,” she said. Years later, after branch expansions and a growing menu (with corned beef sinigang still at its forefront), Pacheco felt like “Sentro has made its mark” last June, when the Sinigang na Corned Beef was featured in the first I Love Filipino series on Netflix. “It was such an honor as it came from out of the blue. I don’t think Sentro was mentioned but since Sentro and Sinigang na Corned Beef are synonymous, it was the same thing. A restaurant can close down and be forgotten, but a dish can stay on for generations as long as there is a recipe and can therefore be cooked by anyone. Think Nora Daza,” she said. As a female chef in a male-dominated industry, Pacheco shares that she is fortunate to not have had any major gender-centric struggles in her career. “Since I was the chef, no one bullied me. I carried the heavy stuff and did not allow them to help me. Up to now, I stay physically fit by doing weights and cardio so that I can stand with the guys in the kitchen at any given time that I have to.” But if there was anything she would change — any piece of advice to give her younger self — it would be: “You should have gone out to the dining room to meet all those wonderful guests.” This means not getting too caught up in the intricacies of the kitchen or lost in its technicalities — because cooking, at its core, is a love language and an act of service. All the hard work ultimately goes to those who choose to dine in your restaurant, spending their time and money to appreciate your labor of love. That is why now, Pacheco makes it a point to regularly visit her restaurants and reach out personally. And for the future, she would love to see Sentro as a house in an area with a garden with lots of trees and parking. “It can then become a home, not just an outlet inside a mall,” she said. As for Filipino dining, she has high hopes — she sees it continuing to evolve. And through her work and those of other younger chefs, she believes it’s important to show the new generation that it’s not always about price, portion size, or trends. “There is such a thing as authenticity and sensibility, and that Filipino food can be prepared with care and served with sincere hospitality.” And that’s what she plans to continue for Sentro 1771 — and all her ventures to come. – Rappler.com Sentro 1771 has branches in Bonifacio Global City, Greenbelt, and Capitol Commons.
label: True
title: Who is the female chef behind the famed Corned Beef Sinigang?

text: MANILA, Philippines – In one of the rare infrastructure undertakings of the Sy family, Iloilo City in Western Visayas now has public markets redeveloped by SM Prime Holdings Incorporated, the Philippines’ largest mall developer and operator founded by the late Henry Sy. Built under a public-private partnership (PPP), Iloilo City and SM Prime opened to the public on October 30 the redeveloped Iloilo Central Market, also known as Tienda Mayor, and the Iloilo Terminal Market, the bagsakan or drop-off area for goods traded in Panay Island. The two markets, built decades ago, are located in Iloilo City’s Cultural Tourism Heritage Zone and Historic Center. The redevelopment seeks to preserve and enhance the city’s old commercial business district and help improve the city’s tourism. From drab and unsightly, the new markets have been transformed into bright and clean spaces for the city’s micro, small, and medium enterprises (MSMEs). “Before, the old market’s condition was really difficult for us. When it rained, everything got wet, and our regular customers found it inconvenient,” said Jedda Navales, a native coffee vendor. “Now, with the new Iloilo Terminal Market, we’re finally leveling up.” SM Prime spent P3 billion to redevelop the two buildings, which it described as “two of the city’s historic public spaces.“ With additional floors, the Iloilo Central Market now has a gross floor area (GFA) of 17,000 square meters, while the Iloilo Terminal Market has a GFA of 20,000 sqm. The redevelopment projects, solicited for PPP by the local government unit, were undertaken at no cost to the Iloilo City government. SM Prime president Jeffrey Lim said the projects do not signify a new business field for the conglomerate. “This is more to support entrepreneurs which is part of how we do business and as we move to provincial areas so we can create shared growth between us and the MSMEs,” Lim said in a press briefing on Monday, November 10. Lim added that SM Prime currently has no other public market redevelopment projects in its pipeline, but that it is open to working with other local government units (LGUs) to help local entrepreneurs. The PPP was signed in August 2022 between then-Iloilo City mayor Jerry Treñas and SM Prime, and the projects were opened to the public by his successor, daughter Raisa Treñas-Chu, and SM Engineering Design and Development president Hans Sy Jr., a grandson of SM founder Henry Sy. The redevelopment of the Iloilo Central Market, built in the 1920s, expanded the central market section, increasing the space available for vendors (fish and meat, dried fish, flower shops, rice and grains, frozen food) from 529 to 850. This area will be managed by the Iloilo City government. Unlike before, the Iloilo Central Market now has ramps and an elevator for easier access to the two upper floors. In addition, the Iloilo Central Market now has 61 long-term leasable spaces and communal areas which will be handled by SM Prime and from which it hopes to recover its investment. SM Prime said this area includes dining areas where Ilonggo dishes such as batchoy and pancit molo will be available. Iloilo is the Philippines’ first UNESCO Creative City of Gastronomy. The Iloilo Terminal Market’s market section, on the other hand, now has spaces for 1,160 vendors from the previous 911. Plus, it now has a lifestyle center in the upper floors with 58 long-term leasable spaces to be handled by SM Prime. SM Supermalls president Steven Tan said the the redeveloped public markets will be fully operational by the end of November. He said the focus in the redevelopment was on hygiene “making sure everything was clean,” including recycling, the sewage treatment plant, and water supply, and improving access. “We have professionalized this and we added more parking to make it more convenient for people who go to the market,” Tan said. “This day marks an important milestone in the history of Iloilo City, a new beginning for our vendors and shoppers. Everything is organized, clean, bright and well-ventilated,” said Treñas-Chu during the soft opening ceremony on October 30. “This project raises the bar and serves as a model of how the private and public sectors can work hand in hand to deliver meaningful, lasting benefits for communities,” the LGU also said in a statement. In a statement on September 22, the Iloilo City Local Economic Enterprise Office (LEEO) clarified that the Iloilo Central Market was “not privatized.” “SM will only manage their designated area, while the rest of the market operations remain under the Local Economic Enterprise Office (LEEO),” it said. It also denied that rent for each of the market space will go up from P900 per month to P5,000 per month. “No such increase has been implemented. In fact, under Executive Order No. 21, the City Government has deferred any adjustment in market rental rates for two years, covering 2025 to 2026,” the LGU office said. SM Prime will manage and maintain the facility under a 25-year lease with the Iloilo City government. – Rappler.com
label: True
title: If SM were to redevelop your city’s palengke, what would it look like?

text: The façade has finally cracked. The Securities and Exchange Commission (SEC) has confirmed that the very appraisal underpinning Villar Land’s trillion-peso “profit” wasn’t just inflated — it failed to comply with International Valuation Standards, making it a textbook case of misrepresentation. It not only supports Vantage Point’s exposé branding the trillion profit as a mirage; a factual forensic analysis which the Villar camp tried to disparage. E-Value, the appraiser handpicked to justify the ₱1.34-trillion leap in land value, couldn’t even produce the documents that supposedly supported its assumptions and methodology. In other words, the valuation that turned ₱5.2-billion worth of land into “₱1.34 trillion” wasn’t just unbelievable — it was unsupported, undocumented, and unacceptable by global standards. More than a technical oversight, it is a damning red flag that strikes at the core of corporate honesty, investor protection, and the integrity of the Philippine capital markets. When a valuation firm claims compliance with global standards — but the SEC finds no evidence to back it up — it’s misrepresentation. It casts a dark shadow over every executive and director who relied on that number to trumpet Villar Land’s phony near-₱1-trillion profit. The regulator has drawn blood: the trillion-peso fairy tale wasn’t just aggressive accounting — it was built on a valuation report that doesn’t meet the most basic thresholds of transparency and credibility. For a brief, dizzying moment, Villar Land looked like it had broken the laws of financial gravity. On paper, it was suddenly worth over ₱1.3 trillion, after a land revaluation in Villar City turned a ₱5.2-billion acquisition into a ₱1.34-trillion “asset” almost overnight. That sleight of hand helped produce a nearly ₱1-trillion profit for 2024 — what would have been the largest in Philippine corporate history. The market swallowed the story. Villar Land’s shares last traded at ₱2,296 apiece, valuing the company at around ₱1.48 trillion, more than many long-established conglomerates combined. Then the adults entered the room. Audit giant Punongbayan & Araullo (P&A) refused to sign off on the fantasy valuation. The Securities and Exchange Commission (SEC) ordered Villar Land and its appraiser E-Value Philippines to explain how empty or sparsely developed land in Villar City could justify a 25,000% gain. And when the dust settled, Villar Land quietly agreed to slash that valuation by 99%, bringing the supposed ₱1.34-trillion land haul down to a far more earthly figure. What’s left after the trillion-peso mirage evaporated is now visible in the company’s own audited numbers — numbers that the Villar group can no longer spin away. (READ: From P999-B profit, Villar Land’s 2024 net income flat amid dipping sales) And those numbers are ugly. According to Villar Land’s 2024 audited disclosure: That means: Does it look like a triumphant trillion-peso juggernaut? This is what a strained balance sheet looks like: more assets funded by more debt, but providing less cushion for shareholders. If you strip away the hype and just do the math, roughly 62% of Villar Land’s assets are now funded by liabilities, leaving only about 38% backed by equity — yet, this is the same company that recently tried to sell itself as the most valuable listed property play in the country. The most damning part of Villar Land’s 2024 profile is not even the asset write-down. It’s the sudden collapse in liquidity: A year ago, Villar Land had more than three pesos in current assets for every peso of short-term liabilities. Now, it’s down to ₱1.46. Strip out inventory and prepayments, and the cushion almost disappears: the quick ratio is barely above 1.0. In plain language: Short-term obligations have ballooned. The buffer to meet them has almost vanished. Now overlay that with what’s happening outside the balance sheet: A company whose short-term liquidity is visibly eroding cannot afford to be on the wrong side of both its regulators and its investors. And yet, this is what Villar Land’s situation is: tighter cash, heavier scrutiny. On paper, Villar Land can still claim to be profitable: And yet the profitability ratios miraculously improved: How do you get higher margins out of falling revenues and stagnant profits? Look at what’s happening below the operating line: In other words, core business is weakening, but the bottom line is being propped up by non-operating gains — the same part of the financial statements where that now-infamous ₱1.33-trillion fair value “gain” once sat. After you’ve seen one of the most aggressive revaluation attempts in Philippine corporate history, you’d be reckless not to question the quality of every peso that comes from “non-operating” sources. The retained earnings ledger tells an equally troubling story. Do the reconciliation, and you’ll find Villar Land effectively paid out around ₱1.9B in dividends or equity adjustments — more than it earned in 2024 — at a time when: When a company under a valuation scandal is still prioritizing cash distributions over balance-sheet repair, the question practically writes itself: Is the listed firm being used as a cash machine for its controllers while ordinary investors are left holding the suspension risk and regulatory fallout? The valuation gap: 1,000× P/E, 100× P/B, and a shattered narrative. At its last traded price of ₱2,296, Villar Land carried metrics that would be laughable if they weren’t so dangerous: That implies: These are certainly not “premium” valuations. They look more like detached-from-reality valuations, built on the back of a trillion-peso land story that no longer exists in the audited books. Yet as of the last trading day before suspension, the market still priced Villar Land as if that story were true. After a six-month suspension for failing to file audited reports, Villar Land finally returned to the trading floor on November 13, 2025. The market’s reaction should have been a referendum on corporate honesty. Instead, the reopening exposed something far more dangerous: the collapse of price discovery in the Philippine stock market. There are two versions reported by the media Version 1 — The crash The stock plunged 30% on its first day back, falling from ₱2,296 to ₱1,608, Wiping out roughly ₱450 billion in market value. Yet unbelievably — even after a 30% collapse, Villar Land still had a market cap of more than ₱1 trillion. A trillion-peso valuation for a company with ₱1.42B in earnings and ₱21 book value per share. Isn’t it delusion? Version 2 — The “nothing happened” scenario This version paints the opposite picture: that Villar Land didn’t fall at all — it even gained 0.17% to ₱2,300, restoring its pre-suspension market cap of ₱1.5 trillion. A company stripped of its trillion-peso accounting trick somehow came back trading as if nothing had happened. Which is correct? Both — and that’s the problem. Whether it’s ₱1,608 or ₱2,300, both outcomes expose the same hard truth: Villar Land remains valued like a fantasy stock — not a real business. Either the market fell for the hype again, or the stock is so illiquid and insider-dominated that real price discovery is impossible. Either way, it is catastrophic for investor protection. A valuation still over ₱1 trillion — even after the scandal — underscores how fragile and distorted our capital markets have become: …yet still trades at: 1,000× earnings, over 100× book value, higher than Ayala Land and SM Prime combined. If this doesn’t alarm investors, regulators, and policymakers, nothing will. This is not just a problem for Villar Land shareholders. It’s an indictment of a broader ecosystem — from brokers and analysts who cheered the rise, to regulators who moved late, to media players who repeated the trillion-peso headline without interrogating how an “empty or sparsely developed” patch of land could suddenly rival major global properties in value. To be fair, the SEC has now begun to bare its teeth. Look again at the 2024 ratios: Villar Land’s greatest vulnerability today is no longer its leverage or its liquidity — serious as those are. Its greatest vulnerability is trust: This is not just about one billionaire or one property firm. When a listed company can: It sends a chilling message: In the Philippines, paper wealth can still be conjured, traded, and celebrated long before anyone asks if it’s real. If pension funds, banks, and ordinary investors are exposed to that kind of “wealth,” they deserve to know exactly what they’re buying. They deserve a regulator that moves swiftly, an exchange that demands answers, and auditors who are empowered — and protected — when they say “no.” The Villar Land numbers you see now — shrinking revenues, collapsing liquidity, swollen liabilities, and cash payouts that exceed earnings — are not just a financial snapshot. They are evidence of how far the story was allowed to go before anyone hit the brakes. And until the market, the regulators, and the political establishment are willing to confront that uncomfortable truth, the real scandal won’t be the trillion pesos that disappeared. It will be the credibility that goes with it. – Rappler.com
label: True
title: [Vantage Point] Villar Land’s paper empire unravels

text: Once whispered about in clinics or ignored altogether, hormones are finally taking center stage in women’s wellness. From perimenopause to postmenopause, a new generation of doctors, advocates, and everyday women are breaking the silence. They are turning taboo topics into discussions about empowerment, balance, and longevity. For hundreds of years, menopause was treated as a quiet inevitability. Something that women go through, but never talked about out loud. But that narrative is changing. With new science, bioidentical hormone therapies, and holistic approaches redefining care, women are now reclaiming control of their bodies. Some experts are calling this the “second puberty” of adulthood. Menopause, coined in 1821, marks the natural end of a woman’s reproductive years, which the World Health Organization says typically occurs between ages 45 and 55 when the ovaries stop releasing eggs and menstrual periods cease for 12 consecutive months. For some, the transition happens earlier, before age 40, due to genetics, autoimmune conditions, or medical treatments such as chemotherapy, radiation, or ovarian surgery. While timing varies and cannot be precisely predicted, menopause is part of a broader biological continuum influenced by a woman’s overall health, lifestyle, and environment. Globally, women are entering this stage healthier and living longer than ever. In 2021, women aged 50 and older made up 26% of all women and girls worldwide, up from 22% a decade earlier, and a woman aged 60 in 2019 could expect to live another 21 years on average. As a result, menopause now represents not an end but a transition, one that affects physical health, emotional wellbeing, and social identity. Experts say it’s a crucial moment to reassess lifestyle and health priorities, paving the way for a new era of proactive, informed, and empowered aging. As conversations around menopause become more open and women continue to seek answers and support, so does the need for dedicated wellness centers and specialists who can guide them through this life stage with care, science, and empathy. “Back in the 1980s and 1990s, hormone therapy had a bad reputation,” said Dr. Candy Drilon-Dalman, a Functional and Integrative Medicine physician who bridges modern science with traditional healing. As co-founder and medical director of Centro Holistico, a wellness center that blends Eastern and Western practices, she focuses on addressing the root causes of chronic disease through personalized care that combines nutrition, lifestyle changes, and acupuncture. “But now, thanks to research and technology, we have bioidentical hormones, plant-based and molecularly identical to what our bodies naturally produce,” Drilon-Dalman said, explaining that unlike synthetic hormones, which can cause side effects and liver strain, bioidentical hormone replacement therapy (BHRT) integrates seamlessly into the body’s system. “It’s not about reversing time,” she emphasized. “It’s about restoring balance.” Drilon-Dalman was one of the experts who spoke with the women who gathered one Tuesday morning late October at Culture Salon MNL in Global City, Taguig, to talk about hormones, hot flashes, brain fog, and “menopause rage,” among many others. She was joined by Dr. Venisse Valdez, medical consultant at Centro Holistico and CEO of ASL Pharma Philippines, and Claudine Viquiera, ProAge CEO and certified menopause coach. The event was hosted by Michelle Aventajado. Hormones are “messengers,” according to Valdez. “When one signal goes off, like estrogen, progesterone, thyroid, cortisol, the whole system feels it.” Valdez explained that each woman’s hormonal landscape is unique, which is why Centro Holistico uses personalized testing, lifestyle mapping, and holistic therapies to design treatment plans. “You don’t just walk in and get a prescription,” she said. “We talk about your sleep, stress, diet, even your relationships. The goal is to help you live in sync with your hormones.” With as many as 48 recognized symptoms, ranging from insomnia and anxiety to weight gain and loss of libido, Viquiera said it’s not a surprise that women are seeking more holistic, science-backed ways to navigate this chapter. According to her, they’re lifelines for women who simply want to “feel like themselves again.” For many women, perimenopause remains uncharted territory. “When I first started having symptoms, I thought I was too young,” said Viquiera. “But I’ve seen women in their 30s going through the same thing.” Viquiera described how the uncertainty pushed her to research, then advocate. Her ProAge community challenges the notion that women must fight aging. “I was tired of everything being labeled ‘anti-aging.’ Aging is natural, we just need to age well.” She recalled her “aha moment” when she realized she wasn’t “crazy,” just hormonal. “I’d have rage outbursts, anxiety, brain fog, things I couldn’t explain. But once I understood it was perimenopause, everything clicked. I started keeping a journal, tracking sleep, mood, diet, and it changed how I approached my health.” Her advice? “Keep notes. Know your body. Information is power.” The doctors agree that testing is key, but it’s not one-size-fits-all. “We start with baseline hormone tests,” Drilon-Dalman explained. “If you’re on BHRT, we retest after four to five weeks to see how your body responds. For others, every three to six months is enough.” For menstruating women, day 21 of the cycle is the ideal testing window, when both progesterone and estrogen peak. For fertility monitoring, testing on days 5, 14, and 21 helps track hormonal fluctuations. But numbers aren’t everything. “We don’t just look at lab results,” Valdez said. “We ask: are you sleeping better? Do you have more energy? Are your moods stabilizing? Your body’s feedback matters as much as your labs.” That feedback loop, Drilon-Dalman said, becomes the foundation for holistic care, where healing isn’t just medical, but emotional and behavioral. Beyond hormones, the conversation shifted to what Drilon-Dalman calls “low-tox living.” “We’re exposed to so many environmental toxins, from food additives to hair colorants,” she said. “That’s why we partnered with Culture Salon, to offer plant-based beauty options that don’t overload the liver.” Detoxification, she explained, isn’t just about a juice cleanse. It’s about supporting the liver, the body’s main detox organ, so it can process used hormones efficiently. “If your liver’s sluggish, you get estrogen buildup, leading to mood swings, bloating, or heavy periods.” Viquiera echoed this, stressing that “health is a mindfulness practice.” Even self-care rituals matter. “Skincare isn’t just superficial,” she said. “It’s grounding. When you take time to care for your skin, you’re also caring for your mind.” Her brand ProAge, made in Korea, focuses on hydration with seven types of hyaluronic acid, a formulation she insisted on developing for menopausal skin. “We’re the forgotten market,” she said. “Brands cater to 20-somethings, but our needs are different. Self-care is self-respect.” As women rethink menopause, another conversation is quietly unfolding: the hormonal link between mothers and daughters. The experts said today’s girls are entering puberty earlier than ever, raising new questions about how lifestyle and environment shape women’s health across generations. “Yes, puberty is happening earlier,” Drilon-Dalman confirmed. “We’re seeing estrogen dominance in young girls, not because they produce more, but because their bodies can’t detoxify properly.” The culprits: processed foods, dairy, sugar, and lack of sleep. Her advice? “Support their liver early, through natural detoxifiers like chlorella, whole foods, and daily bowel movement. It makes a huge difference.” Valdez added that “detox and stress management” are as important for teens as for menopausal women. “Puberty and menopause are both hormonal transitions. When moms and daughters go through them at the same time, it’s literally a clash of hormones.” For many women, the mention of hormone therapy still raises fears. That’s because early studies in the 1990s linked hormone replacement therapy to cancer, Drilon-Dalman explained. But those trials used synthetic estrogen, not the bioidentical hormones now available. “Bioidentical hormones are derived from natural plant sources like soy or yams,” she said. “They’re molecularly identical to what our bodies make. Synthetic hormones, on the other hand, don’t fit the receptors perfectly, that’s why some women experience liver strain or side effects.” Modern BHRT, she added, can even protect against cardiovascular disease, osteoporosis, and cognitive decline. “We’re learning that estrogen isn’t just about reproduction — it supports the brain, bones, and skin. Testosterone helps preserve muscle and mood. These hormones are essential for long-term health.” Beyond hormone therapy, Centro Holistico also runs Biovitalis, a longevity clinic offering peptide therapy, stem cell therapy, and exosome therapy, advanced treatments that aim to rejuvenate cells and restore balance. “Some patients in their 40s still want to conceive,” Drilon-Dalman said. “While we can’t stop menopause, we can support fertility through regenerative medicine.” Stem cells, she explained, can be derived from the patient’s own fat tissue or screened donor umbilical cords. “It’s about regeneration, helping your body repair itself.” But she clarified that “these are just tools, not miracles.” The foundation will always be sleep, nutrition, stress management, and hormone balance. Hormonal changes during menopause can leave the skin feeling drier, thinner, or more sensitive, but the right routine can help bring back its natural glow and resilience. Here’s what the ProAge CEO recommends: Swiss brand Instytutum also offers precise and results-driven approach to skincare, with 18 multifunctional products that combine actives like Vitamin C THD, AHA/BHA acids, and advanced retinoids to rejuvenate, hydrate, and protect skin at every stage of life. Founded in 2014 by Dr. Natalia Bobok, MD, PhD, the Swiss beauty firm focuses on extending the skin’s active vitality rather than simply “fighting aging.” Apply products from lightest to richest texture, allowing each layer to absorb fully for optimal results. (The tips below are not a substitute for professional medical advice). – Rappler.com Jinji Abaño is a business writer and a lover of the arts. When she is not monitoring the stock market or covering summits, she reads, attends ballet classes or practices some of her old piano pieces.
label: True
title: Redefining menopause: How women are changing the conversation

text: SEOUL, South Korea – South Korea’s parliament has passed a bill to legalize tattoo artists, ending a decades-long ban on tattooing by those without medical licenses. The Tattoist Act passed convincingly on Thursday afternoon with 195 votes in favor out of 202 members present, enabling non-medical professionals to obtain a license. The new law will take effect after a two-year grace period. South Korea is the only developed country where tattooing is considered a procedure that only medical professionals are capable of legally performing. While tattoos are not illegal, tattoo artists face fines of up to 50 million won ($35,464) as well as prison terms for practicing their craft. Despite the ban, Korean tattoos have become increasingly popular at home and abroad, making it easy to spot people on the streets of Korean cities with tattoos including K-pop stars.
