Tattoo artists welcomed the act’s passage after years fighting to end the ban. “Tattooists in Korea, each working in their own spaces, overcame the isolating nature of our profession and built a solidarity of 1,100 members,” said Doy, a famous South Korean famous tattoo artist and union organizer who has been prosecuted and fined for practicing his profession. “In doing so, we ourselves changed the injustice that had long denied our profession.” President Lee Jae Myung, who has supported legalizing tattoists, is expected to sign it into a law. ($1 = 1,409.8700 won). – Rappler.com
label: True
title: South Korea passes landmark bill to legalize tattoo artists

text: MANILA, Philippines – For the third straight year, it’s in the Philippines’ property sector where Filipino woman leadership in business has been recognized by Forbes Asia, a publication that chronicles entrepreneurial success and economic growth in the region. Mybelle Aragon-Gobio, 52, the first woman to head the Gokongwei family’s property conglomerate, Robinsons Land Corporation (RLC), and Mariana Zobel de Ayala, chair and president of Ayalaland Malls Incorporated, are the two Filipino women on the publication’s 2025 list of “power businesswomen” in Asia. The list, Forbes Asia said, recognizes “20 accomplished leaders who are at the forefront of the region’s fast-evolving business and economic landscape.” Forbes Asia noted that Aragon-Gobio is also the first non-Gokongwei family member to head the firm founded by the late John Gokongwei. She succeeded the patriarch’s only son, Lance Gokongwei, as head of RLC. (READ: Why John Gokongwei donated billions to education) She rose from the ranks and has been with RLC for over 26 years. She has a Bachelor of Science in Management Engineering degree from Ateneo de Manila University (ADMU), and a minor in International Business from the University of Antwerp in Belgium. RLC’s “Vision 5-25-30” roadmap adopts 5 strategies that the company hopes will deliver P25 billion in net income by RLC’s 50th anniversary in 2030. (Roadmap to 2030: Robinsons Land to build 12 new malls in next 5 years) Zobel de Ayala, 37, daughter of Ayala Corporation chairman Jaime Augusto Zobel de Ayala, is an “eighth-generation heiress… shaping the future” of the legacy Philippine company, Forbes Asia said. She is the second youngest businesswoman in Forbes Asia‘s 2025 list next to Manasi Kirloskar Tata, 36, vice chairperson of Toyota Kirloskar Motor in India. Mariana heads Ayala Land Incorporated (ALI) leasing and hospitality group, overseeing Ayala Malls, Ayala Land Offices, Ayala Land Hospitality, and Ayala Land Leisure Estates. “In March [2025], Mariana was appointed Ayala Corp.’s managing director, 12 years after she left her job as an investment analyst at JPMorgan in New York to join her family’s 191-year-old, banking-to-property group,” Forbes Asia said. She has a Bachelor of Arts in Social Studies (Philosophy, Politics, and Economics) from Harvard College (part of Harvard University), in Cambridge, Massachusetts, USA. She also has a Master of Business Administration (MBA) from the business school INSEAD. “The roll call of trailblazers, hailing from a dozen countries and territories, includes those playing key roles in powering the AI and advanced tech boom by heading up companies in sectors such as data centers, semiconductors and rare earths. Others are remaking family legacies, taking charge at storied enterprises in property, hospitality, retail and sports gear as they steer them toward new growth,” said Forbes Asia. In 2024, it was Lourdes Gutierrez-Alfonso, president of tycoon Andrew Tan’s property conglomerate, Megaworld, who made it to Forbes Asia’s Power Businesswomen list. She was the only Filipino on the list. She has a Bachelor of Science major in Accounting degree from the Far Eastern University (FEU) where she graduated cum laude. In 2023, Forbes Asia recognized Anna Ma. Margarita Dy, president and CEO of Ayala Land. She was also the only Filipino on the list. Dy is the first woman Chief Executive Officer (CEO) of Ayala Land. Dy, who started her career in IBM, Bain, and Benpres Holdings, has a Bachelor of Arts in Economics from Ateneo de Manila University, a Master of Science in Economics from the London School of Economics, and an MBA from Harvard Business School. In 2022, there was no Filipino on Forbes Asia’s Power Businesswoman list. Filipino businesswomen in the fields of telecommunications and in manufacturing were recognized by Forbes Asia during the pandemic years of 2020 and 2021. In 2021, it was Grace Uy, co-founder and president of telco Converge ICT Solutions, who made it to the list. Uy, a certified public accountant, cofounded Converge in 2007 with her husband Dennis Anthony Uy, the company’s CEO. In 2020, Forbes Asia picked Olivia Limpe-Aw, chairman and CEO of Destileria Limtuaco. She was the only Filipino on the list that year. She has a Bachelor of Science in Business/Managerial Economics from the the University of the Philippines. Destileria Limtuaco, with more than 40 different products, is the Philippines’ oldest distillery. The 18 other women on Forbes Asia‘s Power Businesswomen 2025 list are: – Rappler.com
label: True
title: Two Filipinos make it to Forbes Asia Power Businesswomen 2025 list

text: SAN FRANCISCO, USA – Amazon is planning to cut as many as 30,000 corporate jobs beginning on Tuesday, October 28, as the company pares expenses and compensates for overhiring during the peak demand of the pandemic, according to three people familiar with the matter. The figure represents a small percentage of Amazon’s 1.55 million total employees, but nearly 10% of its roughly 350,000 corporate employees. This would mark Amazon’s largest job cut since late 2022, when it started to eliminate around 27,000 positions. An Amazon spokesperson declined to comment. Amazon has been trimming smaller numbers of jobs over the past two years across multiple divisions, including devices, communications and podcasting. The cuts beginning this week may affect a variety of divisions, including human resources, known as People Experience and Technology or PXT; operations, devices and services; and Amazon Web Services, the people said. Managers of impacted teams were asked to undergo training on Monday for how to communicate with staff following email notifications that will start going out on Tuesday morning, the people said. Amazon CEO Andy Jassy is undertaking an initiative to reduce what he has described as an excess of bureaucracy, including by reducing the number of managers. He installed an anonymous complaint line for identifying inefficiencies that has elicited some 1,500 responses and over 450 process changes, he said earlier this year. Jassy said in June that the increased use of artificial intelligence tools would likely lead to further job cuts, particularly through automating repetitive and routine tasks. “This latest move signals that Amazon is likely realizing enough AI-driven productivity gains within corporate teams to support a substantial reduction in force,” said Sky Canaves, an eMarketer analyst. “Amazon has also been under pressure in the short-term to offset the long-term investments in building out its AI infrastructure.” The full scope of this round of job cuts was not immediately clear. The people familiar with the matter said the number could change over time as Amazon’s financial priorities shift. Fortune earlier reported that the human resources division could be targeted with a cut of roughly 15%. A program begun early this year to bring employees back in the office five days per week, among tech’s most stringent, has failed to generate sufficient attrition, said two of the people, citing that as another reason for the size of the layoff. Some of the employees who are not swiping in daily because they live far from corporate offices, or for other reasons, are being told they have voluntarily quit Amazon and must leave without severance, a savings for the company. Layoffs.fyi, a website tracking tech job cuts, estimated that about 98,000 jobs have been lost so far this year among 216 companies. For all of 2024, the figure was 153,000. Amazon’s largest profit center, cloud computing unit AWS, reported second-quarter sales of $30.9 billion, a 17.5% increase that was well below gains of 39% for Microsoft’s Azure and of 32% for Alphabet’s Google Cloud. Estimates indicate that AWS will have boosted third-quarter sales by about 18% to $32 billion, a slight slowdown from last year’s 19% increase. AWS is still reeling from a roughly 15-hour internet outage last week that felled many of the most popular online services, like Snapchat SNAP.N and Venmo. Amazon appears to be expecting another big holiday selling season. It plans to offer 250,000 seasonal jobs to help staff warehouses, among other needs, the same as in the prior two years. Amazon on Friday also announced a reorganization of a segment of its PXT unit focused on diversity initiatives, a memo reviewed by Reuters showed. The changes largely involved promoting people to new roles. Amazon shares rose 1.2% to $226.97 on Monday. The company plans to report third-quarter earnings on Thursday. – Rappler.com
label: True
title: Amazon targets as many as 30,000 corporate job cuts, sources say

text: MANILA, Philippines – Even at a young age, kids are already learning how to communicate with others and recognize emotions — from their own facial expressions to those of the people they’re talking to, whether fellow children or adults. As they grow and engage with their environment, it helps to start early conversations about emotions and mental health. Sometimes, it can be as simple as introducing them to animated films and storybooks that talk about feelings and emotions. Through stories told from a child’s perspective, they can see that it’s okay to feel excited, sad, anxious, or angry. This list of books, films, and series teaches the youth that it’s totally normal to feel different emotions, and that acknowledging these feelings is a step toward better mental health and empathy for others. Adarna House’s Emotions Picture Book series brings a Filipino touch to emotional learning. Each title helps readers name and identify emotions like hiya (shyness), inip (boredom), sabik (excitement), kilig, gigil (cute aggression), sungit (grumpy), and pikon (short-tempered). These books easily capture a kid’s attention since, even before opening the pages, emotions are already illustrated on their expressive covers. Written and illustrated by local talents such as Beth Parrocha (Sabik), Jamie Bauza (Gigil), and Pergy Acuña (Kilig), each story allows children to explore not just the feeling itself but also how to respond to it. Through this collection, simply knowing what an emotion looks like is one easy way to understand it. Written by Jocelyn Francisco and illustrated by Clarissa Tong, Damdaman: Feelings in Filipino is a creative way to connect emotions with nature. The title combines the Filipino terms damdam (feelings) and halaman (plants), creating a garden of emotions — from sadness and happiness to hunger and sleepiness. Inspired by the makahiya, a plant that gets shy when touched, this book sends a message to children that they are free to react whenever they feel overwhelmed. Damdaman also serves as a reminder that even nature feels, just like we humans do. A bilingual children’s book written in Filipino and English, Ang Mga Alon sa Amin offers comfort to youth who have experienced fear or loss. Written by Rainey Dolarte, it tells a story of courage, healing, and growth through Mario, a Tagbanua boy from Palawan whose community was heavily affected by Super Typhoon Yolanda (Haiyan) in 2013. Apart from its storyline, the book also features expressive art activities that allow parents to encourage their kids to talk about their emotions and learn healthy ways to cope with stress. Written by Palanca hall of famer Eugene Evasco, the classic storybook Federico features the story of a child with Down syndrome, seen through the eyes of his friend Buboy. Its touching narrative serves as a reminder to young readers that mental health and emotional understanding begin with empathy. Through Federico’s story, it can be understood that every child feels, thinks, and expresses themselves differently — and that strength can come from sensitivity and kindness. Pixar’s Inside Out film remains a valuable film for teaching kids about emotions. Through the story of an 11-year-old girl named Riley, emotions named Joy, Sadness, Anger, Fear, and Disgust are introduced. The film guides young viewers to understand the purpose of every emotion. Nearly a decade later, its sequel Inside Out 2 introduced new characters: Anxiety, Ennui, Embarrassment, and Envy, along with Nostalgia’s brief cameos. These new feelings perfectly capture the adolescent phase of Riley, full of mixed and unfamiliar emotions for young people. Disney’s Encanto film tells the story of the magical Familia Madrigal, where every family member is gifted but not without hidden personal struggles. Apart from its songs and colorful animation, Encanto‘s story makes it a must-watch as it explores generational trauma, people-pleasing, and the journey toward healing unspoken pain. For many children (and even adults), the film serves as a reminder that even the strongest families must learn to talk about their feelings, especially about what hurts them. Turning Red follows the story of a 13-year-old who turns into a giant red panda whenever she experiences overflowing emotions. While Turning Red is light, heartwarming, and fun, the film captures the chaos of puberty, self-discovery, and the challenges of managing relationships. It also shows that change — even the messy kind — is a natural part of growing up. The Emmy Kids Award-winning animated series Bluey has become a favorite among young fans not just because of its fun and adorable dog characters, Bluey and Bingo, but also for its genuine portrayal of childhood and parenthood. With three successful seasons, each episode of Bluey addresses emotions such as anxiety or disappointment through relatable everyday situations. Netflix’s Hilda is a melancholic series that deals with emotional maturity. As Hilda navigates her whimsical world, viewers are introduced to themes of loneliness, curiosity, and courage. This series unpacks the natural capacity of its young audiences to feel deeply and think critically about their emotions. From the educational cartoon channel Lingokids, Baby Bots Backyard Tales turns short episodes into life lessons. Each video helps children explore common feelings like loneliness, nervousness, and anger — even teaching them how to say “no.” In just a few minutes per episode, young audiences learn emotional lessons in a fun and engaging way. – Rappler.com Alessandria Corral is a Rappler intern studying Bachelor of Arts in Speech Communication at University of the Philippines Diliman.
label: True
title: LIST: Books, films, series that teach children about emotions and mental health

text: Those who meet him for the first time may find Ron Magsakay as someone full of surprises. Others may be confused by his constant sunny demeanor. Those who realize what Ron has been through get puzzled. This jumble of reactions is understandable. Ron’s trademark is his humor. He is fond of telling comical anecdotes with himself as butt of his own jokes. When he debuted recently as a public speaker, Ron warmed up his audience with his signature self-deprecating approach. Minutes into his maiden facilitation of the session on “care for one’s well-being,” he dropped, so to speak, “the punchline.” He presented in his slideshow a photo of the Magsakay family snapped most likely at Mines View Park in Baguio City. In the picture was a teenaged Ron — then called Ron-ron — his father, mother, and younger sister and brother. Then he told those present that, months later, on April 28, 1986, everyone in that photo, except for Ron, died in a car accident. Editor’s Note: We earlier reported that Ron Magsakay was 12 when he lost his family. This has been corrected. All of a sudden, Ron Magsakay’s family was wiped out. He became an orphan and lost all his siblings at 16 years old. The tragedy happened on a highway in Pozorrubio town, Pangasinan, as the Magsakay family was again on a trip to Baguio. Aside from Ron, a cousin who joined the family, survived the accident. “I lost my family, entirely and immediately,” he said. It was in 2022 when Ron first went upfront with “the punchline” of his life when he self-published his autobiography I Got Humor. COVID was still raging when he launched in a hybrid event the book, or what he now calls the “written” I Got Humor. The book is a collection of his journal entries, recalling and reflecting the peaks and valleys of his life. It unravels his resilience in probably the most difficult of adversities. He took to journaling after it was recommended as part of the healing process of his mental health challenges. Ever since that unspeakable tragedy, Ron has gone through and has overcome a bevy of psychological issues. Along the way, though, he has still managed to succeed as an entrepreneur, and raise a family of his own. His latest malady surfaced in 2020 and was assessed as post-traumatic stress disorder (PTSD). The site mayoclinic.org defines PTSD as “a mental health condition that’s caused by an extremely stressful or terrifying event — either being part of it or witnessing it. Symptoms may include flashbacks, nightmares, severe anxiety and uncontrollable thoughts about the event.” Magsakay said: “PTSD took a heavy toll on me because I could not sleep. If I do not take medication I have difficulty sleeping. The mental effect of PTSD of 2020 was worse than what I went through in 1986 (after the accident). In 1986, someone told me I survived because I had a mission.” He recalled that the PTSD first manifested during a panic attack he experienced on the day of his 51st birthday while driving at the North Luzon Expressway. The panic attack was just the beginning and it took a turn for the worse in the succeeding days. It developed into what professionals told him was “catastrophic anxiety.” Throughout his journey, Ron acknowledged what helped him prevail over his tribulations was the steady stream of emotional support. It was also crucial that he acknowledged he had problems, needed help, and heeded their advice. Ron has emerged as a “mental health advocate.” From the perspective of an outsider, Ron does seem fit to this role, after all he made it through going to hell and back. Last July, he facilitated a session on “Happy Teams, Happy Results: Taking Care of Employees’ Well-being.” He likens this development to a “spoken” edition of I Got Humor. People will attend his talk sessions for the same reason they will pick up and read his book. You are reeled in by the “humor” in a package which promises to give advice on building “happy teams” and getting “healthy results.” From someone with the surname Magsakay, which in Filipino translates to a ride or a trip, Ron delivers in his mentoring sessions bits of advice he himself has collected along his journey. It’s surprising that for what Ron has been through and still witnessing what is no doubt a dark life episode, his book and his workshop will uplift you. He is a humorist, and he admits that he watches videos of stand-up comics to pick up a thing or two from them. But he wields an advantage over most speakers on the topic of mental health — he actually is in the trenches of the toughest of times. In a way, Ron’s ongoing journey is what the German philosopher Friedrich Nietzsche described in his autobiography Ecce Homo. Nietzsche said persons like Ron are “nature’s lucky strokes…among men.” The German philosopher said this person “divines remedies for injuries; he knows how to turn serious accidents to his own advantage; that which does not kill him makes him stronger.” These days, Ron draws strength from his immediate family. His wife Cathy, their children Jamie, Digna and her husband Rennier, and the youngest member, grandchild Amiera. In Ron’s book and in his talks, the car accident in 1986 is just a starter, but not the whole story. His fight against adversity, and becoming an inspiration, is the story. – Rappler.com Note: To help him deal with his mental issues, among the groups where Ron Magsakay turned to was the Ruben M. Tanseco, S.J. Center for Family Ministries (RMT-CEFAM).
label: True
title: Ron Magsakay survived a tragedy — now he provides inspiration through humor

text: MANILA, Philippines – Unemployment eased in August as jobs affected by severe weather in July made a comeback, the Philippine Statistics Authority reported on Wednesday, October 8. The country’s unemployment rate fell to 3.9% in August from a three-year high of 5.3% in July. The latest unemployment figure translates to 2.03 million jobless Filipinos. Meanwhile, the number of underemployed individuals or those seeking additional jobs or working hours decreased to 5.38 million Filipinos, equivalent to a rate of 10.7%. This is significantly lower than the 14.8% recorded in July, which translated to 6.8 million underemployed Filipinos, and the 11.2% or 5.48 million logged in August 2024. National Statistician Dennis Mapa attributed the improvement to the revival of weather-sensitive jobs that were previously lost due to tropical cyclones that hit the country. “The job losses in July, particularly in agriculture, retail trade, and construction, have now returned. The job losses in July were temporary,” Mapa said in Filipino. Construction followed by fishing and aquaculture were the major industries with the highest annual increases in employment. Construction saw a major rebound as it added 540,000 jobs in August, a reversal from losing 147,000 jobs in July. The fishing and aquaculture sector, which lost 173,000 jobs in July, recorded the second highest annual increase in August with 448,000 new jobs. Meanwhile, wholesale and retail trade still had the highest annual drop for August, as it lost 788,000 jobs. Despite improved weather conditions in August, Mapa said some sectors are still recovering from the aftermath of the July tropical cyclones. He added that certain groups of workers find it difficult to go back to their regular jobs, especially those directly impacted by weather disturbances. “In a way, we need to weather-proof these weather-sensitive groups since they may permanently or temporarily leave these sectors during [the rainy] season,” said Mapa. He also noted that tropical cyclones in September and the recent Cebu earthquake may affect the unemployment rates for September and October. “These are some of the threats brought about by the September weather conditions, which are similar to those in July. These are the risks that can affect certain subsectors, particularly agriculture, retail trade, and construction,” Mapa said in Filipino. Department of Labor and Employment (DOLE) Secretary Bienvenido Laguesma welcomed the August jobs data, describing the labor market’s performance as “impressive.” He also vowed to continue scaling up employment and internship programs for the youth. “DOLE will remain steadfast in its commitment to efficient, honest, and transparent public service in the implementation of our programs, projects, and activities,” Laguesma wrote in a statement. The Department of Economy, Planning, and Development (DEPDev), for its part, said that the latest labor market data shows the government’s commitment to sustained economic growth that can be felt by Filipinos. “As industries evolve, we must ensure that our workers are equipped with the competencies required in new and emerging sectors — so that no Filipino is left behind in our country’s development journey,” said DEPDev Secretary Arsenio Balisacan. – Arriane dela Cruz, with reports from Tatiana Maligro/Rappler.com Arriane dela Cruz is a Rappler intern. Learn more about Rappler’s internship program here.
label: True
title: Unemployment eases to 3.9% in August 2025 as construction, fishing jobs rebound

text: MANILA, Philippines — Nearly four years after IKEA opened in Pasay City the world’s biggest IKEA branch, the Swedish home furnishing brand cemented its presence in the northern part of Metro Manila, with a new concept shop now open in TriNoma Mall, Quezon City. IKEA and Ayala Malls collaborated to bring the first-ever “Plan and Order Shop” to the country, just six months after the two teams’ first meeting. More than a place to shop for homeware and furniture, the smaller Quezon City branch also has a new planning studio. This allows customers to consult with planning specialists on how to arrange their homes with the right furniture and home decor pieces, even if it’s a tight-knit space. Customization is at the center of this new home improvement experience. “[The Plan and Order Shop] is a quite brand new concept for IKEA in our retail operation. It’s a way to bring our range closer to the many Filipinos,” said IKEA Philippines country retail manager Ricardo Pinheiro at the branch opening on October 23, Thursday. Apart from accessibility to different sectors with its free planning service, Swedish Ambassador-Designate Anna Ferry also emphasized the store’s display of the core values that IKEA and Sweden stand for. “Most importantly, [IKEA promotes a] business sector [that] is ethically sustainable, oriented with people and the planet in mind,” she said. Ferry highlighted the trust and belief IKEA has in the Philippines, as seen in its willingness to invest and expand stores in the country through the opening of the Plan and Order Shop. Also present at the branch opening, Quezon City Mayor Joy Belmonte pointed out the opportunities for the new IKEA branch with its strategic location in the northern part of the capital region. “[Quezon City is] the largest city in the Philippines with a population of 3.2 million. As said earlier, all of [IKEA’s] customers, or many of [IKEA’s] customers in Pasay are actually from [here],” she said. She added the advantage of the branch’s location at the center of other big local government units. With the city recently being recognized as the Hall of Fame Awardee for being one of the most business-friendly LGUs in the country, the IKEA branch is further proof of the LGU’s move towards growth in the business sector. Belmonte also acknowledged the Ayala Corporation, which she says has been a “close partner of the local government of Quezon City” and has ensured continuous progress in Quezon City. Mariana Zobel de Ayala, currently head of the Leasing and Hospitality Group of Ayala, shared that TriNoma was a mall intentionally built for the city and its people. “We really wanted to serve the dynamic and incredible, and large community that’s here in Quezon City,” she said. With the Plan and Order shop’s location, its services have become within reach of Quezon City’s diverse population living in condos, townhouses, and smaller houses. Zobel de Ayala emphasized that the partnership with IKEA is more than just a business expansion. Beyond offering accessibility to Quezon City and northern residents, she said that the Plan and Order Shop format aligns with IKEA’s vision of inclusive and customer-centric spaces that “elevate everyday life.” “Over the past year, we’ve been looking to move with purpose. [We] reimagine our goals beyond just commercial centers, but really, as the vibrant and future-ready destinations that will continue to inspire, to push, and to engage all of the communities that we serve.” Housing IKEA’s second branch is only one of the steps the Ayala Group is taking towards transforming TriNoma into a space that addresses the lifestyle and needs of its community. – Alyana Fabella/Rappler.com Alyana Fabella is a Rappler intern studying Bachelor of Arts in Communication at the Ateneo de Manila University.
label: True
title: What IKEA’s new TriNoma branch means for QC’s bustling business scene

text: LAOAG CITY, Ilocos Norte – Traditional handloom weaving in the Philippines is in decline due to the rise of modern garment technology. However, weavers from Luzon to Mindanao continue to fight for the survival and continued recognition of their cultural heritage. Based on estimated data, there are over 5,200 weavers from 481 weaving communities in the country. The survival of traditional handloom weaving, passed down through generations, depends on these communities and the people who continue to patronize their work. Five weavers from Luzon, Visayas, and Mindanao share their stories and the significance of their traditions to their lives. Florence Amily Ao-wat, 66, of Kinwa Etnika Handicrafts in Tabuk City, Kalinga, began learning backstrap weaving at 15. After completing an accountancy degree in Baguio City and starting her career, she returned home and noticed that their weavers were aging, and younger people were no longer interested in continuing the craft. “The young generation does not like to weave because they are educated and they do not see the worth of our weaving tradition,” Ao-wat said in a mix of English and Filipino. Seeing this problem, Ao-wat relearned and practiced weaving, eventually organizing her siblings to form Kalinga Indigenous Weavers Association (KINWA ETNIKA), a community of weavers established with a starting capital of P2,500. Kinwa, an Ilocano term for “create,” prides itself on being an inclusive weaving community. Ao-wat gathers women weavers, persons with disabilities, and nursing mothers to help sustain their panaglaga (weaving) heritage. “Ito ay natutuhan namin sa mga ninuno, and sayang naman kung mawala ito (We learned this from our ancestors, and it would be a shame if it disappeared),” Ao-wat told Rappler. “We have 21 designs in Kalinga and they should not be lost.” To keep Kalinga weaving alive, Kinwa provides cultural immersion activities for students, helping them understand and practice their heritage. “In a year, we can train up to 50 students. Some of our products are made by Grade 12 students who come for immersion,” she said. Kinwa also encourages these students to explore their own designs under the guidance of heirloom weavers. In the Visayas, young weavers also face similar challenges. For Daisy Rose Nanas, 24, and Celestine Marie Otian, 22, of Reyden’s Hablon — cousins and fifth-generation hablon weavers in Iloilo — weaving is a legacy they learned from their mothers and grandmothers. “Importante ang paghahabi dahil nagbibigay po ito ng trabaho sa mga taong walang income at maraming opportunities para sa mga nahihirapan maghanap ng trabaho,” Nanas told Rappler. (Weaving is important because it provides work for those without income and offers many opportunities for people who struggle to find jobs.) “[At saka] importante na matutunan ng mga kabataan ang paghabi dahil inumpisahan po ito ng ating mga ninuno, kaya kailangan po nating ipagpatuloy,” she added. (It is also important for the youth to learn weaving because our ancestors started it, and we need to continue it.) Otian echoed this sentiment, saying that many youth in Iloilo also show little interest in hablon weaving. “Walang ibang magpapasa ng kultura kundi tayo. Para ma-enhance ang tradition natin, to support local, and to earn an income,” Otian told Rappler. (No one else will pass on our culture but us. This is to enhance our tradition, support local, and earn an income.) Their weaving center is one of the main suppliers of hablon fabric for the University of the Philippines’ Sablay, the university’s official academic costume. Similar to the weaving communities in Luzon and Visayas, the inaul heirloom tradition in Datu Piang, Maguindanao, is both a source of livelihood and a symbol of peace and unity. In this remote municipality, rebel returnees from previous conflicts in Maguindanao turned to inaul weaving to rebuild their lives, finding renewed purpose in the craft. Today, their descendants continue the practice, sustaining their families while keeping their cultural heritage alive, just like the weavers from the Weaving for Peace Philippines. Isnila Bensali, 42, one of the descendants, learned to weave from her mother-in-law and the women in their community. “Kaya important talaga — and [I’m] very proud — na napunta ako sa lugar nila na marunong maghabi. Kailangan ko talaga ang paghahabi. Kung wala ito, wala kaming hanapbuhay, lalo na kaming mga pamilya ng farmers,” Bensali said. (This is why it is really important — and I’m very proud — that I ended up in a place where people know how to weave. I truly need weaving; without it, we wouldn’t have a livelihood, especially us farming families.) Meanwhile, Asgar Gulam, 35, Bensali’s brother and a designer, has been weaving for 13 years, learning the craft from observing his aunties. “Maliit pa ako, hindi ko inisip na matuto ako ng ganito. Noong tinitingnan ko ang mga naghahabi, karamihan babae,” Gulam said. (I was still young and never thought I would learn something like this. When I watched the weavers, most of them were women.) By watching the women in their community weave daily, Gulam eventually learned the craft and developed his own designs. He draws inspiration from what he sees around him — flowers, heart shapes, and bamboo gates — to create unique patterns for their inaul textiles. The concerns of the five weavers were also echoed during the first-ever Philippine Handloom Weaving Festival in Ilocos Norte, home of the inabel and binakol textiles. To support the country’s heirloom weavers, Dr. Julius Leaño Jr., director of the Department of Science and Technology-Philippine Textile Research Institute (DOST-PTRI), urged Filipinos to stop buying fake or machine-made textiles. “Because you’re not just depriving them of their livelihood — you are depriving them of their culture. You are depriving them of their identity. And most importantly, you are depriving them of their future,” Leaño said. The DOST-PTRI also appealed to government agencies not to convert traditional textile designs into sublimation prints. “On behalf of the handloom weavers of the Philippines, we call on all of you to please refrain from transferring these beautiful patterns into very cheap printed products that you sell at very low prices,” he added. Leaño emphasized that heirloom fabrics are chronicles of the lives and dreams of various weaving communities. Ao-wat, Nanas, Otian, Bensali, and Gulam were among the 120 weavers from the 40 weaving communities who participated in the first Philippine Handloom Weaving Festival at the home of Gawad ng Manlilikha ng Bayan awardee Magdalena Gamayo, held from November 19 to 22. The event also introduced SalinHabi, a digital platform designed to preserve local textiles by showcasing woven fabrics across the country. The pre-launch of the Regional Yarn Production and Innovation Center in Ilocos Norte, a micro-scale yarn spinning facility converting abaca, banana, pineapple leaf, cotton, bamboo, and other natural fibers into threads, was also held during the festival. The festival also included a textile exchange, forums, a weaving technology demonstration, workshops, and exhibits. “[Events like this] help us in the promotion of our product and the selling, to be exposed, and to let the government know there are people who are working in the industry, and who are helping the people in our community employed by means of weaving,” Ao-wat told Rappler. For the five weavers, keeping their tradition alive means teaching their communities, passing the craft down to their families, promoting peace, and receiving stronger support through opportunities to market their products, as only with shared effort can their traditions continue to thrive in the generations to come. – Rappler.com
label: True
title: How loomweavers from Luzon to Mindanao keep their traditions alive

text: “The power to tax is the power to destroy.” In history, it was also the power to destroy corruption. The downfall of Al Capone, one of America’s most infamous gangsters, is the clearest example. Despite evidence of murders and racketeering, what finally put him in prison was tax evasion. In 1931, Al Capone was convicted for failing to pay taxes on his lavish, illegal income and sentenced to 11 years in prison. His case proved one thing: when all else fails, follow the money. This principle has been applied globally. In Italy, mafia bosses were brought down through tax audits and asset seizures. In Brazil, “Operation Car Wash” exposed a web of corruption worth over $5 billion, leading to hundreds of convictions. In South Korea, two former presidents were jailed for corruption and tax-related crimes tied to family conglomerates. Around the world, tax enforcement has proven to be the sharpest tool against corruption. In the Philippines, corruption drains ₱700 billion to ₱1.3 trillion annually (equivalent to 20% of the national budget, based on assessments cited by multilateral institutions such as the World Bank, the International Monetary Fund (IMF), and the Asian Development Bank (ADB). From ghost projects and padded contracts to the misuse of confidential funds, taxpayers’ money is diverted to the private luxuries of the powerful. Political dynasties and their favored contractors thrive through joint ventures and undue influence, enriching themselves while ordinary Filipinos struggle. Meanwhile, social media flaunts their ill-gotten wealth — luxury cars, designer bags, million-peso lifestyles — far beyond what their declared incomes can justify. This is not just immoral. Under Philippine law, it is tax evasion, punishable by imprisonment, fines, and perpetual disqualification from public office. Transparency International’s 2024 Corruption Perceptions Index (CPI) ranks the Philippines 114th out of 180 countries, behind peers in ASEAN like Malaysia (57th) and Vietnam (88th). Weak enforcement not only embarrasses the country globally, but it also undermines democracy at home. Corruption is more than theft — it is a failure in governance. It undermines the law, weakens democratic institutions, and erodes the moral foundation of society. If taxpayers see the corrupt escape accountability, voluntary compliance collapses. If foreign investors perceive dynasties enriching themselves through public funds, confidence erodes. Corruption acts like a hidden tax on investment, discouraging FDI and weakening economic growth. The consequence is clear: less revenue for the state, fewer jobs for the people, and weaker resilience for the future. To restore trust, the Bureau of Internal Revenue, the Commission on Elections, and the Office of the Ombudsman must: 1. Audit confidential funds and discretionary allocations. 2. Investigate joint ventures and contractors linked to political dynasties. 3. Scrutinize campaign donors who benefit from government contracts. 4. Prosecute relentlessly — not only contractors, but politicians and families who profit from corruption. 5. Enforce perpetual disqualification for convicted officials to end dynastic abuse. This is not just about punishing crimes. It is about spending taxes judiciously — not for the lavish lifestyles of the few, but for the urgent needs of the many: In my book, Reimagining the World Without Corruption, launched at Harvard Kennedy School, I argue that corruption is not only a political failure but an economic trap. It erodes public trust, deters investments, and worsens inequality. To break free, we must ensure that every peso collected serves the people — not political dynasties. A post shared by CSR Philippines (@csrphilippines) The global message is clear: Countries that hold the powerful accountable attract more investment and build stronger democracies. For the Philippines, the path forward is equally clear: follow the money, prosecute the guilty, and rebuild trust in governance. Your taxes must build schools and hospitals, not bankroll luxury bags and mansions. No one is above the law. – Rappler.com Raymond “Mon” Abrea is the founder and chief tax advisor of the Asian Consulting Group (ACG). Known as the “Philippine Tax Whiz,” he is a Harvard-educated public policy expert, Oxford-trained in Climate Policy, and Duke-certified in Tax Policy. He is the author of the “Reimagining the World Without Corruption,” which he launched at Harvard, and has served as a tax expert resource in both the Senate and the House of Representatives, including during the Pharmally investigation.
label: True
title: [Ask the Tax Whiz] Why corruption must end where accountability begins

text: Department of Public Works and Highways (DPWH) engineers and contractors engaged in a number of infrastructure projects are the new faces of corruption in the Philippines — and deservedly so. But there’s an upside to Filipino engineers and their work. Many of our engineers have helped build solid infrastructures here and abroad. Many countries in the Middle East, in particular, have long recognized the contributions of Filipino professionals — engineers, architects, and other occupations — in building their infrastructures. For instance, in this year’s award of top engineers and architects in the Middle East 2025 by the news publication The Filipino Times, Philippine Ambassador to Oman Raul Hernandez said: “From groundbreaking designs to engineering feats that shape skylines and transform cities, their work is a source of pride for our nation, proving that Filipinos’ talent and expertise shine on the global stage.” Here in the Philippines, a number of conglomerates and their partners have put up flood control projects that highlight the good side of Philippine infrastructure. They exemplify the skills, talents, and hard work of Filipino engineers and architects, proving that under the right conditions, they do a good job. Some of these projects hit two birds with one stone: while serving its main purpose of controlling floods and saving lives and property, they double as parks that we badly need amid urbanization and climate change. Take the case of property and township builder Megaworld. Kevin Tan, executive director of Megaworld, recently uploaded a video of a flood control project in Megaworld’s 35-hectare township in San Fernando, Pampanga — the 2-hectare Rainwater Park in Capital Town. The facility can hold 3.7 million gallons of water equivalent to 6 Olympic-size swimming pools. Tan describes it as an “innovative approach that manages stormwater, protects surrounding communities, and creates a vibrant hub for leisure and tourism,” and “because of this, the area around Capital Town no longer experiences flooding.” Since its opening on May 6, 2025, the Rainwater Park, designed by landscape architect Paolo Alcazaren, has become a popular spot for recreation and community interactions, attracting around 200,000 guests monthly for Capital Town. Although the video is also meant to help sell Megaworld’s properties, it also gives a sense of hope during this time of the country’s worst corruption scandal. Similarly, the Ayala Group also recently highlighted a flood control project called the Rain Garden in its 46-hectare Vertis North property beside TriNoma in Quezon City. You can watch it in this video below: A post shared by Ayala Land (@ayalaland) Many are unaware that such a park exists given that it’s partly hidden from the busy TriNoma mall. “What looks like a peaceful green space doubles as a detention pond, designed to manage rainwater, prevent flooding, and protect the estate from erosion, all the while creating a serene view within the city,” says property developer Ayala Land in a social media post. Ayala Land had intentionally built the Rain Garden due to the flooding concerns in the area. It now also serves as a central park which people can use for exercise. Another good project that’s often been cited in light of the flood control scandal is the underground storm water reservoir beneath Burgos Circle in Forbes Town, Bonifacio Global City (BGC), Taguig. This project is a 60-meter-diameter reservoir that can hold 22,000 cubic meters of storm water, helping keep BGC flood-free. Burgos Circle is the lowest point in BGC, and the rainwater the facility collects eventually drains to Manila Bay. On top of the reservoir is a small round park with the Instagrammable The Trees sculpture by Reynato Paz Contreras. The Sy family has long been recognized for incorporating the problem of flooding in their projects. Who can forget how their SM City Marikina mall survived the catastrophic flooding caused by Tropical Storm Ondoy (Ketsana) on September 26, 2009? While half of Marikina City saw their properties ravaged by flood waters, SM Marikina stood above the disaster, becoming a symbol of disaster preparedness and scientific environmental planning. The 6-hectare SM City Marikina is built on top of stilts in an area that had been identified as high-risk to floods. Property developer SM Prime built its Marikina mall farther than the recommended 90-meter-distance from the Marikina River centerline to reduce the risk of mall damage in case of extreme floods. SM Marikina’s lower parking level has no wall enclosures, and its ground floor level was built 20.5 meters higher than the maximum flood level that had been recorded. “These features allowed water to flow freely through the parking structure while the mall area rests on the third floor lifted by the supportive stilts during extreme floods,” according to a case study on the project. The steps taken by mall developer SM Prime on SM City Marikina’s disaster resiliency resulted in avoidance of around P1 billion in losses from business sales alone during Ondoy. SM Prime says the “additional 15% in costs to build a disaster-resilient mall were more than recouped in avoided losses.” SM Prime has cited two other case studies of disaster-resilient malls: SM City Masinag in Antipolo City, Rizal province, and SM City Cabanatuan in Nueva Ecija province, both of which are in flood-prone locations. SM City Cabanatuan’s ground level parking area serves as a temporary catch basin for water that overflows from a nearby creek. The facility can hold 14 million gallons of flood water. It served its purpose during Typhoon Lando on October 18, 2015 when most of Cabanatuan City got flooded. SM Investments told Rappler that 30 of its 89 malls have rainwater catchment basins with a total capacity of 85,6010 cubic meters, equivalent to 34 Olympic size swimming pools. “These massive underground tanks, similar in size to swimming pools, collect and store rainwater from the street level, mitigating flooding in surrounding communities,” SM Supermalls said. In the case of SM City Masinag, its catchment basin collected 8,652 cubic meters of rainwater during Typhoon Carina (Gaemi) in July 2024. The town of Masinag is a flood-prone area because of the rainwater that flows toward it from upper Antipolo. SM City Masinag’s rainwater catch basin has helped solve flooding in villages such as the nearby Vermont Park Executive Village. These projects by SM Prime have been cited as models of disaster risk management in the United Nations Office for Disaster Risk Reduction ARISE Private Sector Alliance, where SM Prime’s Hans Sy has played an active role in the international board. So, why aren’t the engineering/architectural firms behind these notable flood control projects generally not involved in public works? Those in the know say the good guys don’t participate in bidding for public works projects since they’re aware they have to give bribes in order to win. Or, they know the biddings are rigged and thus don’t participate. Some of the big ones, especially the companies that are publicly listed in the Philippine Stock Exchange, don’t bother at all due to their good corporate governance principles and practices. How then should the Philippines move forward from the flood control scandal? Aside from all the steps now being taken on making the bad guys account for their misdeeds, one key reform measure that is needed but hasn’t been discussed sufficiently is how to inculcate integrity in the DPWH. The key steps needed are to professionalize the bureaucracy, institute meritocracy, remove the influence of politicians in appointments, and inculcate the value of good governance. I recently came across an article, “What is happening to our government civil engineers?” by former DPWH engineer Alvin Claridades, who related his sad encounter with an apparently corrupt former colleague in the agency. In his piece, he says: “If the government truly wishes to ‘build better,’ it must begin by rebuilding the morale, integrity, and dignity of its engineers. “Our civil engineers are not the problem; they are part of the solution. Given the right environment — one that values competence, shields integrity, and enforces accountability — they can once again become the vanguards of public trust and technical excellence. “Infrastructure is not merely about concrete and steel — it is about conscience, competence, and commitment.” This reminds me of what former finance secretary Jesus Estanislao, a strong advocate of reforms, once said, “My advocacy is good governance: corporate governance in the business sector; public governance in the government sector; family governance for families; school governance for school institutions; and personal governance for individuals. At the end of the day, it is governance at the personal level that makes a vital difference.” – Rappler.com Click below for other BizSights articles:
label: True
title: [BizSights] Not all flood control projects are bad. Here are some we can be proud of.

text: MANILA, Philippines – Business leader and former finance secretary Ramon del Rosario Jr. has put forth an important question that President Ferdinand Marcos Jr. has not yet fully addressed in connection with the flood control scandal: Why didn’t he use his veto power to stop the insertions in the “mangled” 2025 budget? On Monday, October 13, Del Rosario said in an interview on the One News business show Money Talks that Marcos cannot wash his hands of responsibility in what has been described as the worst budget in Philippine history. It saw P289 billion in net insertions by Congress in the 2025 Department of Public Works and Highways (DPWH) budget, of which only P26 billion was vetoed by Marcos. (Figures are from the People’s Budget Coalition’s analysis of the 2025 and 2026 national budgets.) “I’m sorry to say, even the President, when he said, ‘Mahiya naman kayo,’ (Shame on you), that’s a little strange for him to say because it was his budget to start with. And he should have been aware of what was going on, and he had the opportunity to veto a lot of these things,” Del Rosario said, referring to Marcos’ statements in his fourth State of the Nation Address last July. In his speech, Marcos exposed corruption in poorly done flood control projects. If he was not aware of what was going on, Del Rosario said “it should have been brought to his attention by the DBM [Department of Budget and Management] and the different department secretaries whose budgets had been mangled.” This way, Marcos “could have acted on it at least with full information,” and “if he did not have the information, his department secretaries were not doing their job,” he said. Budget Secretary Amenah Pangandaman has tried to distance herself from the mangled budget by saying she had no role in the National Expenditure Program revisions. The NEP, also called the President’s budget, is prepared by the DBM and submitted to Congress for review. Del Rosario, now a co-convenor of a multisectoral group called Roundtable for Inclusive Development, said corruption in flood control and other public works projects got bigger and bigger because of “greed” and because the checks against corruption failed. “More and more, it became a system where everyone was in on it. The way they did it was there was something for everyone: the congressmen, the senators would connive with the executive branch so that there were percentages given to everyone along the way, all the way, including the contractors. “And that’s the system that evolved, and because everyone was getting a share of it, everyone decided to be tight-lipped and it just grew and grew and grew, until it became the monster that it now is. And now everybody is saying, how did this happen? It happened because people let it happen.” The way forward, Del Rosario said, is to make sure those responsible are held accountable, especially the “big fish.” “You cannot get away with all of this and think that you can get it done by just going after district engineers…. You have to go beyond that, you’ve got to go to legislators, very senior people,” he said. Based on their conversations with people in the executive and legislative branches of government, Del Rosario said he believes “a growing number of them sincerely want to do the right thing,” although “some are in a defensive mode” because some forces are “exploiting the situation.” “But we’re being very clear about our position: stick to the Constitution, let’s not fool around with extra-constitutional ideas all over again. Let’s make our democracy work, is what we’re saying,” he said. He said the more than 20 organizations and 100 individuals in the People’s Budget Coalition, are demanding that the Marcos administration make sure that the 2026 budget is “in no way a repeat of 2025.” Based on the analysis by the People’s Budget Coalition of the 2026 budget, Del Rosario said it still had around P230 billion for pork barrel that will go to social programs that “make it sound like they’re highly needed.” He said the money should instead be allocated to the Pantawid Pamilyang Pilipino Program or 4Ps, which has very specific guidelines where beneficiaries are entitled to certain amounts based on certain school attendance and nutrition conditions. Del Rosario warned that the people’s anger will continue unless those in power “show serious intent to change things.” “I think we’ve got to wake up as a people and say we deserve better than this.” Del Rosario is chairman and CEO of conglomerate PHINMA Corporation, which is involved in education, construction, hospitality, energy, and housing. He served briefly as finance secretary from 1992 to 1993 during the Fidel Ramos administration. – Rappler.com
label: True
title: Marcos, DBM can’t wash hands of ‘mangled’ 2025 budget – ex-finance chief

text: MANILA, Philippines – The long-awaited debut of Maynilad Water Services Incorporated or Maynilad on the Philippine Stock Exchange (PSE) is finally happening. The country’s largest private water utility is gearing up for the biggest initial public offering (IPO) of the year, in a market where blockbuster listings have become few and far between. It will be the largest public offering the Philippines has seen in years, surpassed only by Monde Nissin’s record-breaking debut in 2021, the biggest IPO in the nation’s history. Maynilad supplies water and wastewater services across the West Zone of Metro Manila, which includes 11 cities and extends to several cities and municipalities in Cavite. It serves around 10.5 million people through a network of treatment plants, reservoirs, pumping stations, and pipelines. The company also operates related businesses such as waterworks engineering, treated bulk water supply, and wastewater operations outside the West Zone. To recap, an IPO is the process by which a private company offers its shares to the public for the first time. Investors can participate by subscribing to shares during the offer period. Once the shares are listed on the exchange, they can be traded like any other publicly listed stock. Maynilad’s IPO stands out not only for its scale but also for the timing and the industry that it’s in. The utility giant will be testing the waters in a sluggish market, with the PSE index hovering near multi-year lows and showing little momentum (READ: [Finterest] What does it really mean when the PSE loses value?). So far, the only other IPO this year has been that of Cebu-based fuel firm Top Line, which raised just P732 million — a far cry from the more than P34 billion Maynilad could bring in. As part of its congressional franchise, Maynilad is mandated to go public by January 2027, meaning this IPO also fulfills a regulatory obligation rather than just being a purely market-driven decision. Maynilad has priced its shares at P15 each, at the upper end of its revised range. The price was lowered from an earlier ceiling of P20 per share after consultations with cornerstone investors including the International Finance Corporation (IFC), the Asian Development Bank (ADB), and the United Kingdom’s Mobilist program. At P15 per share, the company could raise as much as P34.3 billion in gross proceeds, making it the largest IPO of the year. IFC and ADB are set to lead institutional investors with investments of over US$200 million. The IPO, originally targeted for July, will have an offer period running from October 23 to 29, and the shares are set to list and begin trading on the PSE on November 7 under the ticker symbol MYNLD. Proceeds from the IPO will fund capital expenditures and general corporate purposes, including part of Maynilad’s P163.3-billion investment plan from 2023 to 2027. The program aims to expand water and wastewater coverage, construct new treatment facilities, and upgrade its existing network. Maynilad is not a fast-moving tech company. It is a water utility with predictable revenues and heavy regulation, which makes it a classic “defensive” stock. This means its business tends to hold steady even when the broader market weakens or experiences volatility. Over the past two years, Maynilad’s financial performance has been strong. Revenue grew by about 21 percent annually in 2023 and 2024, while net income rose by an average of 47 percent. Its concession agreement with the government runs until 2047, ensuring a long horizon for growth and stability. Maynilad is best suited for investors who want stable returns and can stay invested for the long term rather than those hoping to profit quickly. Still, remember that steady performance does not mean zero risk. Utilities are subject to government regulation, and rate adjustments can take time. Infrastructure projects also require large amounts of capital, so cash flow can fluctuate. These plans could also be disrupted by environmental or humanitarian concerns. The offer period runs from October 23 to 29. If you already have a brokerage account, you can apply for shares through your broker during this window. The exact process varies depending on the platform, but it typically involves filling out an application form and paying for the shares you wish to buy. Once your application is approved and the IPO lists, the shares will automatically appear in your portfolio when trading begins. For example, First Metro Securities allows online clients to subscribe to IPOs through its website by navigating to Account and then Corporate Actions and selecting the stock offering from the list. This feature is currently available only on the web platform, not the mobile app. If you are new to investing, there is also a fully digital option through Maya Stocks, the investing feature inside the Maya app. In partnership with DragonFi Securities, 2TradeAsia, and Philstocks Financial, Maya lets users open and fund a brokerage account with one of the above entirely in-app using their Maya Wallet, with no transfer fees. During the offer period, the Maynilad IPO will appear on the partner brokers’ pages inside the app, where users can select the number of shares they want and confirm their subscription. Before you make any decision to invest, it is worth reviewing Maynilad’s prospectus, which clearly shows the company’s financial statements, strengths, and risks. – Rappler.com Finterest is Rappler’s series that demystifies the world of money and gives practical advice on managing your personal finances.

text: Gold and silver are on a tear — breaking records and defying gravity. Gold has soared past $4,100 an ounce, while silver has rocketed to more than $52, its first record in nearly half a century. The surge is but a reflection of global anxiety, as trade tensions between the United States and China flare anew. Now, investors are flocking to the oldest safe havens known to man. The rally is precipitated by a new chill between Washington and Beijing. Fresh tariff threats, tighter export controls, and brewing disputes over rare earth minerals have revived fears of another trade war. These are not minor skirmishes — port fees, sanctions, and supply-chain disruptions are once again reshaping global trade flows. Every time rhetoric hardens, investors run for cover — and the first shelter they find is in precious metals. Here are the key drivers: Trade war rhetoric has escalated again, with the US signaling tougher tariff and export control postures on China, especially in high-tech and rare earths. Investors, fearing supply chains shocks and global growth disruption, have bid up precious metals. The more the market anticipates that the Federal Reserve will shift toward looser policy (lower rates), the more attractive “non-yielding” assets like gold become (since their opportunity cost falls). The Bangko Sentral ng Pilipinas (BSP) holds ~130 tons of gold (Q2 2025), up from ~127.5t in Q1. When global prices jump, the peso value of these reserves rises, improving the BSP’s balance sheet and the country’s perceived external buffer. But that’s a valuation gain, not spendable cash — helpful for confidence and reserve adequacy, but it doesn’t directly fund the budget. Why it matters: 1. Stronger reserve position A stronger reserve position can stabilize foreign exchange (FX) expectations during risk-off episodes tied to US-China flare-ups and precious-metals volatility. If the rally reverses, those gains can evaporate just as fast; the BSP treats this prudently. 2. Tailwinds for domestic gold mining (jobs, taxes, LGU shares) High gold prices improve margins for producing mines (e.g. OceanaGold’s Didipio; Philex’s Padcal with gold in copper concentrates). Their latest disclosures highlight robust free cash flow and ongoing reserve life, which high prices further support. More cash flow → more royalties, taxes, community shares, and potential capex. Small-scale miners benefit too. Since the promulgation of the Implementing Rules and Regulations (IRR) of Republic Act 11256, gold sold by registered small-scale miners to the BSP is tax-exempt and the BSP pays ~99.5% of the preliminary assay value — encouraging formalization and local sales. With record world prices, incentives to sell to BSP strengthen, pulling production into the legal channel and boosting rural incomes. Macro effect: More formal gold sales lift rural cash flows, raise Local Government Unit (LGU) royalty shares, and can modestly improve the current account if exports increase. It also deepens the BSP’s domestic bullion pipeline — strategically useful in volatile times. 3. Silver’s boom is a mixed bag for industry Unlike gold, silver is a critical industrial input (electronics, solar, electric vehicles). The present run — fueled by tight London inventories, elevated lease rates, and strong investment/Indian festive demand — pushes up component costs and squeezes manufacturers’ working capital. The squeeze has been severe enough to trigger air shipments and premiums over futures in London. For a country where electronics dominate exports, pricier silver can raise input costs for local assemblers/electronics manufacturing services (EMS) firms. Macro effect: In the short run, higher input costs can pressure margins and delay orders. Over time, exporters try to pass on costs to buyers; success depends on contract structures and global demand. With the Philippine Statistics Authority (PSA) showing electronics as the linchpin of exports, sustained silver tightness is a mild headwind. 4. Jewelry, pawnshops, and household balance sheets Retail jewelry prices rise when bullion does. That hurts discretionary jewelry demand but raises collateral values for households which use jewelry for short-term liquidity via pawnshops. In a high-price regime, loan-to-value amounts improve — useful during income squeezes — though ticket sizes and interest terms still dominate outcomes. (Industry commentary has highlighted Filipinos’ inflation hedging instincts with gold.) Inflation channel: The Consumer Price Index (CPI) weight of jewelry is small, so direct CPI impact is muted. Indirect effects — via electronics and imported durables using silver — are more relevant but typically gradual. 5. Financial markets and the peso Gold up, silver squeezed, and US–China tensions typically tighten global risk appetite. That can support local miners’ equities on earnings upgrades, but broad equities might face risk-off flows if global growth fears resurface. For foreign exchange (FX), outcomes are path-dependent: if safe-haven dollar strength outweighs gold’s reserve optics, USD/PHP can still drift weaker; if the Fed easing narrative dominates, emerging markets (EM) FX (including PHP) can stabilize. Key swing factor: The Fed path: If real yields fall on dovish guidance, gold remains underpinned and global financial conditions ease — a friendlier setup for the peso and risk assets; a hawkish surprise would do the opposite. (Global coverage flags that 2025’s “gold mania” is already stretching beyond traditional drivers — raising reversal risk if the macro narrative turns.) BSP Gold Valuation (Sensitivity) Illustrative Mining Revenue Uplift (per quarter) Electronics Exporter: Silver Shock Sensitivity (Illustrative) Imagine that you have ₱1 million idling in the bank. The interest barely keeps up with inflation. You decide to divide it evenly: ₱500,000 in gold, ₱500,000 in silver. At today’s prices — ₱7,700 per gram of gold and about ₱70 per gram of silver — you acquire real, portable wealth. But what happens one year from now? Gold is trading near US$4,150 per ounce, up nearly 13% in the past month and over 50% year-on-year. Analysts like Bank of America now project $5,000 by 2026, driven by global uncertainty, central-bank buying, and fading confidence in fiat currencies. If this plays out, your ₱500,000 in gold could be worth roughly ₱600,000 — a 20% gain. Even in a moderate case (+12%), that’s ₱560,000, comfortably above inflation. The only major risks are a strong US dollar or stubbornly high interest rates that make yield-less metals less attractive. But gold rarely disappoints those who wait. It’s the “sleep-sound” asset — quiet, heavy, and timeless. If gold is the wise old sage, silver is its restless cousin — volatile, brilliant, and full of surprises. Currently priced at US $52 per ounce (₱3,030), silver has skyrocketed 67% in the past year. Industrial demand from solar panels, electric vehicles, and battery production keeps driving it higher. Should it reach $65 per ounce by 2026, your ₱500,000 stake would climb to ₱625,000 — a 25% jump. A moderate 15% rise still nets you ₱575,000. The metal’s volatility can cut both ways, but its long-term fundamentals are silver-solid. In a balanced portfolio, the metals complement each other — gold steadies, silver sprints. Here’s how your ₱1 million could look in a year: Even in the middle case, you outperform most local investments and bank deposits several times over. Gold and silver move not only with charts and central-bank cues, but with emotion — fear, hope, distrust, and belief. When governments wobble, investors instinctively run to the metals that never lie. Every peso you park in bullion is a quiet protest against uncertainty, a hedge against the manipulations of paper wealth. If you invest today, your story will not be about chasing speculative highs — it will be about preserving value while the world experiments with digital currencies, debt ceilings, and geopolitical gambles. A year from now, whether gold hits $5,000 or silver flirts with $65, you’ll hold something heavier than paper: peace of mind. Because when markets burn, the metals don’t melt—they shine. – Rappler.com Sources: Bangko Sentral ng Pilipinas, Bureau of Internal Revenue, Philippine Statistics Authority, Reuters, The Economic Times, Bloomberg, AP News
