title: [Vantage Point] Gold and silver’s record-breaking run: A boom built on fear

text: Paramount Skydance on Monday launched a hostile bid worth $108.4 billion for Warner Bros Discovery, in a last-ditch effort to outbid Netflix and create a media powerhouse that would challenge the dominance of the streaming giant. Netflix had emerged victorious on Friday from a weeks-long bidding war with Paramount and Comcast, securing a $72 billion equity deal for Warner Bros Discovery’s TV, film studios and streaming assets. But Paramount’s latest attempt means the jockeying for Warner Bros and its prized HBO and DC Comics assets will not come to a conclusion swiftly. The Warner Bros Discovery board of directors on Monday afternoon said it would review Paramount’s offer, but was not modifying its recommendation with respect to Netflix. It advised the company to “take no action at this time” in regard to the Paramount Skydance proposal. Paramount’s $30-per-share cash offer includes financing from Affinity Partners, the investment firm run by Jared Kushner, US President Donald Trump’s son-in-law, and several Middle Eastern government-run investment funds, and is backstopped by the Ellison family. Larry Ellison, the world’s second-richest person, is the father of Paramount head David Ellison and has close ties to the White House. The studio argues its bid for the entirety of Warner Bros Discovery is superior to Netflix, giving shareholders $18 billion more in cash and an easier path to regulatory approval. It said a Paramount-Warner Bros combination, which would be among the largest media deals in history, would be in the best interest of the creative community, movie theaters and consumers, who would benefit from enhanced competition. “We believe our offer will create a stronger Hollywood,” Paramount CEO David Ellison said in a statement. Separately, he said Paramount’s proposal offered “higher headline value, increased certainty in that value, greater regulatory certainty, and a pro-Hollywood, pro-consumer and pro-competition future.” Paramount’s bid includes Warner Bros Discovery’s cable television properties; Netflix’s bid is limited to the Warner Bros film and television studios, HBO and the HBO Max streaming service. Analysts noted that Paramount’s offer comes with its own antitrust scrutiny as a consolidation of two major television operators. Last month, Democratic senators warned that such a transaction would result in “one company controlling almost everything Americans watch on TV.” The combined studio would also have a greater market share than current leader Disney, and add to fears of consolidation that have hit the industry in recent years. The offer represents a 139% premium over the company’s value from before the buyout talks started, and bests Netflix’s $27.75 offer that mixes cash and stock. At a UBS conference, Netflix co-CEO Ted Sarandos said Paramount’s hostile bid for Warner Bros was “entirely expected,” but added that he was confident of closing the deal. “In the offer that Paramount was talking about today, the Ellisons were talking about $6 billion of synergies,” said Sarandos. “Where do you think synergies come from? Cutting jobs? So we’re not cutting jobs. We’re making jobs.” In a regulatory filing, Paramount said that the Ellison family, which owns Paramount, along with private equity firm RedBird Capital, had agreed to backstop $40.7 billion in equity capital. The offer also includes financing from Kushner’s Affinity Partners, the Saudi and Qatari sovereign wealth funds, and L’imad Holding Co, owned by the government of Abu Dhabi. “A Paramount Skydance-Warner Bros merger would be a five-alarm antitrust fire and exactly what our anti-monopoly laws are written to prevent,” US Senator Elizabeth Warren, a Democrat, said on Monday. The hostile bid “is backed by a who’s who of Trump buddies … raising serious questions about influence-peddling, political favoritism, and national security risks.” If Warner Bros accepts Paramount’s offer, it will have to pay Netflix a $2.8 billion breakup fee. Netflix, on its part, is on the hook for $5.8 billion if its deal falls through. The streaming pioneer is likely to face strong antitrust scrutiny, and Trump has already raised questions about its offer. On Monday, Trump said neither bidding party “are friends of mine,” and he wanted “to do what’s right.” He added that he had not spoken to Kushner about the Paramount bid. Netflix’s bid has already drawn sharp criticism from bipartisan lawmakers and Hollywood unions over concerns that it could lead to job cuts as well as higher prices for consumers. “While it is perhaps a sad commentary on the US that Paramount thinks its closeness to the occupant of the Oval Office will help it seal the deal, it is merely doing what it can to steal a march on its rival,” said Chris Beauchamp, chief market analyst at UK-based IG Group. Shares of Paramount were up 7.3% on Monday. Warner Bros Discovery rose 5.3%, while Netflix shares fell 4%. Reuters had already reported, citing sources familiar, that Paramount had raised its offer to $30 per share on Thursday for the entire company, but that the Warner Bros board had concerns about the financing. “The Warner Bros Discovery acquisition is far from over,” said eMarketer senior analyst Ross Benes. “Paramount will appeal to shareholders, regulators, and politicians to try to stymie Netflix. The battle could become prolonged.” Paramount maintained that it would be a champion of Hollywood and its talent, would remain committed to releasing movies in theaters, and that its path to regulatory approval would be faster than Netflix’s. In its appeal to shareholders, Paramount said it submitted six proposals over the course of 12 weeks, but Warner Bros “never engaged meaningfully” with these proposals. The company said it had sent a letter to Warner Bros, questioning the sale process and alleging the company has abandoned a fair bidding process and predetermined Netflix as the winner. That followed reports that Warner Bros’ management called the Netflix deal a “slam dunk” while speaking negatively about Paramount’s offer. In an interview with CNBC on Monday, Paramount CEO David Ellison said there was an “inherent bias” in the bidding. – Rappler.com
label: True
title: Warner Bros fight heats up with $108 billion hostile bid from Paramount

text: MANILA, Philippines – Malacañang assured concerned Philippine business groups that the government’s anti-corruption campaign is in full swing, after 34 organizations described the flood control scandal as having “eroded public trust” which “now threatens our national security.” Presidential Communications Office (PCO) Undersecretary Claire Castro, in a Palace briefing on Monday, October 20, cited various actions taken by the government. These include the issuance of lookout bulletins for contractors and officials under investigation, as well as various requests for asset freeze orders. “Nararamdaman po ng Pangulo at ng administrasyon ang mga nararamdaman ng mga businessmen kaya po patuloy ang ginagawang pag-iimbestiga at patuloy ang pagpapabilis ng aksyon para po mapanagot ang dapat na mapanagot,” Castro said. (The President and his administration feel what the businessmen feel. That’s why we continue to investigate and expedite action steps to hold the guilty accountable.) Castro also called out those allegedly trying to discredit the ongoing investigation of the Independent Commission for Infrastructure (ICI). She said that President Ferdinand Marcos Jr. understands the private sector’s desire for results, but assured the business community that the anti-corruption crackdown was ongoing. Malacañang’s statement comes after 34 business groups co-signed a resolution urging Marcos to urgently address the corruption surrounding flood control and other public works projects. The 34 signatories include the Philippines’ influential business groups such as the Makati Business Club, Philippine Chamber of Commerce and Industry, and the Management Association of the Philippines. “We have contributed to the national funds through taxes locally and nationally and have paid additional assessment of taxes… Yet trillions of pesos supplied and intended to protect our communities from disasters have been squandered through ghost projects, substandard work, and inflated contracts,” the groups said. The business organizations urged Marcos to bestow full legal authority and independence upon the ICI, prosecute all those responsible, implement institutional reforms and recover ill-gotten wealth, and provide regular updates to the public. “This is more than a financial loss – it is a fatal breach of public trust that leaves our people vulnerable and outraged,” they wrote. Marcos formed the ICI in September through Executive Order No. 94 to probe alleged corruption in public works projects in the last decade. – Rappler.com
label: True
title: Palace assures business groups: Gov’t taking anti-corruption drive seriously

text: MANILA, Philippines – How does P185 billion just disappear? That’s roughly how much market value vanished from the Philippine Stock Exchange (PSE) in just a few weeks. And while it’s not quite the P1.7 trillion that Securities and Exchange Commission Chair Francis Lim first claimed — a figure so wildly off the mark it turned out to be “fictitious” — the real number is still worrying. (READ: [Finterest] PSE may not have lost P1.7-T, but its weakness is still a problem) Taken at face value, it sounds catastrophic, but what really happens when we report such a loss? What exactly happened to those billions? Was it just destroyed, like torching piles upon piles of cash? If not, where does it go, and who’s paying the price? When analysts or reporters say the market “lost P185 billion,” they’re referring to a drop in total market capitalization, which refers to the overall value of all listed companies on the PSE. Public companies are priced share by share. Multiply a company’s share price by the number of shares outstanding and you get that company’s market capitalization. Add up the market caps of all listed companies and you get the market’s total value. The difference between two periods (say, last week’s total and today’s) is what we call the market’s “loss” or “gain.” Sometimes, instead of measuring the change in market cap for every single company in the PSE, only the change for the companies in the PSE index (PSEi) is used. In simple terms, a loss in market value means the total market cap of companies in the PSE went down because their share prices dropped. You can think of market cap as the crowd’s latest opinion, not a hard appraisal of a company’s factories, cash flows, or land. That’s why when we say that it dropped by P185 billion, it doesn’t mean that the cash literally vanished. What it really means is that, on paper, the collective value of companies has declined because investors are now willing to pay less for their shares. This doesn’t automatically mean that all investors lost that money outright. If you’re holding stocks that fell in value and you don’t sell, that “loss” is unrealized. It exists only on paper, reflecting weak market sentiment at a specific moment. If prices rise again, the value returns. But if you sell when prices are low, then the loss becomes realized, and that’s when the money is truly gone from your pocket. Prices move when buyers and sellers agree to trade at a new level. That agreement reflects lots of inputs: company earnings, interest rates, currency moves, liquidity, and risk appetite. It also reflects stories that change how investors feel about the future. Corruption headlines matter because they raise the perceived risk that rules will not be followed, projects will not get built, and bribes will erode profits. When share prices fall, it usually means there’s more selling than buying at those levels. But that doesn’t mean everyone selling is losing money. Some investors may have bought their shares much earlier, at lower prices, and are now cashing in profits. Others, especially those who entered recently, may be cutting losses or shifting funds somewhere safer. So, if your portfolio is flashing red, it doesn’t always mean every investor is bearing a loss. In fact, that dip you’re seeing might even be the result of a big institutional investor taking profit on a position they made years ago, back when the stock was much cheaper. Who exactly is driving this selling? In recent months, foreigners have consistently been net sellers, which isn’t something that’s isolated to the Philippines. In fact, that’s reflective of a regional trend of fund outflows from emerging markets. But in the Philippines, it’s particularly a big deal because foreigners still make up nearly half of all trading activity in the PSE year-to-date. Heavy foreign selling tends to weigh on blue chips, especially those with large foreign ownership. Retail activity tends to show up more in mid- to small-cap names or speculative counters. That’s why when foreign investors pull out, it can cause the index to jitter. But outflows aren’t always a “vote against” the Philippines. Across Asia, foreign institutional investors have been trimming exposure to emerging markets, driven by global risk sentiment, such as higher US interest rates, tensions in the Middle East, and portfolio shifts toward less risky assets like the US Treasuries. Meanwhile, some funds are simply rebalancing ahead of the year-end, locking in profits or reducing risk. We can never be 100% sure what is causing markets to move. We can say corruption likely contributed, but we should also be honest about what the data can and cannot prove. It’s not like the PSE publishes a footnote at the end of each day saying the market “fell 1.2% due to scandal.” Market movements are influenced by countless factors, such as economic data, global sentiment, policy signals, quarterly earnings, political rhetoric, and even social media posts. What we can do is look at evidence and make an informed interpretation, rather than assert a cause-and-effect relationship. For example, you may see several negative governance headlines in succession, a pickup in net foreign selling, and larger drops in stocks exposed to public works. That supports the narrative that governance fears weighed on prices. Another example is when REIT prices fall immediately after a surprise interest rate hike by the Bangko Sentral ng Pilipinas (BSP). Higher rates make bonds and other fixed-income assets more appealing than dividend-paying REITs, which may prompt REIT investors to sell. If price drops sharply right after such an announcement, it’s reasonable to link the event to the market’s reaction. But attribution is probabilistic. In the case of the recent sell-off, remember that besides the flood control scandal, there’s also the global backdrop of tensions in the Middle East, the US government shutdown, uncertainty over tariffs, and shifting central bank policies from the BSP and Fed — all of which may be top of mind for foreign institutional investors. It’s for this reason why analysts would say “The market retreated as investors reacted to…” or “The sell-off coincided with…” — to emphasize that we’re really only looking at correlations. For retail investors, the biggest impact of a market slump is psychological. It’s unnerving to see your portfolio balance drop, especially when headlines reinforce the fear about billions disappearing. But as long as you don’t sell, your losses remain paper losses, and they can reverse as easily as they appeared. Historically, investors who stay disciplined and ride out volatility often end up better off, especially when the fundamentals of their investments remain sound. It’s a different story if the company you’re investing in is directly tied to the corruption scandal. Otherwise, fluctuations like these are completely normal in investing and may even make the stock of a strong company undervalued and ripe for buying. That said, your response depends on your goals. If you’re investing short-term, you might need to rebalance to avoid being forced to sell at an even lower price if this downturn lingers. But if you’re in for the long haul and own solid companies or diversified funds, you can ride out this volatility. Investors who stay disciplined and resist panic selling may still recover as markets rebound. While the flood control mess may have shaken some investor confidence, it doesn’t change the fundamentals of most Filipino companies overnight. – Rappler.com Finterest is Rappler’s series that demystifies the world of money and gives practical advice on managing your personal finances.

text: Executive Secretary Ralph Recto has declared in a statement that “better days are coming” for the Philippine economy. It arrives at a moment when President Ferdinand “Bongbong” Marcos Jr.’s administration is eager to showcase its wins with inflation dropping to 1.5% in November — well below the government’s target band — while major credit rating agency S&P’s reaffirmation of the country’s BBB+ rating has given Malacañang a welcome seal of external validation. Recto frames these developments as evidence of a disciplined, more transparent governance culture under Marcos Jr., pointing to asset seizures, Anti-Money Laundering Council (AMLC) freezes, and recovered kickbacks as signs that the state is finally cracking down on corruption. In his telling, low prices, a strong labor market, and a “disciplined” 2026 budget will pave the way for a stronger, more confident economy. But optimism must coexist with realism. Debt is rising faster than growth, the peso remains exposed to political shocks, and institutional credibility is still repairing itself after the turbulence of the past year. Whether the Philippines truly enters a “better, stronger” economic phase will depend, not on inflation numbers or international ratings, but on the country’s ability to confront the structural risks that soften the foundations beneath Recto’s upbeat narrative. Vantage Point does not dispute Recto’s optimistic claim. I concede that it is grounded in real macroeconomic gains, but it also sits atop a fiscal landscape that demands more caution than celebration. The same period that produced low inflation also produced a swelling national debt, which reached ₱17.56 trillion in October — a 9.62% increase from the previous year, and much faster than the economy’s own expansion. Gross domestic product (GDP) growth of roughly 5.2% cannot keep pace with the speed at which obligations are piling up, particularly as the peso softens from ₱56.145 to ₱58.58 to the dollar over the past year. That depreciation alone has inflated the peso value of foreign-denominated debt, tightening fiscal space even before new borrowings enter the picture. This vulnerability is deepened by a governance storm that Recto himself acknowledges but does not fully confront. The flood-control scandal, which began as a procurement anomaly, has widened into a larger indictment of the national budget process. Investors have taken notice. Public construction slowed during the third quarter as agencies reexamined procurement flows; foreign funds, already cautious, pulled back further; and the Philippine Stock Exchange (PSE) Index reflected the country’s governance anxiety with lackluster performance. The result is a market increasingly inclined to price a governance risk premium into Philippine assets — a premium that low inflation, on its own, cannot offset. His promise of a “better, stronger Philippine economy ahead” arrives at a moment when the administration is eager to reclaim the narrative. Inflation has fallen to multi-year lows, governance initiatives are showcased as proof of reform, and the Palace is intent on signaling renewed economic momentum heading into 2026. On the surface, the optimism is defensible: headline inflation sits at 1.5%, the country maintains a BBB+ rating with a Positive Outlook, and criminal cases stemming from the flood-control scandal have produced visible arrests, asset freezes, and restitutions. Yet the data carefully threaded through this political storyline tells a more complicated truth — one that demands scrutiny as the country’s debt climbs to ₱17.56 trillion and its macroeconomic pillars show signs of stress. The Bangko Sentral ng Pilipinas (BSP) sharpened this contrast when on Thursday, December 11, it capped 2025 with another 25-basis point policy rate cut, lowering the benchmark borrowing rate to 4.5%. That move, the fifth cut this year and the eighth since August 2024, officially places the economy in an aggressive easing cycle — one enabled by collapsing inflation, but driven by something far less celebratory: weakening growth and rising governance risk. The BSP move acknowledges that overall business sentiment “has continued to decline” due to governance concerns and global uncertainty, and that GDP growth “continued to weaken further.” The third quarter’s 4% expansion, down sharply from earlier quarters, marks the slowest pace since the pandemic-era recovery and reflects the corrosive impact of the flood-control scandal on investor sentiment, public spending execution, and capital formation. The BSP’s decision to ease policy rate, despite a fragile peso, underscores the complexity of the moment. At ₱58.58 to the dollar in October, the peso has depreciated steadily from ₱56.145 a year earlier, eroding purchasing power and inflating foreign-denominated obligations. Every incremental weakening now directly inflates the government’s external-debt burden — already a significant component of the ₱17.56 trillion outstanding stock. This is the structural tension at the heart of today’s macroeconomic landscape: easing monetary policy is meant to stimulate domestic demand, even though it risks amplifying the very debt dynamics that constrain fiscal maneuvering. Meanwhile, the economy’s fundamentals present a mixed picture. Private consumption remains the main growth engine, but real wages have only recently begun to recover; youth unemployment ticked up slightly in October; manufacturing output slowed in four of the last six months; and infrastructure disbursements — supposedly the backbone of the administration’s growth strategy — fell behind schedule due to integrity reviews triggered by corruption investigations. Foreign direct investment inflows, which peaked at US$10.5 billion in 2021, have moderated to around $7.8 billion in the first ten months of 2025, reflecting a cautious external stance toward Philippine political risk. The current account deficit remains sizable at roughly 2.5% of GDP, financed increasingly by short-term portfolio flows rather than long-term investments. Remittances could continue to provide resilience — growing 2.6% year-to-date — but even this stabilizer is insufficient to counterbalance the broader weakening of capital inflows. Recto’s positiveness, while not unfounded, therefore exists alongside structural vulnerabilities that demand careful weighing. Inflation’s benign behavior — below 2% since February — has indeed given the central bank room to maneuver, but the BSP itself warns that the easing cycle is “nearing its end,” and any additional cuts will be strictly data-dependent. It has revised its inflation forecasts modestly upward for 2026 and 2027, signaling early caution. Growth projections, meanwhile, paint a slower path than what the Palace implies: the BSP expects a “gradual” recovery, driven not by organic momentum, but by the lagged effects of monetary easing and improved public spending efficiency. This is not the language of an economy sprinting toward a strong rebound; it is the language of an institution preparing for a long, uneven healing process. The Philippines does have assets: a young demographic profile, resilient remittances, moderating inflation, and a central bank willing to act decisively. Yet the challenge now is credibility: fiscal, institutional, and political. The cumulative 2-percentage-point rate cut since last year may support domestic demand, but unless governance reforms translate into predictable budgeting, transparent procurement, and restored investor trust, monetary stimulus alone will not deliver the “strong comeback” heralded by the administration. The country must grow faster than its debt, restore confidence faster than scandals can erode it, and bolster the peso faster than external shocks can weaken it. Recto’s optimism may indeed prove prophetic — but only if the numbers, not the rhetoric, begin moving in his desired direction. The “better, stronger” economic phase will depend, not on inflation numbers or international ratings, but on the country’s ability to confront the structural risks that soften the foundations beneath Recto’s upbeat narrative. This is where the administration’s narrative becomes difficult to sustain. Recto’s emphasis on the Philippines’ better inflation numbers — a genuine achievement given global price volatility — neither neutralize concerns over the country’s debt trajectory nor calm markets increasingly sensitive to institutional instability. Price stability may support consumption, but it does not address the deeper risks posed by slower output expansion, rising refinancing costs, and a currency that remains vulnerable to both global conditions and local governance shocks. The government’s optimism rests on inflation data, while investors are looking at debt ratios, fiscal credibility, and signals from the political economy. It is no coincidence that Recto’s statement devotes substantial attention to the administration’s anti-corruption drive. The flood-control scandal — which now implicates lawmakers, Department of Public Works and Highways (DPWH) officials, and contractors — has evolved into a broader examination of how the national budget is crafted, allocated, and potentially manipulated. That the executive secretary finds it necessary to highlight arrests, AMLC asset freezes amounting to ₱13 billion, the auction of ₱38.2 million worth of seized luxury vehicles, and the ₱110 million restitution from a DPWH district engineer, speaks volumes about the scale of reputational damage the scandal has inflicted. Markets do not respond to arrests as they do to institutional reform, but they do react to credibility risk — and the scandal has already tightened scrutiny on the entire ₱6-trillion fiscal cycle. Even public construction, a traditional growth engine, has shown signs of deceleration, as agencies quietly reassess procurement procedures in the wake of the controversy. Foreign funds that had already reduced exposure to Philippine equities and bonds now cite governance uncertainty as a major reason for maintaining underweight positions. In this sense, Recto’s assurances of stronger governance become less a sign of institutional strength and more an admission that the Marcos Jr. administration knows market confidence is fragile and must be aggressively managed. The promise of a “disciplined” ₱6.793-trillion budget for 2026 reinforces this point. Governments do not promise discipline unless they know discipline is in doubt. The budget process — magnified by the controversies of bicameral insertions — has turned into a barometer of political influence rather than economic planning. Investors understand this intuitively, rating agencies model it explicitly, and the peso now reflects it through sensitivity to governance headlines. Recto’s optimism that reforms, tax enforcement recalibrations, and investment promotion efforts will revive growth in 2026 is plausible only if the government can rebuild trust in the fiscal system itself. The macroeconomic risks ahead are neither abstract nor distant. A debt-to-GDP ratio drifting toward 62 to 63% would place the Philippines at the edge of ratings-agency caution. A continued slide of the peso could widen fiscal gaps and further inflate foreign debt obligations. A slowdown in public or private investment — even marginal — could weaken the growth base needed to sustain long-term borrowing. These are not risks that inflation can offset, or issues that can be resolved merely by high-level assurances of a “strong comeback.” Ultimately, the Philippines stands at a critical juncture where credibility has become the economy’s most valuable — and most vulnerable — asset. Recto’s optimism is not misplaced; it is incomplete. The administration’s success will depend, not on inflation numbers or credit ratings, but on whether it can restore confidence in the country’s fiscal architecture, institutional discipline, and governance systems. Until then, markets will continue to price the economy, not on the promise of better days, but on the reality of rising debt, slowing growth, and a political environment still struggling to convince investors that the rules of public finance are stable, predictable, and enforced. – Rappler.com Click here for more Vantage Point articles.
label: True
title: [Vantage Point] As BSP cuts policy rates, PH’s mounting debts weaken optimism

text: MANILA, Philippines – The market value of publicly listed firms in the Philippines has taken a hit due to investors’ concerns on corruption in the flood control mess, Securities and Exchange Commission (SEC) chief Francis Lim said. During a Financial Executives of the Philippines (FINEX) conference on Tuesday, October 7, Lim said P1.7 trillion in market value was wiped out from the Philippine Stock Exchange (PSE) amid investors’ concerns over the flood control project controversy. However, in a statement on Thursday, October 9, Lim corrected himself and said the figure was based on a fictitious report. He also apologized. (Editor’s note: We have revised and updated this article, including its title and url, to correct the mistake. Please read Lim’s statement below: Waning investor confidence also caused the PSEi to plunge to its six-month low of 5,997.6 before returning to the 6,000 level on Wednesday, October 1. “Investors aren’t fleeing because of weak fundamentals; they’re fleeing because of weak integrity. It’s a stark reminder that corruption is a weapon of mass wealth destruction,” Lim said. Lim also warned that it is the government and the public that pay the price when investor trust is broken. “Because when markets are trusted, capital flows. And when capital flows, the economy grows,” he said. For Lim, the country’s “laggard” capital market also reflects what he describes as a “crisis of confidence.” The chief corporate regulator noted that companies generally still hesitate to go public, while a number of public companies choose to leave the stock market altogether. This is why Lim considers rebuilding investors’ trust as one of the SEC’s most urgent missions. He hopes to achieve this by strengthening the independent director system, making real estate investment trusts more inclusive, as well as championing financial literacy as a mandatory subject in schools. (READ: SEC chief Francis Lim wants youth, judiciary to understand how markets work) Since the government began probing alleged ghost flood control projects, the Anti-Money Laundering Council (AMLC) has secured five freeze orders covering over P4.4 billion in assets. – Rappler.com
label: True
title: SEC chief: Corruption a weapon of mass wealth destruction

text: BAGUIO CITY, Philippines – The Municipal Trial Court in Cities (MTCC) Branch 5 in Baguio City recently dismissed the criminal case against Camp John Hay Development Corporation (CJHDevCo) chairman Robert “Bob” Sobrepeña and Fil-Estate Management Incorporated (FEMI) vice president Ramon Jimenez, after the complainants filed an affidavit of desistance and formally dropped the charges. The case stemmed from a ₱11.2 million hotel leasehold sale involving units at The Forest Lodge in Camp John Hay. Sobrepeña and Jimenez were indicted in August 2025 for “other deceits” under Article 318 of the Revised Penal Code after prosecutors found prima facie evidence that they had concealed the rescission of CJHDevCo’s lease with the Bases Conversion and Development Authority (BCDA) when the transaction was made. The indictment was based on the complaint of spouses Monica Carla and Erwin Galang, who claimed they were misled into purchasing leasehold rights to two Forest Lodge units valid until 2046 — despite a standing Supreme Court decision ordering CJHDevCo to vacate the leased premises and barring it from entering new contracts. However, on September 5, the Galangs submitted an affidavit of desistance. The court accepted their withdrawal of interest, and after both Sobrepeña and Jimenez pleaded not guilty, the case was dismissed on September 11. Judge Jeanylene Isip-Fukai cited the complainants’ voluntary desistance as the sole basis for dismissal. The court order noted that the private complainants fully understood the consequences of their withdrawal, including waiving their right to testify or pursue related civil actions. Following the dismissal, CJHDevCo issued a public statement claiming the case was dismissed due to the prosecution’s “failure to prove guilt beyond reasonable doubt.” The statement was posted on the CJHDevCo-controlled Camp John Hay Facebook page on September 11 and posted by online Facebook news page Balitang Northern Luzon on the same day. In a strongly worded manifestation submitted to the court on September 12, City Prosecutor Christian Amistad said the CJHDevCo post was misleading and omitted the key fact that the case was dropped because the complainants desisted — not because of a court finding on the merits. “To the prosecution, the said ‘post’ or ‘story’ is simply an inaccurate narration of the events that transpired,” the manifestation read, stressing that no full-blown trial took place and that the court never evaluated the strength of the evidence. Amistad urged the court to take note of the online post, arguing that it had the “tendency to undermine the integrity of our justice system,” and that freedom of speech does not cover “wanton disregard of truth for purposes of personal gain.” In their affidavit, the Galangs acknowledged they had purchased the Forest Lodge units directly from FEMI, not CJHDevCo, and had since clarified that FEMI derived its rights through a 2008 Memorandum of Agreement between CJHDevCo, Fil-Estate entities, and BCDA. The Galangs declared that they were no longer interested in pursuing the case against Sobrepeña, Jimenez, or other CJHDevCo officials — except for two individuals, whom they reserved the right to sue separately. This case was the first criminal prosecution tied to transactions conducted by CJHDevCo after the Supreme Court upheld BCDA’s reclamation of Camp John Hay in 2024. The decision enforced a 2015 arbitral ruling requiring CJHDevCo and all persons claiming rights under it to vacate the 247-hectare property. The Department of Justice (DOJ) earlier announced the formation of a special task force to investigate post-rescission transactions and other alleged irregularities involving CJHDevCo and its affiliates. Prosecutors had hinted that the Sobrepeña-Jimenez indictment was “just the beginning,” raising expectations of further legal action. With the dismissal now formalized, it remains to be seen how the DOJ will proceed with other possible cases. In its public statement, CJHDevCo maintained that all its transactions were “lawful, transparent, and conducted in good faith.” It emphasized that the 2015 arbitral award allowed it to retain benefits from its decades-long lease and acknowledged the validity of third-party contracts extending until 2047. The company reiterated its commitment to protecting investor rights within Camp John Hay and implied that its legal troubles stem from “misunderstandings” rather than wrongdoing. – Rappler.com
label: True
title: Why Bob Sobrepeña won latest round in Camp John Hay saga

text: On October 31, at the tail end of World Cities Day, UNESCO dropped the news: Dumaguete City was now UNESCO Creative City of Literature, alongside Quezon City, which was designated as UNESCO Creative City of Film. I was in the middle of a Halloween party in a Dumaguete hotel when I received the news from my fellow coordinators of this campaign. Forgive me, but I cried. Because this was always a pipe dream that felt possible, and now it was real. But a pipe dream is comfortable. Indulging in pipe dreams is safe, because there are really no risks involved, only pronouncements. You can just say, “I’ve always wanted to have Dumaguete become a UNESCO creative city” — and some sort of satisfaction gets sated in the recesses of your ambitions. The pronouncement is there, hanging in the air — and somehow that is enough. But it really isn’t. The best fulfilment of dreams is in the tangible. And there lies the rub: because most of the pursuit of our dreams actually involve risking it all — carving time out of our busy lives to fill out a fragile schedule of creation, despite the demands on our lives from other things we have also made commitments to — like work, like family, like friends; committing to accomplish the dirty work of untangling seemingly insurmountable paper work or bureaucracy, generally sweating out the small stuff; and developing fortitude of spirit, because you will meet constant disappointments, as well as the firewall of unhelpful individuals who do not understand what you want to accomplish. The road to dreams fulfilled is never smooth, never easy. Pipe dreams, on the other hand, are easy. One pipe dream I had indulged in for so long was Dumaguete City becoming UNESCO Creative City of Literature. As a writer born and raised in Dumaguete, I know — perhaps in the most personal sense how this city has carved a place for itself as an unlikely capital of the literary arts in the Philippines, helped for the most part by writers from Silliman University, like the Tiempos, who chose to stay in Dumaguete (despite the tangible promises of more fulfilled careers outside of it) and have made it the home for which they could steward, not just their own literary creations, but also foundational institutions that would turn out to be great contributions to the national literature. But much was at stake. To quote National Artist for Literature Resil Mojares: “In promoting Dumaguete as a UNESCO City of Literature, two things are important. One must see not only the city’s tradition and current status but the award’s potential and prospective value in raising the city’s visibility and promoting further development that will go beyond the literary field to sectors like tourism, education, and the local economy, as well as diffuse outwards to other places in the country. The stakes are high since Dumaguete is the country’s best bet for being a city of literature and I really think that if Dumaguete does not get this honor, it is unlikely that another Philippine city will.” In 2010, I was one of two Philippine delegates chosen as honorary fellows of the International Writing Program (IWP) in Iowa City, which just became a UNESCO City of Literature in 2008. When I was in Iowa for this very prestigious fellowship, it dawned on me that this distinction was also fitting for Dumaguete. Iowa City is small, like Dumaguete. It only has one major bookstore; same as Dumaguete. It regularly hosts international writers and literary conferences; same as Dumaguete. And it has the same vibe as Dumaguete — replace Iowa’s corn fields with the sea, and you will get Dumaguete, only with blonde people. In fact, Dumaguete writer Rowena Tiempo Torrevillas, who is a resident of Iowa City, calls that Midwestern city as her “blonde Dumaguete.” Iowa City is also a place whose writing culture is driven by the University of Iowa, the biggest university in town — essentially its own Silliman University. (The writer Robin Hemley, who ran the creative nonfiction program at the University of Iowa for many years, is actually married to a Filipina — from Siquijor.) The famous Iowa Writers Workshop — the grandfather of all writing workshops in America — was the model for the Silliman University National Writers Workshop, the oldest creative writing workshop in Southeast Asia, founded in 1962. In fact, both Edilberto Tiempo and Edith Tiempo, co-founders of the SUNWW, were products of the Iowa Writers Workshop, graduating in the 1950s: Edilberto for fiction and Edith for poetry. And when Paul Engle, the longtime director of the Iowa Writers Workshop, visited Dumaguete in the 1960s to be part of the SUNWW, the idea of establishing the International Writing Program came to him. He, in fact, invited some of the early alumni of SUNWW to be part of the early batches of the IWP’s famous fall residency. All these literary crosscurrents were already in place when I went to Iowa in 2010 to be part of that fall residency — which is probably why I felt so much at home there. Since I came back from the US, I’d been advocating for the idea of Dumaguete as UNESCO Creative City of Literature every chance I got, including at several editions of the 6200 PopUp, sponsored by the Department of Trade and Industry (DTI) Negros Oriental, as well as in all my lectures about Dumaguete literature in various seminars and fora, including one on the creative economy at Silliman University, sponsored by the National Commission for Culture and the Arts. In 2014, in my capacity as the founding coordinator of the Edilberto and Edith Tiempo Creative Writing Center, I even curated an exhibit at the Silliman Library titled Cities of Literature, which traced the link between Dumaguete and Iowa, with the blessings of the IWP’s Christopher Merrill. In 2018, prodded by former Dumaguete City tourism officer Jacqueline Veloso-Antonio, I prepared a white paper for Mayor Ipe Remollo to determine whether we should apply to UNESCO for City of Music or City of Literature. (You see, only the LGU can apply for the designation of UNESCO Creative City.) Naturally, as a writer, my bias was clear. But the pandemic put these plans on hold. When I gave a talk about this very same thing at the first edition of Dumaguete Literary Festival in April 2024, however, this propelled then-DTI Negros Oriental director Nimfa Virtucio to take the first steps and got me involved in the official application to UNESCO, with the blessings of Mayor Remollo. That’s the story. We submitted our application on the deadline: March 3, 2025. Truth to tell, the UNESCO application, which lasted from December 2024 to February 2025, took such a toll on my mental and physical health, and, by the end, I actually found myself getting sick a lot. The application — in its blank state, composed of eight pages with seven chapters of questions, with each question having their own sub-questions, and each one with a specific character count — looked simple, but soon proved intimidating. The final bid ultimately amounted to about 40 pages of well-considered responses, tackling not just the heritage of Dumaguete specific to literature, but also the plans the LGU has in place to make sure the sector prospers in the coming years. We persevered. Was it the sheer ambition, the “internationality” of it all, that was intimidating? I guess so. I was so exhausted and anxious I couldn’t even entertain some of the minor blowbacks to the effort from people you would think would be the most supportive of the campaign. (Some people actually thought we were applying for grant money. Where will the money go? they asked. But that’s not what the UNESCO designation is all about. We tried to reach out to many stakeholders in Dumaguete — representing the creatives, the schools, the publishers, the book sellers, the cultural workers — and form them into a technical working group to help us thresh out what the community wants in a creative city of literature. In the end, while we could not control some of the divisiveness, or miscommunication, or benign disinterest, most people in Dumaguete were very kind and supportive, even with last-minute asks.) In my darkest moments during those months, I actually felt I was so alone. That’s not true, of course. In the end, it was a coterie of friends and associates from Buglas Writers Guild and the Dumaguete Literary Festival who pulled me out of the darkness, and together we made it to the deadline. If there is one person to thank, it would be DTI’s Anton Gabila, who was the steadfast keeper of our light, the rock to all our efforts, never mind the mixed metaphors. There’s also the indefatigable efforts of former city tourism officer Katherine Aguilar, who provided the grease to get the LGU involved in the entire process. In the end, we did become UNESCO Creative City of Literature. I will take the road of gratefulness. I have always believed in the magic of trying instead of wishful thinking and pipe dreams; this was our attempt to make things tangible. And we were justly awarded for the effort. – Rappler.com Ian Rosales Casocot is the author of Don’t Tell Anyone, Bamboo Girls, Heartbreak & Magic, and Beautiful Accidents. He has won the Palanca nine times for his fiction, plays, and children’s poetry. In 2008, his novel Sugar Land was longlisted in the Man Asian Literary Prize. He was writer-in-residence for the International Writers Program of the University of Iowa in 2010. As president of Buglas Writers Guild, he was the lead coordinator in the campaign for Dumaguete to become UNESCO Creative City of Literature. He is based in Dumaguete City.
label: True
title: A personal journey to the City of Literature

text: MANILA, Philippines – “Ay, ‘wag yan…he’s a Pisces.” “Sis, I’m an Aries – you know I don’t do long-term!” “Gemini siya? I’m an Aquarius! Meant to be talaga kami.” Today’s dating scene has been dominated by astrology. Nowadays, you’re no longer just a quirky Aquarius or a passionate Aries – you’re also “emotional” because of your moon, or “non-committal” because of your Venus. People swear that compatibility can be determined just by your zodiac signs; it seems like the stars have been playing a more vital role in guiding people in making the right (or even wrong) decisions in love. Certain signs have even become non-negotiables, and birth charts have become background checks! For many, the stars really don’t lie, and “astrolove” – the intersection of astrology and compatibility – has been taking the dating world by storm. Dating app Bumble termed this trend after seeing a renewed interest in astrology from the Gen Z and millennials. After all, isn’t “What’s your sign?” one of the first questions people always ask on the first date? Bumble’s Astrology badge has become one of the top three most popular lifestyle badges in the country. Recent data showed that users in the Philippines who added the Astrology badge to their dating profile “experienced over 120% more average monthly matches than those without,” Lucille McCart, Bumble’s APAC Communications Director, told Rappler. This badge of your star sign on display allows you to share more about yourself without taking up space in your bio. It even allows you to filter potential matches by star signs. “Astrology has a universal appeal. It can be a fun conversation starter and a fascinating way to understand each other and build the foundations of a healthy and equal relationship,” Lucille said. But can this shared interest enhance your dating journey by helping you form more meaningful connections? Can it also help you find yourself? Bumble resident astrologer and drama therapist Monch the Mystic – Monica Lopez Gamboa – believes that your potential match can be found in the heavens. Using one’s natal birth chart, Monica can break down your astrolove journey by analyzing your signs, your love interest’s or partner’s, and even your love languages and coping mechanisms. Based on my insightful birth chart reading with Monica, I can confirm that astrology can be scarily accurate – as long as you keep your mind and heart open! Before my 1:1 reading with Monica, I was asked to send my birth place, birth time, and birthday – the basics of a birth chart. The reading then started with a presentation of my chart, plus a simple rundown of what I was seeing on my screen (for a first-timer, the chart and symbols can look very chaotic and overwhelming). I’m an Aquarius Sun, Gemini Moon, and Libra Rising. “Your birth chart is a map where all the celestial bodies were when you were born. This snapshot is captured from the exact location, at the exact time of your birth. This is your unique astrological thumbprint – a holistic image of a person which describes both inner and other circumstances and all levels of their personal history and experience,” Monica explained. “The process of understanding our birth chart is the process of embracing our lives. It is the process of radical self-acceptance,” she added, also tying astrology to mental health awareness (they can go hand-in-hand)! Astrology isn’t just for romantic connections – it can help you delve deeper into who you are as a person, friend, sibling, daughter, employee, and loved one. Astrology can supplement inner healing and mental health as serving as a guide in noticing trends and themes in our lives. “We can use astrology to understand first your connection with yourself and which parts needs more attention and healing. It is only once we have done that for ourselves that we are able to in a healthy way, create and sustain healthy partnerships,” Monica said. “It is first knowing your values and priorities to be able to attract people and opportunities that are a match. For other people, astrology can be a wonderful tool to connect and establish genuine relationships with other people.” Note that astrology – as many misconstrue – is not a fortune-teller or a final decision-maker. Rather, it is a tool that can affirm what you already know, or shed some light on hidden aspects about yourself. It can offer guidance or direction, and it lets you “take only what resonates with you” anytime. Several synchronicities in my reading were eerily applicable to my life. According to my birth chart, most of my signs are in the “Fourth House” (most of them Aquarius). The Fourth House symbolizes home and family, and Aquarius is known for being unconventional. Monica pointed out that “a lot has been going on in the home,” which rings true because my family life has been very unpredictable, unstable, and not your textbook definition of “normal.” My Tenth House – which is career – is in Gemini, which is the sign of emotions and communication. Monica said that these are typically good communicators and emotional story-tellers in media or publication careers – and yes, I am a writer! She also mentioned that I am a Libra Rising, which is the social personality. Libras are generally diplomatic, charming, and easygoing peacemakers, but also struggle with saying “no” and being people-pleasers to a fault (raises hand). My Venus – the planet of love and relationships – is in Aquarius, which means that as an idealistic sign, I am most attracted to partners that I can “mentally connect with.” Same interests, same humor, conversations, and even the same goals, values, and vision in life. Since Aquariuses thrive on friendship, community, and companionship, I am most likely to “fall in love with a friend first, who enjoys spending quality time with me.” True enough, my partner now was my best friend from work first. Monica also got my love languages right – words of affirmation and quality time. An Aquarius also prioritizes independence and freedom, and this manifests in my desire to be accepted and loved for who I am authentically; in my relationships, I need to feel like I can be myself 100%. Self-care also looks different for everybody – for the Aquarius, it means enjoying a variety of hobbies (also me) and grounding one’s self with light physical movement when we get “too stuck in our heads.” My Mars – the planet of motivation and desire – is in Capricorn, which means that when it comes to relationships, I am usually in it for the long haul. Even if most of my signs are Air (flighty overthinkers), my Capricorn Mars (an Earth sign) keeps me grounded in terms of long-term relationships and enduring commitments. When it comes to relationships, friends, or work, I have the “stamina” to build the foundation from the bottom up for it to be secure and stable. My partner’s sign is Leo – the confident, self-assured sign. Monica said Aquarius and Leos are compatible and complement each other: when air meets fire, it grows stronger. Air signs are typically chill, and may lack the “fire” to be ambitious. Leos can help provide this motivation and support. On the flip side, since Leos are typically set on a goal, an Aquarius can offer new concepts and ideas to expand his world and help him see the “bigger picture” in life. An Aquarius conceptualizes, and the Leo executes. Leos are usually artists, which also holds true! Monica also mentioned different communication styles between our signs, and how each one’s flaws may come out during arguments, and how to repair conflict better. It was a very eye-opening, validating session that affirmed truths about myself and shed light on personal areas to be aware of. Zodiac signs don’t just come as is: they have both “low road” and “high road” versions, depending on your level of inner work. For example, a “low road Aquarius” is an extremely independent lone wolf, while the “high road Aquarius” thrives in her “tribe” of like-minded people. A “low road Leo” is attached to his pride and ego, while a “high road Leo” is a leader who gets things done. A “low road Aries” is impulsive and self-centered; a “high road Aries” is a passionate leader who fights for the underdogs. A “low road Taurus” is stubborn and greedy; a “high road Taurus” is generous and stable. Astrology is not a one-size-fits-all, take-it-as-it-is approach. Like dating, there is more than meets the eye. “Creating stereotypes about each astrology sign is something so often done. It’s about understanding the development of each sign – the high road and low road – and where the person might be in their development. Even in terms of compatibility, we cannot just be looking at the sun signs of two people and need to take into account the entire chart,” Monica said. In astrology, just like how you can meet your match, you can also encounter your deal-breakers. “In astrology, aspects that are incompatible are often identified as planets in “square,” which forms a 90 degree angle, such as the sign pair Libra and Capricorn. Capricorns can can be seen as self-motivated, often focused on their own goals and valuing tradition, especially in relationships. While both like to initiate, Libra is focused on the other and in maintaining harmony with the other. This is evident in Bumble’s data, which revealed that over the last year (2022) in the Philippines, Libras on Bumble were the luckiest in love! They had the most matches of any star sign, followed by Virgos and Scorpios. When it comes to compatibility, it’s all about finding the sign that balances you out. Compatibility is complementary, and astrology can help you find out what you truly want out of a relationship. Some people do use astrology with passive dependence, using it to pass blame or simply saying “this is who I am, take it or leave it.” Astrology is meant to be a tool for spiritual growth, through understanding ourselves more. If you want your partner to join you in your astrolove journey, go for it! “You don’t need to be talking astrology jargon. Stay in the moment. Don’t preach, practice. Live your chart and observe your experiences instead of reading off what apps say and labeling yourself and others based on it. Use your observations, connections, and experiences of your birth chart to connect with your partner,” Monica said, and most importantly, to connect with yourself. “Let astrology enhance your connection with your matches rather than dictate it. Building a fulfilling relationship involves more than just the stars and the moons. Astrology in online dating gives you a chance to show off personality, and at the same time to also see if the both of you have that initial chemistry that we’re all looking out for,” Lucille said. “It’s always important to navigate relationships with an open heart and an open mind!” – Rappler.com
label: True
title: Is the love of your life written in the stars? What you need to know about astrology and compatibility

text: MANILA, Philippines – After sharing the story of The Traveller Across Dimensions through an album and concert, nine-member Filipino band Ben&Ben is now taking it to new forms. Tracing back to their third studio album release in November 2024, their storytelling began with The Traveller Across Dimensions, which was the title of the album. The band introduced 12 tracks centered on the story of Liwanag, an animated character who was described as an inter-dimensional being who is on a journey to find inner peace. “Liwanag” (light) is also the name of Ben&Ben’s fanbase. By naming the character after their supporters, the concept highlights the shared human experiences of Liwanags. During the band’s 2024 interview on Rappler Talk Entertainment, band member Paolo Benjamin explained that the dimensions in the story serve as an allegory for the human journey. “We wanted to tell the kind of story in one album and one story arc which was etong album na ‘to. And therefore, parang yung Light, Energy, at saka Feel, ‘yun ‘yong dimensions of innocence, of struggle, and of maturity,” he said. (We wanted to tell the kind of story in one album and one story arc, which was this album itself. And therefore, Light, Energy, and Feel are the dimensions of innocence, struggle, and maturity.) Their first-ever major concert at the MOA Arena in December 2024 also shares the same title. The event expanded on their story concept by bringing Liwanag’s story on live stage through animations, projections, and music performances. The concert was structured into three acts: Light, Energy, and Feel. It reflects Liwanag’s story as she travels across three symbolic dimensions of the same name that represent the phases of the human experience. Liwanag’s story goes beyond the album release and concert, as two of its songs were turned into animated music videos. The visual storytelling for “Triumph,” the album’s first track, features Liwanag and her pet companion, Puhon (someday), as they battle a creature using the power of music. Ben&Ben described “Triumph” as a fight song, reflecting the band’s own struggles and those of their listeners who face similar challenges. Meanwhile, “New Dimensions” narrates the earlier part of the character’s story. It depicts her innocence before encountering hardship and pain. Through these two animations released last year, fans were able to further grasp the story of Liwanag. This year, twin singers Paolo and Miguel Benjamin released their co-authored book The Traveller Across Dimensions, turning the narrative that started with their album and concert into a written form. A post shared by Ben&Ben (@benandbenmusic) In an Instagram post, Paolo shared that writing the book allowed him to express his thoughts that music and social media could not fully capture. A post shared by Paolo Benjamin (@paolobenjamin_) “Magkadugtong silang lahat, yung libro, yung mga kanta sa album, at yung traveller plushie,” he wrote. (They’re all connected, the book, the songs in the album, and the traveller plushie.) Before the story begins, the e-book encourages readers to listen to their third album, with its 13 curated songs, to create what the authors describe as a full storytelling experience. Apart from the book, Ben&Ben also surprised fans with new merchandise, the Traveller Plush Series, which was released on the same day, October 28. A post shared by Ben&Ben (@benandbenmusic) Each dimension symbolizes a phase of human experience: Light for innocence, Energy for struggle, and Feel for maturity. Throughout Liwanag’s adventure, the character comes up with existential questions like, “What am I here for?” and “What is my purpose?” Meanwhile, at the end, it leaves readers with an important message, “To be present with love.” The Traveller Across Dimensions features vibrant illustrations by Puppeteer Studios. It is currently available in ebook or PDF format for free on thetravelleracrossdimensions.com. – Alessandria Corral/Rappler.com Alessandria Corral is a Rappler intern studying Bachelor of Arts in Speech Communication at University of the Philippines Diliman.
label: True
title: From stage to page: How Ben&Ben tells Liwanag’s story in different forms

text: MANILA, Philippines – In a city where most of us rush from commutes to the classroom or the office and back, cafés have become “third spaces” — places where Gen Z and young professionals socialize, study, and hang out. These spaces have become small antidotes to the daily grind, promising a pause, a seat, and a ritual. While coffee’s familiar bitterness has long fueled Metro Manila’s mornings, matcha has emerged as its calmer counterpart: grassy, vibrant, and endlessly versatile. From ceremonial whisking to cocktail fusions, cafés are reinterpreting the green tea ritual for a new generation of café-goers. This reimagining of matcha takes many forms at up-and-coming, mom-and-pop cafés around Metro Manila. For example, in Forbes Town, Taguig City, each homegrown café offers its own spin on how to enjoy the trendy powdered green tea, reflecting the city’s evolving tastes and café culture. Here are some cafés exploring different matcha experiences, depending on your preferences. At Chotto Matcha, the focus is on purity and provenance. The café sources its tea from small, family-owned farms in Shizuoka, Japan, ensuring that every leaf is cultivated with care rather than mass-produced. Handpicked by the founder and ground with stone to preserve both flavor and nutrients, the matcha highlights the quiet craftsmanship often overshadowed by larger brands. Chotto Matcha’s interiors are warm and intimate, designed with wood-panel ceilings and walls that give the shop a clean, natural feel. A stone-textured wall frames the counter, where drinks are prepared in full view, emphasizing transparency and craft. Despite the minimalist design, the vibe feels cozy rather than austere: soft lighting, neatly arranged tools and utensils, and the occasional whisking of matcha create a sense of calm ritual. The menu includes Authentic Matcha Latte (P205) from Mt. Fuji, Local Matcha Latte (P205) for a sweeter note, Strawberry Matcha (P220), Matcha Lemonade (P220), Dirty Matcha (P240), and Hanami Matcha (P250). Despite the emphasis on tradition, they also experiment with playful drinks such as the Marshmallow Cloudy Matcha (P220), Ube Matcha Einspanner (P270), Banana Pudding Matcha (P270), Coconut Matcha (P250), and Matcha Float (P305). Meanwhile, the pastry case is stacked with matcha cakes, roll cakes, cookies, and the trendy “crookie” (cookie meets croissant) pastries, available in Matcha, Choco Chip, and Biscoff flavors and priced at P270 each. Matcha Mama stands out for putting green tea at the very center of its concept. This specialty bar builds its identity around it — from sourcing premium matcha from Uji, Kyoto to crafting drinks that highlight its versatility. Matcha Mama trades in a brighter, more playful aesthetic. Its counter is rendered in soft blush pink, accented by gold-letter signage and pastel tiles underfoot, giving the kiosk a distinctly modern look. The Classic Matcha menu lists familiar favorites like the Matcha Latte (P160), as well as the Spanish Matcha (P170) with condensed milk, Matcha Chai (P180), Lavender Matcha (P190), Matcha Horchata (P210) — its signature drink using rice milk and cinnamon — and White Chocolate Matcha (P230). If you want to take things up a notch, they also offer a Ceremonial Matcha line, which mirrors many of these drinks but uses a higher-grade, stone-ground powder traditionally whisked with water. The Specialty Matcha includes the Pink Sea Salt Matcha Latte (P240), Vanilla Oat Matcha (P210), Honey Matcha (P190), and Strawberry Matcha (P250), which adds strawberry milk and strawberry jam. The overall vibe is light and trendy, compact but stylish; a natural stop for anyone who treats their matcha order as both drink and small ritual. DEN by Nikkei takes matcha out of the teahouse and into something bolder. As the café arm of Nikkei, a Japanese-Peruvian fusion restaurant, it treats matcha less as a ritual of purity and more as an ingredient to experiment with. The place blends the warm aesthetic of a modern Japanese izakaya with a more sophisticated bar setup. It feels casual enough for drinks with friends and refined enough for date nights. The overall atmosphere is both contemporary and rooted in tradition — a space where late-night drinks and quiet ritual co-exist. Unlike the last two stops, DEN by Nikkei doesn’t wear its matcha heart on its sleeve. The menu skews toward Japanese-Peruvian fusion with little in the way of overt matcha offerings, which makes the new Matcha Grasshopper (P395) stand out. Built with sake, Giffard Menthe de Pastille, white chocolate matcha sauce, and fresh mint, it’s a fusion that leans into indulgence, reimagining matcha not as a calm ritual but as a playful accent in a cocktail glass. Because matcha appears here sparingly, its presence feels more like a nod to Nikkei’s Japanese roots than a menu filler. It’s a small discovery for matcha fans — not the main reason to visit — but a surprise in its fusion-driven lineup. Overall, DEN by Nikkei is ideal for adventurous drinkers who like their matcha with a twist and less about quiet ritual and more about sleek cocktails and bold experimentation. Better known for its brick-oven pizzas, Pizzulu offers a different approach to matcha through its café arm, Caffé Pizzulu. Rather than making matcha the star, Caffé Pizzulu folds it into a lineup of inventive specialty drinks. This is where coffee lovers and matcha lovers can meet in the middle, showing how matcha can thrive alongside espresso and other flavors. Pizzulu’s Forbes Town branch radiates sleek sophistication with its soft beige walls, marble textures, and golden lighting that washes the room in a gentle glow. Round tables, cushioned banquettes, and modern wooden chairs make the dining area feel both upscale and inviting, while floor-to-ceiling glass panels open the restaurant into the street, blending indoor polish with the urban view. The signature coffees include Seasalt Cold Foam Latte (P195), Coconut Espresso Slush (P225), which fuses the tropical taste of coconut with the bitterness of espresso, and the Banana Cereal Cold Foam Latte (P246), which blends banana and cereal flavors in a creamy, fluffy latte. On the matcha end, Caffé Pizzulu offers the classic Matcha Latte (P210) as well as the Matcha Banana Cold Foam Latte (P275), which adds banana syrup and tops it with a light vanilla cold foam. A space that balances coffee’s sense of productivity with matcha’s calmer ritual, Pizzulu feels elegant enough for focused work but relaxed enough for slow conversations over pizza and a caffeinated drink. These cafés show that matcha in Manila is no longer just a passing trend but a canvas: pure and mindful for the traditionalist, colorful and sweet for the aesthetic-minded, hybrid and playful for the adventurous, and paired with coffee for those chasing balance. Beyond the drinks themselves, these interpretations reveal how cafés in the city are shaping shared rituals for a busy, fragmented urban life. – Rappler.com
label: True
title: A matcha map of Manila: Rituals, reinventions, and café culture

text: MANILA, Philippines – Tourists, especially budget-conscious Filipinos who go abroad to shop at lower prices, often make shoe store ABC-MART part of their Japan itinerary to cop their favorite pairs of sneakers at tax-free prices. Starting in 1985 in Japan, ABC-MART grew exponentially across the country, opening more than 1,000 stores in just a few decades. Soon after, it expanded to other Asian markets. This concept of budget shoes eventually evolved into a new, more premium format: ABC-MART Grand Stage, first introduced in Japan in the 2010s. The Grand Stage concept leans towards the more higher-end selection of sneakers and lifestyle footwear, still curated for the mainstream sneaker crowd but with more thought on design, exclusivity, and the customer experience. After successful rollouts in Japan across key cities like Hyōgo, Sasebo, and Yokohama, ABC-MART Grand Stage specifically eyed Southeast Asian growth. And after expanding to South Korea, Taiwan, China, and Vietnam, the concept has made it to the Philippines for the first time. The store launch is part of a larger joint venture between ABC-MART Japan and Sonak Retail Group, which plans to expand both Grand Stage and Standard store formats nationwide starting October. Sonak Retail Group, a division of Sonak Corporation, operates over 40 retail stores in the Philippines, representing brands such as Onitsuka Tiger, ASICS, Molten, Mikasa, and Mueller, among others. “This is one of our first 4.0 stores in Southeast Asia,” said Koji Higashimae, CEO of ABC-MART Sonak Philippines. “We’re introducing not only a wide selection of top footwear brands, but also the spirit of Japanese service and retail innovation that has made ABC-MART Grand Stage a trusted brand.” Kabir Buxani, director of Sonak Retail Group, added that the Philippine ABC Mart experience was thoughtfully curated for this market — from its design, store layout, selections, and exclusive drops. The two-level store in Bonifacio High Street, BGC spans two floors across 750 square meters of sneakers, shoes, caps, and workout gear. Shelves of limited-edition releases and exclusive drops from brands like Nike, Adidas, Puma, ASICS, Vans, New Balance, Saucony, Salomon, Patrick, and Crocs merge with the space’s Japanese minimalism and modern retail design. The Philippines already has a growing sneaker culture, fueled by the resale market, pop-ups, online “pasabuys,” and other global retail chains. Competing in a crowded sneaker scene has its challenges; how does ABC-MART Grand Stage plan to play the game? The Sonak Retail Group said that the Manila branch has the concept’s first Wellness Corner: a dedicated area with a running space where customers and runners can test footwear performance and comfort. There’s also the brand’s ABCLUB loyalty program, which offers perks like cashback, birthday discounts, free shipping, and early access to exclusive drops. The launch of an official online store is also in the pipeline. For the Japanese company, it’s about adapting to shifting consumer habits. As observed through the years, Filipinos want a more experiential, personalized, and curated shopping experience, and ABC-MART’s Southeast Asia expansion plans to bank on this mindset, combining the retail experience with selective brand partnerships and lifestyle positioning to stay relevant in a fast-evolving industry. ABC-MART Grand Stage is open at C1, Bonifacio High Street Central, 5th Avenue corner 28th Street, Bonifacio Global City, Taguig, from 11 am to 10 pm on Sundays through Thursdays, and until 11 pm on Fridays and Saturdays. – Rappler.com
label: True
title: Japan’s ABC-MART Grand Stage steps into Manila, eyes Southeast Asia growth

text: MANILA, Philippines —Two masters of Japanese cuisine bring their expertises to one intimate omakase table at The Counter at Ginza One, Makati City on October 12-19. “Masters in Harmony” is a weeklong omakase experience, where chef Masahiko Kodama and chef Kengo Tomita from Japan will display the precision and soul that comes with Japanese craftsmanship. From yakitori to wagyu, these chefs serve up different forms and expressions of their beloved specialties. Hailing all the way from Japan for this multicourse experience is Kodama, dubbed the “Yakitori God.” His restaurant in Tokyo, Yakitori Masakichi, had been awarded the Michelin Bib Gourmand Distinction. He has been featured in Netflix’s Ugly Delicious episode on barbecue, earning an emotional hug from the host, David Cheng, after he tried his yakitori. This is where Ginza and Ginza One owners Pepper and Jae Guanio first heard of him. On a family visit to Japan, the couple took a long walk just to try his iconic yakitori. And the journey proved to be worth it after just one bite — the yakitori was as good as its reviews. After great efforts and a lot of convincing, Kodama finally visited Manila and eventually agreed on the collaboration with the family-owned yakitori restaurant, which opened in 2024. Kodama helms the creation of The Counter’s yakitori menu, utilizing almost every piece of the chicken in simple but exquisitely tasting ways; he retains most of his signatures while experimenting with seasonal ingredients and new techniques. Kodama now flies to Manila every month for a week or so to do constant R&D and menu improvement with the Guanio family. This time, Kodama is working with another set of hands as Tomita brings his neo-washuku style of modern Japanese cuisine to The Counter’s kitchen for the first time. Tomita has been all around the world, spending 20 years in Spain at three-Michelin-starred restaurant Arzak, then working in Dubai and the Maldives. He later made his way to the Philippines as the executive chef of the premiere resort, Amanpulo. In June, he was appointed executive chef of the Ginza Group, refining the kitchen’s techniques and menu with his modern yet authentic culinary style, with 30 years of international culinary experience under his belt. These two culinary masters from Japan will thoughtfully curate a tasting menu this month at The Counter, an extension of the Ginza One restaurant located on the ground floor of Ecoplaza Building, Chino Roces Avenue Extension in Makati City. Guests won’t know the exact menu until they are seated — since it is an omakase, the night’s dishes are completely up to the chefs. Limited seats are available for the multicourse lunch or dinner. Guests can reserve their spot by calling +639176212171 or messaging on Instagram. — Steph Arnaldo and Alyana Fabella/Rappler.com Alyana Fabella is a Rappler intern studying Bachelor of Arts in Communication at the Ateneo de Manila University.
label: True
title: Two Japanese chefs, one omakase: A weeklong experience at The Counter
