text: MANILA, Philippines – Christmas and New Year are often described as festive, with families and friends reuniting and catching up after months of work and routine. But for some, the holidays bring stress. In a report released by the Department of Health (DOH) on Monday, December 29, the National Center for Mental Health (NCMH) received 675 calls since December 21. Most frequent callers, the DOH said, are those aged 18 to 30. It added that the majority of the callers are female. The most common reason for reaching out was symptoms of anxiety or depression, followed by relationship issues and family problems. Clinical psychologist Rea Villa shared that she has a surge of patients — many of which were first-time patients — during the holidays. “From a [psychologist’s] perspective, ‘yung holidays kasi amplify what we call emotional load. So, ito, combination kasi ‘yung emotional load ng pressure, expectations, responsibilities, and actually, mga unresolved emotions,” Villa told Rappler. (From a psychologist’s perspective, holidays amplify what we call emotional load – it is a combination of pressure, expectations, responsibilities, and unresolved emotions.) Villa said there are several factors that affect a person’s mental health: psychological, social, economic, and biological. Psychological factors include unresolved grief and past trauma. Some social factors, meanwhile, are family conflict and receiving unsolicited comments. Financial constraints and gift-giving pressure fall under economic factors. Biological factors such as disrupted sleep, increased alcohol consumption, and lack of routine also affect mental health. “‘Yung mental health [issue] kasi in general is never caused by just one thing; interaction siya ng stressors without enough emotional recovery,” Villa said. (A mental health issue, in general, is never caused by just one thing; but by an interaction of stressors without enough emotional recovery.) If a person is already experiencing a toll on their mental health, Villa said the first step is to acknowledge the feeling. “It’s always good to ask why. Bakit ka nalulungkot? Are there reasons for it or ano kaya ‘yun? Introspection ‘yung kailangan, like a deep reflection of yourself and what’s happening would help a lot,” she said. (Why are you sad? Are there reasons for it, what are those? We need introspection, like a deep reflection of yourself and what’s happening would help a lot.) Villa said it would also help to have safe social support. Social support means having people you can lean on and who make you feel heard. A person should also have coping mechanisms that can help soothe them when they feel overwhelmed. Among the coping mechanisms are journaling, meditating, and going out with friends. Villa said coping mechanisms vary, depending on the person’s preference. But when feelings of hopelessness or thoughts of self-harm intensify, they should immediately seek help. Those struggling with their mental health may call the NCMH Crisis Hotline at 1553. Villa further advised the public to be conscious and sensitive of their words and actions as it may be hurtful for others. “[The] holiday season doesn’t need to be emotionally perfect to be meaningful. Sometimes, choosing being gentle, being kind, having that support is the healthiest way to honor the season and to honor yourself,” she said. As the New Year approaches, Villa urged people to be kinder to themselves, move at their own pace, let go of what drained them, and carry forward what helped them survive — as they prepare mentally for the year ahead. – Rappler.com
label: True
title: Caring for mental health during the holidays

text: Are you up for an eccentric adventure – one where you don’t need to buckle your seat belt or buy a ticket, but may instead find yourself tucked into a warm blanket? If you are, then cozy up! This “trip” virtually takes you to different places in the Philippines through the magic of binge-watching local films. For cinephiles and casual moviegoers alike, the experience is not only about resonating with a film’s storyline but also about being enthralled by the places where its scenes come to life. Whether a spot is buried in or woven directly into the plot, it’s undeniable that a film’s shooting location shapes the overall movie experience. Jazz in Love documents the love story of young gay man Jazz with a German military staff, Theodor. This film is set in Jazz’s hometown, Malita, Davao Occidental, where he learns the Deutsch language as part of Germany’s migration requirement. Jazz introduces Theodor to the Davaoeno culture during his birthday visit to the province. The film showcases the place’s rich natural environment, but more than that, it serves as a moving snapshot of the locals’ everyday lives. Watch the full movie here. Can’t get enough of Baguio City? Then the iconic That Thing Called Tadhana is perfect for you. The movie follows Mace (Angelica Panganiban) and Anthony (JM de Guzman) on a spontaneous adventure in Baguio City and Sagada. Mace and Anthony are both heartbroken; they are trying to run off painful emotions and experiences. This storyline, together with the film’s astounding cinematography, romanticizes the highlands’ escapist charm, especially for people living in the lowlands. The film passes by several tourist hotspots in Baguio City, like the BenCab Museum and Cafe by the Ruins. It further spotlights Sagada’s Mt. Kiltepan, where the peak reaches and exceeds the clouds. In Crazy Beautiful You, black sheep child Jackie (Kathryn Bernardo) meets her total opposite, Kiko (Daniel Padilla), when she was forced to tag along on her mother’s medical mission in Capas, Tarlac. Beyond the unwinding love story between the two teenagers — and the undertone of growing up in dysfunctional families — the film accentuates the Aeta community in Sitio Tarukan, Capas, and showcases the pulling scenery of Lake and Mt. Pinatubo, the beautiful results of a volcanic disaster. Following heartbroken Cielo (Alessandra De Rossi) on her local adventure — in a quest to find her mystery post-card sender and in hopes of developing a new romantic connection — Sakaling Hindi Makarating features five different provinces from Luzon, Visayas, and Mindanao. For one, the film highlights Zamboanga’s rich culture and tradition through the Regatta de Zamboanga festival, an annual boat race that stresses not just the province’s affluent maritime heritage, but also the Chavaconos’ creativity and excellent boat craftsmanship. Along her journey, Cielo learns to appreciate Marinduque’s wood artistry, too, as Manuel (JC Santos) teaches her how to make a wood mask, an essential to the province’s famous holy-week tradition, Moriones Festival. Apart from these spots, Sakaling Hindi Makarating captures so well the alluring sceneries of Siquijor, Ilocos Norte (Pagudpud), and Batanes (Basco). Together with her sons, Jude (Chai Fonacier), Jay (Melde Montañez), and Hubert (Vincent Viado), and their dog Judas, single mother Iyay (Jacklyn Jose) goes on a long road trip from Cebu to Dumaguete City to attend the wake of her children’s father. Crammed together in a red mini-van, the dysfunctional family humorously confronts matters within and beyond the social unit. The trip takes on different stops in Cebu province, including San Fernando, Carcar City, Sibonga, and Santander. Among the featured locations in Patay na si Hesus are Pitalo Chapel and Simala Shrine. When the family reaches Dumaguete, a closer relationship apparently develops, as seen in the scene set in Rizal Boulevard, where the three sons talk about their wake preferences while indulging in a box of the city’s delicacy, silvanas. Filmed around different locations in La Union, My Amanda can arguably stand alone with its storyline: life-long friends Fuffy (Piolo Pascual) and Fream (Alessandra De Rossi) navigate different life stages together — from a loop of endings, to a completely new beginning. However, the film is, dare to say, a complete package. The setting of each scene, enhanced by excellent videography and color grading, just adds more depth to the story. For instance, Fuffy and Fream’s comical and intimate conversations become even more soulful — and literally, beautiful — because they were either set under the stars, on a beach at night, or on a road that looks like a tunnel of canopy trees. These scenes were filmed in Paraoir Man Made Forest located along a 500-meter highway in Almeida, Balaoan, the coastal areas in San Juan, and the Thunderbird Resort Poro Point in the city of San Fernando. This movie captures not only an unfolding love story between former schoolmates Dee (Janine Guiterrez) and Endong (Pepe Herrera), but also the pristine beauty of the Bicol region — in a successful attempt to showcase the rich natural environment of the film’s two featured provinces. Set in Cagraray, Albay (particularly in Misibis Bay), and Bulusan, Sorsogon, Ikaw serves as a snapshot of the simple, often conservative lifestyle of Bicolanos, as well as their value of having a tight knit community. It also pictures the region’s primary livelihood, agriculture, through Endong’s small “kupra” (coconut) business. Strangers Uly (Carlos Aquino) and Ikay (Eisel Serrano) turn into lovers, in one place, but in two entirely different timezones — all because of mysterious two-way radios. The storyline of Love You Long Time may be enough reason to watch the film, after all, it takes inspiration from Kimi no Na wa, a Japanese animated film that Filipinos have come to love. However, beyond the plot, the movie proves the undying appeal of Baguio City, featuring some of its famous spots like the Mountain Lodge Hotel and Wright Park. Love You Long Time also takes its shot to showcase the natural, captivating beauty of Atok, Benguet — the home of Luzon’s third highest mountain, Mt. Timbak, and various flower hotspots like the Northern Blossom Flower Farm and Sakura Park. A psychological thriller might not be the first thing you’ll reach for when you want to get a glimpse of a province’s beauty, but trust us on this. Outside follows the story of Francis (Sid Lucero) and his family, his wife Iris (Beauty Gonzales), and their children Joshua (Marco Masa) and Lucas (Aiden Tyler Patdu), as they unpack personal and family baggage in the midst of a zombie apocalypse. Outside is filmed in La Carlota and Kabankalan cities in Negros Occidental, showcasing sugar fields and abandoned sites that, when color graded on the mark, evokes eerie visual scenes. One of the particular locations spotlighted in the film is St. Francis Xavier Cathedral. This film itinerary attests that tourist spots are no longer beyond your reach. Thanks to moving pictures and streaming platforms, you can now go on an adventure — this time, in the comfort of your own bed, or in the solace of your third place. – Rappler.com Deanne Reese Imperial is a Rappler intern studying journalism at the University of Santo Tomas.
label: True
title: Virtual travel? Watch these 9 films for a breathtaking glimpse at the Philippines

text: MANILA, Philippines – Ever wonder what happens to secondhand kimonos from Japan? As no two kimonos are ever the same, each piece is often owned by families and passed down through generations. But what happens when the younger ones no longer wear the traditional Japanese robe that their grandparents used to? The premium silk or cotton fabric and the intricate hand-drawn designs risk being discarded, ending their lineage — thrown away, never to be worn again. But not on Marjorie Resuello-Kobayashi’s watch. The 32-year-old Filipino lecturer and entrepreneur based in Laguna saw an opportunity to bridge the two cultures she loves, guided by her advocacy for sustainability. Why not take these discarded kimonos and sew new life into them? As they say, another man’s trash is another woman’s handwoven treasure, and for Marjorie, this saying became the catalyst of her family-run business, Cool Kimono Crafts, which slowly stitched itself up in 2021, starting with handsewn face masks made from discarded kimono cloth patches. Today, the Cool Kimono Crafts line uses the cultural beauty, smooth fabric, and distinctly intricate patterns of kimonos and transforms them into Filipiniana pieces — traditional sleeves and cuts reimagined as modern Filipiniana formalwear, barong, or even casual t-shirts for men and women. Her creations have already made it to London and New York Fashion Week runways, worn proudly not just by models of all ages and sizes but also by people from around the world who take pride in wearing two pieces of Asian culture in one stylish garment. Cool Kimono Crafts made its artisanal local debut at ArteFino Fair in Rockwell last August; her hybrid creations presented on mannequins stopped amazed fairgoers in their tracks. “I was so surprised about the reception, especially since it was my first time, and my booth setup was so simple compared to other, more established brands. I was so nervous,” Marjorie told Rappler. “But since nakakaiba siya, it worked. It’s something that promotes friendship between the Philippines and Japan. It’s diplomacy. And it’s sustainable. It’s something unique for them. I think that’s why it catches their attention,” she said. For a brand that only started in 2021, Marjorie didn’t have high hopes yet; but what she did have was her passion for the earth. As a Sustainable Development Goals (SDG) and English professor in Japan, she knew her advocacy had to be woven into whatever she pursued. “During the pandemic, travel halted and disposable masks harmed marine species,” she said. “I would share good practices of other people, but I didn’t really have my own. So, that’s where I started. In 2021, during the pandemic, I began the project. At first, I didn’t promote it seriously — just to friends,” she said. Her first kimono masks used cotton, not silk, since masks had to be double-layered. She experimented with scrunchies and other hair accessories, and shortly after, decided to expand and promote more. “I wanted the masks to be sustainable and fashionable while also bringing a piece of Japan closer to Filipinos who couldn’t travel. It unexpectedly became popular,” she added. By 2024, the business expanded into tote bags, messenger bags, pouches, accessories, passport holders, and the “Kimono Filipiniana.” She joined fashion shows and community bazaars in Japan that celebrated international friendship between Filipinos and Japanese. Later, back home, she joined a university bazaar in her alma mater, University of the Philippines (UP) Los Baños, during Women’s Month in March — her first bazaar in the Philippines. The biggest one so far was ArteFino. Marjorie first fell in love with Japan in 2014, when she presented her undergraduate research at a conference. “It had always been a dream of mine to visit Japan, though it was very expensive. I sought sponsors, and thankfully, I was able to come,” she said. In 2015, UP Los Baños partnered with Nagoya University, which became her school. As a master’s student, she joined both short-term and long-term exchange programs. After her master’s, she pursued a PhD in International Development, returning in 2017. The pandemic, however, disrupted her fieldwork in the Philippines, delaying her dissertation. Around the same time, she received a job offer to become a university researcher, which she prioritized. Today, she is in her third academic year teaching as a lecturer at a university of foreign studies in Japan, invited to teach both English and SDGs in universities and high schools. But amid her quest for knowledge, at what point did Cool Kimono Crafts come in? “The first time I wore a kimono,” she recalled. It was in 2016. during her long-term exchange program. “That experience amazed me. I felt something so special wearing it and wanted to do it again. I got to know more about Japanese culture beyond anime, cars, and manga. Kimono opened another door for me,” she shared. By 2017, while working part-time teaching SDGs, her heart opened up not only to the beauty of the kimono but also to the possibility of love. “In 2018, I met my husband through a common friend, my churchmate in Japan. At that time, I wasn’t looking for a relationship. But we started hanging out as a group, we got to know each other more,” she shared. In 2019, they began dating, and in August 2023, they got married. Kimono Crafts started as — and is still — a mom-and-pop family business. Her mother, skilled in sewing, helps Marjorie bring her designs to life, while her father, who retired early, now handles logistics and driving. Being the eldest of five, Marjorie is in charge of conceptualization until the final result — vision, sketching, finance, and marketing, though social media is her weak point, she admitted. However, she shared that her mother’s job is the hardest — the sewing of kimonos is “extremely challenging because you have to preserve the flow of the kimono’s patterns,” Marjorie explained. Her sister makes accessories and also models for the brand, which boosts her confidence, Marjorie fondly shared. Her other siblings help with logistics and marketing. For now, they are still operating from their home in Laguna, where clients come for fittings, but Marjorie is hoping for a standalone boutique shop soon. Marjorie said they cater to both Japanese and Filipino buyers, making zero-waste items such as T-shirt patches and kimono earrings, priced from P850 to P1,200, which her sister makes to help with her tuition. Dresses and gowns, such as the kimono Filipiniana pieces, cost around P17,000, with both ready-to-wear and customized designs at the same price and with clients able to choose their fabric and colors. “Each kimono is unique — often hand-painted and bearing the artist’s seal — so every piece is one of a kind.” Marjorie’s relationships with trusted shops in Japan are just as important, too — this is where she sources her silk kimonos, many of which have piles of unused or unsold pieces. “Sayang, kasi bawat isa (It’s wasteful, because every piece) is a work of art. Mahal ang silk (Silk is expensive), and yet they were just being discarded.” “That’s why I love working with the Japanese. Once you establish trust with them, they will really support you. I admire their ethics — they take pride in craftsmanship and value trust. That’s something I want to bring into my own brand as well: building trust with people.” Like the Filipiniana, kimonos in Japan are now rarely worn — at weddings, funerals, tea ceremonies, or the coming of age at 20. For Marjorie, this similarity deepened her drive to bring these cultural symbols back, but in novel ways. “I was really surprised by the number of inquiries! Mostly women in their 30s and above are my customers, though some men, too,” she said. Marjorie also came up with the “bundle” idea — since each kimono is one of a kind, why not use one kimono and create six items out of it? For Marjorie, it was part of her zero-waste approach. “Each part of the kimono is used. We don’t waste anything, which is important for us. That way, we honor the material and the culture it represents.” It’s a labor of love that every member of the family contributes to — each design takes two weeks to a month to finish, all handmade, depending on where the kimono is sourced. “The Philippines and Japan are friends, after all. Through my designs, I want to honor that relationship, promote sustainability, and serve as a bridge.” Cool Kimono Crafts’ big break came in January 2024, on Marjorie’s birthday, when she staged her own fashion show in Tagaytay. “It was my first time, so, of course, we even had a same-day edit! We presented all our items — bags, kimono Filipiniana, even kimono suits. Many inquired, mostly women in their 30s, and even men,” she said in a mix of English and Filipino. The same-day edit posted on Facebook caught attention, leading to an invitation to New York Fashion Week. While she couldn’t join on short notice then, her designs still appeared on a Times Square billboard, much to her glee. But in September 2025, Marjorie’s designs finally graced the runways of New York Fashion Week and London Fashion Week — a feat she never imagined possible when she first started with face masks back in 2021. “It’s never too late to rediscover your strengths,” Marjorie said. Recognition from fashion icons like Renee Salud, who praised her designs and expressed interest in collaborating after one of her shows, keeps Marjorie raring to go but grounded. And being invited to fashion shows in New York and London this September is proof, she said, “that Filipino creativity, craftsmanship, and heart can stand on the global stage.” But why is this cultural collaboration so important to Marjorie? Aside from the business bringing her family closer, she wants to remind everyone that the Philippines and Japan are friends. “Filipinos are among the top migrant workers here, especially in Aichi Prefecture, where I live. In the Philippines, so many Japanese companies have factories in Laguna, where I’m from,” she said. “There are strong cultural and economic ties between the two countries. And through my designs, I want to honor that relationship, promote sustainability, and serve as a bridge,” Marjorie added. It’s nowhere to go but up for Marjorie, who has actually never formally studied fashion design. Her brand has been invited to bazaars organized by the Japanese Embassy, and she’s launching kimono sandals in Tokyo with a Laguna-based brand soon. “I don’t have a fashion background — I just wanted to wear fashionable clothes. But passion led me here,” she said. And with that spirit, there is sew much more in store for Cool Kimono Crafts’ handwoven future. – Rappler.com
label: True
title: Sew unique! This Pinay designer bridges cultures with Filipiniana made from kimono

text: MANILA, Philippines – The Securities and Exchange Commission (SEC) has revoked the registrations of two Discaya-owned firms for failing to disclose beneficial ownership information. In resolutions dated November 26, the SEC Enforcement and Investor Protection Department canceled the certificates of incorporation of St. Timothy Construction Corporation and St. Gerrard Construction General Contractor and Development Corporation. The two firms were also ordered to pay a penalty of P2 million each. Their directors were further disqualified from being a director, trustee, or officer of any corporation for five years. The corporate watchdog cited a Senate blue ribbon committee hearing on September 1, when Sarah Discaya admitted she was the owner and officer of St. Timothy and St. Gerrard. The SEC noted that Discaya’s involvement was not disclosed in St. Timothy’s beneficial ownership declarations from 2022 to September 2025, and St. Gerrard’s from 2022 to 2024. Discaya said in April that she divested from St. Timothy in 2018. “The failure of St. Timothy and St. Gerrard to disclose [Discaya] as their beneficial owner constituted a violation of SEC MC No. 15, Series of 2019, as amended by MC No. 10, Series of 2022, which required companies to submit their beneficial ownership information as part of their general information sheets,” the SEC explained. The corporate regulator also noted that it gave both companies 15 calendar days to explain their side, but neither complied with this. According to a report by the Philippine Center for Investigative Journalism, the Discayas’ nine construction firms bagged 421 government projects worth P31 billion. St. Timothy and Alpha & Omega — another Discaya firm — were among the top 15 contractors of flood control projects nationwide. – Rappler.com
label: True
title: SEC revokes 2 Discaya firms’ registration over false ownership information

text: On September 30, Tuesday, the Senate committee on government corporations and public enterprises (CGPE) conducted a hearing to probe alleged malfeasance committed specifically by the Government Service Insurance System (GSIS). During that particular session, it was found out that the GSIS still has to account for its investment in Alternergy Holdings Corporation which the pension fund president Jose Arnulfo “Wick” Veloso promised to immediately address. For context, Vantage Point had exposed on July 22 that Alternergy had insufficient market capitalization/financial strength and its market capitalization was way below the minimum required under GSIS investment rules. Alternergy was also heavily leveraged (i.e. high debt relative to equity) and had weak interest coverage, which made it financially risky. We also reported that the shares (preferred shares) purchased by the GSIS were not listed on the Philippine Stock Exchange (PSE) at the time the agreement and payment were made. Since GSIS rules require investments in listed companies (or at least properly listed securities) for such equity exposures, this non-listing is a violation. Representatives of the Commission on Appointments (COA) validated Vantage Point’s exposé during that CGPE hearing. Recently, I found out that Stronghold Insurance Co. Inc. (SICI) — the company which provided bonds to the Department of Public Works and Highways (DPWH) flood control projects of Pacifico “Curlee” Discaya II and Cezarah Rowena “Sarah” Cruz Discaya and where Senator Rodante Marcoleta’s wife Edna is an independent director — is also the reinsurer of the GSIS. SICI won in 2023 the Reinsurance of the GSIS Property and Engineering Combined Risk and Catastrophe Excess of Loss Treaty Service with a total coverage of P14 billion. It is an agreement aimed at safeguarding government and private properties against unforeseen events. Was this a coincidence or just one of the many absurd things happening in the Senate these days? Another absurdity is the fact that the Senate CGPE, chaired by Senator Mark Villar, is also being investigated along with his family enterprises for a far more serious transgression. Such is the sad state into which that erstwhile esteemed institution has spiraled. What began as a moment of reckoning for contractors, legislators, and bureaucrats who fattened themselves off taxpayers’ money is now turning into a circus of self-preservation and selective amnesia. The promise of accountability has been washed away by political undercurrents that seek to confuse, divide, and exhaust the public, and dampen their moral outrage. At the heart of the investigation lies a fatal flaw: the absence of independence and prosecutorial coherence. Each committee, commission, or lawmaker now seems more engaged in finger-pointing. The Senate drags in witnesses with dubious backgrounds; the House selectively names enemies while shielding allies; and the so-called “independent commission” has been gutted by resignations, political meddling, and lack of subpoena power. The result? A fragmented inquisition where every camp tries to weaponize testimony rather than uncover facts. Early on, along with majority of Filipinos, I had high hopes that justice would at last catch up with the entrenched network of fixers and contractors who for years have been turning flood-control projects into a cottage industry. But the supposed “star witnesses” — some of whom are accused masterminds themselves — have converted the hearings into a theater of convenience. They remember only what benefits them, name only those from rival factions, and plead innocence in the same breath as they confess to massive bribery. It was an execrable script written for a scenario that echoes past scandals which ended in hollow verdicts. This selective disclosure has crippled the integrity of the probe. Instead of building a timeline of graft and corruption, investigators are now chasing ghosts of allegations that shift weekly. The COA, Ombudsman, and Department of Justice (DOJ) should have been the backbone of this inquiry. Unfortunately, their findings are being drowned by political noise and media sensationalism. Perhaps the most damning proof of this circus’ collapse is how the investigators themselves have become the investigated. Senators are being accused of bias, committee chairs are facing ethics complaints, and even members of the so-called “independent” commission are being scrutinized for alleged conflicts of interest and leaks. What was supposed to be a search for truth has degenerated into a circular firing squad — a tragicomic spectacle where everyone claims to be clean, while pointing dirty fingers at each other. It’s a level of absurdity that defies logic: the accusers now demanding immunity, the enforcers pleading innocence, and the supposed watchdogs biting each other instead of the culprits. When truth commissions turn into mutual defense clubs, justice is no longer the goal — damage control is. And the public, forced to watch this farce, learns the worst lesson of all: that corruption probes in this country rarely punish the guilty, but almost always devour the honest. The credibility crisis of the Discayas, and the spectacle of senators like Marcoleta turning witnesses into martyrs, all point to a deliberate campaign to blur, not reveal, the truth. The COA’s red flags on DPWH contracts are being buried under political noise; the Ombudsman has yet to file a single solid case; and the DOJ seems paralyzed by factional pressure. Accountability cannot survive in a swamp of politicking. Unless this probe is rescued from self-interest and rebuilt on forensic evidence — not confessions traded for protection — it will produce nothing more than a deluge of wasted time and the reaffirmation that, in the Philippines, every flood finds a way to rise and justice always sinks first. In the Senate, former Senate president Francis Joseph “Chiz” Escudero is sparring with House allies of former speaker Martin Romualdez, each accusing the other of politicizing the probe. The Independent Commission for Infrastructure (ICI) created by Malacañang — once hailed as a neutral truth-seeker — has been gutted by the resignation of Baguio Mayor Benjamin Magalong and exacerbated by the public’s growing mistrust with the ongoing ICI investigation which, according to its executive director Brian Osaka must be kept closed-doors. These troubling developments symbolized what many feared from the start: the commission was never meant to expose the full rot, only to manage the fallout. Senator Marcoleta and his bloc have gone to extraordinary lengths to vouch for their witnesses’ credibility — even suggesting witness protection — despite glaring inconsistencies and a lawyer’s denial of ever signing their affidavit. Escudero thunders against corruption in flood-control projects even as questions mount over his own alleged fund insertions in DPWH allocations. Documents flagged by auditors reportedly trace questionable items tied to local projects in Escudero’s political stronghold — projects inserted late in the budget process and now under quiet review. Meanwhile, former DPWH Secretary Mark Villar, once the architect of the Duterte administration’s “Build, Build, Build” program, is now under preliminary investigation by the DOJ for alleged irregularities tied to flood-control contracts. The DOJ’s fact-finding teams have begun examining project clusters from Villar’s tenure — many awarded to firms now tagged in COA red flags and whistleblower affidavits. If substantiated, the findings could blow open the entire system of collusion between DPWH insiders and their favored contractors. What was meant to expose rot has turned into a mirror reflecting the decay of the entire system. The irony is grotesque: senators defending tainted witnesses, whistleblowers under state protection despite self-confessed crimes, and Cabinet men feigning ignorance when their names negatively surface in audit reports. Three reasons now explain why I believe this fact-finding crusade against government corruption has turned to rubble: If nothing changes, this probe will end like all its predecessors — theatrical, wasteful, and utterly inconsequential. Billions in flood-control funds will remain unaccounted for; tainted contractors will quietly reemerge next fiscal year; and senators will resume posturing as reformists, while burying their own fingerprints under procedural mud. Opaque ICI’s investigations, the DOJ’s move against Villar, and the swirling whispers of everyone partaking of the loot all point to a single, damning truth: the investigation has turned inward, devouring itself. The COA’s red flags have been twisted by partisanship; the Ombudsman has yet to act decisively; and the DOJ is walking a tightrope between exposure and complicity. Accountability cannot bloom in poisoned soil. Unless rebuilt on hard evidence and purged of hypocrisy and self-preservation, this probe will drown — not in floodwater, but in the sludge of its own deceit. – Rappler.com
label: True
title: [Vantage Point] The Senate probe absurdities

text: MANILA, Philippines – If you live in Metro Manila and frequent malls, those flashy electric vehicles you see are hard to miss. China, which made it a policy to specialize in electric vehicles (EVs), currently dominates the EV market worldwide. China-made cars were once derided for their lousy designs. Not anymore, not by a long shot. In fact, many of the Chinese EVs have surpassed Japanese and American cars when it comes to design. Ditto for Vietnam’s EVs such as VinFast. These cars look like the ones shown in fictional sci-fi movies. In suburbs, too, there are more e-trikes on the road, due partly to their affordability to the masses. Registration of two- and three-wheeled EVs has gone up from only 172 in 2023 to 43,441 in 2024, a 25,156% increase. Some of these EVs were displayed in the recently concluded 13th Philippine Electric Vehicle Summit held October 23, Thursday, to October 25, Saturday, at the SMX Convention Center in Pasay City. And the star of the summit, of course, was BYD, the world’s leader in EVs, currently being distributed in the Philippines by Ayala Corporation subsidiary ACMobility. BYD Cars Philippines country head Adam Hu said BYD has delivered 3.2 million new Energy vehicles (nEvs) worldwide as of September 2024. BYD Cars Philippines unveiled during the summit its BYD eMAX 9 DM-i, a family car which can run 1,200 kilometers on a full charge plus a full tank of gas. That covers a trip from Manila to Baguio and back without need for a refill or recharge. The 7-seater car’s interior looks like the business class of an airplane, with a pair of captain’s seats with massage feature and a 6-bottle mini-fridge. It also has middle-row tables for convenient use of laptops. Price tag? The BYD eMAX 9 DM-i premium variant sells for P2.99 million, while the advanced variant costs P2.67 million. In last year’s 12th Philippine Electric Vehicle Summit, ACMobility CEO Jaime Alfonso Zobel de Ayala talked about the company’s move to help “transform the electric vehicle landscape in the Philippines.” This year, ACMobility representatives discussed the “daunting task” of building a network of charging stations nationwide to help address car buyers’ concern about “range anxiety” or the fear of not being able to charge their vehicle due to lack of charging stations. The Asian Development Bank has provided $100 million or around P5.8 billion in co-financing with Ayala Corporation for the procurement of EV charging stations and of more EVs for commercial distribution. Though the growing presence of these EVs on the road may seem like Filipino consumers are finally adopting green vehicles, the numbers say otherwise. According to the Department of Energy, based on Land Transportation Office (LTO) data, there were only 24,286 EVs registered in the Philippines in 2024, accounting for only 0.2% of total registered vehicles. On the other hand, there were 14,595,467 conventional vehicles (gas and diesel) registered, which means 99.8% were conventional. The percentages were not that different from 2023 LTO data (see graph below from the Philippine Statistics Authority): gasoline-powered vehicles reached 11.23 million or 78.7% of the total number of registered vehicles in 2023; 3.03 million or 21.3% were diesel vehicles; 0.1% were others, i.e. Liquified Petroleum Gas (3 registered vehicles), Compressed Natural Gas (9 registered vehicles), electric (1.36 thousand registered vehicles), and hybrid (6.16 thousand registered vehicles). Admittedly, the Electric Vehicle Association of the Philippines (EVAP) said the country is still a long way from reaching a tipping point toward adopting EVs. “Unfortunately, we’re not,” said EVAP president Edmund Araga, when asked recently by the ABS-CBN News Channel’s Market Edge if the Philippine EV market had reached “inflection point.” But Araga prefers to look at the glass half-full than half-empty. He said that around 29,000 EVs were registered from January to June 2025, a 100% increase from the number of EVs registered from 2013 to 2024. An October 2024 EVAP report said there’s been an 8.4% annual average growth in market sales of EVs from 2013 to 2023. Araga said many car buyers are “very engaged” in switching to hybrids and EVs, and that the interest extends to companies that are shifting from internal combustion engines (ICEs) to electrified vehicles for their trucks and buses. Araga highlighted the need for local government units (LGUs) to push the EV industry in order to convince more consumers to adopt EVs. Here are other electric vehicles that were displayed at the just-concluded 13th Philippine EV Summit: – Rappler.com
label: True
title: Are Filipinos shifting to green vehicles?

text: MANILA, Philippines – The Philippine Stock Exchange (PSE) set the record straight amid online claims surrounding the market capitalization (MCAP) lost since December 2024. In a statement, the local bourse clarified that domestic MCAP was only down P273 billion or 1.88% from December 2024 to October 2025. The PSE issued the clarification after what it described as a “pseudo-expert” on the stock market falsely claimed that the local bourse lost P5 trillion during that period. “Unfortunately, this fake news was irresponsibly published on the same day and reposted the following day in an online tabloid that is known for prioritizing sensationalism that will generate clicks and engagements over providing news that have been fact-checked or verified,” the PSE said. Market capitalization, also known as market cap, is the total value of the outstanding shares that is traded on the stock market. The PSE explained that it tracks two types of market cap: total and domestic. Domestic MCAP includes Philippine firms that are primarily listed in the PSE. On the other hand, total market cap includes the foreign companies that are also listed with the local bourse: Sun Life Financial, Inc. (SLF), Del Monte Pacific Ltd. (DELM), and Manulife Financial Corporation (MFC). “Since only less than 1% of the outstanding shares of MFC and SLF and less than 5% of DELM are lodged for trading in the PSE, PSE uses domestic MCAP data as the reference number since it more accurately captures the performance of the Philippine stock market,” the PSE said. The local bourse further likened comparing domestic and total MCAP to comparing apples to oranges. “Deliberately comparing apples to oranges by comparing Domestic MCAP to Total MCAP is dishonest, if not malicious, and is clearly meant to provoke investors to lose confidence in the Philippine capital market and destabilize the economy,” the PSE said. The PSE’s clarification also comes after Securities and Exchange Commission (SEC) chief Francis Lim fell victim to a fake industry report that claimed the stock market lost P1.7 trillion in MCAP in August due to falling investor confidence amid the controversies surrounding anomalous flood control projects. – Rappler.com
label: True
title: PSE: Domestic market cap only down P273 billion, not P5 trillion

text: MANILA, Philippines – The National Privacy Commission (NPC) on Thursday, October 30, said it concluded its investigation into reports of a possible data leak involving GCash and found “no sufficient basis to conclude that a personal data breach occurred within G-Xchange, Inc. (GCash).” The review began after a dataset allegedly linked to GCash appeared on a deep-web forum. The regulator said it immediately initiated an inquiry upon discovery of the report, and on October 27 ordered the company to submit technical documents, preserve system logs, and join a clarificatory conference and live system demonstration. GCash complied, providing a written explanation and participating in the demonstration. The NPC’s Complaints and Investigation Division found the data sample “was inconsistent with GCash’s verified data structures. Several of the listed accounts were found to be invalid or inactive, and no indicators of unauthorized access, infiltration, or data exfiltration were detected.” A technical demo on October 29 covering logs from January 1 to October 29, 2025, showed “no unauthorized access attempts” to core databases, including those with e-KYC (know-your-customer) information. Logs showed “zero events, confirming that only pre-approved internal IP addresses interacted with the system.” The public was urged to stay vigilant and report suspected privacy violations to the commission. – Rappler.com
label: True
title: NPC finds no GCash data breach after probe

text: Claim: Former president Rodrigo Duterte has been released from the custody of the International Criminal Court (ICC) and is set to spend Christmas in the Philippines. Why we fact-checked this: The YouTube video containing the claim has 37,000 views, 2,900 likes, and 444 comments as of writing. It was uploaded on a YouTube channel claiming to be a news outlet, which has 168,000 subscribers. The video claims that Duterte’s release has been confirmed and that he will spend Christmas in the Philippines. It also alleges that the media withheld this information from the public and asserts that the Supreme Court has already issued an ultimatum for his release. The title in the video states: “Sa wakas! Kumpirmado na, tatay Digong makakalaya na? Supreme Court matinding utos, bring FPRRD home!“ (Finally! It’s confirmed! Father Digong will be freed! The Supreme Court has issued a strong order to bring him home!) The facts: Duterte has not been released by the ICC. He remains in detention at the ICC Detention Centre in Scheveningen Prison, The Hague, after the ICC Appeals Chamber unanimously denied his request for interim release on November 28, 2025. There are no credible reports confirming his release because no such release has occurred. Claims that the Philippine Supreme Court has issued an “ultimatum” for his release are also false as Philippine courts have no jurisdiction over ICC custody or proceedings and cannot order, compel, or interfere with ICC detention decisions. As an “independent and impartial judicial institution” established under the Rome Statute, the ICC’s detention orders cannot be overturned or interfered with by any domestic body. The ICC has repeatedly stated that it will continue its work “independently and impartially, undeterred by external pressure,” and that all decisions are governed solely by the Rome Statute. Jurisdiction issues: The ICC has asked the prosecution and victims’ lawyers to provide additional explanations on its jurisdiction over Duterte in the ongoing crimes against humanity case. In a December 16, 2025 order, the Appeals Chamber directed the parties to submit “additional observations” by January 16, focusing on how Articles 12(2), 13(c), and 127 of the Rome Statute interact. Article 12 sets the preconditions for the ICC’s exercise of jurisdiction, Article 13 defines when the court may assert jurisdiction, and Article 127 outlines a state’s continuing obligations even after leaving the ICC. The defense must submit its response by January 23, five working days after the other parties’ deadline. This directive follows the defense’s November 14 appeal challenging the court’s jurisdiction, which comes after the Pre-Trial Chamber’s October 23 ruling affirming the ICC’s authority to prosecute and detain Duterte. – Marjuice Destinado/Rappler.com Marjuice Destinado is a senior political science student at Cebu Normal University and an alumna of the Aries Rufo Journalism Fellowship of Rappler for 2025. Keep us aware of suspicious Facebook pages, groups, accounts, websites, articles, or photos in your network by contacting us at factcheck@rappler.com. Let us battle disinformation one Fact Check at a time.
label: True
title: FACT CHECK: Duterte is not free to spend Christmas in PH

text: MANILA, Philippines – In 2025, the Philippines faced its largest corruption scandal: the flood control and other public works controversies. Its impact has rippled through every corner of our country’s development, including our economy. With high-profile lawmakers and contractors tied to the issue, public trust, financial stability, and even international investor confidence have all been affected. All this is unfolding as GDP in the third quarter of 2025 rose by 4%, our weakest non-pandemic quarterly growth rate since 2011. Look back on how the flood control scandal has shaken the Philippine economy this year — and what can be done to fix it — in Rappler’s in-depth analyses below. [In This Economy] Economic malaise grips the Philippines [In This Economy] How safe are your deposits and investments amid widespread corruption? [BizSights] Not all flood control projects are bad. Here are some we can be proud of. – Rappler.com
label: True
title: How has the flood control scandal affected our economy?

text: The Lucio Co Group’s full-control acquisition of PrimeWater marks a pivotal consolidation in the Philippine water sector, underscoring how essential utilities have become strategic, defensive assets for large conglomerates. By bringing one of the country’s largest private water portfolios under Crystal Bridges Holding Corporation, the deal signals a shift toward scale, balance-sheet strength, and long-term capital commitment in a sector strained by aging infrastructure, climate risk, and fragmented ownership. While the transaction is legally sound despite the undisclosed purchase price, it sharpens investor and regulatory focus on governance, transparency, and the treatment of public water district partners whose assets and consumers are directly affected by any change in control. Beyond market impact, the acquisition places responsibility squarely on Crystal Bridges to address PrimeWater’s long-standing operational and consumer service challenges. Service reliability, non-revenue water, billing disputes, and wastewater compliance are not peripheral issues but core financial and reputational risks. Lucio Co’s credibility and capital discipline give it the opportunity to reset standards through visible investment, clearer performance benchmarks, and greater disclosure — turning PrimeWater from a politically sensitive operator into a predictable, accountable utility. Ultimately, the success of the deal will be judged, not by consolidation alone, but by whether scale is translated into better service, restored trust, and sustainable returns in one of the country’s most critical sectors. The Lucio Co Group’s buyout of PrimeWater Infrastructure Corporation (PrimeWater) from the Villar family is being brandied as a straightforward consolidation play in a capital-hungry sector. But Vantage Point sees it as something more significant. It reshapes power dynamics in the Philippine water industry, exposes lingering governance fault lines, and forces a reckoning on a question that utilities cannot escape forever: whether scale and capital alone can repair trust once consumers have lost it. PrimeWater is not a marginal asset. It operates one of the country’s largest private water portfolios, spanning joint ventures with local water districts, bulk water supply, septage, and wastewater management across fast-growing urban and provincial areas. Folding that platform into Crystal Bridges, the Lucio Co Group’s investment vehicle, effectively transfers control of a critical slice of the country’s water infrastructure to one of the Philippines’ most disciplined capital allocators. For the market, the signal is unmistakable. Regulated utilities, once dismissed as slow and politically messy, are now being treated as core defensive assets, prized for long-duration cash flows in an economy where volatility is the norm rather than the exception. This transaction reinforces a broader consolidation trend. Water infrastructure is becoming too capital-intensive, too regulated, and too exposed to climate stress for fragmented ownership structures to survive. Operators need balance sheets that can absorb pipe rehabilitation, wastewater compliance, and non-revenue water losses without lurching from one tariff petition to the next. From that perspective, the entry of Lucio Co into full control of PrimeWater may ultimately strengthen the sector by forcing weaker operators and underfunded water districts to confront the true cost of service delivery. Yet markets do not price infrastructure on assets alone. They price governance, transparency, and execution risk. And this is where the PrimeWater deal becomes more complicated. The acquisition price was not disclosed. In a purely private transaction, that omission is not, by itself, illegal. Philippine law does not compel private companies to publish valuation details unless they are publicly traded or listed on the stock exchange, or if the disclosure directly impacts public shareholders. But legality is not the same as adequacy. PrimeWater’s business model is deeply intertwined with public assets through water district joint ventures that are subject to state audit and regulatory oversight. Any change in control that affects capital structure, risk allocation, or investment commitments reverberates beyond shareholders and into the public sphere. This is where governance questions begin to surface. If PrimeWater carried significant related-party funding, guarantees, or contingent liabilities under its previous ownership, regulators will want to know how those exposures are being unwound — or whether they are simply being transferred to a new sponsor with deeper pockets. (READ: White flag? Why the Villars want out of PrimeWater) If listed entities related to Villar or Co were indirectly involved through loans, guarantees, or receivables, disclosure obligations do not vanish simply because the transaction headline says “private.” The real test will be whether the transaction leaves behind clean financial boundaries or merely shifts complexity out of sight. For Crystal Bridges, the strategic rationale is clear, but the operational inheritance is less forgiving. PrimeWater has faced sustained consumer complaints over service reliability, billing disputes, and wastewater compliance. These are not public-relations problems; they are balance-sheet issues waiting to happen. Chronic underinvestment in maintenance shows up first as leaks and service interruptions, then later as emergency capital expenditure (CapEx), regulatory penalties, or political backlash. Non-revenue water is not just water lost to leaks—it is revenue lost to inefficiency, often masked by accounting profits that do not translate into cash. This is where Lucio Co’s reputation becomes an asset, if it is deployed deliberately. Crystal Bridges can address PrimeWater’s consumer problems only by breaking with the legacy playbook that treats water districts as captive partners rather than stakeholders. The most immediate fix is capital discipline: ring-fenced funding for pipe rehabilitation, wastewater upgrades, and metering modernization that is visibly tied to service improvements, not just expansion announcements. Consumers do not experience EBITDA (Earnings Before Interest, Taxes, Depreciation, and Amortization). They experience pressure, continuity, and billing accuracy. Equally important is governance at the operating level. PrimeWater’s joint ventures need clearer performance metrics, transparent tariff logic, and predictable dispute-resolution mechanisms. Crystal Bridges has the institutional credibility to impose standardized service benchmarks across regions, replacing the patchwork approach that has fueled uneven performance and public frustration. Doing so would not only reduce regulatory risk, but also stabilize cash flows through the alignment of consumer trust with revenue sustainability. The acquisition also offers an opportunity to reset disclosure norms. Even if not legally required, greater transparency around CapEx commitments, service targets, and financial health would send a powerful signal to regulators and water districts alike. (READ: PrimeWater probe covers ‘possible conflict’ of DPWH under Mark Villar) In essential utilities, opacity breeds suspicion, and suspicion eventually attracts intervention. Lucio Co’s long-term advantage lies in making PrimeWater boring in the best possible way: predictable, compliant, and visibly accountable. The market impact of this deal therefore is not confined to ownership charts. It raises the bar for how private capital participates in public-facing utilities. If Crystal Bridges succeeds, it could accelerate consolidation, while restoring confidence that private operators can deliver both returns and reliability. If it fails, it will reinforce the argument that water infrastructure is simply too sensitive to be governed by balance sheets alone. In the end, Co is not just acquiring pipes and concessions. He is buying a relationship with millions of consumers and dozens of public institutions. The true valuation of PrimeWater will not be measured by the undisclosed purchase price, but by whether the new owner can convert scale into service, capital into credibility, and consolidation into confidence within consumers who expect clean and clear water to flow steadily from their taps. – Rappler.com
label: True
title: [Vantage Point] Lucio Co’s PrimeWater bet: The price of trust

text: The Global Minimum Tax is a tax system developed by the Organisation for Economic Co-operation and Development (OECD) and the G20 countries (OECD/G20) under its Pillar 2, or the Global Anti-Base Erosion Rules (“GloBE Rules”). It compels big multinational corporations — those with annual revenues exceeding €750 million — to pay a minimum 15% corporate tax rate, regardless of their location of operation. This aims to prevent companies from tax avoidance by relocating profits to nations with no or low tax rates or Base Erosion and Profit Shifting (BEPS). Currently, more than 147 countries, including the Philippines, have joined the OECD/G20 Inclusive Framework on BEPS, which includes the implementation of the GMT. Implementing the Global Minimum Tax in the Philippines is advantageous. It can increase government revenues by ensuring that big multinational corporations (MNCs) pay their fair share of tax, rather than transferring profits to tax havens. For the Philippines, the implementation of GMT presents a timely opportunity to strengthen its tax system and safeguard domestic revenues. Many MNCs operating in the Philippines currently benefit from generous tax incentives; however, with the proposed introduction of the Qualified Domestic Minimum Top-up Tax (QDMTT) and the Income Inclusion Rule (IIR), the government aims to ensure that these MNCs pay a minimum effective tax rate of 15%, aligning with global standards and safeguarding domestic tax revenues. The first mechanism, Qualified Domestic Minimum Top-up Tax (QDMTT), enables the Philippine government to collect the difference between the actual tax paid and the 15% minimum rate for MNCs with subsidiaries in the Philippines. The QDMTT mechanism ensures that any tax revenue due stays within the country, rather than being redirected to foreign jurisdictions. The second mechanism is the Income Inclusion Rule (IIR), which empowers the home country of the MNCs to impose a top-up tax on the income of its foreign subsidiaries when that income is taxed below the agreed global minimum rate. Adopting the GMT may also assist the Bureau of Internal Revenue (BIR) in the fight against tax evasion and demonstrate the Philippines’ dedication to equitable taxation by guaranteeing that MNCs and domestic firms have an equal footing in competition and defending local businesses. Without the GMT, the Philippines runs the risk of losing tax revenue to other countries that may impose top-up taxes on locally sourced income. Previously, under the Corporate Recovery and Tax Incentives for Enterprises (CREATE) Act and the Corporate Recovery and Tax Incentives for Enterprises to Maximize Opportunities for Reinvigorating the Economy Act (CREATE MORE), companies operating in the Philippines — especially multinational corporations — have benefited from preferential tax incentives such as Income Tax Holidays (ITH) lasting up to 4 to 7 years of tax exemption, depending on location and industry, and options like the Special Corporate Income Tax (SCIT) at a reduced rate of 5% on gross income or the Enhanced Deduction Regime (EDR), allowing companies to claim deductions on qualifying expenses. These incentives provide temporary tax exemptions or reduced tax rates, helping businesses lower their overall tax burden. However, the introduction of the Global Minimum Tax (GMT) under the OECD’s BEPS initiative is set to reshape the tax incentive landscape in the Philippines. If the effective tax rate in the Philippines falls below the 15% threshold due to incentives such as ITH or SCIT (5%), these companies could face additional taxes in other jurisdictions through mechanisms such as the Income Inclusion Rule (IIR) or the Undertaxed Profit Rules (UTPR). This means that incentives that currently reduce tax rates well below 15% may no longer provide a net tax advantage for multinational corporations. This shift necessitates a reassessment of the country’s tax incentive policies. Instead of relying heavily on steep tax rate reductions — such as the current 5% SCIT rate or full exemption during ITH — incentives may need to focus more on performance-based or activity-specific rewards, such as grants tied to job creation, infrastructure investments, or research and development. This approach not only aligns with global tax standards but also encourages investments that contribute to sustainable economic growth. Furthermore, the Enhanced Deduction Regime (EDR), which allows deductions linked to qualifying activities at up to 150% of the actual expenses, reflects a move toward more substance-driven incentives rather than pure tax rate cuts. These reforms come alongside a broader corporate tax reduction — from a previous standard rate of 30%, among the highest in ASEAN, to the current 25%. While this reduction enhances competitiveness, the GMT’s 15% minimum effective tax rate challenges the attractiveness of incentives that push the effective tax rate below this threshold, as they risk triggering top-up taxes abroad. Therefore, the Philippines will likely need to combine its tax reforms with other strategies, such as improving infrastructure, regulatory ease, and workforce skills, to maintain its appeal to foreign investors in a global tax environment increasingly focused on transparency and fairness. Although the Philippines joined the Inclusive Framework in November 2023, it has not yet enacted legislation to operationalize GMT rules domestically. Meanwhile, neighboring countries like Vietnam, Singapore, and Thailand are already advancing their GMT policies, giving them a competitive edge in capturing and retaining tax revenues from global corporations. Delay in implementation could put the Philippines at a disadvantage — not only in terms of lost revenue but also in its ability to shape global tax policy and investment trends in the region. The global minimum tax represents a bold step toward ending aggressive tax avoidance schemes and ensuring that large multinational corporations contribute their fair share to the economies in which they operate. For the Philippines, it is more than just a revenue tool, it is a strategic move toward fiscal sustainability, fair competition, and global cooperation. By adopting and implementing the GMT, the Philippines can protect its tax base, enhance its credibility on the world stage, and build a more equitable economic future for both domestic businesses and Filipino citizens. – Rappler.com
label: True
title: [Ask the Tax Whiz] The Global Minimum Tax and its impact on the Philippines

text: Newly surfaced records obtained by Vantage Point expose how GSIS trustees, Evelina Escudero, Merceditas Gutierrez and Rita Riddle, helped usher in a dubious ₱2-billion IT deal with DBP Data Center Inc. (DCI) — a firm whose own executives later admitted to have lacked the capability in building the public sector’s social insurance institution’s core systems. What began as a push for “modernization” now reeks of impropriety and influence-peddling within a pension fund in which these ladies claim to have been mismanaged. When guardians of the public trust start behaving like brokers, institutions crumble from within. The Government Service Insurance System (GSIS), already bruised by allegations of governance lapses and flood-control controversies, now finds itself entangled in another scandal — this time involving a ₱2-billion computerization deal pushed by trustees Evelina Escudero and Rita Riddle and allegedly backed by Merceditas Gutierrez. Gutierrez and Riddle resigned from the GSIS board last month. What makes this case galling is not just the staggering amount or the timing — coming as GSIS struggles to rebuild credibility — but the audacity with which key trustees introduced and advanced a project pitched by a company that ultimately confessed it couldn’t deliver what it was promising. On September 2, 2025, representatives from DBP Data Center Incorporated (DCI) — Business Development Head Jose Enrique Singson, Project Lead Apolonia Salud Jr., and domain experts Ma. Isabel Domingo and Dennis Dizon — met with the GSIS Board of Trustees to present their information technology (IT) services. That meeting alone raised eyebrows. DCI was no mere vendor — it was a government-owned and -controlled corporation (GOCC) under the Development Bank of the Philippines (DBP). Yet its delegation was allowed to pitch directly to the GSIS board, a move that blurred procurement lines and created a cozy dynamic between trustees and a potential contractor. Just two weeks later, on September 15, 2025, during the Legal Oversight Committee meeting, trustees proposed that GSIS and DCI execute a Memorandum of Understanding (MOU) — fast-tracked through a board referendum which bypassed a full deliberation. For an institution managing billions in pension assets, such haste is indefensible. The trustees weren’t merely entertaining a presentation; they were laying the groundwork for a partnership that would later balloon into a ₱2-billion IT “modernization” project. Thankfully, not everyone was asleep at the switch. Vantage Point learned that on September 29, 2025, GSIS President and General Manager Jose Arnulfo “Wick” Veloso intervened during the Risk Oversight Committee meeting, requesting that approval of the MOU be deferred. Veloso, who had not attended the earlier presentations, questioned why such a significant deal had progressed without his knowledge. He requested a direct meeting with DCI’s top executives — President and Chief Executive Officer Michielson Luakian and Chief Operating Officer Jose Carmelo Porciuncula — to better understand their proposal. The meeting was scheduled for October 9, 2025. What unfolded there should have killed the deal permanently. During that October meeting, DCI executives revealed more than they intended. They described their company as a “40-year-old startup” offering IT support and staff augmentation services to various government agencies and private clients. When asked if they developed the core systems of the Development Bank of the Philippines (DBP), they admitted they did not — DBP handled its own IT infrastructure. DCI merely provided manpower support “when needed.” When pressed further about their readiness to take on GSIS’s modernization, DCI’s own president conceded that “GSIS is significantly more advanced in IT than most government-owned or -controlled corporations,” and that DCI “does not have the capability to undertake the development of GSIS’s core systems.” The clincher came when Luakian stated DCI would formally withdraw its interest to avoid further delays in GSIS’s internal plans. If this were a private-sector board, the next step would be an investigation into how such a weak proposal ever made it to board-level presentation. In GSIS, however, it became another footnote in a long saga of institutional decay. After the meeting, Veloso reportedly asked who had introduced DCI to GSIS. The answer came from Vice President and Chief Information Security/Data Protection Officer Jonathan Pineda: it was trustees Riddle and Escudero. It was later learned that the deal had the backing of Gutierrez. Pineda disclosed that during the September 2 Risk Oversight Committee meeting, Riddle and Escudero had suggested that GSIS’s IT systems be “reviewed and audited by DCI,” and that an MOU be signed to facilitate an “agency-to-agency procurement.” That phrase — agency-to-agency procurement — is key. Such arrangements between government entities are exempt from public bidding under Republic Act 9184, the Government Procurement Reform Act. In theory, agency-to-agency procurements promote efficiency. In practice, they create a loophole: a way to move massive sums without competitive scrutiny. It’s not modernization; it’s maneuvering. The revelations did not stop there. Upon background check, Vantage Point discovered that DCI President Luakian — the same man who had just admitted lack of IT expertise — was previously business development head of M.E. Sicat Construction Incorporated, a DPWH contractor involved in public works projects. So, the man behind a proposed ₱2-billion IT deal for GSIS came from the same world of construction contracting now tainted by flood-control scandals. To call that a conflict of interest would be an understatement — it is a revolving door between two sectors notorious for cost overruns and patronage politics. Trustees Riddle, Escudero, and Gutierrez appear to have facilitated, endorsed, or at best tolerated a process that flirted dangerously with impropriety. Gutierrez, who recently resigned from the GSIS board and carries her own history of ethical baggage as former Philippine justice secretary and Ombudsman — should have been the first to demand due diligence. Their actions betray a disturbing inversion of duty: trustees meant to guard public funds became the very conduits for questionable partnerships. At a time when GSIS is under intense scrutiny for investment losses — which the three ladies, along with other signatories, alleged procurement opacity — and political entanglements, the last thing the institution needs is another scandal cloaked in the language of “digital transformation.” The DCI episode is symptomatic of a larger sickness in public finance: the weaponization of “modernization.” Every time an agency is caught in a scandal, it announces a grand reform project — usually IT-related, often multimillion-peso, or in this case multibillion-peso, worth. These projects rarely fix the core problem. They merely digitize dysfunction. Without ethical leadership, every system — no matter how advanced — becomes another conduit for graft. What must happen now GSIS doesn’t need a ₱2-billion IT overhaul. It needs an ethical reboot. Until the board cleans its ranks, no system — digital or human — can restore the public’s trust. Escudero, Gutierrez, and Riddle’s fingerprints on the DCI affair show that the danger to GSIS is not technological inadequacy, but moral decay. When trustees act like sales agents and former contractors pose as technological innovators, modernization becomes just another scam in bureaucratic clothing. If GSIS cannot fix that, it won’t need a new system; it will need a rescue. – Rappler.com
label: True
title: [Vantage Point] The DCI-GSIS affair: A billion-peso blunder

text: MANILA, Philippines – Chinese fast-food restaurant chain Chowking is reinventing itself in a pivot to the Philippines’ young demographic. Chowking, now 40 years old, has been rolling out new concept stores that it hopes can further entice the GenZ market or those who were not yet born when ChowKing was first established by its founder, Robert Fung Kuan, in 1985. The Jollibee Group acquired Chowking in 2000. How best to get more GenZs to dine in a legacy fast-food brand? One tack is to make the stores Instagrammable. The strategy may not be obvious to those who live in Metro Manila, since most of the concept stores are in the provinces. Take the case of the newly opened Chowking in SM City La Union in the Philippines’ surfing capital in the north. The store’s interior is much brighter than Chowking’s older stores. While older stores have lots of white and some brown colors, the new concept stores have orange, yellow, red as the dominant colors. Various studies have found that the colors orange, yellow, and red help boost appetite. “We’ve just launched our new concept store, and we’re very encouraged by the reception,” Ken Lingan, president of Chowking told ABS-CBN News Channel’s business show Market Edge on October 23. “The thing we’re concerned about is: how does it appeal to the GenZ market. And the actual word we’ve been hearing is, Instagrammable.” The new stores have modern art designs that could make people, young and old, post photos of them dining in Chowking — and get more people to visit. “It’s not just about the food. We want to really elevate the whole experience our consumers have in our stores,” Lingan said. Other outlets with the new concept are: Chowking Nepomall in Angeles City, Pampanga; Chowking SM Marilao, Bulacan; Chowking Buhay na Tubig, Imus City, Cavite; Chowking Robinsons Dumaguete, Dumaguete City, Negros Oriental; and Chowking Batangas Passenger Terminal, Santa Clara, Batangas City. Another strategy to get more young customers? Offer them sugary drinks. More Chowking stores now have Milksha counters. This Taiwanese bubble tea brand is popular among young consumers. Jollibee bought a majority stake in the company behind Milksha in November 2021. Milksha drinks are being paired with Chowking favorites like its top-selling Chao Fan rice dish. As part of its 40th anniversary celebration, Chowking recently held its first-ever Chow Fun Run at the Mall of Asia grounds in Pasay City, a community engagement that helps build real connections with the youth. A post shared by Chowking 超群 (@chowkingph) Chowking has also added more self-order kiosks that young people, unlike many seniors, find easy to use. Lingan said close to half of Chowking’s network of 600 stores already have self-order kiosks. “We believe this adds convenience to our consumers,” he said. Chowking is also reinventing itself in response to a change in consumer behavior brought about partly by the COVID-19 pandemic, with more people working from and eating at home. Whereas dine-in made up the bulk of Chowking’s sales pre-pandemic, Chowking is seeing more consumers turn to take-outs and deliveries post-pandemic. “We now see the emergence of off-premise, and we continue to expand our drive-thru channels and delivery,” said Lingan. “It [drive-thru] used to be less than 10% of our business…. Now, our off-premise channels contribute to close to half our business.” In the next three to five years, Lingan said “close to 50%” of Chowking’s network will have drive-thrus. These are all part of Chowking’s contribution to making the Jollibee Group one of the top 5 food companies in the world. Chowking is also present in six countries outside the Philippines, mainly in the Middle East with 35 stores and 15 in the US, as of end 2024. – Rappler.com
label: True
title: Chowking reinvents: How this 40-year-old fast-food is pivoting to the GenZ market

text: Our furry friends have always been with us — wagging their tails once they hear your footsteps, purring whenever they’re being petted, asking for a belly rub before they sleep, or simply staying by your side when you’re sad or alone. Nowadays, they’re not just simple companions. They’re being treated as actual children with how pampered they are — dressed in clothes and diapers and even being mistaken as babies while sitting in their strollers. The pet and owner attachment is unbreakable, which is why it’s so hard knowing their precious time in the world is always too short. And with this, we would also want to honor them by bidding them a respectful goodbye as they cross the rainbow bridge. Across the world, there are services and traditions done to furr-ever remember these animals who once filled our lives with joy. In the Philippines, several companies offer pet memorial services including burial, traditional cremation, and aquamation. A pet memorial service allows pet owners to have their own time to say goodbye, similar to how it’s done for humans. It’s where pets are laid out for viewing. There’s also an option for a short chapel viewing. Through heat, cremation turns the pet’s remains into ashes, and are given to pet owners. On the other hand, aquamation is the water-based alternative to the traditional fire cremation, and a more eco-friendly way. Memorial packages often include a photobox urn, the pet’s paw prints, and even a portion of their fur and nails. For a meaningful keepsake, some also offer to store the fur in a piece of jewelry so owners can carry a part of their pets with them. Some local government units also provide pet memorial services. In Cainta, Rizal, cremation services are free for residents. The Muntinlupa city government also offers a cremation package with a P500-discount for those who reside in the area. There are also other public spaces in Metro Manila that serve as pet cemeteries, such as the Barangay Fortune Pet Memorial Garden in Marikina City. There’s also a pet burial service available at the Manila South Cemetery. Disney’s Coco (2017) introduced us to Día de los Muertos (Day of the Dead), a Mexican holiday that honors deceased loved ones. In Mexico, the Day of the Dead for pets is observed every October 27. Ofrendas (offerings) are set up on an altar, which include important elements like the pet’s photo, an arch made of flower or reeds, and a papel picado (traditional perforated paper). Other items included are salt, sugar skull, candles, flowers, food, and water. A post shared by Chloe Chung + MisTricks (@mistricks) To make it more personal, symbols of the pets are also placed on the altar such as their favorite items like toys, treats, or collar, as well as their urns. While this is a practice that’s common in Mexico, this is also adapted by fur parents from other countries too. Japan’s affection for pets is extraordinary. According to Japan Today, the number of pets has surpassed the number of children in their country! With this, it’s no surprise that countless cemeteries and temples in Japan offer spaces for pet mourning and remembrance, helping fur parents to mourn and express their love and gratitude after their companions have passed. Most practices are grounded in Buddhist ideas that view animals as beings whose spirits, like those of humans, also deserve guidance in the afterlife. A post shared by Calum McSwiggan (@calummcswiggan) One example is Unrinji Temple in Yamaguchi Prefecture. Here, visitors can write and send letters to a special postbox dedicated to departed pets. While it’s also called Cat Temple, it welcomes all kinds of animals, offering memorial services, prayers, and rituals. Beyond the temple grounds, Japan also has another form of remembrance at Shibuya Station. A statue of Hachiko, the loyal Akita dog that inspired the 2009 film of the same name, was built and became well-known among locals and tourists because of his heartwarming story. Visitors often touch the statue’s legs as a sign of respect. April 8 is Hachiko Day, a ceremony where flowers and speeches are offered to honor his loyalty. Nepal has a special day to celebrate dogs: Kukur Tihar or Day of the Dogs, which falls around October or November. According to The Seattle Times, dogs are worshiped with the belief that they are the messengers of Yamraj, the Hindu God of Death. Both living and deceased dogs are honored during the festival. It is their way to recognize their loyalty, protection, and companionship. It’s part of Tihar, a Hindu festival that goes on for five days. During the second day, these four-legged pets are bathed, draped with flower garlands around their necks, and marked with a tilaka on their foreheads as part of the ceremony. – Rappler.com Alessandria Corral is a Rappler intern and a Bachelor of Arts in Speech Communication student at the University of the Philippines Diliman.
label: True
title: How do different countries honor pets as they cross over to the rainbow bridge?
