And not a few people might think that a historically “weak” peso might reflect a similar weakness of the President. But to be honest, I don’t care too much for the terms “weak” or “strong” peso. A “weak” peso, for instance, is actually a good thing for exporters (because our goods and services become more competitive) and dollar-earning OFWs (because the money they send home will translate into more pesos). The bigger concern is that our export industry is not sufficiently diversified to begin with: the biggest chunk of our exports remains to be semiconductors, and we can’t expect to earn a lot more if we don’t export goods which are higher value-added. The fact that the peso is weakening also suggests that remittance growth is not as strong as they used to be (because strong remittance inflows would tend to make the peso stronger rather than weaker). Above anything else, the weaker peso is a sign of weaker confidence in the Philippine economy. And the longer it takes for the Marcos administration to go after (and even jail) the corrupt, the longer it will take for business confidence to recover, and the more capital will want to flee the country. The peso’s fate is in the hands of Marcos himself. – Rappler.com JC Punongbayan, PhD is an assistant professor at the UP School of Economics and the author of False Nostalgia: The Marcos “Golden Age” Myths and How to Debunk Them. In 2024, he received The Outstanding Young Men (TOYM) Award for economics. Follow him on Instagram (@jcpunongbayan).
label: True
title: [In This Economy] Is massive corruption to blame for the historically weak peso?

text: MANILA, Philippines – We talk about self-care a lot, but many of us don’t see it for what it really is. Type “self-care” on any search engine, and you’ll find the usual advice meshed with more glamorous ones: move your body, do a quick makeover, journal, eat a balanced diet, go on a shopping spree, take a warm bath, sleep eight hours, or book a “wellness getaway” for the weekend. But is there more to self-care that we tend to overlook? Self-care isn’t always pretty, and it isn’t meant to be. It’s also intended to be uncomfortable, real, and vulnerable. Let’s unpack what the “ugly” side of self-care truly means, just like how we peel onions — raw and sometimes stinging — with the help of Marie Angelica Paz, a registered guidance counselor and licensed psychologist. Pop culture — and capitalism — sell the idea that we should book our next trip as soon as possible, follow a 10-step skincare routine, or check out everything in our cart to find relaxation and joy in our lives. Self-care is being commodified, and we’re falling for it. Paz told Rappler that surface-level practices are not inherently wrong, but they can be counterproductive if they don’t align with one’s values or if they are done mainly for clout or aesthetics. Indulgent fixes can be confused with real healing or fulfillment. “It’s called self-care, pero if you’re doing it for flex, nawawala ‘yung idea ng ‘self’ doon. Para saan ba talaga ‘yang ginagawa mo (It’s called self-care, but if you’re doing it for flex, the idea of ‘self’ gets lost. What are you really doing it for)?” she told Rappler. Performative self-care can distract us from real emotional work, especially when we engage in too many activities yet still feel lost. Another downside of this idea is that it can be alienating for those who cannot afford them or those who don’t have access to the same resources. Surface-level self-care doesn’t address deeper emotional wounds. This is where inner work, also known as shadow work, comes in. It offers opportunities for individuals to come to terms with parts of themselves that are beneath the surface. This is when we unearth the pains we have repressed for so long. The process can be ugly and messy because it’s when imperfections usually reveal themselves. This is when it starts to hurt the most. “When you do inner work, it’s important to get to know parts of yourself that are not easy to accept or embrace. That’s why it takes a lot of care. When one feels invalidated, there can be resistance or denial,” Paz said. Emotional work demands self-accountability, which is why it’s often avoided. Many face the question: What role have I played in my own suffering? And as a therapist, Paz feels responsible for bringing the client back to reality by helping them face hard truths. She admits that she cannot always validate her clients, or she risks enabling unhealthy behavior. At its core, self-care means taking full responsibility for securing our personal wellness. “It is when you take the initiative to address your needs holistically, in line with your values or according to what matters to you most,” Paz expressed. What we don’t always realize is that self-care requires hard work. Others tend to choose the relatively easy fixes over the more complicated ones, like setting boundaries or taking accountability, because they’re not ready to deal with the emotional work the latter requires. Paz further explained that there’s nothing wrong with having things easy, but if we succumb to self-indulgence, we can lose the chance to be truly responsible for our well-being. For Paz, we can use self-care to nurture our appetite for life by starting with the basics. Number one on the list is sleep and rest. “Your body needs time to recover, just like how your phone needs charging after use. Sleep is the body’s way of recharging. Even in your busiest time, sleep should be the last thing you sacrifice,” the psychologist explained. Second is exercise. She highlighted that our bodies are meant to be moving and compared it to stagnant water, which can be toxic when left unattended over a period of time. Third is food intake. Others eat to “take care” of themselves, but are not mindful of what they consume. As part of self-care, we need to check whether our bodies are getting proper nourishment. In some cases, however, even the basics may not be feasible. That’s why there’s no foolproof playbook for self-care. Living conditions, societal norms, socioeconomic factors, and support systems could all play a role. But as Paz said, starting with what’s easy and available goes a long way. Once it catches meaning, that’s our gateway to doing something more for ourselves. Seeking professional help should be the next step when one still struggles despite addressing basic needs. This is especially true for high-functioning individuals, who tend to juggle too much and lose balance. Paz also noted those who are born with mental health conditions. “It’s difficult to make sense of a situation, kapag ‘yung guidelines ng mundo is ‘yung nasa norms. There are extreme cases, those in the outliers, and they need extra help in processing things (It’s difficult to make sense of a situation when the world uses the norms as guidelines. There are extreme cases, those in the outliers, and they need extra help in processing things),” she said. Therapy can help individuals thrive despite mental health challenges. However, access to it remains a challenge. It can be expensive, so how can someone earning a barely livable wage avail of it? Moreover, even if the system improves and the state subsidizes the fees, there are not enough mental health professionals in the country. Stigma and misconceptions continue to exist. In her practice, Paz has noticed that the older generations still view therapy as something embarrassing or something only “crazy” people do. There is a growing appeal among the younger generations — they even view going to therapy as a status symbol — but Paz finds this romanticization alarming. As a mental health professional, it’s good news if her clients no longer need therapy. She also shared her concern about some people using mental health as an excuse. They fake symptoms to escape accountability, and it doesn’t help the cause. Ultimately, Paz reminds us that when it comes to self-care, it’s a myth that things always come easily. We have to proactively approach it until it becomes a part of our lifestyle. We have to commit to it despite the discomfort or struggle. “Hindi puwedeng palagi kang komportable (You can’t be comfortable all the time). As my favorite proverb goes, ‘Sunshine all the time makes a desert.’ It’s about balancing everything. Nothing in itself is purely good or bad. It all comes to how you’re gonna balance everything. Even if something is not appealing, you have to think that maybe it’s what is necessary for you to grow,” she expressed. After unpacking self-care layer by layer, what remains is the hope that if we move past the surface and push through the messy, stinging parts of the process, we’ll eventually be rewarded with a sweeter taste of life. When life gives you onions, peel the layers like your life depends on it — and turn them into something that truly nourishes your body, mind, and spirit. – Rappler.com
label: True
title: The ‘ugly’ side of self-care: What a therapist wants you to know about it

text: MANILA, Philippines – Inflation eased to 1.5% in November as the rise of vegetable and meat prices slowed, the Philippine Statistics Authority (PSA) said on Friday, November 5. The latest inflation print brings the average rate for 2025 to 1.6%, still below the government’s target range of 2% to 4%. Deputy National Statistician Divina Gracia del Prado said inflation of food and non-alcoholic beverages fell to just 0.1% in November. For vegetables in particular, inflation dropped to 4% from 16.4% in October, while for meat, inflation slowed to 4.2% from 5.2%. But “other pelagic fish,” which ranked as the top contributor to the overall November figure, saw higher inflation of 13% from 11.7%, driven by galunggong (round scad) prices that went up due to the recent tropical cyclones that hit the country. “Naapektuhan din siya, so we have a scarcity of galunggong kaya mataas din ‘yung price niya,” Del Prado said. (The supply was affected, so we have a scarcity of round scad and that’s why its prices are currently high.) Del Prado also noted that inflation of beans jumped from -12% in October to 12.4% in November. Prices of onions and shallots have also been trending upward, recording an even higher 48.2% inflation rate from the already elevated 34.9%. In Metro Manila, inflation slightly eased to 2.8% from 2.9% the prior month. Regions outside Metro Manila also saw a similar slowdown to 1.2% from 1.3%. Central Visayas recorded the fastest inflation rate at 3.3% while the Bangsamoro Autonomous Region in Muslim Mindanao saw continuous deflation or negative inflation at -1.4%. Deflation means price levels are decreasing. Department of Economy, Planning, and Development (DEPDev) Secretary Arsenio Balisacan attributed the slowdown to the Marcos administration’s efforts to strengthen the food supply chain and ensure food security. “The sustained moderation in inflation reflects our commitment to protect consumers and strengthen our economic resilience against global and domestic headwinds. We will continue implementing timely, well-coordinated policies to keep prices stable and ensure progress is felt by every Filipino,” the country’s chief economist said. DEPDev added that the Department of Agriculture has issued guidelines to safeguard the country against African swine fever while facilitating safe pork imports. These include the recognition of ASF-free zones within accredited exporting countries. Executive Secretary Ralph Recto also said the latest inflation print will give the Bangko Sentral ng Pilipinas (BSP) more room for another rate cut in its final monetary policy meeting of the year on Thursday, December 11. Apart from the BSP’s monetary policy meeting, the Development Budget Coordination Committee is also set to discuss the country’s economic growth and inflation targets on Tuesday, December 9. – Tatiana Maligro, with reports from Arriane dela Cruz/Rappler.com Arriane dela Cruz is a Rappler intern. Learn more about Rappler’s internship program here.
label: True
title: Inflation cools to 1.5% in November 2025 amid slower price hikes in vegetables, meat

text: When we plan trips to other countries, the most popular destinations are no longer the first places we immediately flock to. Tokyo in Japan, Shanghai in China, and Seoul in South Korea — spots often featured in travel brochures because they’ve been visited countless times by countless people over the years — prove time and time again why they’re so popular in the first place. Travelers nowadays are changing, though. With the days of post-COVID revenge traveling being long gone, people are now booking trips to lesser known places, and diving into activities you probably would have never considered visiting another country for. Even in major cities, the attention shifts to cafes in secluded residential areas, novelty shops that have been around for decades but are only just beginning to be discovered, and bustling hawker stalls that are kept alive by nearby office workers and students. “People are looking further away from destinations they’re comfortable with. Even if they might go to Tokyo, they are no longer staying in Shinjuku and Shibuya and Ginza, the usual places. They’re going a little further and further,” Klook’s chief commercial officer Wilfred Fan told Rappler. The main culprit — or catalyst, rather — lies in the palms of our hands: social media. According to data from Klook’s Travel Pulse, 80% of Gen Zs and 78% of millennials are putting on their itinerary experiences they just came across on social media. It wasn’t through a thick guidebook that they thought to get a chibi portrait of themselves done at a night market in Bangkok. It was likely through a traveler who happened to stumble upon the experience during their trip, and decided to share it in the form of a short video on platforms like TikTok, YouTube, or Instagram. It’s a classic cycle, really. We discover an activity, we consider if it’s what we want to do, we make the purchase, then we share all about our experiences. And repeat. Experiences are key now. Travelers aren’t only going to temples and art museums to experience a country’s culture — they’re also beginning to explore in the same way as people who have lived there all their lives. “If you’re talking about big theme parks, you actually don’t have to market it. However, if you’re talking about something like a traditional jeans making workshop in Japan, nobody will know that it exists. Nobody will go and search for it. They will only know about it because they went on social media. Either they are scrolling and [they see it], or they search for interesting things to do in Japan and it’s one of the videos that pops up,” Marcus Yong, Klook’s vice president for global marketing, told Rappler. Travelers are now dipping their toes into niche activities like tea tasting ceremonies, renting cultural garb for a day, or even going on wellness retreats. They may not be able to keep a tangible souvenir from these experiences, but will it really matter at the end of the day if you’re coming home with irreplaceable memories anyway? It’s also through this cycle that hidden gems no longer remain under the radar. Places that are usually referred to as “second cities” (think Sa Pa in Vietnam and Hiroshima in Japan) are becoming people’s first choices. They’re places that wouldn’t immediately be at the top of your mind if someone were to ask you to name cities from a tourism-friendly country, but in 2025, they’re climbing their way to the top. It’s a welcome change — one that puts on the map destinations that are just as rich in culture and history, but just had yet to be talked about by more people. For instance, I was able to explore Tomonoura, a quaint fishing port town in Hiroshima prefecture that inspired the Studio Ghibli movie Ponyo. Years ago, if I were to put together my own itinerary for Japan, it probably would not have even made it on the list. I would have stuck to wherever everyone else had gone. It’s content creators who are leading the charge, too. They go out there to show what a new place has to offer — all in a matter of a minute-long video at that. Things aren’t as simple as just stitching chronological clips of a travel destination. With the dwindling attention span of social media users, they only have about three seconds to hook their viewers and show them why this destination that goes off the beaten path deserves a spot in their itinerary. Content creator Alvin, who runs Just Got Fed on Facebook, TikTok, and Instagram, can attest to this. A post shared by Just Got Fed | travel • food • stories (@justgotfed) “I think sa social media ngayon, everybody wants to showcase a different experience sa napanood nila. ‘Pag pupunta ka ng Hong Kong, hindi ko naman siya mashoshowcase kung Disneyland lang. So, hahanap ako ng iba, or mag-eexplore ako ng iba. Kaya what I want to showcase most is yung mga kakaibang areas, and kakaibang places apart from the common ones,” shared Alvin, adding that it’s the video hooks that are crucial. (On social media nowadays, everyone wants to showcase an experience that’s different from what they usually see. If you’re going to Hong Kong, I can’t just showcase what it has to offer if I just focus on Disneyland. So, I look for something else, or explore other places. That’s why what I want to showcase most are the unique areas, and unique places apart from the common ones.) Just as travelers rely on social media for destination recommendations, it’s becoming an outlet for them to ease their pre-trip anxieties, too. Videos on how to not get offloaded by immigration are usually sure viral hits, and so are video guides for getting your visa approved. But for those traveling for the first time, Alvin’s best piece of advice is to always, always plan ahead. “Hindi lang itinerary. Check the requirements, check all the limitations. Kasi once you travel, there are different cultures and different rules. So being familiar with that would make your trip easier… Sa Philippines mismo, ang dami nating kailangan na visa. Be prepared sa mga requirements kasi doon naman talaga ‘yung first barrier mo before you travel,” Alvin told Rappler. (Not just your itinerary. Check the requirements, check all the limitations. Because once you travel, there are different cultures and different rules. So being familiar with that would make your trip easier… In the Philippines, we need so many visas. Be prepared with the requirements because visas are your first barrier before you travel anyway.) It goes without saying that modern travel really has changed. People don’t flock to what’s popular as often anymore, short-form videos are king, and the value of experience are what people look for when exploring a new place. All these, it seems, are here to stay. – Rappler.com
label: True
title: Modern travelers aren’t going for popular destinations anymore. Here’s why.

text: MANILA, Philippines – Western Union on Wednesday, October 1, launched a new mobile app in the Philippines that allows users not only to send but also to request money from abroad — a first for the global money transfer company. The app enables consumers to send funds overseas through Western Union’s global financial network, which connects billions of bank accounts, millions of digital wallets and cards, and hundreds of thousands of retail locations. Users can pay online using the national QR code system, QR Ph, and track transactions via the app’s Money Transfer Control Number (MTCN). Filipino users can also request remittances from senders in countries such as the United States, Australia, Singapore, and the United Kingdom. Funds can then be received via cash pickup, bank deposit, or digital wallet transfer, with an option to redirect incoming remittances to preferred accounts. “Today’s launch marks an important milestone in our effort to serve consumers in the Philippines better and connect them to their families and loved ones across the world,” said Gregory Laurent, Western Union vice president for the Philippines, Japan, Australia, New Zealand & Pacific Islands. “Our new app gives the opportunity to do both, with the flexibility and trust that Western Union can provide.” The Philippines is Western Union’s first market globally to feature both send and request capabilities in one app. According to the Bangko Sentral ng Pilipinas, remittances to the Philippines hit a record high of $38 billion in 2024, with the World Bank ranking the country fourth among low- and middle-income nations in remittance inflows. The United States and Singapore were the top sources of cash remittances last year. The app is now available on the App Store and Google Play. – Rappler.com
label: True
title: Western Union launches mobile app in PH with send-and-request remittance feature

text: A trowel (/ˈtraʊ.əl/), in the hands of an archaeologist, is like a trusty sidekick – a tiny, yet mighty, instrument that uncovers ancient secrets, one well-placed scoop at a time. It’s the Sherlock Holmes of the excavation site, revealing clues about the past with every delicate swipe. Standing above the cliff dwellings at Mesa Verde National Park, my son Leka asked, “What do you think the people who lived here did every day, Dad?” The question pulled me back to my own childhood, when I first encountered these places through grainy photos in a children’s encyclopedia in the Philippines. Back then, the stone rooms carved into cliffs felt distant and unfamiliar, more like curiosities than places where real people once lived ordinary lives. I told Leka what archaeology has taught me over the years. People here lived much as we do. They worried about food. They cared for family. They watched the weather, dealt with drought and danger, and made choices under uncertainty. The cliffs offered protection, but daily life unfolded far beyond the stone walls, across fields, water sources, trails, and neighboring communities. These were not static or vanished societies. They were indigenous communities making decisions, adapting to change, and shaping their futures in ways that still matter today. Archaeological work shows that Ancestral Pueblo communities began settling the Mesa Verde region around AD 600, building deep knowledge of farming, architecture, and movement across the landscape. The cliff dwellings themselves appeared much later, mainly in the 12th and early 13th centuries. When prolonged droughts placed pressure on crops and water, people chose to move. This was not collapse or failure. It was reorganization. Descendant Pueblo communities remain connected to these places, reminding us that Mesa Verde is not just a ruin but part of a living indigenous history. Our family has made a habit of these road trips, piling into the car to visit national parks and historic sites. They are moments we share together, but they are also how our children learn about the world. Walking through these places allows history and environment to come alive, not as stories sealed in textbooks or documentaries, but as landscapes shaped by human decisions over time. Growing up in the Philippines, I encountered places like Mesa Verde only through books or films. The country has extraordinary cultural landscapes and ecological diversity, yet many of these places remain difficult to experience in ways that help young people connect history, culture, environment, and everyday life. This gap appears in small but telling ways. Some recently promoted “heritage” attractions illustrate how easily good intentions can slide into display without context. Many such places attract attention and visitors, reflecting a desire to connect with history. At the same time, heritage can drift away from historical understanding when interpretation and sustained educational engagement are limited or non-existent. When this happens, complex histories risk being reduced to visual appeal rather than understood as lived experiences shaped over time. When interpretation remains shallow, visits often center on photo-taking rather than learning. Sites become backdrops for images rather than places for asking questions. This does not reflect a lack of curiosity, but a lack of guidance. Without accessible narratives and educational framing, visitors are left with images instead of understanding, and the deeper histories of decision-making and social life remain out of view. This contrast becomes more apparent when set alongside how heritage has been supported institutionally elsewhere. In the United States, the national park system was built through legislation and an explicit commitment to public education. Even as that foundation is increasingly contested today, it shows how heritage can be treated as a public good rather than a discretionary expense. Interpretation, research, and access are understood as part of stewardship. The Philippines already has important foundations that could support a similar approach. These include the National Integrated Protected Areas System and laws protecting cultural heritage, and participation in the UNESCO World Heritage. These can provide a framework for treating natural and cultural landscapes as shared national responsibilities, guided by research and public engagement. The challenge lies in turning these frameworks into sustained, meaningful practice on the ground. The Philippines has many places that could be approached in this way. The Agusan Marsh holds long histories of river-based life and seasonal movement. The Tabon Caves and their surrounding landscapes connect archaeology, ecology, and maritime worlds. In Bicol, the terrain shaped by Mayon Volcano tells stories of settlement, farming, eruption, and recovery across centuries. These places document how people have lived with uncertainty and change, not simply as scenic backdrops. For places like these to connect meaningfully with the present, archaeology also has to change how it speaks. Too often, the past is framed as a story of loss or collapse. That framing creates distance and makes history feel finished. When we shift attention to how people managed resources and made collective decisions under pressure, the past becomes easier to relate to. It becomes a record of problem-solving rather than disappearance. When Leka asked what people did every day at Mesa Verde, he was really asking how people lived with uncertainty and how they made choices in changing environments. That is exactly the kind of question archaeology can help us ask. The Philippines has the landscapes and the lived experience to create places where young people can ask those same questions of their own pasts. Heritage is often treated as secondary when daily survival feels more urgent, when the pressure to put food on the table makes conservation seem like a luxury. Yet landscapes and histories carry knowledge about how people have endured scarcity and managed risk. When heritage is approached as education rather than as a decoration, and as a shared responsibility rather than a constraint, it can help guide how tourism and development are shaped. Creating spaces that connect history, land, ecology, and lived experience provides the next generation more than information. It gives them perspective, and a way to think about how their own choices will shape the future. – Rappler.com Stephen B. Acabado is professor of anthropology at the University of California-Los Angeles. He directs the Ifugao and Bicol Archaeological Projects, research programs that engage community stakeholders. He grew up in Tinambac, Camarines Sur.
label: True
title: [Time Trowel] Heritage is not luxury

text: When the world went silent in 2020 due to the COVID-19 pandemic, dancing and music at Ballet Manila did not stop — it simply moved online. While theaters across the country closed their doors, the company founded and led by the Philippines’ first prima ballerina, Lisa Macuja-Elizalde, found a new rhythm in the virtual space. “During the pandemic, we transitioned to online classes out of necessity,” Macuja-Elizalde tells Rappler. “But it turned out to be a blessing. We gained students from all over the world — people logged in to take ballet classes online.” The Lisa Macuja School of Ballet, the official training school of Ballet Manila, became an unexpected digital stage, connecting young dancers from Manila to Malaysia, Indonesia, and beyond. Even after restrictions were lifted, the company decided to keep this model alive. “We still have hybrid classes now — online and on-site at the same time,” she shares. “It allows us to stay connected with our international students, and I even get to see many of them in person when I travel to conduct workshops and masterclasses abroad.” The shift not only sustained Ballet Manila through the pandemic, it widened its reach and influence in ways few classical dance institutions had imagined possible. Resilience, however, has always been a defining trait of Ballet Manila. Before the pandemic, the company had already faced trials that would have crushed most performing arts groups. In 2019, just before a scheduled performance of Giselle, a massive fire gutted the Star City compound, home to Aliw and Star Theaters, Ballet Manila’s home stage for about two decades. The fire damaged Aliw Theater, a loss that deeply affected Ballet Manila. “We were homeless for a long time,” Macuja-Elizalde recalls. “Then the pandemic happened. And after that, a typhoon.” Yet, rather than retreat, Ballet Manila rebuilt itself — physically and spiritually. “Bouncing back from that kind of nothingness wasn’t easy,” she says. “But we continued. We kept teaching, performing online, and finding ways to bring ballet to people even when the world was shut down.” That perseverance has since paid off. The company’s dancers — now a 42-member ensemble, including 22 women and 20 men — are once again filling the Aliw Theater with movement and music. “We came back with more energy, more purpose,” she says. “When you lose something so important and get it back, you value it even more.” Among the brightest symbols of Ballet Manila’s recent rebirth is Florante at Laura, a full-length ballet adaptation of Francisco Balagtas’ 19th-century epic. The production first premiered in 2024 as part of Macuja-Elizalde’s 60th birthday celebration and returned this year for a limited run from October 3 to 5, complete with a live orchestra conducted by Toma Cayabyab, son of National Artist Ryan Cayabyab. “The ballet is close to my heart,” she says. “It’s a Filipino classic, and I want it to be performed often so that every generation of audiences can experience it.” Everything in Florante at Laura is original — the music, libretto, and choreography. Ryan Cayabyab composed and orchestrated the score, while Michael Coroza served as librettist and consultant. The choreography was crafted by Martin Lawrance and Gerardo Francisco Jr., both long-time collaborators of Ballet Manila. For Cayabyab, the process of creating the score was a journey guided entirely by story and emotion. “The inspiration really came from the story itself and the way it was structured,” he tells Rappler. “I didn’t begin with a theme in mind — I let the narrative lead me. The story always tells me what kind of material or emotion is needed for each scene.” When the ballet required Middle Eastern or Persian influences, Cayabyab dove into research. He said he studied traditional Persian music and discovered it often uses harmonic minor scales. “I wanted listeners to feel transported to that region and era,” he shares. “For the European scenes, I added touches of Spanish and Moorish dance music. Everything had to match the characters, setting, and mood of the story.” The result is a sweeping, rhythm-driven score designed for movement. “Ballet music must give dancers rhythm,” Cayabyab explains. “I built rhythmic contrasts — slower, lyrical sections for love scenes, and more dissonant harmonies for conflict or politics. Everything I know about musical storytelling went into it.” Amazingly, Cayabyab completed the entire score in just two to three weeks. “That’s how I usually work,” he laughs. “Once I start, I don’t stop until I finish. The choreography and staging were developed after the score — it all began with the music.” For Macuja-Elizalde, the collaboration was proof that Filipino artistry could match the grandest of productions anywhere in the world. “The music, the story, the choreography — it’s all Filipino,” she says proudly. “It’s a modern retelling, but rooted in our own culture and artistry. It’s exactly what Ballet Manila stands for.” That identity — a fusion of Russian discipline and Filipino soul — defines Ballet Manila’s artistic style. Macuja-Elizalde herself trained under the Vaganova system in Russia during the 1980s, a time when the country was still under communist rule. “The four years I spent in Russia changed me completely,” she recalls. “I learned discipline, hard work, and simplicity. The Vaganova technique gave me the strength and foundation to dance the great classical roles.” Today, that same rigor forms the backbone of Ballet Manila’s training. “The Russian style gives the dancer strength and precision,” she says. “But Filipino dancers bring something special, they dance every performance as if it’s their last. There’s so much emotion and passion. That combination is what makes Ballet Manila unique.” It’s a philosophy that breathes life into both classical and contemporary productions. In 2025 alone, Ballet Manila’s lineup includes The Pearl Gala in March, Swan Lake in May, Don Quixote in August, and Florante at Laura in October. Abroad, the company continues its regional tours with Cinderella in Kuala Lumpur and Snow White in Taiwan and Indonesia. The Snow White Holiday Cheer Series will close the year in December. Even with a demanding schedule, Ballet Manila’s mission remains the same: “to bring ballet to the people and more people to the ballet.” One of the most meaningful ways Ballet Manila fulfills that mission is through Project Ballet Futures, a scholarship program under the Lisa Macuja School of Ballet. The initiative offers free training and equipment to talented young dancers, especially those who may not have the means to pursue formal ballet education. “We audition students around 10 to 12 years old and give them full scholarships,” explains Macuja-Elizalde, who founded Ballet Manila in 1995 with Osias Barroso. “Some drop out along the way, but many stay and grow into professional dancers. In fact, many of our company members today started in Project Ballet Futures.” The program is open to both Filipino and international students, whether they study on-site or online. “The goal is to make ballet accessible,” she says. “Talent can come from anywhere.” The company also conducts outreach performances and student matinees—programs that often serve as the first introduction to ballet for many children. “Just this week (in the week of October 3 to 5), we had a student matinee of Florante at Laura for university students,” Macuja-Elizalde shares. “They were clapping, cheering, completely engaged. Afterward, some said, ‘Now we understand the story of Florante at Laura.’ That’s the power of performance, it connects people to our own stories.” For Macuja-Elizalde, the mission goes beyond entertainment, it’s about cultivating culture. “When people go to the ballet as naturally as going to the movies or a concert, that’s when we know we’ve made progress,” she says. Over the years, she’s seen audiences evolve. “I meet people who tell me, ‘I watched you perform when I was in elementary school, and now I’m bringing my kids to watch Ballet Manila,’” she shares. “That’s very rewarding. It means the cycle of appreciation continues.” Despite fire, storms, and a global pandemic, Ballet Manila continues to pirouette forward — graceful but unyielding. From rebuilding its theater to nurturing dancers across borders, the company embodies the same resilience that has defined its founder’s life on and off stage. “Every time we rise again,” Macuja -Elizalde says with a smile, “We are reminded why we do this — to share beauty, discipline, and the joy of dance. Ballet teaches you to fall, to stand up, and to keep dancing. And that’s what Ballet Manila will always do.” – Rappler.com Jinji Abaño is a business writer and a lover of the arts. When she is not monitoring the stock market or covering summits, she reads, attends ballet classes or practices some of her old piano pieces.
label: True
title: How Ballet Manila danced its way back from fire, typhoon, pandemic

text: MANILA, Philippines — You might save up on work leaves or wait for the next long weekend before going on a trip. But in reality, you don’t always need a week off to travel — there are a lot of destinations near the metro that you can explore in a day. Located somewhere in Quezon City? Here is a list of destinations you can go to with just a few hours of travel. That is, on a Sunday with no traffic! Hinulugang Taktak, Antipolo City If you’re looking to get in touch with nature, Hinulugang Taktak in Antipolo City is just one of the country’s many national parks. Just an hour from the city lies a majestic waterfall with a height of 21.5 meters. Around the area, you can go swimming, follow a nature trail, or, if you’re feeling bold, walk across a hanging bridge and spiderweb overlooking the falls. This rehabilitated and protected site is nature in its rawest form, all within a reasonable drive. The best part? All amenities and entrance are free! The area is open to enjoy from Tuesday to Sunday, 7 am to 4 pm. ATV Adventures, Antipolo City Still want to see nature but with a little thrill? ATV Adventures in Purok 1, Barangay San Juan, Sapinit Road, Antipolo City offers an off-road adventure along forest trails, rough terrains, and rivers. With five routes that range from amateur-friendly to expert-level, you’re sure to find the trail best-suited to you. Their forest trail package is priced at P2,500 for a 3- to 4-hour trail that brings you through greenery and some rough roads. Aside from ATVs, some less rough but equally fun activities they offer are horseback riding, archery, and paintball. The Heritage Town of Taal, Batangas You can take a step back to the Spanish colonial era with just a two-hour drive to the Heritage Town of Taal in Batangas. There are different day tours for one of the oldest towns in the country, but if you feel like exploring by yourself, there are a few sites you shouldn’t miss. The Taal Basilica, the largest Catholic church in the country and in Asia, is surely one of them. The preservation of its baroque architecture and sheer grandeur makes it one of the most iconic tourism spots in the area. Aside from this, you can visit some ancestral homes that are now museums, including the Gregorio Agoncillo Mansion and the Galleria Taal, with an expansive vintage collection. ​Picnic Grove, Tagaytay Want to escape the heat of the metro for the weekend? Go on a day trip to Tagaytay. The Picnic Grove is more than a green space to feel the breeze, share a meal with family, and go kite-flying. With an entrance fee of P75, this vantage point grants you the perfect view of the Taal Volcano. And if you’re looking for more to do, there are also a hanging bridge, zip lines, a cable car, and horseback riding available in the area. Inflatable Island Club, Subic, Zambales If you’re traveling three hours from the city, you can’t miss out on the trending Inflatable Island Club in Subic. Dubbed “The Biggest Floating Playground in Asia,” the inflatables ensure you never tire of running around on water and trying out different obstacles. But once you feel like taking a break, just within reach are tiki huts to unwind. The beach bar is also there to refresh you after a long day for your travel back home. For P1,400, you can get P500 worth of food and whole-day access at the beach club and the inflatable play area. Mount Batulao, Batangas And for exercise that rewards you with a beautiful view of mountaintops, you can take a hike at Mt. Batulao in Batangas for P120 per head. Its peak stands at 811 meters above sea level, and it has an overall distance of 6.5 kilometers and a level four difficulty of climbing. You’ll definitely need lots of water, sunscreen, and the right snacks to fuel you for the hike. But the nature views you get along the way make all the effort worth it. If you start the hike much earlier, you can even take picturesque photos by the sunset once you reach the summit. Laki Beach, Bataan Experience a budget beach trip with fine white sand and crystal clear water at Laki Beach in Bataan. For an entrance fee of P300, you get to enjoy the clean, refreshing waters of the beach for a day. A group of 10 can pay P250 each for a boat that will take you to the “Five Fingers,” or the five different coves with naturally beautiful designs. Bantakay Falls, Quezon Bantakay Falls is one of the hidden falls in Atimonan, Quezon province that has a height of 31 meters and offers a refreshing cooldown after a bit of walking. You pay P300 pesos for a tour guide that is good for six people. From the registration, you take a 15-minute trek that finally brings you to the refreshing currents of the falls. The falls are open from 8 am to 4 pm, giving you enough time to enjoy and even have a meal by the water (as long as you clean up after)! If you leave QC early, you can even combine this with a one-and-a-half-hour hike at Mt. Pinagbanderahan beforehand, making the cool swim all the more rewarding. – Alyana Fabella/Rappler.com Alyana Fabella is a Rappler intern studying Bachelor of Arts in Communication at the Ateneo de Manila University.
label: True
title: Only free for the weekend? Here are 8 same-day travel ideas to save time

text: MANILA, Philippines – The yearly Mooncake Festival is back! The symbolic Chinese celebration, which is anticipated every 15th day of the eighth lunar month, will take place this year on Monday, October 6. Mooncake Festival, also known as the Mid-Autumn Festival, has long been observed by Chinese communities all around the world as part of tradition. The festive season is when families gather to admire the full moon, share beautifully crafted mooncakes, and celebrate unity, joy, and togetherness. Mooncakes are the usual star of the mid-autumn show, and several hotels, restaurants, and food businesses around Metro Manila offer a variety of traditional favorites and contemporary fusion flavors. Whether you’re looking to share these treats with family and friends, gift them to loved ones, or just a fan, here’s a list of places where you can grab these Chinese pastries to-go! Hong Kong’s number one mooncake brand has taken its mooncake game to the next level this year, with a new Super Lemon Mooncake that’s presented as both playful and elegant, with a yellow octagonal gift box. The box contains lava-filled mooncakes that come with a citrusy fragrance. Another interesting set is the MX Pokémon Mooncake Gift Box, which features an adorable imprint of Pokémon’s iconic character, Pikachu, and Poké Ball details. Since it is a collectible, the box also comes with a Pokémon-themed eco-bag for fans. The store’s original flavors are still available, such as the Lotus Seed Mooncakes with two egg yolks, and the Lava Assorted Mooncakes that come in six flavors: Lava Custard, Lava Chocolate, Lava Cheese, Lava Coconut, Lava Caramel Macchiato, and Lava Black Truffle Custard. If you’re quite health-conscious but still want to enjoy mooncakes, check out the Low-Sugar Series — there’s the Low (Reduced) Sugar Mixed Nuts Mooncake, along with last year’s favorite, the Low (Reduced) Sugar Lotus Seed Paste Mooncake with Egg Yolk. Inside Newport World Resorts in Pasay, Hilton Manila offers a Celestial Moonbeam mooncake collection, which was designed as a handbag inspired by traditional Chinese textile art. The collection features five sets: Traditional Set (with a tin can of Chinese red tea), Boutique Set, Snow Skin, Shanghainese Set, and Do-It-Yourself (DIY) Set, with prices ranging from P688 to P3,988. Meanwhile, Marriott Hotel‘s Man Ho mooncakes are available in various flavors. The Red Lotus Paste, Lotus Paste, and Matcha Paste all come with salted yolk, each priced at P338. Another selection of the same price is the Snow Skin with Custard. Mooncake boxes are available for sets of four or six, priced at P2,288 and P2,888, respectively. Pre-orders are open until Friday, October 10. Hotel Okura Manila previously offered the Akizuki Mooncake Box collection until September 30. The hotel featured four mooncakes: Green Tea, Red Bean, White Lotus, and XO Conpoy. Made by Yawaragi’s award-winning pastry team, the mooncake collection was named Akizuki, which means “Autumn Moon.” Solaire Resort North in Quezon City has a mini mooncakes collection called Standard Series, which comes in boxes of two or four. The mini mooncakes are filled with White Lotus Paste with double salted egg yolk, Red Bean Paste with almonds, Pandan Lotus Paste with single salted egg yolk, Ube Paste, Lava custard, and Assorted Fruit Nuts with Kam Hua Ham. For southbound customers, Solaire Resort Entertainment City in Parañaque City is serving both traditional and modern flavors. One type of traditional mooncake comes with various paste options: White Coffee, Chocolate, Orange, and Pineapple. Another type comes with Salted Egg Yolk, White Lotus Paste, Red Bean Paste, Pandan Paste, and Ube Paste. You can find Hong Kong MX Mooncake PH at S Maison, SM Aura, and Ayala Malls Vertis North. There’s also a branch in NuStar Cebu. It can also be found on online stores. The branch’s modern mooncake collection, Snow Skin Series, comes in four flavors: Pineapple Paste, White Coffee Paste, Matcha Paste, and Chocolate Paste. Although Kee Wah Bakery is no longer taking online orders, its Supreme Mooncake collection can still be availed at branches like Robinsons Magnolia, SM Aura Premiere, and S Maison. Among its products are a tin of Chinese Ham Mooncake with Assorted Nuts and Mini White Lotus Seed Paste with Yolk, both priced at P375. Mooncake boxes include White Lotus Seed Paste with Two Yolks and Golden Lotus Seed Paste with Four Yolks Flavors: White Lotus Seed Paste, Golden Lotus Seed Paste, and Chinese Ham. They come in four or eight pieces, with prices ranging from P1,400 to P3,600. For Shangri-La’s EDSA branch, its Mooncake Collection at Shangri-La Boutique includes new products: Hojicha and Snow Skin Champagne Chocolate. The boutique also features its classic mooncakes: Red Bean, White Lotus, Black Sesame, and Mixed Nuts. Mini mooncakes are priced at P488, regular-sized mooncakes cost P788, a box of two costs P2,088, and the square box is available for P3,688. Makati Shangri-La’s Heartfelt Shangri-La Mid-Autumn Collection is themed “Moonlit City,” offering six varieties: White Lotus Seed with Double Egg Yolk, Assorted nuts and Chinese Ham, Jasmine Tea, Coconut and Sesame, Red Bean with Aged Orange Skin, and Red Wine and Dried Raspberry. Prices vary depending on the size and number of pieces, ranging from P1,688 to P4,388. Boxes come in two or four pieces, while you also have a choice of large or small mooncakes. Mooncake sets from Shangri-La branches have been available since July 8 and will be sold until October 6. The Peninsula Boutique in Makati City sells authentic Hong Kong mooncakes. A set of four Mini Egg Custard Mooncakes is priced at P3,888, while a set of eight assorted mooncakes featuring four Lotus Seed Paste and four Egg Custard is available for P5,888. Grand Hyatt Manila in BGC offers mooncakes in two styles: traditional and twist. The collection features classic flavors like White Lotus, Red Bean, Black Sesame, Ube, and Mixed Nuts, while snowskin creations have flavors namely Raspberry, Sangria, and Croquant. The hotel’s mooncake sets are also presented in elegant, pastel pink boxes inspired by the plate motifs of No. 8 China House. The collection is available until October 6. New World Makati Hotel is celebrating the Mid-Autumn Festival with “A Canvas of Connection,” its 2025 mooncake collection. The lantern-shaped box, inspired by traditional paper-cutting art, symbolizes reunion, prosperity, and togetherness. The design depicts mountains, seas, and the full moon, representing stability and the longing for reunion. Inside are mooncakes prepared by the hotel’s culinary team, combining classic flavors with contemporary touches. The mooncake gift boxes will be available for purchase at the hotel lobby in Makati City. City of Dreams Manila in Parañaque City’s Cantonese restaurant Crystal Dragon presents a celebratory menu from October 1 to 19 for lunch and dinner. The restaurant offers a dessert set featuring the Cranberry Mango Lava Snow Skin Mooncake and Oven-baked Traditional Mini Red Bean Mooncake, paired with Chilled Honey Lemon Tea, fresh pomelo, and mallow nuts. Café Society’s limited-edition White Lotus Seed Paste Mooncakes with Double Egg Yolk are available throughout October, and are presented in an elegant four-piece gift box. Crystal Dragon is open daily from 12 noon to 11 pm, while Café Society operates from 10 am to 9 pm, with an early opening schedule at 8 am on Tuesdays. – Steph Arnaldo and Alessandria Coral/Rappler.com Alessandria Corral is a Rappler intern studying Bachelor of Arts in Speech Communication at University of the Philippines Diliman.
label: True
title: LIST: Where to get mooncakes in Manila for Mid-Autumn Festival 2025

text: MANILA, Philippines – The Philippines is home not only to thousands of islands, but also to the many mythological creatures believed to inhabit them. While many Filipinos are familiar with the tree-dwelling kapre, the mischievous duwende, and especially the bloodthirsty aswang, there are also quite a few lesser-known ones — creatures both feared and revered, all born from the same soil that remembers our roots as Filipinos. If you think that only the Greeks have centaurs, then you haven’t heard of this mythological creature from Batangas. The anggitay is an ethereal amalgam of a woman’s face and upper body, a mare’s lower body, and a unicorn-like horn on its forehead. This is not to be mistaken for a tikbalang, which possesses a horse’s head and hooves and is commonly known to be a mischievous trickster who likes to mislead travelers and play tricks on human senses. Other depictions of the tikbalang paint it as a creature that abducts and mistreats children and women. The anggitay is believed to be the opposite, and supposedly helps guide lost travelers back to the right path. It is most associated with collecting precious jewels and gemstones, mirroring their intrinsic connection with the land. However, it is known to be elusive to humans, and is said to often only appear on a bright yet rainy day. If you hear a faint squeaking sound on the street after a midnight shower, it means a karkarison is in the vicinity — and someone in that street is said to fall ill and die the next day. The karkarison is a small cart pulled by a headless bull and ridden by three or four headless, woman-like figures. During epidemics, it roams through villages spreading disease. Otherwise, it only makes rare appearances, and is said to travel from one haunted tree to another before vanishing. Haunted trees are believed to be the resting places of the karkarison and other spirits. Villagers often light fires nearby and throw bones into the flames to keep these creatures away. Other preventive measures include placing rice-chaff smudges by house gates and under staircases, and drawing white crosses with lime on doors and posts. The pasatsat’s story was born out of the trauma suffered by Filipinos during the Japanese occupation. As Filipinos then could barely keep up with the cost of living, they didn’t have the means to honor the dead properly, either. Some families wrapped their deceased loved ones’ bodies in a banig (mat) instead of giving them a proper burial. The pasatsat, said to have originated in Pangasinan, often reveals itself to passersby on deserted paths as a corpse in a rolled up banig. It’s believed to be the spirit of a person who died or was killed during World War II. The word comes from the Pangasinense word “satsat,” which means “punit” (rip) — alluding to the idea of needing to stab the banig for it to disappear. As the body never shows itself, one of the only indicators of its lingering presence is the smell of decay. While many Filipino mythical beings are depicted as violent or malevolent, the lampong is deemed less hostile, and perhaps even friendly, due to its duty to protect and preserve. Among the Ilongot of Northeast Luzon, the lampong’s purpose is to defend wild animals. It’s often known to take the form of one among its flock or metamorphose into a white one-eyed deer, watching over them and even distracting or diverting preying hunters. A hunter’s first five shots are said to always miss the lampong. But when it finally pierces through, the hunter’s strength will begin to fade day by day until he dies at last. Could anything be more bone-chilling than a manananggal flapping its wings across the night sky? Turns out, there is. The sangkabagi resembles a grim reaper on a flying boat, in search of souls to carry and transport to the realm of the dead. Legends say the sangkabagi snatched people as they slept and fed on livers to fill the wounds with herbs. They allegedly command termites or weevils to destroy the clothes, rice, corn, and seeds of anyone who has wronged them. However, some accounts noted that the sangkabagi were antagonized by Spanish colonizers and were originally known to be helpful — guiding the dead to the afterlife, healing the sick, and even gifting their dearest friends a magical book that allows them to travel anywhere in an instant. These are only some of the many Filipino folklore creatures that may have been forgotten, but continue to exist in our memories and in the stories that we tell. While we often find it easier to learn about the mythologies of other countries, whose tales are more accessible and preserved than ours, it’s never too late to be a part of a growing generation that fights to remember. – Jaella Magno/Rappler.com Jaella Magno is a Rappler intern studying AB Literature major in Creative Writing at De La Salle University.
label: True
title: You’ve heard of ‘aswang’ and ‘tikbalang’ — but probably not these other Pinoy folk creatures

text: MANILA, Philippines – Six Philippine business groups voiced their support towards several efforts to promote transparency and good governance. In a statement on Friday, October 17, the groups backed proposed reforms to the bank secrecy deposit law and the Foreign Currency Deposit Act. The statement was signed by the following groups: The groups described the two laws as “straitjackets” for regulators that prevented them from being more efficient in tasks such as investigating and prosecuting those involved in corruption and money laundering. The groups also believe the laws have severely restricted the Philippines’ country’s financial and economic stability. The proposed amendments to the bank secrecy law allows the Bangko Sentral ng Pilipinas (BSP) to examine deposits when its Monetary Board finds reason to suspect bank officials and employees or those tied to BSP-supervised financial institutions are involved in fraud. “By empowering regulators and enforcement agencies with the authority to investigate corruption, tax evasion, and other illicit economic activities, the reforms will help ensure integrity across both public and private financial systems,” they wrote. In a blog post by BSP Deputy Governor Mamerto Tangonan, Assistant Governor Maria Margarita Debuque-Gonzales, and Currency Policy and Integrity Head Eloisa Glindro, the officials called for the easing of bank secrecy laws to curb corruption. “Easing bank secrecy — with appropriate safeguards — would empower investigators to trace illicit funds, match deposits to asset declarations, and build prosecutable cases. Unlike demonetization, which imposes broad costs on the public, transparency reform targets corruption at its source,” the officials wrote. The three officials of the monetary authority also described calls to demonetize the P1,000 and P500 bills as a blunt and high-cost instrument against corruption. Their remarks come after former finance secretary Cesar Purisima called for the phaseout of P1,000 and P500 bills amid claims that billions in public funds were delivered to the homes of Leyte 1st District Representative Martin Romualdez and former Ako Bicol representative Zaldy Co. The three BSP officials also called for complementary measures to curb corruption such as the following: Business groups also strongly support Ombudsman Jesus Crispin “Boying” Remulla’s decision to restore public access to officials’ Statements of Assets, Liabilities and Net worth (SALN). The groups believe that lifting the Duterte-era restriction will reinforce the constitutional principle that accountability is key to maintaining citizens’ confidence in their public institutions. They also underscored the importance of good governance in boosting the confidence of local and foreign investors. “When governance systems are predictable and information is accessible, the risks of corruption and policy uncertainty decrease, lowering the cost of doing business. This attracts sustained capital inflows, promotes fair competition, and contributes to stronger, more resilient economic growth,” they said. – Rappler.com
label: True
title: PH business groups back bank secrecy reforms, restoring SALN access

text: BAGUIO, Philippines – The first night of December always hits differently in Baguio, but this year, it felt like the city took one deep breath and exhaled pure Christmas magic. Before sunset, people began lining Session Road. By 4:30 pm, the Baguio police estimated the crowd at 30,000, including the hundreds set to join the Saint Louis University Lantern Parade. It was not chaos. Rather, it was community – the very Baguio way of filling every curb, step, and ledge with anticipation. When the lights flickered on, the crowd’s collective gasp said it all. The Upper Session Road Christmas tree was towering and seemed alive. Built largely from bamboo and softened with layers of Peruvian ferns, red and Chinese poinsettias, lemon pine, and vincas as ground cover, it felt like a tribute to Baguio’s plantitas (people who love plants and gardening) and every green thumb who has ever whispered, “Kaya ko ’yan alagaan (I can grow that).” The city government decided this year’s decorations should be organic, indigenous, and kinder to the environment, producing less waste after the season and more beauty rooted in nature. Even the Botanical Garden followed suit with local flowers and natural elements. Credit goes to the artists and craftsmen like Resty Lopez, Joey Quinio, Reydon Amking, and James Calicdan whose hands shaped the tree into something that looks grown, not built. The program opened with the familiar sound of the UB Rondalla, instantly setting a homegrown celebratory tone. UB Voices and Graces soon lifted the mood higher with doxology, hymns, and carols. The city’s leaders offered messages rooted in gratitude, unity, and the meaning of light. Mayor Benjamin Magalong’s words echoed through the crowd: “Ang tunay na Pasko ay hindi nasusukat sa garbo o dami ng dekorasyon. Nasusukat ito sa kabutihan ng puso – sa ating pagpapatawad, pag-unawa, at sa liwanag na kaya nating ibahagi sa isa’t isa.” (Christmas is not measured by grandeur or the number of decorations. It is measured by the goodness of the heart, by our forgiveness, understanding, and the light we can share with one another.) Then, in a 10-second countdown and a roar from the crowd, Baguio lit up. The tree burst into color, and fireworks from SM City Baguio drenched the sky in gold and ember, reflecting off dramatic December clouds that seemed as ready for the season as everyone else. The weather wasn’t perfect, but the night was. Immediately after the fireworks, the crowd turned to the 17th Saint Louis University Lantern Parade, a tradition that draws thousands each year. Silk lanterns swayed, glowing floats rolled past, students danced in coordinated costumes, and thousands of phones captured every passing light. Color, culture, and creativity swept through Session Road. This year, the parade became a world tour of light festivals, each represented in artistic displays by an SLU school. Lanterns inspired by Germany and the Netherlands glowed in the evening breeze. Vietnam’s Hội An Lantern Festival was also recreated, while Myanmar’s Tazaungdaing Festival of Lights appeared in crafted lanterns and floats. Australia’s Moon Lantern Trail shimmered alongside Thailand’s Yi Peng Festival. Lanterns evoking South Korea’s Seoul Festival and Japan’s Nagasaki Festival floated past. The parade also showed vibrant representations of India’s Diwali. When the parade ended, Session Road still hummed with laughter and conversation. The glow of the evening lingered, the kind of warmth you carry home after a perfect night. Walking back toward Cathedral Loop, it felt as if December had officially arrived. The Christmas tree was greener than ever. The city was bathed in lights. The parade had “crisscrossed” continents, bringing distant cultures into Baguio’s streets. And the community had shown up once again for moments that truly matter. – Rappler.com
label: True
title: Baguio breathes Christmas: Lights, lanterns, and a city alive

text: MANILA, Philippines – Ask a chef where their culinary inspiration comes from, and many may recall a childhood dish tied to a warm memory, a mother’s regional specialty, a mentor, or a street food vendor they met on their travels. For many chefs, inspiration is borrowed from a special place, a person, or a fleeting moment with a permanent impact. But for Chef Francis Tolentino, inspiration comes from something more elemental: the ground we stand on, the air we breathe, the water we drink, and the earth beneath our feet. At Taupe, located in Bonifacio Global City, Tolentino channels the “elements” in his third tasting menu. Newly recognized by the Michelin Guide Philippines in October, Tolentino is soaring with post-award pride yet keeps his feet firmly grounded, anchored by Taupe’s vision of balancing creativity with traditional techniques and a deep respect for local ingredients. The elements are also his compass, drawing from the smokiness of fire, the lightness of air, the flow of water, and the slowness of earth. “I wanted to go deeper into the fundamentals this time around. Air, water, fire, earth. How does each one influence the way we cook and taste food?” Tolentino told Rappler. “It wasn’t just about using these elements as inspiration but about finding balance between nature and technique. I asked myself: how can we transform an ingredient while still respecting its essence? That became the foundation of the menu.” Tolentino embraces modern culinary techniques such as dry-aging, fermentation, smoking, and freezing. But for him, dry ice isn’t just for dramatic effect, nor is tableside blowtorching a mere performance. These methods are intentionally chosen to reveal the humble depth of each ingredient he champions — from calamansi snow, fermented guava, to charcoal-burnt meringue. Taupe doesn’t scream fine dining to the point of intimidation. Catch Tolentino at the marble counter in the front of the pass, overseeing his line cooks as they calmly and coolly add the finishing touches to the course. Here, he is in his element, setting each dish underneath the warming lights with confidence and ease. Chef is right beside them, sharing a laugh or casual banter with his staff. As Tolentino’s first fine dining concept heads toward another year, the Filipino chef has learned that fine dining isn’t just about the food — it’s about building trust with the guests. “I’ve learned that they come back not only for the dishes but for the story and the experience. Moving into our third year, I want to be more confident in our identity while still pushing myself and the team to evolve. The lesson is: stay grounded, but don’t stop moving forward.” Tolentino had been working for casual dining, bars, hotel kitchens, and cafés in the past before deciding to pursue fine dining in 2024. He knew that he still wanted to celebrate Filipino flavors and ingredients, but with a global approach. Years of traveling across Asia and the West provided the modern culinary techniques, but his love for the Philippines keeps the heart and soul of each ingredient at the center of each menu. His childhood days in the province of Nueva Ecija, where he paired suman or sticky rice with grilled pork, still find their way in his dishes. The name of his restaurant, Taupe, reveals the mindset behind the food. “Taupe is my canvas, where I express my passion for elevating Philippine ingredients into an art form. It’s a place where the love for my homeland’s produce and my favorite global flavors come together to create culinary masterpieces,” he said. With the Michelin Guide finally recognizing restaurants in the Philippines, Tolentino is ecstatic. Taupe was awarded Michelin Selection recognition, putting Tolentino’s philosophy on the map, where familiar ingredients are given a contemporary but refined and warm approach. “It’s a big deal because it puts our food culture on the global stage and highlights the talent, passion, and hard work of so many Filipino chefs and restaurateurs,” he told Rappler. “I think this will have a huge impact on tourism. Food has always been a big part of our culture, and now, more people might travel here just to experience our dining scene.” He told Rappler that with his dishes, he wants people to think of it as comfort food at its core, beyond the innovative iterations and intricate presentations. Food that is nothing too gastronomically alien or extravagant, but dishes that guests wouldn’t mind ordering à la carte another time. “For chefs and restaurant owners, this definitely raises the bar. It’s great motivation to keep pushing for excellence, but at the end of the day, what really matters is staying true to who we are — cooking with heart, telling stories through our food, and making people happy.” For his current menu, Tolentino utilizes the elements in each dish’s presentation — a dramatic puff of dry ice here, or a glittering dusting of 24k edible carat gold there — inviting an atmosphere of immersion for diners to understand which element grounds the course. A journey from air (lightness) to earth (depth) with the interludes of water and fire take guests on a ride of airy foams, crisp layers, and fluffy textures; smoke, char, and grilled intensity; clean crudos and fresh fish; and umami depth, slow-cooked meats, and soil-like textures. When asked what his favorite element to play with was, Tolentino was the most excited about air. “It’s intangible but it changes how you experience flavor and texture. Working with lightness — foams, aerations — allowed me to surprise guests without overwhelming them. It taught me how something almost invisible can leave such a strong impression,” he said. The Burnt Brazo dessert — air and fire meeting halfway — features local passion fruit, calamansi, vanilla egg custard, and Italian meringue, whipped delicately and then burnt with hot charcoal right at the table, a reminiscent nod to childhood s’mores. Roasted and sweet, fluffy and light, the fruit components bring liveliness to the meringue, something Tolentino aims to do when presenting familiar produce and ingredients — breathing air and new life into them. But water is where his favorite dish of this menu lies. “The Blue Crab Ice Cream Sandwich is very close to my heart. It takes something familiar from our waters and presents it in a way that’s unexpected, playful, but still comforting. I love that it challenges perceptions without losing that connection to home,” he said. It’s a crunchy and delicate snack eaten with your hands, an ode to childhood ice cream sandwiches (but one that we definitely couldn’t afford back then). Blue crab filling is inside an indulgent chicken skin biscuit, with mango gel, osetra caviar, and cold smoked roe, to give it an elevated one-bite umami bite that isn’t too overwhelming but is actually cold and refreshing. The amuse-bouche Prawn Butter Brioche is another highlight — rich, fresh local river prawn custard butter atop a fluffy and slightly sweet lemongrass brioche. Water and fire do not usually go together, but Tolentino’s Hokkaido Scallop and Corn do, proving even opposing elements can be respectfully united. The scallops are lightly smoked and cured, bouncy and tender, atop a creamy bisque of Japanese corn with shrimp head fat drizzled on top. Mixed, the shrimp fat adds richness to the sweet corn. The palate cleanser 24k Magic is pretty and sparkly, and a welcome break from the richness of the first half of the menu — fermented guava soft gel and lime pandan syrup offer a fruity, tart pause before the heavier, fire-breathing courses that follow. “Lately, I’ve been working a lot with fermentation. It’s alive, ever-changing, and brings a depth that you can’t create any other way. There’s a certain humility in letting time and process shape flavor — it’s not just the chef’s hand, but about patience and respect,” Tolentino shared. Each dish has a story to tell, and an element takes center stage — from fire breathing smoky life into the tender A5 wagyu balbacua, grilled and dry-aged, with beef tendon demi-sauce and kadyos purée for a hint of acidity to counterbalance the beef’s richness; to water and flow in the wet-aged hamachi, plump, fresh, and clean, laid on a snow of fresh longan and calamansi. Add a scoop of creamy avocado purée, and you have Tolentino’s vision of a refreshing crudo, where both fruit and fish shine. The Dry Aged Duck, grilled until gamey and tender, features a keso de bola veil, braised duck meat quenelle, smoked truffle sauce, and coconut ash duck sauce — a brown-on-brown dish that doesn’t hold back on richness and saltiness. “I want them to leave curious and inspired. Whether it’s their first fine dining meal or one of many, I hope they see how food can be both thoughtful and approachable,” Tolentino said about his wish for Taupe’s diners. “We’re not just about spectacle. It’s about transformation, balance, and discovery. If they walk away with a memory that makes them think differently about what food can be, then we’ve done our job.” The meal ends with petit fours influenced by his childhood and travels — Turon with smoked banana mousse, banana cylinder, and caviar; Bibingka with salted egg semifreddo and coconut custard; Hopia with red and green mung bean ganache and pinipig tuile; and Karyoka with fried glutinous rice, purple yam, and rosehip compote. Taupe’s 10-course tasting menu, priced at P7,800, and its eight-course tasting menu at P6,500, sit at the higher end of the tasting menu price range. But considering the number of courses, the handpicked selection of high-quality ingredients, and the overall dining experience, they are justified. The atmosphere is neither stiff nor stuffy, but modern and simple — an ambiance that directly reflects Tolentino’s culinary philosophy. With Michelin recognition now attached to both Tolentino and Taupe, there are no plans to change course. After all, why fix what isn’t broken? Tolentino’s promise for every seasonal tasting menu is to continue focusing on the best local ingredients of the moment while constantly reimagining how to highlight what makes each component special — both individually and together in unison. – Rappler.com
label: True
title: Nature meets technique: Chef Francis Tolentino is in his element at Taupe

text: About one in four employees has a diagnosable mental health condition, and up to 65 percent say mental health concerns interfere with their ability to work. The economic toll is staggering. In the United States alone, mental health concerns cost over $280 billion annually. Worldwide, that figure reaches an estimated US$1 trillion annually. Mental health is increasingly being recognized as critical to workplace functioning. Organizations invest substantial resources in wellness programs, mental health training and employee assistance programs. Some even offer on-site therapy sessions at no cost to their employees. Yet despite these efforts, many employees remain hesitant to seek help or disclose their mental health conditions. This reluctance can leave employees under-supported and contribute to increased absenteeism and turnover. Those who choose not to disclose often miss out on access to workplace accommodations and support, which can exacerbate their conditions and even increase the risk of job loss. Disclosure can be a gateway to vital support, but questions remain about how to facilitate such disclosures. Our research, recently published as an open-access article, shows the decision to disclose a mental health condition isn’t purely personal and can depend on the broader workplace environment. Across two samples, we surveyed 1,232 employees from Canada and the US. We recruited participants from Qualtrics, an online panel provider, and a large financial institution in Canada that operates across multiple locations. We asked employees — both with and without mental health concerns — to indicate the extent to which they perceived their organization as supportive of disclosing mental health concerns. Employees with mental health concerns shared whether they had disclosed their condition to their employer, how willing they were to disclose in the future, their levels of anxiety and depression, and a range of work-related attitudes and behaviors. We found that a work environment that was safe and supported the disclosure of mental health concerns was extremely beneficial for both employees and organizations. First, employees working in highly supportive environments were 55 percent more likely to disclose their mental health concerns. These environments were also linked to greater willingness to disclose current or potential mental health concerns. Second, supportive environments were associated with lower levels of anxiety and depression, both of which are important indicators of mental health. This suggests that organizations can contribute to employee mental health by fostering supportive environments. Third, employees who felt their organization supported disclosure reported higher job satisfaction, greater work engagement, and more organizational citizenship behaviors, such as helping co-workers or going above and beyond their job duties. These kinds of behaviors help create healthy, high-performing workplaces. In one of our samples, we matched employee responses with their organizational records of absenteeism. We found that when employees rated their organizational environment as supportive of mental health disclosure, they were less likely to miss work due to illness. Our study identified three elements of a workplace that support mental health disclosure. The first is the absence of stigma and anticipated discrimination. Many employees choose to conceal their concerns because they are fearful of being stigmatized, facing unfair treatment or being passed over for promotions. Employees often pick up on subtle cues in their environment — consciously or not — to estimate the risk of stigma. If they observe colleagues with disclosed mental health conditions being treated negatively, this signals low organizational support and makes disclosure appear risky. The second element is the availability of organizational resources. Disclosing one’s mental health concerns should unlock access to organizational supports, such as time off or counseling programs. These supports need to be tangible and go beyond mere mentions in the employee handbook. Employees form perceptions about how seriously their organization takes mental health based on whether these resources are present and accessible. The third element is the presence of social support. Our research found that social support was an important indicator of informal culture around mental health concerns. Such support may include emotional support from peers or supervisors, and the ability to openly discuss mental health. Employees notice whether, and how, mental health is discussed at work. When employees are encouraged to talk openly about it, the workplace appears more conducive to disclosure. In contrast, when concerns are dismissed or met with unhelpful advice such as “stay positive” or “toughen up,” the environment is unlikely to be seen as supportive. Our research points to four main strategies organizations can use to foster an environment that signals support for disclosing mental health concerns. 1. Identify areas for improvement Our research provides a list of survey items that organizations can use to track employee perceptions and identify priority areas for improvement. For example, employees might be asked whether they feel safe disclosing a mental health concern, or whether they believe the organization responds supportively when others do. These items can be include in annual employee surveys, with anonymity ensured to encourage honest responses. 2. Combat stigma by role modeling Workplace leaders are well-positioned to make positive change and role model appropriate behaviors. Employees often look to leaders and model their behavior. Providing leaders with training about implicit biases, and equipping them with tools to provide support to employees with mental health concerns, can help start the cycle of positive change. Leaders who receive mental health training tend to be more supportive, more likely to encourage disclosure and are better able to guide employees toward appropriate help. 3. Make resources visible and easily accessible Even when organizations have resources available, employees may not know about them or may find them difficult to access. Organizations and managers need to frequently communicate about the availability of mental health resources and ensure they are easy to access. Red tape and bureaucracy can deter employees from accessing organizational supports. 4. Talk openly about mental health Talking about mental health can help normalize it and encourage employees to share their concerns. This can include intentionally creating opportunities for such discussions, such as mental health days. In addition, when senior leaders share their experiences with mental health concerns, it can help normalize such discussions. Ultimately, a disclosure-supportive environment benefits employee mental health and encourages positive work behaviors. In other words, when employees feel safe enough to speak up, both employees and organizations benefit from it. – Rappler.com Zhanna Lyubykh is an assistant professor at Beedie School of Business, Simon Fraser University. Justin Weinhardt is an associate professor of Organizational Behavior and Human Resources at University of Calgary. Nick Turner is a professor and future fund chair in leadership at Haskayne School of Business, University of Calgary. This article is republished from The Conversation under a Creative Commons license. Read the original article.
label: True
title: Why employees hesitate to disclose mental health concerns – and what employers can do about it

text: MANILA, Philippines — Hotels are among the busiest establishments during the holidays, and it’s no secret that it takes logistics and careful planning to give Filipino families the time of their lives in a home away from home.
