It is also possible that your Kuya Arnold purposely chose the time and date of the funeral because he had a feeling this is what would upset you most. This realization won’t erase what happened in 2025, but I hope it will help you look at his behavior from another perspective. Definitely, his behavior can be classified as assh*le, i.e., since his choices seem to depend on what reaction he can get out of you both. However, his behavior is also pathetic, as he cannot seem to make a choice independent of you both. You would think a mature person would choose integrity, the inherent rightness of the situation, and kindness as guides to his behavior, rather than what would piss off his siblings most. In that sense, parang he seems more kawawa (a figure to be pitied) than threatening. It is also possible for adult children to behave the way they used to when they were younger. Was your brother a bully when he was younger? Is it possible that the grief you all experienced during your aunt’s cremation reactivated these old dynamics, reminding him (and you) of unresolved childhood conflicts? You and your brother have chosen to live far away from your brother because of his personality and family expectations. I hope his behavior and your reactions confirm that you made the best decision. Admittedly, this may seem small consolation at such a time, but reminding yourself of this (and of his kawawa-ness) may ease a little of the aggravation you and your brother may still be experiencing. All the best, MG Holmes – Rappler.com
label: True
title: [Two Pronged] Brother insisted on having late aunt buried on New Year’s Eve

text: MANILA, Philippines – A Filipino feast will never be complete without a wide array of sauces and condiments. It’s the “sawsawan culture,” with dips like vinegar, soy sauce, sweet chili, ketchup, fish sauce, and their assortment of combos, often found on Filipino tables. And if you love the spicy kind, the Fire Fest 2025 will definitely be a feast for the palate as hundreds of bottles and jars of hot sauces and condiments will be served from October 4 to 5 at the Renaissance Convention Center in Marikina. Chef Gene Gonzalez, who collaborated with the Philippine Hot Sauce Club during the event kickoff in September, picked early strong contenders: the Ghost Pepper and Carolina Reaper. “When you try it the first time, it won’t knock your brain cells just yet. It’s interesting. You have to wait 15 seconds before it hits you,” said Gonzalez. “It expands in your palate and it will drive you wild in a good way.” In this weekend’s Fire Fest, there will be a Table of Fire, a long, free-for-all buffet featuring almost 450 types of hot sauces and spicy condiments from the Fiery Cup 7 competition. The event will culminate with the Fiery Cup 7 Awarding, which honors the best in chili and spicy creations in different categories; a Fire Fest BBQ Cup, a grilling competition pitting top pitmasters; and the First Chili Cocktail Cup, a mixology battle showcasing innovative spicy cocktails. During the event kickoff, Gonzalez and his team offered a sneak peek, curating an impeccable selection of hot sauces from different brands and makers, and meticulously pairing them with local dishes: “We checked and we’re one of the largest competition of hot sauce in Asia, pertaining to the number of entries received. In the world, we rank sixth or seventh,” said Eric del Rosario, co-founder of the Philippine Hot Sauce Club. But competition aside, the event also gathers the different hot sauce organizations in the country. Ponchit Ponce Enrile, a business owner from Negros, is one of the pioneers of the community that includes the Philippine Chili Federation, Sili PInas, and Chili Growers Philippines, among others. “With the growing number of groups… I put up a federation wherein we’re all together and to also unite everyone under one umbrella,” he said. Del Rosario shared that there are other clubs like Labuyo, who are hardcore collectors of hot sauces, and Labuyo 100, where members must be able to consume 100 pieces of chilis within 15 minutes. For Fire Fest 2025 tickets, visit firefestph.com or the event’s official ticketing partner TicketMAX. – Rappler.com
label: True
title: Fire Fest 2025 brings heat to Filipino food favorites

text: (This is a press release from the Philippine Association of University Women-UP Chapter) The University of the Philippines’ flagship cultural program Tanghal Tertulia emerged as one of three winners in the much-coveted Best Special Events Production category at the 38th Aliw Awards, held at the Fiesta Pavilion of The Manila Hotel on Monday, December 15. Tanghal Tertulia distinguished itself as the only special event mounted by an educational institution of higher learning to be shortlisted and ultimately recognized in this highly competitive category — underscoring UP’s leadership in advancing arts and culture on the national stage. Launched in 2024, Tanghal Tertulia traces its origin to an inspired evening at the UP Executive House Amphitheater, when UP President Angelo Jimenez delivered an impromptu poetry performance, moved by the swaying bamboo trees and the twinkling stars under a clear night sky. That moment sparked a vision for a regular artistic gathering honoring UP’s National Artists. Jimenez then tasked Fina Dela Cuesta Tantuico of the UP Philippine Association of University Women to convene an ad hoc committee to conceptualize a program that would celebrate UP’s creative legacy and inspire new generations of Iskolars ng Bayan. The name “Tanghal Tertulia,” coined by Professor Emeritus Jose “Butch” Dalisay, draws from the Spanish tradition of the tertulia — a gathering for literary and artistic exchange. “When we set up Tanghal Tertulia, we did not set out to win any awards. In fact, our motivations were far more modest,“ said Jimenez. “Sitting as we do on a powder keg of creative talent, it was impossible not to ignore the fact that 44 of the country’s 81 National Artists came from UP. Tanghal Tertulia was our way of putting a spotlight on that legacy, and of sharing it generously with the public. We accept this award on behalf of mga Artista ng Bayan at mga Iskolar ng Bayan. UP Fight!” Tanghal Tertulia is made possible through the collaborative leadership of Atty. Fina Dela Cuesta Tantuico (VP for Public Relations, UP Philippine Association of University Women); Dr. Patricia Brillantes Silvestre (Dean, UP College of Music); Toym Imao (Dean, UP College of Fine Arts and Chair, UP President’s Committee on Culture and the Arts); Dr. Grace Javier Alfonso (Executive Director, TVUP); and Atty. Edlyn Frances V. Verzola (President, UP-PAUW), whose collective vision and stewardship have transformed the program into a nationally lauded cultural institution. Joining Tanghal Tertulia in the winners’ circle for Best Special Events Production are “That’s Amore – RMA” and “JL 75th – The Beatles Concert” — both ticketed, commercial productions. In contrast, Tanghal Tertulia stands apart as a free cultural offering that is open to the public, reaffirming UP’s mission to democratize access to the arts and bring artistic excellence to the widest possible audience. Building on this milestone, preparations are now underway for the next edition of Tanghal Tertulia on February 21, 2026, which will honor three more living National Artists from the University of the Philippines, continuing UP’s enduring commitment to celebrating artistic excellence and inspiring future generations through the transformative power of the arts. – Rappler.com
label: True
title: UP’s Tanghal Tertulia recognized in 38th Aliw Awards

text: MANILA, Philippines – The latest addition to Sunlight Air’s fleet has finally landed. The boutique airline on Friday, October 24, welcomed its first ATR 72-600 turboprop plane, the fourth aircraft in its turboprop fleet. The newer, bigger plane also spots Sunlight Air’s refurbished livery and logo. Sunlight Air’s newest aircraft has a seating capacity of 68 passengers and emits less carbon emissions per passenger as it burns 45% less fuel. The plane also contains advanced noise insulation and fewer seats to provide more legroom to its passengers. Passengers of the boutique airline may spot this new plane on its maiden flight on Sunday, October 26. It will service Sunlight’s Clark-Siargao, Siargao-Cebu, Cebu-Busuanga, and Busuanga-Clark routes. For Sunlight Air’s chief executive officer Ryna Brito-Garcia, the newest aircraft to their fleet aims to bring the boutique aviation experience to more passengers on its short-haul regional flights. “It aligns with our goal to continuously improve our services and expand our route offerings, connecting more travelers to beloved island destinations while showcasing Sunlight Air’s signature hospitality,” she said. Garcia, the country’s only female commercial airline chief, also underscored the carrier’s goal of connecting travelers to underrated destinations in the Philippines. “This new ATR 72-600 will allow us to serve you better, continue connecting communities that deserve better access, and beautiful islands that deserve better awareness,” she said. Sunlight is also set to launch its Cebu-Siquijor route in December, making the boutique airline the first to offer direct commercial flights to the island province. The carrier will be operating flights between Cebu and Siquijor four times a week. As Sunlight Air aims to further expand its operations, the boutique airline also revealed it is in talks with Airbus to purchase its first jet. However, it has yet to disclose the type of jet it is looking to acquire. – Rappler.com
label: True
title: Sunlight Air welcomes ATR 72-600 aircraft to its fleet

text: MANILA, Philippines – Every October, pink ribbons remind women to get screened and checked for breast cancer. But behind the Breast Cancer Awareness Month campaigns lies a dire statistic: more Filipino women are being diagnosed with breast cancer than ever before. In 2022, around 33,000 Filipino women were newly diagnosed with breast cancer, making it the most common cancer among women in the Philippines. Our country’s rate is among the highest in Asia, which is a cause for alarm. For every 100,000 women, about 60 Filipinas are diagnosed with breast cancer each year, while the average in Southeast Asia is around 42, and across Asia, about 34. To put it in perspective, nearly one million of the 2.3 million new breast cancer cases worldwide come from Asia alone. The fact that the Philippines’ rate is significantly higher than the regional average shows that Filipino women face a greater risk. It’s something we should all be concerned about. But why is this happening? Dr. Diana O. Cua, a breast surgeon at Makati Medical Center and one of the first Filipino surgeons to train in breast surgery at Stanford University, said that one major cause is that lifestyles and family habits have shifted over the years. “Many women now have children later in life or have fewer children. More people are also living in cities, and rates of obesity are going up, all of which can raise the risk of breast cancer,” she told Rappler. But lifestyle isn’t the only culprit. Screening remains a weak spot in the country’s healthcare system. “Breast cancer screening in the Philippines is not yet fully organized. Most women get checked only when they visit a clinic for another reason,” said Cua. “There also aren’t enough mammogram machines in many areas, which means many cancers are still found at a later stage.” And as Filipino women live longer, more reach the age where breast cancer risk naturally increases. “Early diagnosis can be difficult because of travel, cost, and lack of proper guidance through the health system,” she added. “But in tertiary centers like MakatiMed and other hospitals, we’re seeing more women diagnosed at early stages — and because they receive full treatment, most go on to be completely cured.” Across ASEAN countries, the Philippines ranks among those with the highest breast cancer rates, alongside Singapore. More women are developing risk factors such as obesity, hormonal changes, and later pregnancies, Cua said. Filipinos also face slow medical access and financial barriers. “Studies have found that low access to mammograms and delays in diagnosis and treatment lead to more advanced cases and higher death rates,” said Cua. “The challenge is twofold: more women are at risk, and many still cannot get tested or treated early. Solving both problems is key to saving more lives.” However, even women diagnosed early often face “catastrophic health expenses within a year,” said Cua. “Many need to travel far for tests or treatment. Some hospitals still lack imaging or biopsy services, and there aren’t enough cancer specialists in many areas.” PhilHealth’s Z-Benefit package now covers more treatments, raising financial coverage to P1.4 million, but gaps remain. Only select hospitals offer the Z package, and the process can still be long and bureaucratic. “Outside big cities, patient navigation — someone guiding you through the system — is still hit or miss,” Cua said. “These hurdles lead to delays and treatment breaks, which can seriously affect recovery.” One troubling trend Cua has observed is that more young women are being diagnosed with breast cancer. Some of these cancers are more aggressive. “Many of my patients in their 30s and 40s are very proactive. They feel a lump, get it checked, and are diagnosed early. These are the women with highly curable Stage 1 or 2 cancers,” she said. “But I also see a few young women who are in denial, and by the time they come in, the cancer has already spread.” Younger women, she added, face unique challenges after treatment, such as fertility issues and emotional recovery. There needs to be more age-sensitive support systems in cancer care, Cua said. There isn’t one sure cause for breast cancer risk. There are various controllable and uncontrollable factors, including genetics. “In the Philippines, about 1 in every 20 women with breast cancer has inherited mutations in genes like BRCA1 or BRCA2,” said Cua. “If breast cancer runs in your family, it’s worth asking your doctor about genetic testing.” Still, she emphasized that lifestyle remains a major area where women can take control. Women today tend to have children later, move less, and consume more processed food. Obesity, high blood sugar, and high cholesterol also raise hormonal risks over time. “The best thing we can do is take care of our overall health — eat real food, move often, and maintain a healthy weight,” she said. While breast self-exams (BSE) are often promoted as a life-saving habit, Cua explained that the data paints a more nuanced picture. “BSE alone doesn’t actually lower breast cancer deaths; it can even cause unnecessary panic or extra tests,” she said. “What we should focus on is breast awareness: knowing what’s normal for your body so you can spot changes early.” The best formula involves mammograms and ultrasounds, paired with immediate medical consultation when something feels off. “It’s not just about having more machines — it’s about making care accessible and helping women understand what to do next,” she said. “Awareness should lead to action.” Despite the grim picture, Cua is optimistic that progress is possible. Cheaper versions of key cancer drugs like trastuzumab have made targeted therapies more affordable, she shared. Newer treatments such as CDK4/6 inhibitors and immunotherapy are also extending lives. Diagnostic tools have improved, too; more patients are receiving core-needle biopsies and hormone receptor testing, allowing doctors to design more personalized care plans. On a global level, there’s also policy progress, with the World Health Organization (WHO), World Bank, USAID, Europe, and Japan pushing to increase their budget allocation for breast cancer. “Breast cancer will soon be recognized as a global health priority under the 2025 United Nations Political Declaration on Non-Communicable Diseases,” Cua shared. “This means more international funding and stronger government accountability, and a step forward for women everywhere.” To truly reduce breast cancer deaths, Cua believes the Philippines needs stronger early-detection pathways, expanded access to screening, and simplified treatment systems. “It’s not enough to tell women to get checked,” she said. “We need to bring care closer to them, especially outside Metro Manila, and make sure benefit packages keep up with new evidence.” At the end of the day, it’s about how we can turn awareness into access, and access into action. It is a community effort. “When all these pieces come together — early detection, equitable care, and financial support — that’s when we’ll start seeing fewer deaths from breast cancer,” Cua said. “Not because of one single fix, but because we finally made the system work for women.” – Rappler.com Dr. Diana Cua is a board-certified medical oncologist at The Medical City and an active member of the Philippine Society of Medical Oncology (PSMO). She completed her Doctor of Medicine at the University of the Philippines College of Medicine and her Internal Medicine and Medical Oncology training at The Medical City. Dr. Cua has been involved in various cancer research, clinical trials, and awareness campaigns focused on early detection and women’s health.
label: True
title: Why are more Filipino women getting breast cancer?

text: MANILA, Philippines – Unemployment improved for a second consecutive month to 3.8% in September as the construction industry added more jobs to the economy, the Philippine Statistics Authority (PSA) said on Thursday, November 6. The latest jobless rate translates to around 1.96 million Filipinos. This is lower than the 3.9% or 2.03 million jobless Filipinos tallied in August but higher than the 3.7% or 1.89 million unemployed Filipinos in September 2024. Meanwhile, underemployment worsened in September at 11.1% or 5.52 million Filipinos. This is higher than the 10.7% or 5.38 million underemployed Filipinos in August, but lower than the 11.9% or 5.94 million underemployed Filipinos in August. The construction sector saw the largest increase in employment in September, adding 514,000 jobs since September 2024. National Statistician Dennis Mapa highlighted gains in the jobs related to the construction of buildings, plumbing, and air conditioning installation, as well as the construction of utility projects. However, Mapa noted that the construction sector was also one of the reasons why underemployment figures increased. This means the jobs added to the sector may only be temporary ones. “So posible na may mga workers, but a number or a portion of the workers hindi nagkaroon ng 40-hour job. Some of them are hired, let’s say, as a temporary hand or partial lang ‘yung kanilang work done in that particular week,” he explained. (So it’s possible that there are workers, but a number or a portion of the workers are not working 40 hours a week. Some of them are hired, let’s say, as a temporary hand or their work was only partially done in that particular week.) Mapa added that the flood control scandal might have contributed to the month-on-month reduction of construction jobs. The Department of Public Works and Highways paused bidding for infrastructure projects for nearly two weeks in September. As for job losses, the PSA found that other service activities such as domestic work (-493,000 jobs) shed the most jobs in September. Mapa said the shedding of jobs in domestic work is often tied to household income. He noticed that jobs in domestic work are often added when households make more money. The manufacturing sector also continued to bleed jobs as the industry contracted for the first time in six months in September, according to data from the Standard & Poor’s (S&P) Purchasing Managers Index. “New orders and output decreased slightly as firms mentioned a fall in client numbers and a modest drop in production from the suspension of rice imports,” S&P Global Market Intelligence senior economist David Owen said. The Department of Economy, Planning, and Development (DEPDev) said the latest job figures reflect the Philippine labor market’s “resilience” despite headwinds. DEPDev Secretary Arsenio Balisacan underscored the importance of implementing interventions to create more stable, high-quality jobs for the informal sector and the youth. The country’s chief economist cited the recent passage of the Lifelong Learning Development Framework Act, which creates a system for continuing education. “Ensuring the timely release of its implementing rules and regulations is a priority. The government must also actively communicate the policy, particularly to local government units, which will play a key role in promoting lifelong learning,” Balisacan said. – Rappler.com
label: True
title: Construction job gains push down unemployment to 3.8% in September 2025

text: (This is a press release from the Manila Electric Company.) MANILA, Philippines – After a P0.1852 per kilowatt hour (kWh) reduction last month, the Manila Electric Company (Meralco) announced on Monday, October 15, an upward adjustment of P0.2331 per kWh for October. This brings the overall rate for a typical household to P13.3182 per kWh this month from P13.0851 per kWh. For residential customers consuming 200 kWh, the adjustment is equivalent to an additional P47 in their total electricity bill. Coming from a P0.2603 per kWh reduction last month, the October generation charge went up by P0.1903 per kWh. Charges from Independent Power Producers (IPPs) and Power Supply Agreements (PSAs) increased by P0.3622 and P0.3567 per kWh, respectively, primarily due to the depreciation of the local currency against the US dollar, which affected 99% and 48% of their respective costs. This month’s generation charge also reflected the impact of the interim extension of Meralco’s power purchase agreement with First Gas-Sta. Rita plant as approved by the Energy Regulatory Commission (ERC). The increase was tempered by lower charges from the Wholesale Electricity Spot Market (WESM) that went down by P2.0688 per kWh owing to a decrease of about 1,000 MW in Luzon’s peak demand. IPPs, PSAs, and WESM accounted for 21%, 74%, and 5%, respectively, of Meralco’s total energy requirement for the period. Transmission, taxes, and other charges also registered a total increase of P0.0428 per kWh. Pass-through charges for generation and transmission are paid by Meralco to the power suppliers and the grid operator, respectively, while taxes, universal charges, and Feed-in Tariff Allowance are all remitted to the government. Meralco reiterates that its distribution charge, on the other hand, has not moved since the P0.0360 per kWh reduction for a typical residential customer beginning August 2022. Customers also continue to benefit from the ongoing implementation of the distribution-related true-up adjustment, equivalent to a reduction of P0.2024 per kWh for residential customers. With the recent earthquakes affecting parts of the country, Meralco assured its customers that it continuously safeguards its distribution facilities from potential hazards to ensure the safety of both of its crews and customers. Among the safety measures the power distributor implements include replacing wooden poles with taller and more durable concrete or steel ones, relocating facilities away from high-risk areas such as railroad tracks and waterways, and conducting regular tree trimming and wire clearing operations to manage foreign attachments on power lines. The company also implements re-insulation and conductor shielding of power lines, enhancing of lightning protection systems, and installing of smart devices to swiftly identify and isolate service concerns. Meralco also stands ready to de-energize power if the situation warrants it to protect the public. Likewise, Meralco enjoins customers to continue observing electrical safety measures to be better prepared for disasters and avoid accidents. These include unplugging appliances when not in use, regularly inspecting electrical cords for damage, and knowing the location of the main electrical switch for quick access during emergencies. After an earthquake, and only if it is safe to do so, customers should turn off the main switch or breaker to prevent fire or electrocution, unplug devices to avoid further damage, and steer clear of any damaged equipment or downed power lines. Electrical hazards should also be reported to Meralco. – Rappler.com
label: True
title: Meralco rates go up in October due to higher generation charge

text: ROME, Italy – Italian cooking, already celebrated around the world, is poised for a new accolade: formal recognition as a cultural treasure from the United Nations’ cultural agency, UNESCO. A preliminary UNESCO assessment has cleared Italian cuisine to be added to UNESCO’s ‘Intangible Cultural Heritage’ lists and a final decision is expected on Wednesday. Launched in March 2023 by Italy’s agriculture and culture ministries, the bid casts Italian cuisine – from pasta and pizza to risotto and cannoli – as a social ritual that binds families and communities together. “There is no single Italian cuisine, but a mosaic of local expressive diversities,” the government said. From Lombardy’s ossobuco – braised veal shanks with gremolata, to Puglia’s orecchiette con cime di rapa – ear-shaped pasta with turnip greens, each region showcases Italian biodiversity and creativity, it said. Prime Minister Giorgia Meloni has championed the effort, calling Italian food a symbol of “culture, identity, tradition and strength.” Industry groups estimate UNESCO recognition could boost tourism by up to 8% in two years, adding 18 million overnight stays. Italian cuisine also connects 59 million residents with up to 85 million people of Italian descent worldwide. Globally, the Italian food service market hit 251 billion euros ($293 billion) in 2024, or 19% of the global restaurant market, Deloitte said. But imitation products abroad cost Italy an estimated 120 billion euros annually. Not everyone in Italy supports the bid to join UNESCO lists, which already feature almost 800 items including Italian opera singing and truffle hunting. Alberto Grandi, a food historian, called the UNESCO candidacy “just a marketing operation” in an interview with website Mantovauno last month. In his 2024 book La cucina italiana non esiste’ (‘Italian cuisine doesn’t exist’), Grandi argued that many dishes considered traditional, including pasta alla carbonara, are relatively modern inventions influenced by foreign cultures. Grandi’s remarks have sparked a backlash from farmers’ association Coldiretti, which called his claims “surreal attacks on national culinary tradition.” For restaurateurs like Luigina Pantalone, owner of Rome’s historic Da Sabatino, a UNESCO nod from Wednesday’s meeting in India would be a source of pride. “Authentic Italian cuisine needs to be protected,” she said, recalling childhood days washing dishes with her brothers and proudly noting that she is the fourth generation of her family to run the restaurant. Three-Michelin-star chef Massimo Bottura summed it up: “Italian cuisine is an ancient, daily, sacred ritual – the art of caring and loving without saying a word.” ($1 = 0.8590 euros) – Rappler.com
label: True
title: Beyond pizza and pasta: Italy’s culinary heritage awaits UNESCO nod

text: It’s the start of a new year again, which means that it’s time for another clean slate. The beginning of the year is a chance to start fresh. It’s an opportunity for you to reset the certain aspects of your life that you aren’t satisfied with — whether that’s through listing down your New Year’s resolutions, decluttering your space, or doing one big clean-up to simulate that feeling of starting over. But many people look for some form of guidance when they turn a new leaf, and one of the most common ways is through the practice of tarot. While tarot has yet to be widely accepted in the Philippines, there are a myriad of Filipino practitioners dedicated to keeping the art alive, and showing curious onlookers that it can be a guiding force for good. Among them are Pau of Paghilom and Rob Rubin of Mysterium Philippines, who both offer tarot readings for clients looking to face the new year head-on. Tarot is a form of cartomancy that typically uses a deck of 78 cards that each correspond to a specific archetype, though there are some instances where readers would interpret cards differently when they come out in reverse. For Pau, tarot reading comes intuitively to her, in contrast with the readers who often take a predictive approach to it. She makes it a point to get in tune with the energy of her clients, as this helps her accomplish a reading that gets down to what’s weighing on their minds. “I use [tarot] personally and for my clients as well. [I do an] intuitive reading of the energies of the client or myself together with the archetypes of the cards,” shared Pau, who started her tarot practice in 2018 while she was still working as a teacher. When reading tarot, Pau explained that the circumstances surrounding the client also matters — from the people around them to their experiences, what they’re feeling at the moment, and the emotions dominating their mood. A post shared by tarot reading, crystals, reiki healing 🧿 (@paghilom__) “I trigger introspection with my clients so at the same time I’m reading the cards, they’re also reading into their [own] energies, emotions, and also their mindsets during times of confusion. Because it’s very important that my tarot reading is participative.” Meanwhile, Rob describes tarot as a tool for empowerment. He emphasizes that while tarot can give you a blueprint to explore what you can achieve as an individual, no reading is ever set in stone. “If you want clarity, you want to understand the unknowns, the options, the possibilities, the promises, the potentials, you can have a tarot reading because that’s going to give you clarity of the issues that are important to you — be it career, love life, spirituality, ambition. All of it is pretty much addressable in the tarot. This golden rule we say in tarot, though, is we do not predict dates of death,” explained Rob, who started his tarot journey around three decades ago at 14 years old. A tarot reading, no matter what aspect of your life it covers, can still change over time. The same goes for New Year readings. It’s normal to look for some sort of guidance when we welcome a new chapter in our lives. We have all these past experiences that have brought us years’ worth of life lessons and opportunities for character development, yet we sometimes don’t know what to do with them. This is where tarot comes in — and it’s more common than you think. According to Pau, in the five years that she’s offered her reading services online, the “year ahead” reading remains to be her most availed one. Her clients would often start booking sessions as early as October the year before, up to February of the succeeding year to gain insight into how they can go into the new year with peace of mind. Pau would always use two spreads for these kinds of readings. First is the thematic one, which covers an individual’s reflective energy based on their greatest lessons from the previous year, and how all these would connect to their aspirations for the coming year. “It’s very reflective in terms of how your habits can affect the different aspects of your life for the next year. So they discuss your love life, career, finances, spirituality, health, well-being, and the possibility of the energies based on your current energies. It’s reflective to the point that it tells you, ‘Okay, because these are your habits, these are your possibilities,’” Pau explained in a mix of English and Filipino. If you’re looking to see changes or movement in your life, this spread will tell you what can happen based on your current energies. But if you want something different, you will know that you have to make radical changes in your energies — because the spread has shown you your current capacities. A post shared by tarot reading, crystals, reiki healing 🧿 (@paghilom__) The other spread is the monthly one, which covers how an individual would plan for the next 12 months of the new year based on the possibilities that can happen then. This spread will still rely on your current energies, but it will dig deeper into what exactly can happen to you this year as Pau will also discuss the internal and external forces that come into play. It will make you aware of the forces you can’t control, and the factors that you can still change. These things are laid out for each month. The kind of “year ahead” reading that works best for you will depend on your own priorities for the coming year. Do you want to have a guide for each month of your life? Consider getting the monthly spread. Do you crave reflection and making sense of your energies? Maybe the thematic spread is for you. Rob, meanwhile, offers to his VIP clients what he refers to as an “annual forecast,” where he forms a roadmap for the next 12 months of their lives. During the reading, Rob would also determine the energy a client would have for each month, and would then provide them with a guide to plan their year. “For example, you want to get married in June, but in that month, during the reading, we see there’s nothing but bad cards there. Then, we might tell you, ‘Hey, let’s not do that in June because we don’t want to be part of that kind of energy,’” Rob said. Every tarot practitioner is different. Pau deems it important for her clients to go into her readings already knowing what they want to gain insight into. It doesn’t have to be specific — just a gist of it all can work. Often, the querent can just tell Pau that they’re feeling confused in life and don’t know what to do, and she can take it from there. “For me, intention is very important. Kaya tawag ko sa mga questions ng mga querents would be intentions. What are your intentions in this reading? Kung wala kang specific question, ano na lang ‘yung ba’t ka nandito?” Pau shared. (For me, intention is very important. It’s why I refer to the questions of my querents as intentions. What are your intentions in this reading? If you don’t have a specific question, tell me instead why you are here.) The same thing goes for Pau’s “year ahead” readings, where she would ask clients what happened in the last 12 months leading to the reading, along with what their goals or intentions are given these experiences. Some clients opt to be extra-specific, while others prefer to keep it a bit more general. But for Pau, anything goes. Rob, meanwhile, takes a different approach. For him, his clients don’t even have to say anything. “You just need to tell me you need to have the reading and then we’ll set it up. And I always highly suggest to my clients that we have it on Zoom so you can have a full recording because it’s a lot of information. It looks at the year per month. It doesn’t matter if you have an idea or not,” he told Rappler. When he starts roadmapping each month of the year, he would tell his clients what they should and should not be doing, and what their options are. A post shared by Robert Rubin Tarot Readings 𓃤 (@robrubinreadings) But tarot readings — above all else — are supposed to empower you. They aren’t supposed to be fatalistic and shouldn’t dictate your life. It’s supposed to give the power back to you rather than the other way around. “If I told you tomorrow that no matter what you do, it’s set in stone, you’re going to Solaire and you’re going to gamble away all your money and become bankrupt. What are you going to tell me? You’re going to say, ‘Then guess who’s not going to Solaire tomorrow?’ A real reader will give the power back to you,” Rob said as an example. And in 2026, as a general outlook, Rob attests that you can get what you want this year, but you need to work for it. The card for 2026 is The Chariot — which symbolizes victory. “With the card being the chariot for the year, you can get your heart’s desire this year. You just need to be willing to put in the work for it. If this is the year you say you want to lose weight, this can be the year you lose weight, but you must be willing to pay the price for it. You must be willing to put in the effort. Don’t just be idle about this,” he said. According to Rob, the energy that 2026 brings is drastically different from that of 2025. “The end of 2025 was very, very morbid. There were a lot of deaths because it’s the snake year. It’s like the snake shedding its skin before it’s over. After it sheds its skin, once 2026 starts, then everything’s going to start moving fast-paced. It’s the Year of the Horse as well. Horses and chariots [are related to each other], so it’s really in alignment,” Rob said. That said, keep a positive mindset that 2026 can be a great year for you. If there’s a big goal you want to achieve, perhaps tarot can help give you that foresight and peace of mind. – Rappler.com
label: True
title: Heal and take action: How tarot reading can help you plan for the year ahead

text: Last week, on November 7, the latest statistics on national income turned out to be a real shocker. For the third quarter of 2025, production only grew by a measly 4% from the previous year. This is the lowest quarterly growth rate of the country since 2011 (if you don’t count the pandemic). This is also very low compared to the target of the economic managers. Back in 2022, President Ferdinand Marcos Jr. targeted growth this year to be 6–8%. But when that proved unattainable, his economic managers lowered the target to 5.5–6.5%. Now, even 5.5% seems to be a moonshot: to achieve that, production in the last quarter of 2025 will have to grow by 7%! Palace spokesperson Claire Castro somehow insists this can still be done — a case of what I might call “delulunomics.” If you break down of the data, you’ll see that the third quarter of 2025 is also notable as the first quarter since the pandemic where the growth contribution of investment spending dropped. In other words, investment spending pulled down growth. A further parsing of the data will reveal that this is also the second consecutive quarter where government construction spending slumped and pulled down total investments. You might interpret this as the government being a lot more cautious in public works spending, amid the flood control scandal that President Marcos himself announced to the world back in July. This brings to mind the administration of the late Benigno Aquino III, whose anti-corruption slogan meant overly cautious government spending in the early 2010s. (This prompted them to implement the Disbursement Acceleration Program or DAP, later declared unconstitutional by the Supreme Court.) One wonders: How much of economic growth is being propped up by corrupt spending? If you take away corruption, will economic growth in the past few years have been a lot lower? Worse, is there a trade-off after all between growth and corruption? On the one hand, we’re seeing years where growth is high but corruption-ridden. On the other hand, growth is weaker because the government is stamping out corruption. Is it too much to ask for high and corruption-free growth? When asked about anemic growth, President Marcos said that other factors are at play, including the multiple class and work suspensions (owing to disasters) and the fallout of Trump’s tariffs. This echoes what his chief economist said a week prior. Sure, the effects of climate change are getting more intense (as evidenced by Typhoon Tino and Super Typhoon Uwan) and Trump’s tariffs are souring the global business environment. But there’s something broken in our own backyard, and it’s getting harder and harder to deny it. Other indicators of economic malaise include the historically weak peso. On November 14, the exchange rate reached P59.11 per US dollar (as of writing) and it seems the Bangko Sentral is not too worried to let the exchange rate cross the psychological threshold of P60 per US dollar. As I wrote last week, one reason for a weaker peso is stronger demand for dollars, and this usually happens when investors want to pick up their money and invest elsewhere. Data from the Bangko Sentral also reported a steep drop of foreign direct investments (FDI): a massive 40.5% drop from August 2024 to August 2025, and a similarly alarming 22.5% drop from January to August 2024 to the same period in 2025. I can’t help but remember the numerous foreign trips made by President Marcos at the start of his presidency, supposedly to attract investments. Years later, that would be undone by large-scale corruption that he allowed to fester. So those foreign trips were useless, after all, and proved to be mere junkets that “reintroduced” the Marcoses on the global stage. In many ways, it’s not so surprising that corruption is festering under yet another Marcos presidency. But it’s also unsurprising to see that his efforts so far to curb corruption have been weak as hell. On November 13, President Marcos appeared in a press conference to update the country about his anti-corruption drive. He boasted about the 20,000 or so complaints received on the online portal “Sumbong sa Pangulo,” and encouraged people to keep on filing reports about anomalous flood control projects. But in launching this website, the President essentially outsourced the investigation to citizens, when in fact his office should be able to scan all flood control projects and pinpoint those which have been corrupted. Remember, his office sits on top of billions of pesos worth of confidential and intelligence funds! More than receiving reports, people expect Marcos to jail the corrupt. But it’s been more than three months since his State of the Nation Address, and everyone is still scot-free. Former lawmaker Zaldy Co is still globetrotting, and former public works secretary Manuel Bonoan has flown to the US. When asked about his cousin Martin Romualdez, former speaker of the House of Representatives, architect of the corrupted national budgets since 2023, President Marcos could not have been more evasive. Instead, Marcos seems to be zeroing in on small-fry scapegoats such as the conjugal contractors, Sarah and Curlee Discaya. Here in the Philippines, it’s notoriously difficult to hold public officials accountable. Heck, Filipinos keep electing the corrupt or giving them even more power than before (think Imelda Marcos and Juan Ponce Enrile, who [finally] passed away yesterday at age 101). Don’t get your hopes up that the real masterminds in the flood control mess will be jailed. And don’t get your hopes up that our economy will magically recover any time soon. – Rappler.com (Editor’s note: This article was written before Zaldy Co, in a video released on Friday, November 14, tagged President Ferdinand Marcos Jr. and former House speaker Martin Romualdez in corrupting the 2025 national budget.) JC Punongbayan, PhD is an assistant professor at the UP School of Economics and the author ofFalse Nostalgia: The Marcos “Golden Age” Myths and How to Debunk Them. In 2024, he received The Outstanding Young Men (TOYM) Award for economics. Follow him on Instagram (@jcpunongbayan).
label: True
title: [In This Economy] Economic malaise grips the Philippines

text: On November 11, 2025, the De La Salle University (DLSU) Ramon V. del Rosario College of Business (RVRCOB) was awarded 4 Palmes of Excellence at the Eduniversal World Convention hosted by the Indian Institute of Management (IIM) Indore at the Indore Marriott Hotel. This puts the DLSU RVRCOB in the top 20% of 1,000 ranked business schools worldwide. Eduniversal recognized the college’s programs that combine academic rigor with real-world business experience. The 4 Palmes recognize academic excellence and regional leadership through research, sustainability, and ethical business practices. By nurturing Lasallian business leaders who make a difference, RVRCOB advances global business education excellence. This award, though very much welcome, raises challenging questions for reflections. How does a school with international influence become a global force for good? The answer requires looking beyond our own achievements to learn from institutions that have wrestled with this question too. The convention, with the theme “Bridging Purpose and Performance: Business Education as a Force for Good,” opened with Professor Himanshu Rai’s remarks and keynote. As the director of IIM Indore, he explained the role of Indore and his business school in contributing to India’s nation-building efforts. His institution holds Triple Crown accreditation, ranks among the world’s top 1% of business schools, and sits on a 193-acre campus, and plays a vital role in the development of Indore. With the efforts of the local government, the school, and the citizens, Indore has been recognized as the India’s cleanest city for seven consecutive years. Moving to his keynote, Rai chose to ground ethical leadership lessons on Vedic wisdom and ancient Sanskrit texts. Rai connected Vedic wisdom to concrete leadership failures he’d witnessed: leaders who lost themselves in performance metrics, who deflected accountability when decisions went wrong, who operated below their capacity because they feared failure more than they valued excellence. Rai calls IIM Indore as “ancient yet agile.” The phrase captures something we need to understand. The school doesn’t treat its cultural heritage as decoration or as separate from “real” business education. Indian wisdom isn’t an elective. It’s the foundation that shapes how they think about leadership, how they structure experiential learning programs, and how they evaluate what counts as success. The Vedas and the Indian heritage are taught as business education, not alongside it. The case of IIM Indore is fascinating in its paradox: it honors its tradition, yet it is considered a top global school of tomorrow. How can Filipino business schools learn from this example? At RVRCOB, we have something similar: our Lasallian tradition and our Filipino values. But do we teach them as business education or merely adjacent to it? Context-wise, the Philippines and India share characteristics. Large populations, rapid growth, collectivist cultures, family business dominance. Colonial histories creating tension between indigenous wisdom and imported models. What if Philippine business schools integrate our respective values with our cultural heritage? What if RVRCOB combines Filipino concepts with Lasallian pedagogical discipline? Filipino psychology and philosophy provide rich cultural resources. The most relevant to management, I think, are the Filipino constructs I would label as “DKL” (in part because it can be read as “dakila”) — diwa, kapwa, and loob. Loob represents the inner self, the seat of volition and authentic conviction. Kapwa captures our relational nature, the recognition that self and other are fundamentally interconnected. Diwa points toward collective consciousness, the spirit that animates groups and organizations. Similar to how Rai drew from the wisdom of the Vedas, DKL describes how Filipinos actually experience and navigate the world. A manager who cultivates loob develops genuine conviction rather than performing what they think leadership should look like. A leader who practices kapwa builds organizations where people matter as people, not as human resources. An institution animated by diwa serves purposes that transcend narrow institutional interests. DLSU’s Lasallian Reflection Framework already provides a structured approach to values-based practice through Masid-Danas (See-Experience), Suri-Nilay (Analysis-Reflection), and Taya-Kilos (Commitment-Action). These aren’t just steps in a process. Masid-Danas means being mapagpansin, genuinely attentive to what’s actually happening, not what theories predict. Suri-nilay goes deeper than standard analysis, malalim (deep), seeking integrated understanding by engaging intellect and intuition together, the capacity to grasp situations holistically, to see patterns that pure logic might miss, to develop insights then validate them iteratively. Taya-kilos is where discernment becomes action, may pananagutan, completely accountable and responsible, not action for its own sake but movement that flows from genuine understanding. The path forward requires three shifts. First, Philippine business schools need to stop treating Filipino values as supplementary to “real” business education. They are our foundations for thinking about management, leadership, and organizational purpose. Second, we need to develop pedagogical approaches that genuinely integrate these values rather than just mentioning them. IIM Indore structures entire programs around their heritage, from their Rural Engagement Program to their Himalayan Outbound Program to their workshops on Mithila traditional art forms. What would Filipino business education look like if we took our own wisdom traditions that seriously? Third, we need to root ourselves more deeply in Philippine social realities. Business education becomes a force for good when business schools become genuine partners in addressing the specific challenges facing Philippine society. RVRCOB’s 4 Palmes recognition tells us that Philippine business schools are worth recognizing globally. IIM Indore shows us one possibility: a business school that draws strength from its cultural context while meeting global standards. Our international peers are calling for us. The global picture needs the colors only we Filipinos can add. – Rappler.com Patrick Adriel H. Aure, PhD (Patch) is the founding director of the PHINMA-DLSU Center for Business and Society and Associate Professor at the Department of Management and Organization, Ramon V. del Rosario College of Business, De La Salle University. patrick.aure@dlsu.edu.ph
label: True
title: [Good Business] Business education as a global force for good

text: ​​I digress from my usual programming to write about a recent vacation to Taipei. The last time I was there was in 2014, and I was eager to see how things had changed more than a decade later, especially with the specter of China hanging over everyone’s heads. I’m happy to report that things are perfectly normal there — for now. The dumplings, hotpot, and large hunks of chicken are as delicious as ever. The boba milk tea is still as sweet. And the stinky tofu is, well, still as stinky. The night markets are bustling with people: there was barely anything to stand on. (READ: From night markets to nature: The vacationer’s guide to Taipei 2023) We went there on the weekend when Typhoon Opong hit the Philippines, and the weather in Taipei was quite hot. At one point, there was, in fact, too much sun. This forced us to go around on Uber rides, which was cool and, well, uber-convenient. Near sundown one day, we climbed Elephant Mountain, which offered a lovely view of the city. We did the same back in 2014, when we had much more limber bodies. This time around, the climb took more of a toll on our bodies. It was a reminder that maybe we (I) should be working out more. An even more breathtaking view of the city can be seen at the topmost floor of Taipei 101, which was the world’s tallest building for some time, beaten only by Burj Khalifa in 2010. We rode the elevator, which scaled 89 floors in just 37 seconds flat, and I’m glad it’s still the world’s fastest. We saw again the damper, the colossal steel ball in the middle of Taipei 101, which stabilized the entire structure. In May 2019, Taiwan became the first Asian country to legalize same-sex marriage. My boyfriend and I stood and took a picture at a rainbow-painted street in Ximending District, but admittedly the LGBT vibes are not as out there as in Bangkok, where same-sex marriage has also been legalized. All in all, it was amazing to see how normal life was in Taipei. It’s business as usual, at least on the surface. (READ: 10 family-friendly things to do in Taiwan) Yet, there were tell-tale signs of how much things have changed amid China’s increasing threats of conquering Taiwan. For example, along the streets, you’d often see small posters pointing to “Air Defense Shelters.” People already know where to go in case the worse happens. People have also been training in first aid, conducting drills on how to evacuate. Said one BBC report, “In downtown Taipei, emergency teams and volunteers practiced evacuating injured people, putting out fires, and lowering themselves down buildings which had been dressed up to look as if they had been hit by missiles. Medical teams triaged evacuees in a car park, wrapping up wounds and stringing up bags of saline for IV drips under tents.” I don’t want to imagine how much destruction will happen in this otherwise peaceful country, with its otherwise peaceable people. But if and when war breaks out, the world’s attention will zero in on this small country, and I’m afraid that life will never be the same again there. One of the sectors most at risk is Taiwan’s semiconductor industry. This country alone produces nearly all of the world’s most sophisticated semiconductors, used in all sorts of products like smartphones, laptops, wearables, smart appliances, engines, servers, robots, military communications systems, satellites, quantum computers, etc. Among Taiwanese firms, TSMC, or the Taiwan Semiconductor Manufacturing Company, is the most prominent and vital. China wants to control Taiwan’s semiconductor industry to boost its own economy and military, and in the process also weaken the influence of the already embattled US economy. But at the same time, China also can’t risk destroying this sector when war pushes through. Such an event will cripple not just China but also the rest of the world. And the last thing China wants is to antagonize the rest of the world and lose allies left and right. At any rate, China’s rhetoric continues to suggest that they’re gearing up to invade Taiwan. Recently, China insisted that a past UN resolution can be used as legal basis for invading Taiwan. But Taiwan denounced this and said it’s plain and simple disinformation. The thing is, even the US seems to be trying to get a piece of the pie that is the semiconductor industry. A US representative recently floated the idea of a 50-50 production scheme between the US and Taiwan. Allegedly, this is because of the US desire to secure semiconductor production in case the China-Taiwan war begins. Under Trump, the US government is also actively pushing for the “reshoring” of tech manufacturing within US borders. Understandably, Taiwan is likewise pushing back against the US on this. Before this, Trump imposed a 20% tariff on imports coming from Taiwan. All this puts into question to what extent the US is a true friend to Taiwan, especially once push comes to shove. Despite being so much richer than us (their per-person income is over seven times ours), Taiwan and the Philippines today face many of the same problems. We both find ourselves trapped between two warring global powers (the US and China), we both face trade attacks from the US (the Philippine tariff is not too far at 19%), and we both face the prospect of Chinese invasion (but obviously Taiwan is so much more at risk, because the risk of invasion is nationwide). A few months ago, I had watched a number of war games that provide hints at various scenarios that could happen if a Chinese invasion of Taiwan happens. I’m not an expert on it, but all the scenarios looked grim to me. The likelihood of the Philippines being roped in is quite high, not least because we’re so very near Taiwan. The old joke is that when you’re in Batanes province, there’s a chance you can hear the rooster crowing in Taiwan. But seriously, President Ferdinand Marcos Jr. himself said on record we will inevitably be pulled into war if and when China decides to attack Taiwan. I can only hope that the worst doesn’t happen. At any rate, I was stumped at how calmly the Taiwanese are going on with their lives. Their bravery and solidarity should be an inspiration to all Filipinos. Somehow, just like Taipei 101, Taiwan seems to have its own society-wide damper that keeps their people steady amid shocks rocking their nation. The Philippines needs to find that stabilizing force, too. – Rappler.com JC Punongbayan, PhD is an assistant professor at the UP School of Economics and the author of False Nostalgia: The Marcos “Golden Age” Myths and How to Debunk Them. In 2024, he received The Outstanding Young Men (TOYM) Award for economics. Follow him on Instagram (@jcpunongbayan).
label: True
title: [In This Economy] All is well in Taiwan (so far)

text: MANILA, Philippines – Is sustainable, fair, and clean food for all even possible for the Philippines? The question has been circling the minds and hearts of chefs, farmers, entrepreneurs, small and medium enterprise (SME) owners, advocates, and nongovernment organizations for years — and it has only grown louder and more urgent. Rising inflation has been hitting households just as hard as our farmers, who struggle for a steady income. Climate change brings floods and typhoons, and consumers are more conscious about health and where their food is coming from. The stakes are high. But the spirit of the Filipino community soars higher. From November 18 to 23, Bacolod City — the emerging slow food capital of the Philippines — offered a vivid, hopeful answer. For five days, the City of Smiles became a beacon of light for both consumer and producer, and a delicious avenue of storytelling through food and delicacies from all over the archipelago. This was Bacolod’s first Terra Madre Asia Pacific Festival — the biggest sustainable gastronomy event in APAC and the first Terra Madre held outside Turin, Italy. The essence of slow food was the binding agent of everything that transpired over those five days. It was a glimpse of what the future could look like. For five days, General Lacson Street and the Capitol Lagoon Park transformed into a bustling hub of flavors: budbud salt from Miagao from a bamboo stalk; tanigue kinilaw chopped fresh with Sagay vinegar; charcoal-grilled eel from Bago City; woven baskets of coffee and cacao from Mindanao; organic produce from Negros farmers; and trays of diwal (razor clams) steaming in butter and garlic. Chefs, farmers, artisans, tourists, and locals converged across the lagoon, running to Taste Workshops, lining up for cooking demos, and listening to insights and tips from regional culinary figures alongside Filipino chefs from Manila’s Michelin-starred restaurants. Slow Food rejects the very grain of fast food. Simply put, slow food is the right to good, clean, and fair food for all. It’s about transparency: who made it, where it was grown, how it was harvested, and what’s in it. Slow Food Negros advocates get to know farmers on the island and put them on a pedestal; farmers are the real stars here. The movement becomes a platform for farmers to showcase the fruits of their labor and then become leaders in their own communities. To the Terra Madre team and its thousands of attendees, the event was a success: sold-out booths, a greater awareness and appreciation of what the Philippines has to offer, and agri-entrepreneurs and SMEs connecting with chefs, local governments, and other businesses. The communal energy was palpable, and the pride was evident. But one event is not enough to sustain the mission. At the end of the festivities, what’s next? How do we move this forward? How do we ensure a fair, sustainable, and clean gastronomy for all? First, it’s about understanding — and never forgetting — where we came from. During Terra Madre, Erwan Heussaff emphasized the importance of keeping our traditions alive through online education. The modern-day food storyteller, content creator, and founder of FEATR creates short and long films that spotlight regional produce from across the Philippines. He won the 2023 James Beard Media Award for social media, a milestone that helped put global attention on Filipino food. “We come from a particular past, and moving to the Philippines is a way to understand our story better — where we came from, how the food shaped our identity, and how our identity shaped the food that we eat,” he said. FEATR zooms in on heirloom ingredients, people, and heritage recipes that are at risk of being forgotten — and with them, parts of our identity. Heussaff said it was affecting farm biodiversity, so FEATR took on the urgent responsibility to communicate this through video, the medium he believes is the best to reach the latest generation. “Education is a great equalizer,” he said. The internet becomes a portal to tell stories. Through his videos, he creates a “marketing flywheel”: tell the story, build awareness, and organically bring in demand. We see it on TikTok and Instagram: a viral review or reel makes a restaurant or product the next must-try. Why not use the same energy for local produce? Heussaff said restaurant owners, chefs, and entrepreneurs play the role of communicators — talking about stories, building traction for artisans, and, while doing so, forcing the hand to provide better logistics and cleaner access so food can circulate better around the country and the world. Johanne Siy, the Dagupan-born chef who helms Lolla in Singapore, was named Asia’s Best Female Chef (2023) by the Asia’s 50 Best Restaurants Academy. Her cuisine is produce-driven and mindful of the culinary traditions she grew up with — a mix of European fine dining and Mediterranean influences. Based in Singapore for 20 years, she said living between contexts opened her eyes. Singapore imports 90% of its food, and the Philippines is actually very lucky to be reliant on agriculture for food security. “I’m in a position to magnify the voices of the local heroes here and introduce that part of our culture to the rest of the world,” she said. Michelin-starred Toyo Eatery’s Chef Jordy Navarra has won the Gin Mare Art of Hospitality Award (2025) and the Flor de Caña Sustainable Restaurant Award (2023). According to Asia’s 50 Best, Toyo “prioritizes Filipino produce and people, fostering long-term relationships with local farmers and artisans.” The academy noted that while many equate sustainability with the environment alone, Toyo prioritizes the sustainability of people and cultural heritage. For Navarra, traveling made him more aware of what he wanted to do for Toyo: “Traveling the world, trying to learn from different cultures, basically focused on learning how to cook in the technical aspect. While on that journey, I realized this isn’t the food I need — it’s the food I grew up eating.” Dining isn’t about the fanfare, the Instagram hits, the upscale ambiance, or the prices. It all boils down to the ingredients. “The more you learn how to cook, the more you realize you’re basically a prisoner to whatever product you have,” he said. Sourcing locally isn’t always easy, with logistical issues and inconsistent supply chains. “But the cool part after that is learning and discovering more through the years,” Navarra said. It has been a humbling journey for him as a chef so far. “What I learned is I can’t dictate to the producer the specs of how I want to cook, but I should accept what the world gives us,” he said. “Accept the best of what the world can give us. As chefs, we try and use that and represent that in the best way we can.” “Now, we are very proud of the industry that we have,” he added. “The majority of restaurants have some form of Philippine-based or locally based approach. Our whole scene came from trying to work with the product we have and adjust our approach.” But challenges remain. Heussaff described the basic struggle: finding a farmer’s contact, discovering whether they even have signal, relying on Facebook Messenger, booking a bus, and going two hours north of Manila to pick up produce. Many low-income and rural communities lack reliable Internet access. But community is the best ingredient. Navarra built a team dedicated to foraging and procurement — “an army of people” — to take on the journey of sourcing. “It’s getting better because one trip can help five restaurants,” he said. Chefs share the product, restaurants come together. Siy stressed the importance of building relationships, too: farmers must “feel good” about their work. “I can just reach out to anyone I see and build a personal relationship with that farmer. Then I enrolled him in the cycle of the restaurant, so that we work together to achieve menu planning and supply scheduling,” Siy said. It’s a win-win for everyone involved. We must convince farmers that what they grow is special — that it’s not a commodity, Heussaff said. It leads to investment, better infrastructure, cleaner processes, and wider access. “We want them to know it’s highly prized and highly looked for. And once you’re able to build that interest and prove that interest to that certain community, then you start community building,” he added. It’s a chain reaction; when everyone around that community starts believing in that product, more time and skills are invested [in] making it. It’s not so much about the revenue but about empowering these farmers and artisans to take pride in what they create. Bringing Philippine pride abroad matters more than we think. Heussaff once saw asin tultul from Guimaras displayed in a Seoul beef restaurant. “The chef didn’t know me. I didn’t know the chef. I asked where he got that. He goes, ‘Chef Jordy brought it to me.’ They proudly display it and still use it in tasting courses,” he shared. Soft marketing drives interest not only back home but also overseas. The conversation must not end here. Talking about it, asking the right questions, and starting the right discussions are the embers to keep the slow food fire alive. “That’s maybe one of the nice things about social media,” Navarra said. Educational exchanges and events like Terra Madre are also a pivotal step forward in boosting attraction from domestic and international tourists. Politics plays a role, too. Heussaff explained how making heritage products “sexy” can generate PR pressure that leads to policy change — the artisanal salt asin tibuok in Bohol became part of a tourism circuit and fed into legal amendments. “You need to give them a really strong story,” he said about our politicians. When the story is attractive enough, they listen. But we don’t need to wait for the law to make a change, Heussaff said. To change the system, we must first change ourselves. If we rely on the system, we may end up waiting a while. “Our role as influencers is to create as much noise as possible, hoping that someone is listening and someone is willing to take that for them,” he said. The same goes for us consumers: we can do our part at home by using social media as a tool. If you see good, clean, and fair food in your community, share it. “We all have that responsibility to make sure somebody knows,” Navarra said. One post can lead a huge audience to discover something local and unique. We must remember that food isn’t just food. According to Heussaff, it can be seen as “very simplified fuel” that we need as humans, but it plays such an important part in the representation of our culture and country. “We’re still very much kind of scratching…the surface of what Filipino biodiversity is and what we actually have to showcase,” Heussaff said — a reality that is fueling the passion of the country’s slow food community, chefs, and supporters. To truly uplift our farmers, we must first cherish what is already ours. There is no reason to look outward, the three chefs echoed; we are abundant in resources and rich in flavors, traditions, and stories from every corner of the country. And in time — through community work, social media, online advocates, and grassroots events like Terra Madre — slow food will grow beyond a movement. It will become a way of life and a natural way of eating, living, and celebrating what the Philippines already has to offer. – Rappler.com
label: True
title: How can Filipinos champion sustainable, fair, and clean food for all?

text: LA UNION, Philippines – Inside the new SM City La Union, the noise of modern life never stops. The music blares from speakers of different stores, each trying to outdo the other and pull passersby inside; the chatter of thousands of mall-goers fills the air; the shrieks of children echo as they run past food kiosks; and the familiar piped in jingle: “Here at Essss Emmmm, we’ve got it all for you!” But turn a corner, and you’ll find a store that seems to breathe at a slower rhythm. Inside Arkus Balay, the light bends differently. It slips through the weave of bamboo pendant lamps, the kind you might see in an upscale resort in Thailand, in a magazine spread of a resthouse in Tagaytay, or in a café that mixes modern design with local texture. Each handcrafted piece looks alive: rattan-crocheted pottery wrapped in lattice, wall trays patterned like woven constellations, towering teardrop vases that stretch up to six feet tall, and traditional diamond-and-cross patterns woven into a bolero made of inabel fabric. Each one shows the marks of the hands that shaped it. Amid this forest of craftsmanship stands Mandrake Palabay, one-half of the daring couple behind the brand. He points to the ceiling, a canopy of lamps: spherical, conical, some fringed like sea grass. “That’s the u-ong lamp,” he said, referring to the mushroom-shaped ceiling lamps. “The weaver moves around the piece, not the other way around.” It’s among his favorite innovations. It’s a design that taught his weavers to think differently, to follow the rhythm of their hands instead of forcing the form. Unlike most designers, he has never studied design. Yet the space he built inside this mall feels like a pause button — a place where craftsmanship slows down what the world keeps speeding up. Mandrake grew up in San Fernando City in La Union, in a family where principles came before comfort. His father, Crisanto Palabay, was an activist tortured during the Marcos dictatorship. His uncles Romulo and Armando were killed for their activism. Their names are on the Bantayog ng mga Bayani, listed among those who stood up to power. “Their courage was on another level,” Mandrake says. “I’m just persistent.” A post shared by 11,103 (@11103.film) Where his father and uncles fought through speeches and marches, Mandrake would fight through craft and continuity. Heritage, too, must be defended, he believes. His father had three rules: never steal, never cheat, never complain about work. “Even when you retire,” his father told him, “you’ll still wash your own dishes, do the laundry, clean the house.” To his activist father, work was not a burden, but a way of life. So when Mandrake, a computer science graduate, left for Hong Kong in his twenties to work as a domestic helper, he carried that lesson with him. He called this season his stepping stone, a way to test opportunities and see what he could learn. His employer tagged him along during a visit to a businessman friend’s showroom. Bored while waiting, Mandrake roamed the vast retail space for artificial flowers and home accents. He started fixing displays. The businessman noticed. A year after, when Mandrake was back in the Philippines, the showroom owner in Hong Kong called with a job offer: Complete a product catalogue that buyers all over the world can refer to. Mandrake didn’t know a thing about design, photography, catalogue-making. He said yes anyway. He remembered what his Uncle Peter, a Swiss man married to his aunt, once told him: “To do a job properly, you need the right tools. You can’t tighten a screw with a knife or scissors.” The newly minted catalogue maker asked for a good camera. “If the pictures were bad, I’d have no excuse.” That habit of saying yes to new work and arming himself with the tools became his way forward. It’s how he learned, advanced, and reinvented himself. Mandrake worked for that Hong Kong-based boss for ten years. The company factories in Sri Lanka , Hong Kong, and Myanmar produced handwoven home products for exports. He learned about proportion and balance while arranging displays. He learned to sell through photographs and catalogues. Later, he joined the design department. “I usually start with the material,” he says. “Can it bend? Twist? Fold? Once I know that, I imagine what it can become: baskets, trays, containers. Then I draw, measure, and sit down with a weaver to make the first sample.” He was exposed to other designs when they joined international trade fairs. His wife Jackie later joined him, handling costing and logistics, checking if sourcing and producing the products made business sense. If it’s an artificial flower, Jackie checked the cost of each petal, stick, leaf. “That’s where I learned to balance creativity with practicality,” Mandrake says. A work mentor once told him: “If you do a job, do it correctly the first time.” Mandrake took that to heart. “That means studying before you start,” he says. “Learn from others’ mistakes so you don’t waste time or materials.” After a decade of working in factories in Hong Kong, Sri Lanka, and Myanmar, he moved to a lighting company in Myanmar. “Chandeliers made of crystals,” he says, laughing. “I didn’t know lighting, but I said yes again.” This new work tested him. “Some designs looked good on paper, then bad in real life,” he says. “Some never went into production.” When the pandemic hit, factories closed, orders stopped, and his salary was cut in half. After 18 years abroad, Mandrake returned to La Union for good. Mandrake and Jackie asked a simple question to guide their next move: What do we know how to do, and who can we do it with? They joined trade fairs, learned about the state of rattan bamboo, and local fabric supplies, as well as the skillsets of local weavers. The old weavers were still at their looms, but they were stuck making the same baskets, blankets, mirrors, and trays that filled souvenir stalls for decades. “They had no product developers,” Mandrake says. “No one to push them to try something new.” The craft celebrated in other countries is tired and dying here. So he started visiting them in the towns of Bangar, Bacnotan, and the quieter barangays in the hills of Abra, Ilocos, and other areas his late uncles had roamed in the 1970s and stayed in while fighting an oppressive government. He showed the weavers his sketches. They hesitated. The new shapes looked odd, the designs unfamiliar. Mandrake understood their fear. Change, in small towns, often feels like betrayal. So he found another way to persuade them: he paid them more. He told them he already had orders, even when he didn’t. He ordered sample after sample, storing them in his own warehouse, just to keep the faith alive. “It was hard,” he says. “But I wanted to prove we could make something different.” In 2022, he opened the first Arkus Balay showroom and outlet in San Fernando, along the highway where tourists from surf town San Juan and other northern travel spots pass as they drive back to Manila. He went full blast on social media, gathering interest and orders from buyers from Ilocos all the way to Tagaytay. Back in the weaving communities, he showed them photos of pendant lamps hanging on hotel lounges, hand-braided baskets used as accents in a posh living rooms. “It changed the energy. It gave them pride,” he beams. “Now they’re the ones asking for new designs.” Not everything sold. “Sometimes you make something and no one wants it,” he says. “Then a few months later, everyone is looking for it. You just have to keep creating.” He laughs. “People don’t always know what they want until they see it.” “La Union craft still lacks exposure,” he adds. “Only now are we starting to gain traction through exhibits and government programs. Before, other places took credit for our work. Even the brooms sold in Baguio, many are made here in La Union.” He doesn’t say this with bitterness, only resolve. “We want to capture the higher market so we can pay the weavers what they deserve,” he adds. “So we focus on quality and design. That’s how we set ourselves apart.” It is, in its own way, activism through craft. A campaign to restore dignity to handmade work and make communities believe again in what their hands can create. “If this craft dies,” he says, “the communities lose their identity.” Before SM City La Union opened its glass doors, Mandrake and Jackie weren’t sure they wanted to be part of it. They already have a thriving roadside studio shop. In the mall, everything would be brighter, faster, noisier. “It was a difficult decision,” Mandrake says. “We knew it would be exposure, but also a big risk.” They initially said no. The numbers didn’t add up. Rent was steep, and SM also took a share of their sales. Not long after, SM called again with a better offer. Once more, Mandrake and Jackie faced the choice between comfort and courage. They said yes. “We put almost all our savings here,” he says. “That’s how we are. Either go full blast, or don’t do it at all.” Two weeks after opening, “sales have been good,” he says, encouraged. Some days, he still doubts. “If it doesn’t work, it’s ok. We’ve failed before.” But the moments when people ask about the lamps or the baskets keep him going. “Those small conversations make me think it’s worth it,” he says. “You realize you’re not just selling things to buyers. You’re reminding the weavers where they came from.” At 50 square meters, the SM branch is small compared to their showroom outside, but it represented something larger. This is a test of whether authenticity could survive commercial speed. Their neighbors are national and global: UNIQLO, Mannam, Philip Stein, Kultura, Toy Kingdom, Miniso, and more. To Mandrake, Arkus Balay’ advantage was something no brand could replicate: proximity to the maker. “We deal directly with the communities. We know the weaver. We know the story.” For him, the mall wasn’t just a business move. It was an experiment in visibility, a statement that La Union’s handmade heritage deserved the same spotlight as imported goods. “If you don’t try,” he says, “you’ll never know.” At 48, Mandrake no longer dreams of becoming a global brand. What he wants is continuity: that the next generation of La Union weavers will still know the rhythm of their hands. Inside Arkus Balay, that rhythm is visible everywhere: in the weaved fabric, bamboo, or rattan that tightens and loosens like breath, in the trays stacked like ripples, in the pendant lamps that throw soft light across the walls. Each piece carries persistence and trial, the proof that beauty can come from things that almost failed. It’s a store that feels like a home that remembers where it came from. When asked what he learned from years abroad, he says, “There’s no such thing as luck. You have to study, research, know your market and your price. Most of all, listen to your customers. Timing and opportunity come rarely, but when they do, you have to be ready.” He looks around the store. “What I learned from my family is to stand for something.” In a mall filled with chain stores and glass displays, Arkus Balay feels like a small resistance: one built not on slogans, but on craftsmanship. Mandrake calls it “making things that are sustainable, natural, ethical, local.” But really, he’s been building something else all along: a living argument that conviction can be inherited, and beauty can be its expression. – Rappler.com
label: True
